Metadata.Title: The Assembly's Shorter Catechism Explained
AlternativeTitles: The Assembly's Shorter Catechism Explained By Way Of Question And Answer

Data.Question: What is the chief end of man?
Data.Answer: Man's chief end is to glorify God, and to enjoy him forever.

SubQuestions.Question: What is meant by man's chief end?
SubQuestions.Answer: That which ought to be man's chief aim and design; and that which he should seek after as his chief happiness.

SubQuestions.Question: What ought to be man's chief aim and design?
SubQuestions.Answer: The glory of God. 1 Chron. 16:28, 29 - "Give unto the Lord, ye kindreds of the people, - give unto the Lord the glory due unto his name."

SubQuestions.Question: What should he seek after as his chief happiness?
SubQuestions.Answer: The enjoyment of God. Isaiah 26:8 - "The desire of our soul is to thy name, and the remembrance of thee."

SubQuestions.Question: What connexion is there between the glorifying God, and the enjoyment of him?
SubQuestions.Answer: The: are connected by rich and sovereign grace, persuading and enabling the sinner to embrace Jesus Christ as the only way to God and glory. Eph. 2:8 - "By grace are ye saved, through faith, and that not of yourselves; it is the gift of God." John 14:6 - "I," says Christ, "am the way; no man cometh unto the Father, but by me."

SubQuestions.Question: Does the chief end exclude subordinate ends?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; for, in aiming principally at the glory of God, men may use the supports of natural life for refreshing their bodies. 1 Cor. 10:31; and be diligent in their particular callings, that they may provide for themselves and their families, 1 Thess. 4:11, 12; 1 Tim. 5:8.

SubQuestions.Question: Why ought the glory of God to be the chief end and design of man?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because it is God's chief end in man's creation, preservation, redemption, and regeneration. Proverbs 16:4 - "The Lord hath made all things for himself;" and therefore it ought to be man's chief end likewise. 1 Cor. 6:19, 20 - "Ye are not your own; for ye are bought with a price: therefore glorify God in your body, and in your spirit, which are God's."

SubQuestions.Question: How manifold is the glory of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: Twofold; his essential and his declarative glory.

SubQuestions.Question: What is God's essential glory?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is what he is absolutely in himself. Exod. 3:14 - "I Am That I Am."

SubQuestions.Question: What is his declarative glory?
SubQuestions.Answer: His showing, or making known his glory, to, in, and by his creatures, Isaiah 44:23; 2 Thess. 1:10.

SubQuestions.Question: Can any creature whatsoever add anything to God's essential glory?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; for his essential glory is infinite, eternal, and unchangeable, Job 35:7.

SubQuestions.Question: Do not the heavens and the earth, and all inferior creatures, glorify God?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; in a passive way, all his works praise him. Psalm 19:1, and 145:10.

SubQuestions.Question: How ought man to glorify God?
SubQuestions.Answer: Man:being endued with a reasonable soul, ought to glorify God in an active way, Psalm 63:4, by declaring his praise, Psalm 103:1, 2; and essaying to give him the glory due to his name, Psalm 96:7, 8.

SubQuestions.Question: How was man to glorify God in a state of innocence?
SubQuestions.Answer: By a perfect, personal, and perpetual obedience to his law, Gen. 1:27; and by giving him the glory of all his works, chap. 2:19.

SubQuestions.Question: Has man answered his chief end?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; for, "all have sinned, and come short of the glory of God," Rom. 3:23.

SubQuestions.Question: Has God then lost his end in making man?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; for God will glorify his justice and power upon some, and his grace and mercy upon others of Adam's family, Rom. 9:22, 23.

SubQuestions.Question: Was ever God glorified by a perfect obedience since Adam's fall?
SubQuestions.Answer: Never, until CHRIST, the second Adam, appeared as a new covenant head, Isaiah 42:21, and 49:3.

SubQuestions.Question: How did Christ, the second Adam, glorify God, as our surety and representative on earth?
SubQuestions.Answer: By finishing the work the Father gave him to do. John 17:4.

SubQuestions.Question: What was the work the Father gave him to do?
SubQuestions.Answer: It was to assume a holy human nature, Luke 1:35; to yield a perfect sinless obedience to the whole law, Mat. 3:15; and to give a complete satisfaction to justice, for man's sin, by his meritorious sufferings and death, Luke 24:26.

SubQuestions.Question: How does Christ glorify God in heaven?
SubQuestions.Answer: By appearing in the presence of God for us, Heb. 9:24, and applying, by the power of his Spirit, that redemption which he purchased by the price of his blood on earth, Titus 3:5, 6.

SubQuestions.Question: When is it that a sinner begins uprightly to aim at the glory of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: When, through a faith of God's operation, he believes in Christ: Acts 8:37, 39. - "The eunuch answered and said, I believe that Jesus Christ is the son of God. - And he went on his way rejoicing."

SubQuestions.Question: Can no man glorify God acceptably, unless he first believe in Christ?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; for, "Without faith it is impossible to please him." Heb. 11:6; and, "Whatsoever is not of faith is sin," Rom. 14:23.

SubQuestions.Question: How is it that faith in Christ glorifies God?
SubQuestions.Answer: As it sets its seal to the record of God, John 3:33; and unites us to Christ, from whom only our fruit is found, Hos. 14:8.

SubQuestions.Question: Is not God glorified by the good works of believers?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; "herein," says Christ, "is my Father glorified, that ye bear much fruit," John 15:8.

SubQuestions.Question: What are these fruits brought forth by believers, by which God is glorified?
SubQuestions.Answer: They may be summed up in faith working by love, Gal. 5:6; or, their aiming, in the strength of Christ, at universal obedience to the law, as the rule of duty. Phil. 4:13 - "I can do all things through Christ which strengtheneth me."

SubQuestions.Question: How should we glorify God in eating and drinking?
SubQuestions.Answer: By taking a right to the supports of natural life, through the second Adam, the heir of all things, who has purchased a covenant right to temporal, as well as spiritual mercies, for his people, 1 Cor. 3:21-23; and thankfully acknowledging God for the same, 1 Tim. 4:4, 5.

SubQuestions.Question: How must we glorify God in our religious worship, and other acts of obedience?
SubQuestions.Answer: By doing all that we do in the name of the Lord Jesus, Col. 3:17; worshipping God in the Spirit, rejoicing in Christ Jesus, and having no confidence in the flesh, Phil. 3:3.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it, next to the glory of God, we should aim at?
SubQuestions.Answer: Next to God's glory, we should aim at the enjoyment of him, Psalm 73:25, 26.

SubQuestions.Question: Why should we aim at the enjoyment of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because he is the chief good of the rational creature, Psalm 116:7; and nothing else besides him, is either suitable to the nature, or satisfying to the desires of the immortal soul, Psalm 144:15.

SubQuestions.Question: How may a finite creature enjoy an infinite God?
SubQuestions.Answer: By taking and rejoicing in him, as its everlasting and upmaking portion, Psalm 16:5, 6, and 48:14.

SubQuestions.Question: Did our first parents, in a state of innocence, enjoy God?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; there was perfect friendship and fellowship between God and them; for, "God made man upright," Eccl. 7:29.

SubQuestions.Question: What broke that blessed friendship and fellowship?
SubQuestions.Answer: Sin: our iniquities have separated between us and our God, and our sins have hid his face from us, Isaiah 59:2.

SubQuestions.Question: Can a sinner, in a natural state, enjoy God, or have any fellowship with him?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; for, "What communion hath light with darkness? and what concord hath Christ with Belial?" 2 Cor. 6:14, 15.

SubQuestions.Question: How may a lost sinner recover the enjoyment of God, and fellowship with him?
SubQuestions.Answer: As we lost it by our fall in the first Adam, so it can only be recovered by union with a second Adam, Rom. 5:18-19; for there is no coming to God but by him, John 14:6.

SubQuestions.Question: When is it that a sinner begins to enjoy God?
SubQuestions.Answer: When, having received Christ by faith, he rests upon him, and upon God in him, for righteousness and strength, Isaiah 45:24; and out of his fulness receives, and grace for grace, John 1:16

SubQuestions.Question: What are the external means by, or in which, we are to seek after the enjoyment of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: In all the ordinances of his worship, public, private and secret; such as the word read and heard, the sacraments, prayer, meditation, fasting, thanksgiving, and the like.

SubQuestions.Question: Are the saints of God admitted to enjoy him in these?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; they are the trysting-places2 where his name is recorded, and to which he has promised to come and bless them, Ex. 20:24 - "In all places where I record my name, I will come unto thee, and I will bless thee."

SubQuestions.Question: What scripture-evidence have we, of their enjoying God in the duties and ordinances of his appointment?
SubQuestions.Answer: We find them much employed in religious duties, Song 3:1-3; and expressing the utmost regard for the ordinances of his grace, Psalm 84:1, 2.

SubQuestions.Question: What satisfaction has the soul in the enjoyment of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: Unspeakably more gladness than when corn, wine, and all earthly comforts, do most abound, Psalm 4:7

SubQuestions.Question: Is there any difference between the enjoyment of God in this life, and that which the saints shall obtain in the life to come?
SubQuestions.Answer: Not an essential, but a gradual difference, as to the manner and measure of it.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the difference as to the manner of the enjoyment here and hereafter?
SubQuestions.Answer: Here, the enjoyment is mediate, by the intervention of means; hereafter, it will be immediate, without any use of these means: "Now we see through a glass darkly; but then FACE TO FACE," 1 Cor. 13:12.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the difference as to the measure of the enjoyment, in this life, and that which is to come?
SubQuestions.Answer: In this life the enjoyment is only partial; in that which is to come, it will be full and complete, 1 John 3:2 - here, the enjoyment is only in the seed, or first fruits; there it will be in the full harvest, Psalm 126:5, 6.

SubQuestions.Question: Is the partial enjoyment of God in grace here, a sure pledge of the full enjoyment of him in glory hereafter?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is both the pledge and earnest of it, Eph. 1:13, 14; Psalm 84:11.

SubQuestions.Question: Does the gracious soul, in that state, fully receive its chief end?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; in regard that then it shall be brimful of God, and celebrate his praises with high and uninterrupted Hallelujahs through all eternity, Psalm 16:11; Isaiah 35:10.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is the glorifying God made the leading part of man's chief end, and set before the enjoyment of him?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because, as God's design in glorifying himself was the reason and foundation of his design in making man happy in the enjoyment of him, Rom. 11:26; so he has made our aiming at his glory, as our chief end, to be the very way and means of our attaining to that enjoyment, Psalm 50:23.

SubQuestions.Question: Is our happiness, in the enjoyment of God, to be our chief end?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; but the glory of God itself, Isaiah 42:8; in our aiming at which chiefly, we cannot miss the enjoyment of him, Psalm 91:14, 15.

SubQuestions.Question: Is not our delighting in the glory of God, to be reckoned our chief end?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; we must set the glory of God above our delight therein, otherwise, our delight is not chiefly in God, but in ourselves, Isaiah 2:11. Our subjective delighting in the glory of God belongs to the enjoyment of him, whose glory is above the heavens, and infinitely above our delight therein, Psalm 113:4.

SubQuestions.Question: Whom does God dignify with the enjoyment of himself, in time and for ever?
SubQuestions.Answer: Those whom he helps actively to glorify and honour him; for he has said, "Them that honour me, I will honour," 1 Sam. 2:30.

SubQuestions.Question: Does any thing so much secure our happy enjoyment of God, as the concern that the glory of God has in it?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; for as God cannot but reach the great end of his own glory, so, when he has promised us eternal life, in Christ, before the world began, Titus 1:2, we cannot come short of it; because it stands upon the honour of his faithfulness to make it good, Heb. 10:23 - "He is faithful that promised."

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear, that the enjoyment of God, which is connected with the glorifying of him, shall be for ever?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because he who is the object enjoyed, is the everlasting God, Isaiah 40:28; and the enjoyment of him is not transitory, like the passing enjoyments of time, but the eternal enjoyment of the eternal God, Psalm 48:14.

Data.Question: What rule has God given to direct us how we may glorify and enjoy him?
Data.Answer: The word of God, which is contained in the scriptures of the Old and New Testaments, is the only rule to direct us, how we may glorify and enjoy him.

SubQuestions.Question: What necessity is there of a rule to direct us how to glorify and enjoy God?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is necessary, because, since God will be glorified by the reasonable creature, nothing can be a perfect rule for that end, but his own revealed will, Rom. 12:2.

SubQuestions.Question: Can man, by any wisdom or power of his own, ever attain to the glorifying of God, and the enjoyment of him, which he has come short of, by his fall in the first Adam?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; his wisdom and knowledge in the things of God, are become folly and ignorance, Job 11:12; and his power to do good is turned into utter impotency, John 6:44.

SubQuestions.Question: Where has God revealed the way, in which man may recover and attain the end of his creation?
SubQuestions.Answer: In the word of God, which is contained in the scriptures of the Old and New Testaments, John 5:39 - "Search the scriptures..."

SubQuestions.Question: How do you know the scriptures of the Old and New Testaments to be the word of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: By the print of God that is evidently to be seen upon them: for, as none works like God, Isaiah 43:13; so none speaks like him, John 7:46.

SubQuestions.Question: What do you understand by the print or impress of God that is so discernible in the scriptures?
SubQuestions.Answer: That majesty, holiness, light, life, and efficacy, which shine in the word itself, Rom. 1:16; Psalm 19:7.

SubQuestions.Question: What may be said of those who do not see that print of God in the word, though they read it?
SubQuestions.Answer: It may be said, "The god of this world hath blinded the minds of them that believe not," 2 Cor. 4:4.

SubQuestions.Question: Since all men are spiritually blind by nature, is it not in vain for them to read the scriptures?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; it is the will of God that they should read and search the scriptures, John 5:39; and the entrance of his word gives light and sight to them that are blind, Psalm 119:130.

SubQuestions.Question: What should a man do that the Bible may not remain a sealed book to him?
SubQuestions.Answer: Whenever he looks into the word of God, he should look up to God, the author of it, saying, "Open thou mine eyes, that I may behold wondrous things out of thy law," Psalm 119:18. "O send out thy light and thy truth; let them lead me," Psalm 43:3.

SubQuestions.Question: By what arguments may we persuade men that are infidels, to receive the scriptures as the Word of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: We may deal with them by rational arguments drawn from their antiquity; the heavenliness of the matter; the majesty of the style; the harmony of all the parts,though written in different ages; the exact accomplishment of prophecies; the sublimity of the mysteries and matters contained in the word; the efficacy and power of it, in the conviction and conversion of multitudes; the scope of the whole, to guide men to attain their chief end, the glory of God in their own salvation; and the many miracles wrought for the confirmation of the truth of the doctrines contained in them.3

SubQuestions.Question: Can these or the like rational arguments, ever produce a divine faith?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; for rational arguments can only produce a mere rational faith, founded on reason; but a divine and saving faith rests wholly upon the divine testimony inherent in the word itself; or upon a "Thus saith the Lord."

SubQuestions.Question: How is this inherent testimony discovered?
SubQuestions.Answer: By the same Spirit of God that dictated the word, 2 Pet. 1:21; he being an "Interpreter, one among a thousand," John 16:13.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it that will fully persuade and assure a person that the scriptures are indeed the word of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: "The Spirit of God bearing witness by, and with the scriptures in the heart of man, is alone able fully to persuade it, that they are the very word of God," John 16:13, 14; 1 John 2:27.4

SubQuestions.Question: Whether does the authority of the scripture, for which it ought to be believed and obeyed, depend upon the testimony of the church, or wholly upon God?
SubQuestions.Answer: "Wholly upon God, (who is truth itself,) the author thereof; and, therefore, it is to be received, because it is the word of God, 1 John 5:9; 1 Thess. 2:13."5

SubQuestions.Question: Why cannot the authority of the scriptures depend upon the church?
SubQuestions.Answer: Bec:use the true church of Christ depends, in its very being, on the scriptures; and therefore the scriptures cannot depend upon it, as to their authority, Eph. 2:20, 22.

SubQuestions.Question: Are not the light of nature, and the works of creation and providence, sufficient to direct us how we may glorify and enjoy God?
SubQuestions.Answer: These "do so far manifest the goodness, wisdom, and power of God, as to leave men inexcusable, Rom. 2:14, 15, and 1:19, 20; yet are they not sufficient to give that knowledge of God, and of his will, which is necessary unto salvation, 1 Cor. 2:13, 14."6

SubQuestions.Question: What makes a further revelation, than nature's light, necessary?
SubQuestions.Answer: The glory of the Divine perfections, particularly his mercy, grace, love, and faithfulness, Psalm 85:8, 10, 11; the gross ignorance and degeneracy of mankind, 1 Cor. 1:20, 21; the sublimeness of the things revealed, which otherwise had never been known by men or angels, John 1:18; it is also necessary for trying the spirits and doctrines of men, and for unmasking the impostures of the devil, 1 John 4:1-3.

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear that the scriptures are not an imposition upon mankind?
SubQuestions.Answer: If the penman of the scriptures had inclined to deceive, they would have accommodated themselves to the dispositions of the people with whom they conversed, and connived at their lusts; but, on the contrary, we find they faithfully exposed the errors and vices of men, and impartially set themselves against every thing that corrupt nature is fond of; and that, though they were laid open to the greatest hardships and sufferings for so doing, Acts 5:29-41.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the meaning of the word scriptures?
SubQuestions.Answer: It signifies writings; and the word of God is emphatically so called, because God has therein written to us the great things of his law and covenant, Hos. 8:12.

SubQuestions.Question: Why was the word of God committed to writings?
SubQuestions.Answer: "For the better preserving and propagating of the truth; and for the more sure establishment and comfort of the church, against the corruption of the flesh, and the malice of Satan and of the world, Luke 1:3, 4; Proverbs 22:20, 21."7

SubQuestions.Question: How was the will of God made known to the church, before it was committed to writing?
SubQuestions.Answer: By immediate revelations, Gen. 2:16, 17, and 3:15; by frequent appearances of the Son of God, delighting, beforehand, to try on the human likeness, Gen. 18:2, compared with v. 3, Judg. 13:11, compared with verses 18, 19; by the ministry of the holy angels, Gen. 19:1, 15; Heb. 2:2, and of the patriarchs, Jude, ver. 14, 15; Heb. 11:7.

SubQuestions.Question: Why are the scriptures of the Old and New Testament called the word of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because "all scripture is given by inspiration of God," 2 Tim. 3:16, being immediately indited by the Holy Ghost, 2 Pet. 1:21.

SubQuestions.Question: Why are they commonly called the Bible?
SubQuestions.Answer: The word BIBLE signifying a book; the holy scriptures are so called by way of eminence, because they are incomparably the best of all books, as containing the invariable grounds of faith in Christ, for life eternal, John 20:31 - "These are written, that ye might believe that Jesus is the Christ, the Son of God, and that, believing, ye might have life through his name."

SubQuestions.Question: Why are the holy scriptures called a Testament?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because they are the last will of the glorious Testator, first typically, and then actually confirmed by his death, concerning the vast legacies therein bequeathed to his spiritual seed: Heb. 9:16, "Where a testament is, there must also of necessity be the death of the Testator."

SubQuestions.Question: Why are the writings of Moses and the prophets called the Old Testament?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because the will of the Testator, Christ, was veiled, legally dispensed, and typically sealed by the blood of sacrificed beasts, upon which account it is called comparatively faulty, Heb. 8:7, 8; and was therefore to vanish away, verse 13.

SubQuestions.Question: To whom were the oracles of God, under the Old Testament, committed?
SubQuestions.Answer: To the church of the Jews, Rom. 3:1, 2 - "What advantage hath the Jew? Much every way: chiefly, because unto them were committed the oracles of God."

SubQuestions.Question: Why are the scriptures from Matthew to the end of the Revelation, called the New Testament?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because they contain the most clear and full revelation, and actual ratification of the covenant of promise, by the death of Christ the Testator, who is also the living Executor of his own testament, Rev. 1:18 - "I am he that liveth and was dead; and behold, I am alive for evermore." John 14:19 - "Because I live, ye shall live also."

SubQuestions.Question: Will this New Testament dispensation of the grace of God ever undergo any other alteration?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; it will remain new and unalterable, till the second coming of the Lord Jesus, Mat. 26:29.

SubQuestions.Question: Do the scriptures of the Old Testament continue to be a rule of faith and practice to us who live under the New?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; because they are the record of God concerning Christ, as well as the scriptures of the New Testament; for all the prophets prophesied of him; to him they did all bear witness, Acts 10:43; and Christ commands all to search them, because eternal life is to be found in them, and they testify of him, John 5:39.

SubQuestions.Question: How could the Old Testament be of force when it was not confirmed by the death of the Testator?
SubQuestions.Answer: The death of Christ, the Testator, was typified in all the expiatory sacrifices of that dispensation; hence is he called, "The Lamb slain from the foundation of the world," Rev. 13:8.

SubQuestions.Question: Is not that typical dispensation now quite abolished, under the New Testament?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; for it was promised, that the Messiah should "cause the sacrifice and the oblation to cease;" and accordingly, "Christ being come, - neither by the blood of goats nor calves, but by his own blood, he entered in once into the holy place, having obtained eternal redemption for us," Heb. 9:11, 12.

SubQuestions.Question: Why was that ceremonial dispensation abolished?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because it was only a shadow of good things to come, and not the very image of the things; that is, not the very things themselves, Heb. 10:1.

SubQuestions.Question: Wherein does the New Testament excel the Old?
SubQuestions.Answer: Amongst other things, it excels it in respect of evidence, worship, extent, gifts, and duration.

SubQuestions.Question: Wherein does the New Testament excel the Old in respect of evidence?
SubQuestions.Answer: The Old Testament speaks of a Messiah to come, but the New presents him as already come, John 1:29, 41; The Old was dark and cloudy, but the New clear and perspicuous, 2 Cor. 3:18.

SubQuestions.Question: How does it excel in respect of worship?
SubQuestions.Answer: The worship of the Old Testament was a yoke of bondage; but the worship of the New is free, spiritual, and easy, Gal. 5:1.

SubQuestions.Question: How does the New Testament excel in respect of extent?
SubQuestions.Answer: The Old was confined to the Jews, Psalm 147:19, 20, and a few proselytes among the Gentiles, Ex. 12:48; but the New extends to all the world, Mark 16:15; and its converts are vastly more numerous than under the old dispensation, Rev. 7:9.

SubQuestions.Question: How does it excel in respect of gifts?
SubQuestions.Answer: The gifts of the Spirit are more plentiful, and more efficacious under the New, than under the Old, Acts 2:17, 18.

SubQuestions.Question: How does the New Testament excel in respect of duration?
SubQuestions.Answer: The dispensation of the Old Testament, by types and sacrifices, was only for a time, Heb. 8:13; but the dispensation of the New, is to continue unalterable to the end of the world, Matt. 28:20.

SubQuestions.Question: Why are the scriptures said to be the only rule to direct us, how we may glorify and enjoy God?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because none but God, the author of the scriptures, could, by them, show the way, how he himself is to be glorified and enjoyed by fallen sinners of mankind, Micah. 6:6, 9; Matt. 11:25, 28.

SubQuestions.Question: Although the light of nature, or natural reason, should not be the only rule, yet may it not be admitted as a sufficient rule, to direct us how to glorify and enjoy God?
SubQuestions.Answer: By no means; because of its utter incapacity to give the smallest discovery of Christ, the Mediator of the new covenant, 1 Cor. 2:14, who is the only way of salvation for lost sinners of Adam's family, John 14:6.

SubQuestions.Question: Is it enough to assert, that the word of God is the principal rule to direct us?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; because this would leave room to conceive of another rule, beside the scriptures, which, though it might not be called the principal one, yet might be in itself abundantly good and sufficient for directing sinners to their chief end; which is false, and contrary to scripture, Luke 16:29, 31; Isaiah 8:20; Acts 4:12.

SubQuestions.Question: Wherein consists the perfection of the scriptures?
SubQuestions.Answer: It consists in this, that, "the whole counsel of God, concerning all things necessary for his own glory, man's salvation, faith and life, is either expressly set down in scripture, or by good and necessary consequence may be deduced from scripture, 2 Tim. 3:15-17; Gal. 1:8, 9."8

SubQuestions.Question: Are plain and necessary scripture consequences to be admitted as a part of the rule, as well as express scriptures?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; as is evident from the instance of our Lord, in proving the doctrine of the resurrection against the Sadducees, Matt. 22:31, 32 - "As touching the resurrection of the dead, have ye not read that which was spoken unto you by God, saying, I am the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob? God is not the God of the dead, but of the living."

SubQuestions.Question: Are the scriptures a clear and perspicuous rule?
SubQuestions.Answer: All things necessary to be known, believed, and observed for salvation, are so clearly laid down in one place of scripture or another, that every one, in the due use of ordinary means, may attain to a sufficient understanding of them, Psalm 119:105, 130.9

SubQuestions.Question: Are human and unwritten traditions, how ancient soever, to be admitted as a part of the rule?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; all human traditions are to be examined by the scriptures; and, "if they speak not according to this word, it is because there is no light in them," Isaiah 8:20.

SubQuestions.Question: Can the heathens, by all the helps they have, without revelation, attain to such a knowledge of God, and his will, as is necessary to salvation?
SubQuestions.Answer: By no means: for they are declared to be "without God, and without hope in the world," Eph. 2:12. "And where there is no vision, the people perish," Proverbs 29:18; there being "no other name under heaven, given among men, whereby we must be saved," but that of Jesus, Acts 4:12.

SubQuestions.Question: Is the light within men, or the Spirit without the word, which is pretended to by the Quakers, and other enthusiasts, to be used as any rule for our direction?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; because whatever light or spirit is pretended to, without the word, it is but darkness, delusion, and a spirit of error, 1 John 4:1, 6.

SubQuestions.Question: In what language were the scriptures originally written?
SubQuestions.Answer: The Old Testament was written originally in Hebrew, and the New Testament in Greek.

SubQuestions.Question: Why ought the scriptures to be translated into the vulgar language of every nation where they come?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because sinners of mankind have a right to, and interest in the scriptures, Proverbs 8:4; and are commanded, in the fear of God, to read and search them, John 5:39.

SubQuestions.Question: Who is the supreme judge, in whose sentence we are to rest in determining all controversies of religion, and examining the decrees and doctrines of men?
SubQuestions.Answer: "No other but the Holy Spirit speaking in the scripture, Matt. 22:29; Acts 28:25."10

SubQuestions.Question: Why are the books called the Apocrypha to be rejected as no part of the canon of scripture?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because they were not written in the original language of the Old Testament; nor acknowledged for scripture by the Jews, to whom the oracles of God were committed; and have nothing of that impress of majesty, holiness, and efficacy, which shines so conspicuously in the scriptures of the Old and New Testaments; and because they were written after Malachi, whose book is called, the end of the Prophets; and contain many false things, contradictory and heretical.

SubQuestions.Question: Wherein consists the incomparable excellency and usefulness of the scriptures?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are the well furnished dispensatory of all sovereign remedies, Psalm 107:20; the rich magazine of all true comfort, Rom. 15:4; the complete armoury of all spiritual weapons, Eph. 6:13-18; and the unerring compass to guide to the haven of glory, 2 Pet. 1:19.

Data.Question: What do the scriptures principally teach?
Data.Answer: The scriptures principally teach, what man is to believe concerning God, and what duty God requires of man.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to believe what the scriptures teach?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to assent and give credit to the truths thereof, because of the authority of God, whose word the scriptures are, John 3:33 - "He that hath received his testimony, hath set to his seal that God is true."

SubQuestions.Question: Are we to believe nothing in point of faith, and do nothing in point of duty, but what we are taught in the scripture?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; because the scripture is the only book in the world of divine authority; and the revealed will and command of God therein, being so exceeding broad, nothing is incumbent on us to believe and do, but what is either directly, or consequentially prescribed in it, Isaiah 8:20.

SubQuestions.Question: Why are the scriptures said principally to teach matters of faith and practice?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because though all things revealed in the scripture be equally true, yet every thing in it is not equally necessary to salvation, 1 Cor. 7:12, 13.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the order of doctrine laid down in this question?
SubQuestions.Answer: Faith or believing is made the foundation of duty, or obedience; and not our obedience, or duty, the foundation of our faith, Titus 3:8.

SubQuestions.Question: Why are the things to be believed, set before the things to be practised?
SubQuestions.Answer: To distinguish between the order of things in the covenant of grace, from what they were in innocency, in the covenant of works, Gal. 3:12.

SubQuestions.Question: What was the order of things in the covenant of works?
SubQuestions.Answer: Doing, or perfect obedience to the law, was the foundation of the promised privilege of life: "The man which doeth these things, shall live by them," Rom. 10:5.

SubQuestions.Question: Is this order inverted in the covenant of grace, or gospel revelation?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; the promise is to be believed, and the promised privilege, namely, life, must be freely received; and upon this follows our obedience to the law, from gratitude and love, Jer. 31:18, 19.

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear that this is the order of gospel doctrine?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because this is the order that God laid, in delivering the law at Mount Sinai; the foundation of faith is first laid in these words of the preface, "I am the Lord thy God," &c., which is the sum and substance of the covenant of grace; and then follow the Ten Commandments, which are, as it were, grafted upon this grant of sovereign grace and love, Ex. 20:2-17.

SubQuestions.Question: Is this the order of doctrine laid down in the standards of the church of Scotland?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; as appears from this answer to that question in the Shorter Catechism, "What doth the preface to the Ten Commandments teach us?" The Answer is, "That because God is the Lord, and our God, and Redeemer; therefore we are bound to keep all his commandments."11

SubQuestions.Question: Are we then to keep the commandments, that God may become our God?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; for this were to slide into a covenant of works; but we are to keep them, because "he is our God," according to the tenor of the covenant of grace; Psalm 45:11, in metre, - "Because he is thy Lord, do thou him worship reverently."

SubQuestions.Question: Why do men naturally think, that upon their doing certain acts, God will be their God?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because of the natural bias of the heart of man, to the order in the covenant of works, "Do, and live," Rom. 9:32, and chap. 10:3

SubQuestions.Question: Does not this order make void the law, or weaken our obligation to the duties of it?
SubQuestions.Answer: By no means; but rather establishes the law, and settles our obligation to duty upon its proper foundation, Rom. 3:31. "Do we then make void the law through faith? God forbid: yea, we establish the law."

SubQuestions.Question: How is this order of doctrine further evinced?
SubQuestions.Answer: From the method of doctrine observed by the apostle Paul, who tells us, that all true gospel obedience is the obedience of faith, Rom. 16:26. And accordingly in his epistles, he first lays down the doctrine of faith to be believed; and, upon that foundation, proceeds to inculcate the duties that are to be practised.

SubQuestions.Question: Does gospel obedience interest us in God, as our God?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; but it is a fruit and evidence of our interest in him, 1 John 2:3, 5.

SubQuestions.Question: Is there any danger of inverting this order, and of making duty done by us, the foundation of believing the Lord to be our God?
SubQuestions.Answer: There is exceedingly great danger; for it is the very soul of Popery. By inverting this order, they were led back to a covenant of works, and the doctrine of the merit of good works, which is the foundation of the whole Antichristian superstructure.

SubQuestions.Question: Do not we find frequently in scripture, a reward promised to good works, Psalm 19:11 - "In keeping of thy commandments there is a great reward:" Psalm 58:11 - "Verily there is a reward to the righteous?"
SubQuestions.Answer: True; but this is a reward of grace, not of debt: the man that is rewarded, must be a believer in Christ, whose person is first accepted, through his union to Christ by faith, and the imputation of his righteousness, before any of his works or duties can be accepted, Eph. 1:6; Gen. 4:4.

SubQuestions.Question: What may be said of the works of a man that has no faith?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are dead works, and so cannot please a living God. An evil tree cannot bring forth good fruit, Matt. 7:18; and without Christ, and union with him, we can do nothing, John 15:4, 5.

SubQuestions.Question: What is to be thought of those who inculcate moral duties, without discovering the necessity of the new birth and union with Christ by faith, as the spring of all acceptable obedience?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are foolish builders, laying their foundation on the sand, perverting the gospel of Christ; against whom the apostle denounces an awful doom, Gal. 1:9 - "If any man preach any other gospel unto you than that ye have received, let him be accursed. "

Data.Question: What is God?
Data.Answer: God is a Spirit, infinite, eternal, and unchangeable, in his being, wisdom, power, holiness, justice, goodness, and truth. Of the nature and perfections of God in general.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the first fundamental truth to be believed, and upon which all other truths depend?
SubQuestions.Answer: That God is; or that there is a God, Heb. 11:6 - "He that cometh unto God, must believe that he is."

SubQuestions.Question: Is this fundamental truth known by the light of natural reason?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; as the apostle declares, Rom. 1:20 - "The invisible things of God, from the creation of the world, are clearly seen, being understood by the things that are made; even his eternal power and Godhead."

SubQuestions.Question: In what volumes has God discovered the knowledge of himself to all mankind?
SubQuestions.Answer: In the great volumes of creation and providence; which he opens to all the world.

SubQuestions.Question: What says the volume of creation as to the being of a God?
SubQuestions.Answer: All creatures in general, and every creature in particular, say that God "made us, and not we ourselves," Psalm 100:3.

SubQuestions.Question: What says the volume of providence?
SubQuestions.Answer: It says, that the same God who gave us being, upholds us therein; and governs us to the end for which he made us, Heb. 1:3.

SubQuestions.Question: Is not every man's own being, a convincing evidence that there is a God?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; for, "in him we live, move, and have our being." No man can have any hand in his own formation in the womb, Psalm 139:15, 16; nor can he add a cubit unto his stature, or make one hair of his head either white or black, Matt. 6:27; and 5:36.

SubQuestions.Question: Though the works of creation and providence declare that God is, can they also tell us what God is?
SubQuestions.Answer: They afford us some dark glimpses of his eternal power, wisdom, greatness, and goodness; but it is only by and through the scriptures of truth, set home on the soul by his Spirit, that we can attain the saving knowledge of God, and of his perfections, John 5:39; 2 Pet. 1:19; Rom. 15:4.

SubQuestions.Question: Who is it that reveals God to the sons of men in the word?
SubQuestions.Answer: Christ, the eternal Son of God: "No man hath seen God at any time, the only begotten Son, which is in the bosom of the Father, he hath declared him," John 1:18.

SubQuestions.Question: What account of himself, has God given us in the scriptures?
SubQuestions.Answer: There are three short, but comprehensive descriptions which he has given of himself there: (1.) That God is light, 1 John 1:5. (2.) That God is love, 1 John 4:8, 16. (3.) That God is a Spirit, John 4:24.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is God said to be light?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because of his infinite purity and omniscience, Hab. 1:13; Heb. 4:13; and because he is the fountain and father of all light, whether material, natural, gracious, or glorious, James 1:17.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is God said to be love?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because, according to the manifestation he has made of himself in Christ, love is the reigning excellency of his nature, which gives a dye or tincture to all his other perfections, in their egress, or exercise about the salvation of sinners, of mankind, John 3:16; 1 John 4:8-10.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is he said to be a Spirit?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because he is necessarily and essentially a living intelligent substance; incorruptible, incorporeal, without flesh, or bones, or bodily parts, Luke 24:39.

SubQuestions.Question: How far does God transcend all created spirits?
SubQuestions.Answer: He is as infinitely above the being of all created spirits, as he is above the conception of all intelligent creatures. Job 37:23 - "Touching the Almighty, we cannot find him out."

SubQuestions.Question: Since God is a most simple and pure Spirit, why are bodily parts, such as eyes, ears, hands, face, and the like, ascribed to him in scripture?
SubQuestions.Answer: Such figurative expressions ought not to be understood in their literal sense, but according to the true scope and intent of them; which is to set forth some acts and perfections of the divine nature, to which these members of the body bear some faint resemblance. Thus, when eyes and ears are ascribed to God, they signify his omniscience; hands are desired to denote his power; and his face, the manifestation of his favour: and in this light, other metaphors of like nature, when applied to God, ought to be explained.

SubQuestions.Question: Is it lawful to form any external image of God with the hand, or any internal imaginary idea of him in the fancy?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is absolutely unlawful and idolatrous; condemned in the Second Commandment, and other scriptures, Deut. 4:12, 15. Rom. 1:23. Man cannot form an imaginary idea of his own soul or spirit, far less of Him who is the Father of spirits.

SubQuestions.Question: What may we learn from God's being a spirit?
SubQuestions.Answer: To worship him in spirit and in truth, John 4:24.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to worship him in spirit and in truth?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to worship him, from a real and saving knowledge of what he is in Christ to lost sinners of mankind, John 17:3.

SubQuestions.Question: Is it possible for man to attain the real and saving knowledge of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: Although neither men nor angels can have a comprehensive knowledge of God, Job 11:7-9; yet, besides the speculative and merely rational knowledge of him, which men have, and may have much of, by the light of nature, a saving and satisfying knowledge of him is attainable, and is promised in the word, Jer. 24:7 - "I will give them a heart to know me, that I am the Lord." And John 6:45 - "It is written in the prophets, They shall be all taught of God."

SubQuestions.Question: Wherein consists the saving knowledge of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is like the white stone and new name, which no man knows but he that receives it, Rev. 2:17; and he that attains it, cannot make language of it, but silently admires what he cannot comprehend: only, there is no saving knowledge of God, but in and through Christ the Saviour, 2 Cor. 4:6.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the language of the soul that sees God, and knows him savingly in Christ?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is like that of Moses, Ex. 15:11 - "Who is like unto thee, O Lord? - who is like unto thee, glorious in holiness, fearful in praises, doing wonders?" Or that of the Psalmist, Psalm 48:14 - "This God is our God for ever and ever: he will be our guide even unto death."

SubQuestions.Question: What are the rays of divine glory in the face of Jesus Christ by which we come to know God savingly?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are the attributes and perfections of his nature, by which he is pleased to manifest himself; such as, that he is infinite, eternal, and unchangeable, in his being, wisdom, power, holiness, justice, goodness, and truth.

SubQuestions.Question: Are these attributes of God, distinct things from God himself, or the divine essence?
SubQuestions.Answer: By no means; for, whatever is in God, is God himself; and therefore the infinity of all perfection, is inseparable from the divine essence.

SubQuestions.Question: Are the divine attributes separable from one another, so as that which is infinite should not be eternal, and that which is infinite and eternal, should not be unchangeable, and so of the rest?
SubQuestions.Answer: All perfections whatsoever being inseparable from God, must also be inseparable from one another; for though we, through weakness, must think and speak of them separately, yet all of them taken together, are, properly speaking, but the one infinite perfection of the divine nature, which cannot be separated from it, without granting that God is not infinitely perfect, which would be the height of blasphemy to suppose.

SubQuestions.Question: Why are the perfections of God called his attributes?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because they are attributed or ascribed to him, as the essential properties of his nature, 1 Chron. 29:11.

SubQuestions.Question: How are the attributes of God commonly divided?
SubQuestions.Answer: Into incommunicable and communicable.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the incommunicable attributes of God, mentioned in the answer?
SubQuestions.Answer: His infinity, eternity, and unchangeableness.

SubQuestions.Question: Why called incommunicable?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because there is not the least resemblance of them to be found among the creatures.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the attributes that are called communicable?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are being, wisdom, power, holiness, justice, goodness, and truth.

SubQuestions.Question: Why called communicable?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because there is some faint resemblance or similitude of them to be found among the creatures, namely, angels, and saints: hence are they proposed in scripture for our imitation, Psalm 11:6 - "The righteous Lord loveth righteousness." 1 Pet. 1:16 - "Be ye holy, for I am holy."

SubQuestions.Question: Can these communicable attributes be ascribed to any creature, as they are in God?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; for they are in God, infinitely, eternally, and unchangeably; he is infinite, eternal, and unchangeable in his being; infinite, eternal, and unchangeable in his wisdom, and so on of the rest, which would be blasphemy to affirm of any creature: hence it is said, Matt. 19:17, "There is none good but one, that is God:" None infinitely, eternally, and unchangeably good, but he only.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it for God to be infinite?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to be absolutely without all bounds or limits in his being and perfections, Job 11:7-9.

SubQuestions.Question: What does the infinity of God imply in it?
SubQuestions.Answer: His incomprehensibleness, immensity, and omnipresence.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it for God to be incomprehensible?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is infinitely to transcend the most enlarged capacity of men or angels, as to his being and perfections, Psalm 145:3; Job 36:26.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the immensity of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: As it includes his omnipresence, it is that perfection of his nature, by which he is every where present with all and every one of his creatures; and infinitely exceeds all their limits and boundaries, 1 Kings 8:27.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the difference between the omnipresence and immensity of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: The omnipresence of God is included in his immensity, and though not separable therefrom, yet may be conceived as having a respect to created substances, with every one of which he is intimately present; whereas his immensity extends infinitely beyond the boundaries of all created substance, 2 Chron. 6:18.

SubQuestions.Question: Is God every where present only as to his knowledge and power?
SubQuestions.Answer: He is every where present also as to his essence of being, as is evident from Jer. 23:23, 24.

SubQuestions.Question: How may this be evinced also from reason?
SubQuestions.Answer: Reason teaches us that no creature can subsist by itself, without the presence of God to uphold it in its being and operation. Acts 17:28 - "In him we live, and move, and have our being."

SubQuestions.Question: How is God present with the church here on earth?
SubQuestions.Answer: He is present, with the church visible, by the ordinances and symbols of his institution, Ex. 20:24; and with the church invisible, or believers, by the inhabitation and operation of his Holy Spirit, Ezek. 36:27.

SubQuestions.Question: How is he present in heaven?
SubQuestions.Answer: By the most bright and immediate displays of his glory; all the inhabitants of the upper sanctuary seeing him as he is, and enjoying him without interruption for ever, 1 John 3:2; Psalm 16:11.

SubQuestions.Question: How is he present in hell?
SubQuestions.Answer: In a way of tremendous power and justice, upholding the damned in their being, that they may lie under the strokes of his vindictive wrath for evermore, Psalm 90:11; Matt. 25:46.

SubQuestions.Question: What may we learn from God's omnipresence?
SubQuestions.Answer: That no affliction or temptation can befall the saints without his knowledge and sympathy, Isaiah 43:2.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the difference between time and eternity?
SubQuestions.Answer: Time has a continual succession, the former time passing away, and another succeeding; but eternity is an infinite immutable duration.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it for God to be eternal?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is that perfection of his nature, by which he continually exists, without any beginning, end, or succession of time.

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove that God is without beginning?
SubQuestions.Answer: From Psalm 90:2 - "Before the mountains were brought forth, or ever thou hadst formed the earth and the world, even from everlasting to everlasting thou art God;" that is, since thou didst exist before the mountains were brought forth, or before the beginning of time, thou art absolutely eternal.

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove that God is without end?
SubQuestions.Answer: From Psalm 102:12, 27 - "Thou, O Lord, shalt endure for ever, - and thy years shall have no end;" for that which had no beginning of duration, can never have an end of it, but must always necessarily exist.

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove that he is without succession of time?
SubQuestions.Answer: From Psalm 90:4 - "A thousand years are in thy sight but as yesterday when it is past:" and 2 Pet. 3:8 - "One day is with the Lord as a thousand years, and a thousand years as one day." He does not only always remain in being, but is always the same in that being, Psalm 102:27.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the difference between God's eternity, and the eternity of angels and the souls of men?
SubQuestions.Answer: God's eternity is essential, absolute, and independent, without beginning, as well as without end; but the eternity of angels, and of the souls of men, is quite of another nature; for, as they had a beginning, so their duration admits of a succession, as long as time lasts: and though they shall never have an end, yet this eternity of theirs is not necessary and essential to their nature, but flows from the will and power of God; who, if he pleased, could bring them to an end, as well as he gave them a beginning.

SubQuestions.Question: What use should the wicked make of God's eternity?
SubQuestions.Answer: It should be matter of the greatest terror to them while they continue in their wickedness; for, in this case, God will be their eternal foe, and will punish them with everlasting destruction, 2 Thess. 1:9.

SubQuestions.Question: What use should the godly, or believers in Christ, make of it?
SubQuestions.Answer: They should improve it as matter of unspeakable comfort; because their God, being the eternal God, will therefore be the strength of their heart, and their portion for ever, Psalm 73:26.

SubQuestions.Question: What do you understand by God's being unchangeable?
SubQuestions.Answer: His most perfect constancy, by which he is infinitely free from any actual or possible change, and is always the same.

SubQuestions.Question: How is God's unchangeableness proved from scripture?
SubQuestions.Answer: From Mal. 3:6 - "I am the Lord, I change not;" and James 1:17 - "The Father of lights, with whom is no variableness, neither shadow of turning."

SubQuestions.Question: How may it be proved from reason?
SubQuestions.Answer: Reason teaches, that if God did change, it behoved either to be to the better, or to the worse; neither of which is consistent with his absolute perfection, Matt. 5:48.

SubQuestions.Question: Can any creature be unchangeable in its nature?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; because every creature depends upon God for being and operation, Acts 17:28.

SubQuestions.Question: Are not holy angels, and glorified saints, unchangeable?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are in a state of unchangeable happiness, Eph. 1:10; but this is owing to sovereign grace, and not to their own natures, Rom. 6:23.

SubQuestions.Question: Did creation make any change in God?
SubQuestions.Answer: It made a change in the creature, from nothing to being; but none in God, because his will and power to create were the same from eternity.

SubQuestions.Question: How is God unchangeable, when he sometimes said in scripture to repent, as in Gen. 6:6. Jonah 3:10?
SubQuestions.Answer: When, in these or the like places, he is said to repent, it imports only an alteration of his way, or outward conduct according to his infallible foresight, but no change of his mind or will, Job 23:13.

SubQuestions.Question: What may we learn from God's unchangeableness?
SubQuestions.Answer: That he will accomplish his promise, Micah 7:20; rest in his love, Zeph. 3:17; and finish the good work which he has begun in the soul, Phil. 1:6.

SubQuestions.Question: In what is God infinite, eternal, and unchangeable?
SubQuestions.Answer: In his being, wisdom, power, holiness, justice, goodness, and truth.

SubQuestions.Question: What is understood by God's being?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is what is usually called his essence.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the divine essence?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is the glorious and transcendent nature of God, by which he is infinitely blessed in himself, and comprehended by none beside himself.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the highest perfection of being?
SubQuestions.Answer: That to which nothing can be added, and from which nothing can be taken, and which is independent of all things else, Job 35:6-8.

SubQuestions.Question: Can being itself, or being in a proper and strict sense, be attributed to any, but God only?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; for though the heavens and the earth, angels and men, have a being; yet there is no infinite, eternal, and unchangeable being, but God only. It is God alone that can say, I AM, Ex. 3:14.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the import of that name, I AM?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is of the same import with the name JEHOVAH: as if he had said, I am being itself, the author and fountain of all beings in heaven or earth.

SubQuestions.Question: What are all other beings, in comparison with the being of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: All other beings are but created, contingent, and shadowy beings, if compared with his, who spoke them into being, Psalm 33:6, 9.

SubQuestions.Question: What says God concerning those that are taken up with created beings, without ever reflecting upon the supreme, infinite, and eternal Being?
SubQuestions.Answer: That they are brutish among the people; fools, destitute of wisdom, Psalm 94:8; more brutish than the ox that knoweth his owner, Isaiah 1:3.

SubQuestions.Question: Are not all created beings, with their perfections, originally in God, and from him?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; as is evident from the unanswerable reasoning of the Spirit of God, Psalm 94:9, 10:- "He that planted the ear, shall he not hear? He that formed the eye, shall he not see? - He that teacheth man knowledge, shall not he know?"

SubQuestions.Question: What may we learn from God's being?
SubQuestions.Answer: That as he gave being to all the creatures, so he will give being to all his promises, in their full accomplishment, Ex. 6:8.

SubQuestions.Question: Is not omniscience, or infinite knowledge and understanding, inseparably connected with infinite wisdom?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; "For the Lord is a God of knowledge, by him actions are weighed," 1 Sam. 2:3.

SubQuestions.Question: What is God's omniscience?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is that perfection of his nature, by which he knows all things most perfectly in himself, by one eternal act, Acts 15:18.

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove from scripture that he knows all things?
SubQuestions.Answer: From 1 John 3:20 - "God is greater than our heart, and knoweth all things."

SubQuestions.Question: How does God's omniscience appear from reason?
SubQuestions.Answer: He who made all things, cannot but know and comprehend his own workmanship, Psalm 94:9.

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear that he has a perfect knowledge of intelligent creatures?
SubQuestions.Answer: If he did not perfectly know them, and their actions, he could not be their supreme governor and judge, Heb. 4:13.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the object of the divine knowledge or omniscience?
SubQuestions.Answer: God himself, Matt. 11:27, and all other things whatsoever, John 21:17.

SubQuestions.Question: How is it evident, that God has a most perfect knowledge of himself, and his own glorious excellencies?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because otherwise his understanding would not be infinite, as it is asserted to be, Psalm 147:5, in regard all other objects, beside himself, are but finite.

SubQuestions.Question: Is the knowledge of God absolutely independent upon12 the creature?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is so independent upon the creature, "as nothing is to him contingent or uncertain, Acts 15:18; Ezek. 11:5."13

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear, that God has a certain and infallible knowledge of contingent actions, or of such things as seem casual and accidental to us?
SubQuestions.Answer: It appears from this, that future events, which depend upon the freedom of man's will, or upon second causes, are expressly foretold in scripture, and, therefore, certainly foreknown by God; such as, Joseph's preferment, and Israel's oppression in Egypt; Ahab's death, though by an arrow shot at a venture; Caesar's decree, that all the world should be taxed, bringing about Christ's birth at Bethlehem; and many other instances.

SubQuestions.Question: How does God know things that are only possible?
SubQuestions.Answer: He knows them in his power, which could easily bring them to pass if he had so decreed, Matt. 19:26.

SubQuestions.Question: How does he know things future, or such as actually come to pass in time?
SubQuestions.Answer: He knows them not only in his power, as able to effect them; but in his will, as determining their futurition,14 or after-existence, Gen. 17:21.

SubQuestions.Question: Is God's knowledge of things general or particular?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is a particular knowledge of every individual creature, and every circumstance about it, Psalm 139:2; Matt. 10:29, 30.

SubQuestions.Question: Is there any succession in his knowledge, or does he know one thing before another?
SubQuestions.Answer: As there is no succession in his essence, so there is none in his knowledge; he knows all things eternally, infallibly, and immutably, by one single act of his infinite understanding, Heb. 4:13 - "All things are naked and opened, unto the eyes of him with whom we have to do."

SubQuestions.Question: What conception may we have of the difference between the infinite knowledge and wisdom of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: His infinite knowledge comprehends all things in heaven and earth, by one intuitive glance of his infinite mind; but his infinite wisdom directs these things to the proper ends, for which he gave them their being, Rom. 11:36.

SubQuestions.Question: How does the wisdom of God appear in the work of creation?
SubQuestions.Answer: It appears in the excellent order, beauty, and harmony that are to be seen in all parts of the creation, Psalm 19:1-7; in the subserviency of one thing to another, Hos. 2:21, 22; the tendency of the whole, to manifest the glory of God, Rev. 4:11; and calculate also for the good of man as his peculiar favourite, Psalm 115:16.

SubQuestions.Question: How does the wisdom of God appear in the works of providence?
SubQuestions.Answer: In adjusting the whole of his administrations according to the plan laid in his infinite mind from eternity; or his most judicious and regular putting his counsels into execution, Psalm 33:10, 11.

SubQuestions.Question: How does the wisdom of God shine in the work of redemption?
SubQuestions.Answer: In making an honourable egress and vent for his mercy and love to sinners of mankind, in the way of satisfying his justice to the full, by the obedience and death of the blessed Surety, Rom. 5:21.

SubQuestions.Question: What encouragement ought we to take from the wisdom of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: That he will make all things work together for our good, Rom. 8:28; and that no plot can be so deeply laid for our ruin, but his wisdom can easily frustrate and disappoint, Job 5:13.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the power of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is that essential perfection of his nature, by which he can do whatsoever he pleases, in heaven and earth, in the seas, and all deep places, Psalm 135:6.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the object of divine power, or to what does it extend?
SubQuestions.Answer: To all things possible, though limited, by his will, to those things only which he has decreed to be done, Matt. 26:53, 54.

SubQuestions.Question: Is it any impeachment of God's omnipotence, that he cannot lie, cannot deny himself?
SubQuestions.Answer: By no means; for, on the contrary, God is therefore omnipotent, because it is impossible for him to do evil or depart from the infinite rectitude of his own will, 1 Sam. 15:29 - "The strength of Israel will not lie."

SubQuestions.Question: In what does God manifest his infinite power?
SubQuestions.Answer: In creation, providence, and redemption.

SubQuestions.Question: How is the power of God manifested in creation?
SubQuestions.Answer: In calling "those things that be not as though they were," Rom. 4:7; without the assistance or instrumentality of any whosoever, Isaiah 44:24.

SubQuestions.Question: How is it displayed in the conduct of providence?
SubQuestions.Answer: In upholding and preserving all his creatures from sinking into their original nothing, Heb. 1:3; and, particularly, in protecting and defending his church, in midst of all the dangers and enemies, with which it is surrounded, Matt. 16:18.

SubQuestions.Question: How is the power of God illustrated in the glorious work of redemption?
SubQuestions.Answer: By laying the chief cornerstone thereof, in the union of the human nature to the person of the Son of God; supporting him under the inconceivable load of divine wrath, for our sins, and spoiling principalities and powers in that very nature which Satan had vanquished at first; hence he is called "the power of God," 1 Cor. 1:24 - "the arm of the Lord," Isaiah 53:1; and "the man of his right hand," Psalm 80:17.

SubQuestions.Question: How is the power of God denied or abused by men?
SubQuestions.Answer: By limiting it, as Israel did, Psalm 78:19; by trusting more to an arm of flesh, than to the arm of God, Jer. 17:5; and by fearing the wrath of man more than the displeasure of God, Isaiah 51:12, 13.

SubQuestions.Question: What improvement may faith make of the power of a promising God?
SubQuestions.Answer: It can fasten upon it, for the performance of his gracious word, Rom 4:20, 21; for resisting and conquering sin, Satan, and the world, saying, "If God be for us, who can be against us?" Rom. 8:31; and for the practice of any commanded duty, however difficult, saying, "I can do all things through Christ who strengtheneth me," Phil. 4:13.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the holiness of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is that essential rectitude or integrity of his nature, by which he infinitely delights in his own purity, and in every thing agreeable to his will, Hab. 1:13; and has a perfect hatred and abhorrence of every thing contrary to it, Jer. 44:4.

SubQuestions.Question: Is God necessarily holy?
SubQuestions.Answer: Holiness is as necessary to him as his being: he is as necessarily holy, as he is necessarily God: "Who shall not fear thee, O Lord? - for thou only art holy," Rev. 15:4.

SubQuestions.Question: What peculiar honour does God put upon his own holiness?
SubQuestions.Answer: He singles it out as the attribute to swear by, for the accomplishment of his promises and threatenings, Psalm 89:35 - "Once have I sworn by my holiness, that I will not lie unto David."

SubQuestions.Question: Are finite creatures able to behold the brightness of God's holiness?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; for when the angels themselves view his infinite holiness, as manifested in Christ, they are represented as covering their faces with their wings, Isaiah 6:2.

SubQuestions.Question: How are sinners of mankind made partakers of his holiness?
SubQuestions.Answer: By regenerating grace, and spiritual ingraftment into the second Adam, John 15:4, 5; by faith's improvement of the great and precious promises, 2 Pet. 1:4; and by beholding the glory of this attribute, as it shines in the person and sufferings of the Son of God, presented to our view in the glass of the gospel revelation, 2 Cor. 5:21.

SubQuestions.Question: Does every thing pertaining to God, bear the stamp and impress of his holiness?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; he is holy in all his works, Psalm 145:17; his word is holy, Rom. 1:2; his covenant or promise is holy. Psalm 105:42; his Sabbath is holy, Isaiah 58:13; his people are holy, chap. 62:12; his ministering spirits are the holy angels, Rev. 14:10; and the place where he dwells, is the high and holy place, Isaiah 57:15.

SubQuestions.Question: In what did the holiness of God appear in the creation of man?
SubQuestions.Answer: In making him upright, Eccl. 7:29, after his own image, Gen. 1:27; and writing a law upon his heart, which was the transcript of his holiness, Rom, 7:12.

SubQuestions.Question: How has God discovered his holiness in his providential procedure?
SubQuestions.Answer: In not sparing the angels who sinned; and in the visible and remarkable judgments, which he has inflicted upon notorious offenders in this life, 2 Pet. 2:4-6.

SubQuestions.Question: What was the highest display of God's holiness, and detestation of sin?
SubQuestions.Answer: His hiding his face from his own beloved Son, as bearing our iniquity, Matt. 27:46.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the greatest opposite of the holiness of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: Sin: therefore called that abominable thing which God hates, Jer. 44:4.

SubQuestions.Question: How does God hate sin?
SubQuestions.Answer: He hates it necessarily, and with a "perfect hatred," Psalm 5:4-6.

SubQuestions.Question: Since God thus hates sin, how does his permission of it consist with his holiness?
SubQuestions.Answer: It fully consists with it, because his permission of sin has no influence upon the commission of it, which entirely flows from the free will of the sinner, James 1:13, 14. Besides, God thereby takes occasion to give a brighter display of his holiness and detestation of sin, than though Adam had continued in innocence; when he spared not his own Son, but gave him unto death on account of it, Rom. 8:32.

SubQuestions.Question: What improvement ought we to make of the holiness of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: To "give thanks at the remembrance of his holiness," Psalm 30:4; to proclaim the glory of it, Ex. 15:11; and to study holiness in all manner of conversation, 1 Pet. 1:15.

SubQuestions.Question: How may we know if we have suitable impressions of God's holiness?
SubQuestions.Answer: If we stand in awe to offend him, Gen. 39:9; and have an habitual desire after more conformity to him, 1 John 3:3.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the justice of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is that essential attribute of his nature, by which he is infinitely righteous and equal in himself, and in all his ways towards his creatures, Deut. 32:4.

SubQuestions.Question: How may the justice of God be considered?
SubQuestions.Answer: Either as it relates to himself, or to rational creatures.

SubQuestions.Question: What is God's justice as it relates to himself?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is his making his own glory the fixed and invariable rule of the whole of his procedure, Isaiah 42:8.

SubQuestions.Question: What is God's justice in relation to rational creatures?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is his righteous government of them, according to their nature, and the law he has given them, Rom. 2:12, 14, 15.

SubQuestions.Question: How is it usually distinguished?
SubQuestions.Answer: Into legislative and distributive justice.

SubQuestions.Question: What is legislative justice?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is his giving most holy, just, and good laws to rational creatures, commanding and forbidding them, what is fit for them to do, or forbear, Isaiah 33:22.

SubQuestions.Question: Has man a power to give obedience to these laws?
SubQuestions.Answer: He once had power, but by the fall has lost it, Rom. 3:23.

SubQuestions.Question: How does it consist with the justice of God to demand that obedience, which man has not power to give?
SubQuestions.Answer: God cannot lose his right to demand obedience to his laws, though man has lost his power to give it; especially as man's inability was contracted by his own voluntary apostasy and rebellion, Eccl. 7:29 - "Lo, this only have I found, that God hath made man upright; but they have sought out many inventions."

SubQuestions.Question: What is God's distributive justice?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is his constant will, to render to rational creatures their due, according to law, without respect to persons, Job 34:11. 1 Pet. 1:17.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the laws according to which God will distribute justice among men?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are two: the law of works, and the law of faith.

SubQuestions.Question: Where are they mentioned?
SubQuestions.Answer: In Rom. 3:27 - "Where is boasting, then? It is excluded. By what law? of works? Nay: but by the law of faith."

SubQuestions.Question: What is understood by the law of works, and the law of faith?
SubQuestions.Answer: By the law of works, is understood the covenant of works; and by the law of faith, the covenant of grace.

SubQuestions.Question: What is due to the sinner, in justice, according to the law of works?
SubQuestions.Answer: Death and the curse; which include all woe and misery, in time, and through eternity, Rom. 6:23; Gal. 3:10.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the sinner's due according to the law of faith?
SubQuestions.Answer: Acquittance and acceptance, on account of the surety-righteousness imputed to him, and apprehended by faith, Rom. 3:24, and 8:1.

SubQuestions.Question: Is God just in dealing thus with the ungodly sinner, who believes in Christ?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; his righteousness is declared in so doing, Rom. 3:25, 26 - "Whom God hath set forth for a propitiation through faith in his blood, to declare his righteousness, - that he might be just, and the justifier of him who believeth in Jesus."

SubQuestions.Question: Does God reward the sincere, though imperfect obedience of his people to the law, as a rule of life?
SubQuestions.Answer: In keeping of his commandments there is indeed great reward, Psalm 19:11; but then this reward is entirely of free grace, and not of debt, Rom. 4:4, 5; it is not on account of any worth in their obedience, Psalm 115:1; but only on account of what Christ has merited, by his obedience to the death, 1 Pet. 2:5.

SubQuestions.Question: How is this kind of justice called?
SubQuestions.Answer: Remunerative or rewarding justice, Psalm 58:11 - "Verily, there is a reward for the righteous."

SubQuestions.Question: Is not God's taking vengeance on transgressors, a righteous act of justice?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; for "every transgression and disobedience receives a just recompense of reward," Heb. 2:2. "It is a righteous thing to recompense tribulation to them that trouble you," 2 Thess. 1:6. Hence says the same apostle, Rom. 3:5, 6 - "Is God unrighteous who taketh vengeance? God forbid: for then how shall God judge the world?"

SubQuestions.Question: How is this justice of God called?
SubQuestions.Answer: Vindictive or punishing justice, Acts 28:4.

SubQuestions.Question: What is vindictive justice?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is God's inflicting the punishment upon sin, which is threatened in the law, Gen. 2:17; Ezek. 18:4.

SubQuestions.Question: Could God, of his own free will, have pardoned sin without a satisfaction to his justice?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; for he has declared, "that in forgiving iniquity, transgression and sin," he "will by no means clear the guilty;" namely, without a satisfaction, Ex. 34:7.

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove, that vindictive, or punishing justice, is essential to God?
SubQuestions.Answer: From the infinite holiness of God, who cannot but hate, and consequently punish sin, Hab. 1:12, 13; from his faithfulness in the threatening, Gen. 2:17; Psalm 95:11; from the remarkable judgments that have been inflicted on sinners in this life, Jude, verse 5, 7; and from the sufferings and death of God's only begotten Son, whom he would surely have spared, if there had been any other possible way of pardoning sin, but through his satisfaction, Matt. 26:42; 2 Cor. 5:21.

SubQuestions.Question: What improvement ought we to make of the justice of God, as glorified by the satisfactory death of his own Son?
SubQuestions.Answer: To plead the perfect and full satisfaction of it by the Surety, as the honourable channel, in which we expect all mercy and grace to flow plentifully to us, as the Psalmist did, Psalm 25:11 - "For thy name's sake, O Lord, pardon mine iniquity, for it is great."

SubQuestions.Question: What is the goodness of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is that essential property of his nature, by which he is infinitely good in himself; and the author and fountain of all good to others, Psalm 119:68.

SubQuestions.Question: How may the goodness of God be distinguished?
SubQuestions.Answer: Int: his absolute and relative goodness.

SubQuestions.Question: What is his absolute goodness?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is the essential goodness of his nature, without considering it in relation to the creatures, Matt. 19:17 - "There is none good but one, that is, God."

SubQuestions.Question: What is his relative goodness?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is the relation that his goodness bears to the creatures; both in the propensity of his nature to do them good, Ex. 33:19, and in the actual manifestation and communication of the blessings of his bounty to them, in creation, providence, and redemption, chap. 34:6, 7.

SubQuestions.Question: How is the goodness of God manifested in the work of creation in general?
SubQuestions.Answer: In giving being to his creatures, when he stood in no need of them, being infinitely happy in himself, though no creature had ever been made, Psalm 16:2; and in making all things very good, Gen. 1:31.

SubQuestions.Question: How is the goodness of God displayed in the creation of man in particular?
SubQuestions.Answer: In making him after his own image; furnishing the world with such a variety of creatures for his use; giving him dominion over them, Gen. 1:27, 28; and in entering into covenant with him, chap. 2:16, 17.

SubQuestions.Question: How is the goodness of God manifested in his providence?
SubQuestions.Answer: In preserving his creatures, and making bountiful provision for them, Psalm 145:9, 15, 16.

SubQuestions.Question: How is this goodness distinguished?
SubQuestions.Answer: Into common and special goodness.

SubQuestions.Question: What is his common goodness?
SubQuestions.Answer: His dispensing the good things of this life, promiscuously among his creatures, Matt. 5:45 - "He maketh his sun to rise on the evil and on the good, and sendeth rain on the just and on the unjust."

SubQuestions.Question: Is God good even to the wicked who are his enemies?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; for he not only provides for them, "filling their hearts with food and gladness," Acts 14:17; but exercises long-suffering patience towards them, Neh. 9:17; and affords such of them as are within the visible church, the means of salvation, Acts 13:26.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the special goodness of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is his distinguishing love to a certain number of mankind lost, manifested in their redemption through Christ, Rev. 5:9.

SubQuestions.Question: In what does the goodness of God appear in the work of redemption?
SubQuestions.Answer: Both in the contrivance and execution of it.

SubQuestions.Question: How does the goodness of God appear in the contrivance of redemption?
SubQuestions.Answer: In remembering us in our low state, Psalm 136:23; laying our help on his own Son, the mighty One, Psalm 89:19; and in setting him up as a new covenant head from everlasting, Proverbs 8:23.

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear in the execution of our redemption?
SubQuestions.Answer: In sending his Son to assume our nature, and thus to fulfil all righteousness for us, John 3:16, Jer. 23:6; and on the foundation of that righteousness, giving us grace and glory, and every good thing, from a cup of cold water, to a seat with him on his throne, Psalm 84:11; Rev. 3:21.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the streams in which the special goodness of God flows out?
SubQuestions.Answer: In the streams of love, grace and mercy, according to his name, Ex. 34:6, - "the Lord, the Lord God, merciful and gracious," &c.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the difference between the love, grace, and mercy of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are much the same, only love considers the sinner simply as God's creature; grace views him as ill-deserving; and mercy, through a satisfaction, respects him as in misery.

SubQuestions.Question: Who are the objects of God's special goodness?
SubQuestions.Answer: His chosen ones, Psalm 106:4, 5 - "O visit me with thy salvation, that I may see the good of thy chosen."

SubQuestions.Question: Can this special goodness of God be expressed in words?
