SubQuestions.Answer: No; for "Eye hath not seen, nor ear heard, neither have entered into the heart of man, the things which God hath prepared for them that love him," 1 Cor. 2:9. And Psalm 31:19 - "O! how great is thy goodness, which thou hast laid up for them that fear thee."

SubQuestions.Question: Where is this goodness of God laid up?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is laid up in Christ, who has received the gifts of God's goodness for men, Psalm 68:18 - "When he ascended up on high, he - gave gifts unto men," Eph. 4:8; and therefore, God has made him most blessed for ever, Psalm 21:6.

SubQuestions.Question: How is this goodness laid out and brought near to us?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is laid out in the exceeding great and precious promises, 2 Pet. 1:4; and brought near in the full, free, and unhampered offer of the gospel, Mark 16:15.

SubQuestions.Question: How are we savingly interested in all this goodness?
SubQuestions.Answer: By faith, receiving and resting upon Christ alone for salvation, as he is freely offered in the gospel, John 1:12; 1 Cor. 3:22, 23.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the properties of this goodness?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is seasonable goodness, Heb. 4:16; it is soul-satisfying, Psalm 107:9; and it is immutable and everlasting, Psalm 52:1.

SubQuestions.Question: What improvement ought we to make of the goodness of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: We ought to "praise the Lord for his goodness, and for his wonderful works to the children of men," Psalm 107:8; to be influenced to repentance from the consideration of his goodness, Rom. 2:4; and to imitate God in it, Heb. 13:16.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the truth of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is that essential perfection of his nature, by which he cannot but fulfil and accomplish whatever he has spoken; or do as he has said, Num. 23:19.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it that this perfection of God has a special relation to?
SubQuestions.Answer: To the revelation of his will in his word: hence the whole scripture is infallible truth; "one jot, or one tittle, shall in no wise pass therefrom, till all be fulfilled," Matt. 5:18. For, "the word of the Lord endureth for ever," 1 Pet. 1:25.

SubQuestions.Question: What is God's truth, as respecting his word, commonly called?
SubQuestions.Answer: His faithfulness, or veracity, Heb. 10:23 - "He is faithful that promised."

SubQuestions.Question: To what is the truth or faithfulness of God opposed?
SubQuestions.Answer: To all change of mind, Job 23:13 - "He is in one mind, and who can turn him?" and to all lying and dissimulation, Heb. 6:18 - "It is impossible for God to lie."

SubQuestions.Question: Can there be any inconsistency in his words?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; for truth always hangs with itself, and he "keepeth truth for ever," Psalm 146:6.

SubQuestions.Question: Can he possibly forget what he has said?
SubQuestions.Answer: No, surely; for "he will ever be mindful of his covenant," Psalm 111:5.

SubQuestions.Question: In what is the truth or faithfulness of God manifested?
SubQuestions.Answer: In the exact accomplishment of his promises, Josh. 23:14; and the certain execution of his threatenings, Zech. 1:6.

SubQuestions.Question: How do we give God the honour of his truth and faithfulness?
SubQuestions.Answer: By faith, which sets to the seal that God is true, John 3:33; and judges him faithful who hath promised, Heb. 11:11.

SubQuestions.Question: By what sin is this attribute of God most dishonoured?
SubQuestions.Answer: By the sin of unbelief, which makes God a liar, because it believes not "the record that God gave of his Son," 1 John 5:10.

SubQuestions.Question: What record does God give of his Son?
SubQuestions.Answer: "This is the record, that God hath given to us eternal life, and this life is in his Son," 1 John 5:11.

SubQuestions.Question: To whom is this record given?
SubQuestions.Answer: To all the hearers of the gospel, as a ground of faith. Mark 16:15 - "Go ye into all the world, and preach the gospel to every creature:" Acts 2:39 - "The promise is unto you, and to your children, and to all that are afar off, even as many as the Lord our God shall call."

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear that this record is given as a ground of faith, to all the hearers of the gospel?
SubQuestions.Answer: If it were not so, it were impossible that unbelievers, under the gospel, could make God a liar; for if they have no concern in this record, and are not bound to believe it with application to themselves, their rejecting of it could not be their sin; because "where no law is, there is no transgression," Rom. 4:15.

SubQuestions.Question: If the record, or promise of the God of truth, be made to every one of the hearers of the gospel, is he not, in that case, obliged to fulfil it to every one?
SubQuestions.Answer: By no means: because the unbeliever wilfully rejects the promise, and will have no benefit by it, Psalm 81:10-13.

SubQuestions.Question: By what example, in scripture, may this be illustrated?
SubQuestions.Answer: By the example of the promise of Canaan, made indefinitely to all Israel who came out of Egypt, Ex. 6:6, 8; yet many of them "could not enter in because of unbelief," Heb. 3:19; even so, the promise of eternal life is made to all the hearers of the gospel; yet many of them come short of it, because "the word preached doth not profit them, not being mixed with faith in them that hear it," Heb. 4:1, 2.

SubQuestions.Question: What then is the deplorable case of unbelievers under the gospel?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are condemned already, and "the wrath of God abideth on them," John 3:18, 36.

SubQuestions.Question: What improvement ought we to make of the truth and faithfulness of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: We ought to choose the way of truth, Psalm 119:30; walk in it, 3 John, ver. 4; bear witness for it before the world, Heb. 10:23; praise God for his truth, Psalm 148:2; and trust him on his word, without staggering at the promise through unbelief, Rom. 4:20.

Data.Question: Are there more Gods than one?
Data.Answer: There is but one only, the living and true God.

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear from scripture, that there is but one God only?
SubQuestions.Answer: From Deut. 6:4 - "Hear, O Israel, the Lord our God is one Lord:" Isaiah 45:22 - "I am God, and there is none else."

SubQuestions.Question: How does reason demonstrate this truth, that there is but one God?
SubQuestions.Answer: Reason says, that there is but one first cause and ultimate end of all things: and that there cannot be two, or more, infinite, eternal and unchangeable beings.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is God's omnipotence commonly adduced to prove, that he can be but one only?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because he could not be omnipotent, or almighty, if any other could oppose or resist him, Job 9:12.

SubQuestions.Question: How may it be proved from his government of the world?
SubQuestions.Answer: There could not be a uniform governing of all things in the world, to one certain end, if the infinitely wise Governor, who is at the helm, were not one only.

SubQuestions.Question: How are some of the divine perfections expressed in scripture, for proving the unity of the essence?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are expressed in the abstract; for instance God is said to be "light," 1 John 1:5; to be "love," ch. 4:8; to be "strength," 1 Sam. 15:29; all which, and the like abstract properties, plainly denote that God is one only.

SubQuestions.Question: Is God compounded of the several perfections of his nature, as the Socinians speak?
SubQuestions.Answer: By no means: for all the several attributes of God are only the one infinite perfection of his most simple and uncompounded nature; which infinite perfection, because of our weakness, is described by parts, according to the several objects about which it is conversant.

SubQuestions.Question: Is the vast variety of the divine decrees any argument against the divine unity?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; because the decrees are various only with respect to the different objects and effects to which they extend, but not with respect to the act of the divine will, which is but one.

SubQuestions.Question: Are there not several in scripture who are called gods?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; angels, magistrates, and the idols of the heathen nations.

SubQuestions.Question: Why are angels called gods? Psalm 97:7.
SubQuestions.Answer: Because of the excellency of their nature, power, and wisdom, Psalm 103:20.

SubQuestions.Question: Why are magistrates so called? Ex. 22:28.
SubQuestions.Answer: Because they are God's deputies for government and justice among men, Rom. 13:4.

SubQuestions.Question: Why are the idols of the heathen nations called gods? 1 Chron. 5:25.
SubQuestions.Answer: Because ignorant and brutish persons have honoured them as such; but there is no reason at all to be "afraid of them, for they cannot do evil, neither also is it in them to do good," Jer. 10:5.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is Satan called the god of this world? 2 Cor. 4:4.
SubQuestions.Answer: Because he reigns and rules over the greatest part of the world, as his servants and slaves; for he is "the spirit that now worketh in the children of disobedience," Eph. 2:2.

SubQuestions.Question: Why are covetous men called idolaters? Eph. 5:5.
SubQuestions.Answer: Because the world has that room in their heart which God should have.

SubQuestions.Question: What may we learn from God's being one only?
SubQuestions.Answer: To beware of mistaken notions of him, as if he were partly in heaven and partly on earth; for he is so much one, that he is wholly every where present, Jer. 23:24.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is this one only God said to be the living God?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because he has life essentially in himself, John 5:26; and is the author and giver of that life that is in any living creature, Acts 17:28; and likewise in opposition to dead and dumb idols, Psalm 115:4-7.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is he called the true God?
SubQuestions.Answer: In opposition to all false and imaginary gods, Jer. 10:10, 11.

SubQuestions.Question: Why are living, and true put together in the answer?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because they are inseparably conjoined in the infinitely perfect nature of God. He who is the living God is the only true God; and the true God, the only living God, 1 Thess. 1:9.

SubQuestions.Question: What may we learn from his being the living God?
SubQuestions.Answer: To present our bodies a living sacrifice, holy, acceptable to God, which is our reasonable service, Rom. 12:1.

SubQuestions.Question: What may we learn from his being the only true God?
SubQuestions.Answer: To worship him in spirit and in truth, John 4:24, because he desires truth in the inward parts, Psalm 51:6; and likewise to beware of setting up an idol, or regarding any iniquity in our hearts; otherwise he will not hear us, Psalm 66:18.

Data.Question: How many persons are there in the Godhead?
Data.Answer: There are three persons in the Godhead, the Father, the Son, and the Holy Ghost; and these three are one God, the same in substance, equal in power and glory.

SubQuestions.Question: Whence is it, that this article of our holy religion has been so much opposed by adversaries, in every period of the church?
SubQuestions.Answer: The devil and his instruments have warmly opposed it because they know it is the primary object of our faith and worship; it not being enough for us to know what God is, as to his essential attributes, without knowing who he is, as to his personality, according as he has revealed himself in his word, to be Father, Son, and Holy Ghost, 1 John 2:23, - "Whosoever denieth the Son, the same hath not the Father."

SubQuestions.Question: Is this doctrine of the Trinity, then; a fundamental article, upon the belief of which our salvation depends?
SubQuestions.Answer: Beyond all doubt it is: because without the knowledge and belief of the Trinity of persons, we would remain ignorant of the love of the Father, the merit of the Son, and the sanctifying influences of the Holy Ghost, in the purchase and application of redemption; without which there could be no salvation, John 17:3, - "This is life eternal, that they might know thee the only true God, and Jesus Christ whom thou hast sent."

SubQuestions.Question: Can the Trinity of persons be proved from the Old Testament?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; not only from the history of man's creation, where God speaks of himself in the plural number, "Let us make man," Gen. 1:26; but likewise from such passages, as expressly restrict this plurality to three persons, such as, Psalm 33:6, - "By the word of the Lord, or JEHOVAH, were the heavens made; and all the host of them by the breath, or spirit, of his mouth;" where there is mention made of JEHOVAH, the Word, and the Spirit, as concurring in the creation of all things: accordingly, we are told that all things were made by the Word, John 1:3, and that the Spirit garnished the heavens, Job 26:13. The same truth is also evident from Isaiah 63:7, 9, 10; where we read of the loving-kindness of JEHOVAH; Of the Angel of his presence saving them; and of their vexing his Holy Spirit. A plain discovery of a Trinity of persons.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the meaning of the word Trinity, so commonly used in expressing this doctrine?
SubQuestions.Answer: It signifies the same with Tri-unity, or three in one; that is, three distinct persons, in one and the same individual or numerical15 essence, 1 John 5:7.

SubQuestions.Question: Is not a Trinity of persons, in the divine Essence, an unsearchable mystery?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; and so is every perfection of God, which infinitely transcends our thoughts, and finite capacities, Col. 2:2; Job 11:6, 7.

SubQuestions.Question: Is it not unreasonable to require a belief of what we cannot understand?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is not at all unreasonable in matters that are entirely supernatural; but, on the contrary, it is the highest reason we should believe what God says of himself, and of the manner of his own subsistence, John 20:31; besides, it is the peculiar office of faith to subject our reason to divine revelation, Heb. 11:1.

SubQuestions.Question: How has God revealed this mystery in his word?
SubQuestions.Answer: He :as in it told us, that "there are three that bear record in heaven, the Father, the Word, and the Holy Ghost; and these three are one," 1 John 5:7. Or, as our Confession expresses it, "In the unity of the Godhead there be three persons, of one substance, power, and eternity; God the Father, God the Son, and God the Holy Ghost," Matt. 3:16, 17 and 28:19; 2 Cor. 13:14.

SubQuestions.Question: What is meant by the word Godhead?
SubQuestions.Answer: The divine nature or essence; Rom. 1:20, compared with Gal. 4:8.

SubQuestions.Question: What is meant by a person in the Godhead?
SubQuestions.Answer: A complete, intelligent, and individual subsistence, which is neither a part of, nor sustained by any other; but is distinguished by an incommunicable property in the same undivided essence.

SubQuestions.Question: Has each person then a distinct nature, or essence of his own?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; but the same divine nature, or essence, is common to all the three glorious persons, 1 John 5:7, - "These three are one;" not only united in will and affection, but in one and the same common nature, or essence: it being the transcendent and incommunicable property of the divine nature, to reside in more persons than one.

SubQuestions.Question: What was the heresy of the Sabellians, and Tritheists, in opposition to this fundamental doctrine of the Trinity?
SubQuestions.Answer: The Sabellians maintained that there is but one person in the Trinity under three different names; the Tritheists, that the three persons are three Gods.

SubQuestions.Question: Is the word Person, as applied to this mystery, made use of in scripture?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; for the Son is said to be the "express image of the Father's person," Heb. 1:3.

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove that there are three persons in the Godhead?
SubQuestions.Answer: From the institution of baptism, Matt. 28:19; from the apostolical blessing, 2 Cor. 13:14; from John's salutation to the seven churches, Rev. 1:4, 5; and from the baptism of Christ, Matt. 3:16, 17; where the Father is manifested by a voice from heaven; the Son, by his bodily appearance on earth; and the Holy Ghost, by his lighting on him in the shape of a dove.

SubQuestions.Question: How is it farther evident that they are three distinct persons?
SubQuestions.Answer: From the distinct capacities in which they are represented to act; for, in the work of redemption, we find in scripture, the Father "ordaining," the Son "purchasing," and the Holy Ghost "applying it," 1 Pet. 1:2.

SubQuestions.Question: How are the persons in the Godhead distinguished from each other?
SubQuestions.Answer: By their personal properties, which are incommunicable to each other.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the personal property of the Father?
SubQuestions.Answer: To beget the Son, and that from all eternity, Psalm 2:7.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the personal property of the Son?
SubQuestions.Answer: To be eternally begotten of the Father, John 1:14, - "We beheld his glory, the glory as of the only begotten of the Father."

SubQuestions.Question: What is the personal property of the Holy Ghost?
SubQuestions.Answer: To proceed eternally from the Father and the Son, John 15:26 - "When the Comforter is come, whom I will send unto you from the Father, even the Spirit of truth which proceedeth from the Father, he shall testify of me."

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear that the Holy Ghost proceeds from the Son, as well as from the Father, when it is not expressly affirmed that he does so, in the above text?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because he is called "the Spirit of the Son," Gal. 4:6 - "the Spirit of Christ," Rom. 8:9; the Spirit is said to receive all things from Christ, John 16:14, 15; to be sent by him, John 15:26; and the Father is said to send him in Christ's name, John 14:26; from all which, it may be safely gathered, that he proceeds from the Son, as well as from the Father.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the difference between a personal and an essential property?
SubQuestions.Answer: A personal property is peculiar to one of the persons only, but an essential property is common to them all.

SubQuestions.Question: Why are the personal properties called incommunicable?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because each of them is so proper to one of the persons in the Trinity, that it cannot be affirmed of any of the other two.

SubQuestions.Question: Is it the divine essence that begets, is begotten, or proceeds?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; for these are not essential, but personal acts. It is the Father who begets the Son; the Son who is begotten of the Father; and the Holy Ghost, who proceeds from both.

SubQuestions.Question: Are the terms necessary existence, supreme Deity, and the title of the only true God, essential or personal properties?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are essential properties of the divine nature, and so common to all the persons of the adorable Trinity, who have all the same essence, wholly, equally, and eternally.

SubQuestions.Question: May the above terms be taken, or are they, by sound authors, taken in a sense that includes the personal property of the Father, and so not belonging to the Son and Holy Ghost?
SubQuestions.Answer: They may not be, and never are, by sound authors, taken in that sense; for this would be to make the Son and Holy Ghost inferior to, and dependent upon, the Father, for being or existence, which is the very soul of Arianism.

SubQuestions.Question: Does not the Father, being called the first; the Son, the second; and the Holy Ghost, the third person in the Godhead, imply an inequality, or preference of one person to another?
SubQuestions.Answer: These are only terms of mere order, and imply no preference or priority, either of nature, excellency, or duration; and therefore we find in scripture, that sometimes the Son is named before the Father, as in 2 Cor. 13:14, Gal. 1:1; and sometimes the Spirit before the Son, as in Rev. 1:4, 5.

SubQuestions.Question: Is not each of these glorious persons truly and properly God?
SubQuestions.Answer: Each of these persons is God, in the true and proper sense of the word; though none of them can be called the Deity, exclusively of the rest, in regard the Deity, being the same with the divine nature, or essence, is common to them all.

SubQuestions.Question: But does not our Lord say, that the Father is the "only true God," John 17:3 - "This is life eternal, that they might know thee the only true God?"
SubQuestions.Answer: Our Lord does not say, that the Father only, is the true God, exclusive of the other persons of the Trinity; but that He is the only true God (as each of the other persons is) in opposition to idols, or gods falsely so called.

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear that the Father is God?
SubQuestions.Answer: From his being expressly so called every where in scripture: particularly, 1 Cor. 8:6; and 15:24; Gal. 1:1, 3, &c.

SubQuestions.Question: Is it proper to say, that the Father is the fountain of the Deity?
SubQuestions.Answer: The expression is dangerous, and now used by adversaries in an unsound sense, to exclude self-existence and independency from the Son and Holy Ghost, and therefore is to be avoided.

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear from scripture, that Christ, the Son, is truly and properly the supreme God, equal with the Father?
SubQuestions.Answer: From the same names, attributes, works, and worship being ascribed to him in scripture as are ascribed to the Father, and in as full and ample a sense.16

SubQuestions.Question: What are the names ascribed to Christ, that prove him to be equal with the Father?
SubQuestions.Answer: He is expressly called "God," John 1:1 - "the great God," Titus 2:13 - "the mighty God," Isaiah 9:6 - "the true God," 1 John 5:20 - "the only wise God," Jude ver. 25; and JEHOVAH, which is a name never ascribed to any, in scripture, but the living and true God, Jer. 23:6; Psalm 83:18.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the divine attributes ascribed to Christ, that prove him to be the supreme God?
SubQuestions.Answer: Eternity, in the strict and proper sense of the word, Micah. 5:2; unchangeableness, Heb. 13:8; omniscience, John 21:17; omnipotence, for he calls himself "the Almighty," Rev. 1:8; omnipresence; "Lo," says he, "I am with you always, even unto the end of the world," Matt. 28:20; and supremacy, Rom. 9:5.

SubQuestions.Question: What are those works which manifest Christ to be the true God?
SubQuestions.Answer: The creating and preserving of all things, Col. 1:16, 17; the obtaining eternal redemption for us, Heb. 9:12; the working of miracles by his own power, Mark 5:41; the forgiving of sins, Mark 2:5; the raising of the dead at the last day, John 5:28, 29; and his judging the world, Rom. 14:10.

SubQuestions.Question: What is that worship ascribed to Christ which proves him to be the supreme God?
SubQuestions.Answer: The same divine worship and adoration that is given to the Father, John 5:23; we are commanded to believe in him equally with the Father, John 14:1; and we are baptised in his name, as well as in the name of the Father, Matt. 28:19.

SubQuestions.Question: In what sense does Christ say, John 14:28 - "My Father is greater than I?"
SubQuestions.Answer: He does not speak in that place of his nature, as God, but of his office, as Mediator; in which respect he is the Father's servant, Isaiah 42:1.

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove the supreme Deity of the Holy Ghost?
SubQuestions.Answer: From the same arguments, by which the Deity of the Son was proved; for, (1.) He is expressly called God, Acts 5:3, 4. (2.) Attributes, which are peculiar only to God, are ascribed to him, Heb. 9:14; 1 Cor. 2:10; Luke 2:26; Psalm 139:7. (3.) Works which can be accomplished by none but God, are performed by him, Psalm 33:6; Job 26:13; Luke 1:35; 2 Pet. 1:21; John 16:13; Rom. 15:16. (4.) The same divine worship is paid to him, as to the Father and the Son, Matt. 28:19; 2 Cor. 13:14.

SubQuestions.Question: Could the Trinity of persons, in the unity of essence, have been discovered by the light of nature?
SubQuestions.Answer: By no means: for then it would be no mystery, seeing divine mysteries are such secrets, as the wisdom of man could never have found out, Matt. 11:27; 1 Cor. 2:9, 10, 14.

SubQuestions.Question: Is it lawful to explain this mystery by natural similitudes?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; for there is no similitude amongst all the creatures, that has the remotest resemblance to this adorable mystery of the three one God. By making similes or comparisons of this kind, men have become vain in their imaginations, and their foolish minds have been darkened, Rom. 1:21-26; and therefore, as this doctrine is entirely a matter of faith, it becomes us to adore it, without prying curiously into what is not revealed.

SubQuestions.Question: Does the asserting of three persons in the Godhead, with distinct personal properties, infer any separation, or division, in the divine essence?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; for the persons in the Godhead are not separated, but distinguished from one another, by their personal properties. As the unity of the essence does not confound the persons, so neither does the distinction of persons imply any division of the essence, 1 John 5:7.

SubQuestions.Question: Can any worship God aright, without the faith of this mystery of the Trinity?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; "for he that cometh to God, must believe that he is," Heb. 11:6; namely, that he is God, Father, Son, and Holy Ghost.

SubQuestions.Question: How is our worship to be directed to this three-one God?
SubQuestions.Answer: We are to worship the Father, in Christ the Son, by the Spirit; and thus, when we pray, we are to ask the Father, in the name of the Son, by the Holy Ghost, Eph. 2:18 and 5:20.

SubQuestions.Question: Will not this mystery be more fully known and displayed in heaven?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; for, says Christ, "at that day ye shall know, that I am in my Father," John 14:20; See also 1 Cor. 13:12; 1 John 3:2.

SubQuestions.Question: What comfortable instruction may we learn from this doctrine of the Trinity?
SubQuestions.Answer: That the gift of eternal life, in the promise and offer of the gospel, to sinners of mankind, is attested by the three famous witnesses in heaven, who are above all exception, 1 John 5:7, 11; and consequently, that a portion infinitely rich, is insured by the covenant of grace to all those who believe, when it makes over all the three persons to them, as their God, Jer. 31:33.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the duty of the judicatures of the church with reference to Arians, Socinians, and Deists, who deny this fundamental doctrine of the Trinity?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is their duty after the first and second admonition, to reject them as heretics, Titus 3:10.

Data.Question: What are the decrees of God?
Data.Answer: The decrees of God are his eternal purpose, according to the counsel of his will, whereby, for his own glory, he hath foreordained whatsoever comes to pass.

SubQuestions.Question: What does the word counsel as ascribed to God import?
SubQuestions.Answer: Not the receiving the knowledge of things from another, or in the way of study and advisement, as among men; but the eternity, wisdom, and immutability of his determinations, Psalm 33:11; Proverbs 19:21.

SubQuestions.Question: Does the scripture speak expressly of God's decrees?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; in many places; such as, Psalm 2:7; Job. 28:26 and 38:10; Isaiah 10:22; Jer. 5:22, &c.

SubQuestions.Question: Are we by the decrees of God, to understand the things decreed, or the act decreeing?
SubQuestions.Answer: The act decreeing or discerning.

SubQuestions.Question: Is the decreeing act of God one simple act only?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; because of the perfect oneness or simplicity of his nature, on account of which he could not but decree all things at once; because all things are naked and opened unto his omniscient eye, Heb. 4:13; and because of his immutability, Mal. 3:6.

SubQuestions.Question: Why then do we speak of the divine decrees as various, or many?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because of the many objects which the decreeing act of God respects: the things decreed are many, but the act decreeing is but one only.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the properties of the divine decrees?
SubQuestions.Answer: That they are eternal, most wise, absolute, and unchangeable.

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove the decrees of God to be eternal?
SubQuestions.Answer: The decrees of election, and publishing the gospel, are eternal, as is evident from Eph. 1:4; and 1 Cor. 2:7; and therefore, all other decrees must be eternal likewise, because he decreed all things at once, by one simple act, Acts 15:18.

SubQuestions.Question: In what does the wisdom of God's decrees appear?
SubQuestions.Answer: In the beautiful order in which they are executed, Mark 7:37 - "He hath done all things well"

SubQuestions.Question: Why are the divine decrees said to be absolute?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because they depend upon no condition without God himself, but entirely and solely upon his own sovereign will and pleasure, Eph. 1:11.

SubQuestions.Question: Are there not certain means by which the decrees of God are executed?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; but these means are decreed as well as the end, 2 Thess. 2:13.

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear from scripture, that the means and the end are connected in the decree?
SubQuestions.Answer: Fro: the preservation of Paul, and those who were with him in the ship; God had decreed to preserve them all, Acts 27:24; yet lawful means were to be used; the shipmen must not get leave to flee out of the ship, otherwise the rest cannot be saved, as Paul tells the centurion and the soldiers, ver. 31.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the difference between the means of execution, and decreeing conditionally?
SubQuestions.Answer: The means of execution are stated in the decree; but to decree a thing conditionally, is to decree it upon an uncertain event, which may, or may never take place.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the absurdity of conditional decrees?
SubQuestions.Answer: They make the will of God, which is the first cause, to depend upon the will of the creature: and they plainly suppose, that either God is ignorant of the event, or incapable to accomplish it, or that he has determined nothing certainly about it; all which are blasphemously absurd.

SubQuestions.Question: Are all the decrees of God then unchangeable?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; "from all eternity he hath, for his own glory, unchangeably foreordained whatsoever comes to pass in time," Eph. 1:11.17

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove the decrees of God to be unchangeable?
SubQuestions.Answer: From scripture and from reason.

SubQuestions.Question: How is it proved from scripture?
SubQuestions.Answer: From Job 23:13 - "He is in one mind, and who can turn him?" Isaiah 46:10 - "My counsel shall stand, and I will do all my pleasure."

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove from reason, that the divine decrees are unchangeable?
SubQuestions.Answer: From this one argument - That there is in God no defect of wisdom, power, or faithfulness, from whence any change of his will may flow; as is the case among men, when they alter their resolutions.

SubQuestions.Question: Does the immutability of God's decree destroy the liberty of man's will, or the contingency of second causes?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; there is in it no "violence offered to the will of the creature, nor is the liberty or contingency of second causes taken away, but rather established," Matt. 17:12; Acts 2:23.18

SubQuestions.Question: Whence is it, that the absolute or unchangeable decree does not take away the liberty of the will?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because God, in the execution of his decree, does not change the nature of things, but suffers rational agents to act freely and voluntarily, as being under no more constraint or compulsion, than though there had been no such decree.

SubQuestions.Question: How is this made clear from scripture?
SubQuestions.Answer: By the instance of Pilate and the Jews, when they crucified the Lord of glory: what they did was with full freedom of their will, and yet they did nothing but what God's "hand and counsel determined before to be done," Acts 4:27, 28.

SubQuestions.Question: Does any thing come to pass in time, but what was decreed from eternity?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; for the very reason why any thing comes to pass in time, is because God decreed it, Eph. 1:11; Acts 15:18.

SubQuestions.Question: Are things that are casual or accidental, positively decreed?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; as is evident from the instances of Joseph's advancement in Egypt; and the not breaking a bone of Christ; and many others.

SubQuestions.Question: What has the decree of God fixed with respect to man's continuance in this world?
SubQuestions.Answer: It has immovably fixed the precise moment of every one's life and death, with every particular circumstance thereof.

SubQuestions.Question: How may it be proved that the precise moment of every one's death is unalterably fixed in the decree?
SubQuestions.Answer: From express scripture testimony, Job 14:5; Psalm 39:4; from the reason given why the Jews could not lay hands on Christ; namely, "because his hour was not yet come," John 7:30; and from God's numbering the hairs of our head, Matt. 10:30; much more the days and moments of our life.

SubQuestions.Question: Were there not fifteen years added to Hezekiah's days, after the prophet said to him, "Set thine house in order; for thou shalt die, and not live," Isaiah 38:1, 5?
SubQuestions.Answer: The sentence of death, by the prophet, was not an intimation of the decree of God, that Hezekiah was presently to die; but of the nature of his disease, which, according to the ordinary course of second causes, was mortal, if the power of God had not miraculously interposed.

SubQuestions.Question: How does the decree of God extend to things naturally and morally good?
SubQuestions.Answer: Effectively: because God is the author and efficient cause of all good, Phil. 2:13.

SubQuestions.Question: How does it extend to things morally evil?
SubQuestions.Answer: Permissively and directively only, Acts 14:16.

SubQuestions.Question: Is the permissive decree a bare inactive permitting of evil?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; it determines the event of the evil permitted, and overrules it to a good end, contrary to the intention both of the work and worker.

SubQuestions.Question: What scripture example is there of this?
SubQuestions.Answer: God permits Joseph's brethren to sell him into Egypt, and Potiphar to throw him unjustly into prison, and yet overrules both these evils, and makes them means, contrary to the intention both of the work and workers, for executing the decree of his advancement to the greatest honour, Gen. 45:5-8; and 50:20 - "Ye thought evil against me, (says Joseph to his brethren,) but God meant it unto good."

SubQuestions.Question: How can the decree of God be permissive and efficacious at the same time?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is permissive, with respect to the sinfulness of the action as a moral evil; and efficacious, with respect to the matter of it as a natural act.

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove that God cannot be the author of sin?
SubQuestions.Answer: From the contrariety of it to his holy nature and law, and the indication he has manifested against it, in what Christ suffered on account of it; for he can never be the author of that of which he is the avenger.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the great end of all God's decrees?
SubQuestions.Answer: His own glory, Proverbs 16:4 - "The Lord hath made all things for himself;" and particularly the glory of his mercy and justice, Rom. 9:22, 23, and, next to his own glory, the good of the elect, both here and hereafter, Rom. 8:28.

SubQuestions.Question: Who are the special objects of God's decrees?
SubQuestions.Answer: Angels and men.

SubQuestions.Question: What is God's decree concerning angels and men, commonly called?
SubQuestions.Answer: His predestinating of them.

SubQuestions.Question: What is meant by predestination?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is God's unchangeable purpose or decree, concerning the last end, and eternal state, of angels and men, 1 Tim. 5:21; Jude ver. 6; Ex. 33:19; Rom. 9:11, 13, 18.

SubQuestions.Question: Is the precise number of angels and men, thus predestinated, particularly and unchangeably defined?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; "their number is so certain and definite, that it cannot be either increased or diminished," 2 Tim. 2:19; John 13:18.19

SubQuestions.Question: How is the decree of predestination usually divided?
SubQuestions.Answer: Into the decree of election and reprobation.

SubQuestions.Question: What is God's decree of election, as it respects men?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is his choosing a certain number of mankind, in Christ, to eternal life, and the means of it, to the praise of his glorious grace, Eph. 1:4; 2 Thess. 2:13, 14.

SubQuestions.Question: Was it the foresight of faith, or good works, or perseverance in either of them, or any other thing whatsoever in the creature, that moved God to make choice of some men, and not of others?
SubQuestions.Answer: By no means; but his mere free grace and love Eph. 1:6, 12.

SubQuestions.Question: What is God's decree of reprobation, as it respects men?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is his passing by, and ordaining all the rest of mankind whom he has not chosen, to dishonour and wrath, to be for their sins inflicted, to the praise of the glory of his justice, Rom. 9:17, 18, 22; 1 Pet. 2:8; Jude verse 4.

SubQuestions.Question: Since God has appointed the elect to glory, has he not also foreordained all the means?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; for "they who are elected, being fallen in Adam, are redeemed by Christ," 1 Thess. 5:9, 10;20 and free grace reigns, through his righteousness, to their eternal life, Rom. 5:21.

SubQuestions.Question: Do the decrees of election and reprobation import any partiality, or, injustice in God?
SubQuestions.Answer: No more than a potter is esteemed partial, or unjust, in making, out of the same lump, one vessel to honour, and another to dishonour, Rom. 9:20, 21.

SubQuestions.Question: Is sin in the reprobate the cause of their damnation, or of their reprobation?
SubQuestions.Answer: Their sin is indeed the cause of their damnation, Rom. 6:23 - "The wages of sin is death;" but the sovereign will and pleasure of God is the cause of their reprobation, Matt. 11:25, 26; Rom. 9:18.

SubQuestions.Question: Are the secret decrees of God, concerning the eternal state of men, the rule of faith and practice?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; but the revealed will of God only, Deut. 29:29.

SubQuestions.Question: Does not this doctrine of particular election and reprobation limit the general call of the gospel?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; for Christ commissions to go "into all the world, and preach the gospel to every creature," Mark 16:15; not as they are elect or reprobate, but as they are lost sinners of Adam's family, Matt. 9:13; therefore, all that hear the gospel have an equal warrant to believe, 1 John 3:23.

SubQuestions.Question: Has it a tendency to make men careless in the use of the means of salvation?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; because God has chosen us to salvation, "through sanctification of the Spirit, and belief of the truth," 2 Thess. 2:13.

SubQuestions.Question: Ought we then to improve the means of salvation, without regard to the decree?
SubQuestions.Answer: We ought no more to regard the decree in the matter of believing to the salvation of our souls, than in eating, drinking, buying, selling, or any other common action of life; because "the secret things belong unto the Lord our God, but those things which are revealed, belong unto us, and to our children for ever," Deut. 29:29.

SubQuestions.Question: What improvement ought we to make of the doctrine of absolute election?
SubQuestions.Answer: We ought to be encouraged to believe in Christ: considering that electing love pitches on the chief of sinners, Ezek. 16:6; that it flows not from, nor is rounded upon, any condition to be performed by men, Rom. 9:11; and that it contains in it all things pertaining to life and godliness, 2 Pet. 1:3.

Data.Question: How does God execute his decrees?
Data.Answer: God executes his decrees, in the works of creation and providence.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it for God to execute his decrees?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to bring them to pass; or, give an actual being in time, to what he purposed from eternity, Isaiah 46:10.

SubQuestions.Question: Does not God leave the execution of his decrees to second causes?
SubQuestions.Answer: Whatever use God may make of second causes, in the execution of his decrees, yet they are merely tools in his over-ruling hand, to bring about his glorious designs; they are his servants, and must do all his pleasure, Acts 4:27, 28.

SubQuestions.Question: What difference is there between the decree and the execution of it?
SubQuestions.Answer: The decree is an immanent or inherent act in God, and is nothing else but God decreeing; but the execution is a transient or passing act of his infinite power, bringing the thing decreed into actual existence, 2 Pet. 1:3.

SubQuestions.Question: Is there an exact harmony, or correspondence, between God's decree and the execution of it?
SubQuestions.Answer: When the thing decreed is brought actually into being, it exactly corresponds to the idea or platform of it in the infinite mind of God, Psalm 139:16; as the tabernacle of Moses answered the pattern given of it in the Mount, Ex. 25:40.

SubQuestions.Question: Can none of the decrees of God be defeated, or fail of execution?
SubQuestions.Answer: By no means; the counsel of the Lord shall stand, and he will do all his pleasure, Isaiah 46:10. "Who hath resisted his will?" Rom. 9:19. "None can stay his hand, or say unto him, What dost thou?" Dan. 4:35.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the works of God, in which his decrees are executed?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are the works of creation and providence.

SubQuestions.Question: To which of these works of God does redemption belong?
SubQuestions.Answer: To the providence of God, as the most glorious part of it towards men.

SubQuestions.Question: What then is the first external work of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is creation: which is therefore called, "The beginning of his ways," Proverbs 8:22.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the difference between God's executing the work of creation, and that of providence?
SubQuestions.Answer: He executed the work of creation entirely without means, by the word of his power; but he executes the work of providence, ordinarily, in the use of them.

SubQuestions.Question: What may we learn from God's executing his decrees?
SubQuestions.Answer: That all his promises shall be punctually accomplished, and not one of them fall to the ground, Mark 13:31.

Data.Question: What is the work of creation?
Data.Answer: The work of creation is, God's making all things of nothing, by the word of his power, in the space of six days, and all very good.

SubQuestions.Question: How do you know that the world had a beginning?
SubQuestions.Answer: The light of nature teaches, that there must be a first cause; besides, "through faith we understand that the worlds were framed by the word of God," Heb. 11:3.

SubQuestions.Question: Might not this world have existed from eternity?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; it is impossible: this supposition is not only contrary to scripture, but to common sense and reason, which tells us, that what is created; and has a duration by succession of time, must have had a beginning.

SubQuestions.Question: From whom did this world receive its being and beginning?
SubQuestions.Answer: From God only, who is being itself, and gives being to all things, Neh. 9:6.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it for God to create?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is his making all things of nothing.

SubQuestions.Question: When did God create this world?
SubQuestions.Answer: In the beginning of time, Gen. 1:1.

SubQuestions.Question: Was there any pre-existent matter out of which God created the world?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; for, by his powerful word, he called "those things which be not, as though they were," Rom. 4:17; "so that things which are seen, were not made of things which do appear," that is, of any pre-existent matter, Heb. 11:3.

SubQuestions.Question: In what time did God create all things?
SubQuestions.Answer: In the space of six days, Ex. 20:11.

SubQuestions.Question: Could he not have created all things in a moment of time?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; but he saw it more for his own glory, and the good of mankind, to set them an example of working six days, and resting the seventh.

SubQuestions.Question: On which of the six days, is it reckoned, that the angels were created?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is probable they were created upon the first day, as would seem from Job 38:4, 7 - "Where wast thou when I laid the foundations of the earth, - when the morning stars sang together, and all the sons of God shouted for joy?"

SubQuestions.Question: Can creating power be imparted to any creature?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; it implies a contradiction for a creature to create, because this would vest a finite creature with infinite power, Isaiah 14:12.

SubQuestions.Question: Is it not then a clear proof of the supreme Deity of the Son of God, that all things were made by him?
SubQuestions.Answer: No doubt it is: for, none but he, who is truly and properly God, can command things that are not into being, Isaiah 44:24.

SubQuestions.Question: Is creation a work common to all the persons of the Trinity?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; for all the external works of God are common to each person; every one of the three adorable persons being the same in substance, equal in power and glory, 1 John 5:7 - "These three are one."

SubQuestions.Question: For what end did God make all things?
SubQuestions.Answer: He made all things for himself, or for the display of his matchless excellencies, Proverbs 16:4.

SubQuestions.Question: What are those excellencies or perfections of God which are more especially displayed in the work of creation?
SubQuestions.Answer: His infinite power, extensive goodness, and manifold wisdom, Rom. 1:20.

SubQuestions.Question: How does the infinite power of God shine forth in creating the world?
SubQuestions.Answer: In bringing all things, of a sudden, out of nothing, by his bare word, Psalm 33:6.

SubQuestions.Question: What was that bare word?
SubQuestions.Answer: Let such a thing be, Gen. 1:3.

SubQuestions.Question: How is his manifold wisdom displayed in this work?
SubQuestions.Answer: In the vast variety of creatures, great and small, which he has made; the order and harmony of them all; and their subserviency one to another, Psalm 104:24.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is it said that he made all things very good?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because God, upon a survey of his works, declared them to be so, Gen. 1:31 - "God saw all that he had made, and behold, it was very good."

SubQuestions.Question: In what consists the goodness of the creatures of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: In the perfection of their nature, their being fit to answer the end of their creation; and their usefulness to man, being both profitable and pleasant to him.

SubQuestions.Question: Are not many creatures hurtful to man?
SubQuestions.Answer: They were not so at their first creation, and while man continued in his allegiance to God: but through his sinning against God he has brought a curse on himself, and the whole creation, Gen. 3:17 - "Cursed is the ground for thy sake."

SubQuestions.Question: Is not God said to create evil, Isaiah 45:7?
SubQuestions.Answer: Not the evil of sin; but of punishment, as a just judge, Rom. 3:5, 6; Amos 3:6.

SubQuestions.Question: How then came sin and death into the world?
SubQuestions.Answer: Man is the parent of sin, and sin opened the door to death: "By one man sin entered into the world, and death by sin," Rom. 5:12.

SubQuestions.Question: Upon what day did God rest from creating the world?
SubQuestions.Answer: Upon the seventh day, Gen. 2:2, 3; which was therefore appointed to be the weekly Sabbath, till the resurrection of Christ.

SubQuestions.Question: Does this resting, on the seventh day, say that he was weary with working?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; "The everlasting God, the Creator of the ends of the earth, fainteth not, neither is weary," Isaiah 40:28.

SubQuestions.Question: What then is meant by his resting?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is spoken after the manner of men; and the meaning is, that God ceased to create any other sorts of creatures than he had already made.

SubQuestions.Question: Is not the same power that created all things, exerted in sustaining them in their being?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; for he, by whom the worlds were made, is said to uphold all things by the word of his power, Heb. 1:2, 3.

SubQuestions.Question: Do not the scriptures speak of a new creation, as well as of the old?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; the Spirit of God, in scripture, speaks of a new world of grace, under the name of "new heavens" and a "new earth," Isaiah 66:22; Rev. 21:1.

SubQuestions.Question: What is to be understood by this new creation, or new world of grace?
SubQuestions.Answer: The true church of Christ, particularly under the New Testament, not excluding the church triumphant in heaven.

SubQuestions.Question: By whom is this new world created?
SubQuestions.Answer: By the same God that made the old world; "Behold, I create new heavens, and a new earth," Isaiah 65:17.

SubQuestions.Question: Who are the inhabitants of this new world?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are all new creatures, taken out of the old world, 2 Cor. 5:17.

SubQuestions.Question: How came they out of this material, into that spiritual world?
SubQuestions.Answer: By the new birth; for, except a man be born again, he cannot enter into it, John 3; flesh and blood, or corrupted nature, continuing such, cannot inherit it, 1 Cor. 15:50.

SubQuestions.Question: Is there any difference of nations, sexes, or persons, in this new world?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; for "there is neither Greek nor Jew, circumcision, nor uncircumcision, Barbarian, Scythian, bond nor free; but Christ is all, and in all," Col. 3:11.

SubQuestions.Question: By what door do men enter into this new world of grace?
SubQuestions.Answer: Christ says, "I am the door; by me if any man enter in, he shall be saved, and shall go in and out, and find pasture," John 10:9, and chap. 14:6 - "I am the way - no man cometh unto the Father, but by me."

SubQuestions.Question: In what lies the happiness of the inhabitants of this new world of grace?
SubQuestions.Answer: None so happy as they, because they dwell in God, and God dwells in them as in a temple, 1 Cor. 3:16; and walks in them as in his garden of pleasure, 2 Cor. 6:16; and, at death, they are transported by the ministry of angels, to the world of glory above, Luke 16:22.

SubQuestions.Question: What may we learn from the doctrine of the creation?
SubQuestions.Answer: That we ought to contemplate God in all his creatures, Psalm 104; acknowledge him as the rightful proprietor and sovereign disposer of them all, 1 Chron. 29:11; and believe that the same almighty power of God, which was put forth in creating of all things, shall be exerted in defence and support of his church and people, in the time of their need, Psalm 121:2.

Data.Question: How did God create man?
Data.Answer: God created man, male and female, after his own image, in knowledge, righteousness, and holiness, with dominion over the creatures.

SubQuestions.Question: Upon which day of creation was man made?
SubQuestions.Answer: Upon the sixth day, Gen. 1:26, and 31, compared.

SubQuestions.Question: Why was the creation of man delayed, or put off, to the sixth day?
SubQuestions.Answer: To discover the great regard God had to man's happiness and welfare, in that he would first furnish the great house of the creation for him, before he brought him into it, Psalm 8:6-8.

SubQuestions.Question: Was there any more solemnity observed in the creation of man, than in making the rest of the creatures?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; for as to the rest of the creatures, he just commanded them into being; but when man is to be created, a council of the Trinity is held about his formation. Gen. 1:26 - "Let us make man."

SubQuestions.Question: Why so much solemnity about man's formation beyond other creatures?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because man was to be God's viceroy in this lower world, the only image of his Creator, in his formal perfections; and it was the purpose of God, though not then revealed, that the second person of the Godhead was to become man.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it that constitutes the human nature, or nature of man?
SubQuestions.Answer: A true body and a reasonable soul united together.

SubQuestions.Question: Of what was the body of man formed?
SubQuestions.Answer: "Of the dust of the ground," Gen. 2:7; hence God is resembled to a potter, and man to the clay, and a potsherd, Isaiah 64:8, and 45:9.

SubQuestions.Question: What should this teach us?
SubQuestions.Answer: To remember we are dust, Eccl. 3:20; to admire the condescension of the son of God in coming into our tribe, and assuming a human body, 1 Tim. 3:16; to consider that we are in God's hand, as the clay is in the hand of the potter, Jer. 18:6; and that, in this our fallen state, we are to return to the dust again, Gen. 3:19.

SubQuestions.Question: How was the first woman formed?
SubQuestions.Answer: Of a rib taken from the man's side, Gen. 2:21, 22.

SubQuestions.Question: Of what was this a figure?
SubQuestions.Answer: Of Christ and the church, Eph. 5:31, 32.

SubQuestions.Question: In what respect was the formation of the woman a figure of these?
SubQuestions.Answer: In as much as the church was, as it were, taken out of the pierced side of Christ, when the Lord God caused the deep sleep of death to fall upon him; first, typically, in the sacrifice; and then actually, in his decease which he accomplished at Jerusalem.

SubQuestions.Question: Why was marriage instituted of God before the fall?
SubQuestions.Answer: To show that it belongs to the law of nature; and that mankind, as such, have a title to it. Heb. 13:4 - "Marriage is honourable in all."

SubQuestions.Question: What is the other part of man's nature?
SubQuestions.Answer: A reasonable soul.

SubQuestions.Question: How was the soul of man made?
SubQuestions.Answer: God "breathed into his nostrils the breath of life, and he became a living soul," Gen. 2:7.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is the creation of the soul of man thus expressed?
SubQuestions.Answer: To show, that as the Lord is "the God of the spirits of all flesh," Num. 27:16; who creates them immediately, and by himself, without the intervention of second causes, Zech. 12:1; so he has an absolute dominion over them, and can call them back to himself when he pleases, Eccl. 12:7.

SubQuestions.Question: In what does the soul of man differ from the body?
SubQuestions.Answer: The body is a corporeal, but the soul is a spiritual and immaterial substance.

SubQuestions.Question: In what does the soul of man differ from the spirit or life of a beast?
SubQuestions.Answer: The spirit or life of a beast goes downward to the earth, and perishes at its death, Eccl. 3:21; but the soul of man, being rational and immortal, "returns to God who gave it," Eccl. 12:7.

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove the immortality of the soul of man?
SubQuestions.Answer: (1.) From the great price paid for the redemption of the soul, which had ceased for ever, without a ransom of infinite value, Psalm 49:8. (2.) From the promises of eternal life, and the threatenings of eternal death, Mark 16:16. (3.) Christ tells us, that they who kill the body cannot kill the soul, Matt. 10:28. (4.) Christ, and his dying saints, commit their spirits, or souls, into the hand of God, Psalm 31:5; Luke 23:46; Acts 7:59; and the soul of the thief went to paradise, with the soul of Christ, that day they died, Luke 23:43. In a word, if the soul perishes with the body, the saints of God would be of all men the most miserable, 1 Cor. 15:19.

SubQuestions.Question: What should this teach us?
SubQuestions.Answer: To be more concerned for the salvation of our souls than for all things in the world: "For," says Christ, "what is a man profited, if he gain the whole world, and lose his own soul?" Matt. 16:26.

SubQuestions.Question: Why did God create man male and female?
SubQuestions.Answer: For the propagation of mankind, Gen. 1:28; and mutual helpfulness to each other, chap. 2:18.

SubQuestions.Question: Why were both the man and the woman called Adam, Gen. 5:2?
SubQuestions.Answer: To intimate that their original was of the earth; that they were both of the same nature; that the promises and threatenings concerned them both equally, Rom. 5:12; and to teach us, that notwithstanding this, the man was the representing head of the covenant, 1 Cor. 15:22.

SubQuestions.Question: After whose image did God create man?
SubQuestions.Answer: After his own image, Gen. 1:26, 27.

SubQuestions.Question: Did this image of God lie in any outward shape of man's body?
SubQuestions.Answer: By no means: for God is a pure Spirit, without bodily parts, John 4:24.

SubQuestions.Question: What then was the proper seat of it?
SubQuestions.Answer: The soul of man was the painting table, on which this image of God was expressed and delineated, Gen. 2:7; James 3:9.

SubQuestions.Question: In what did the soul of man bear a likeness to God?
SubQuestions.Answer: In its spiritual and immortal nature; and in the faculties of the understanding and the will, with which it was endued.

SubQuestions.Question: In what did the image of God, which was drawn on man's soul, chiefly consist?
SubQuestions.Answer: In knowledge, righteousness, and holiness, Col. 3:10; Eph. 4:24.

SubQuestions.Question: What knowledge was man endued with at his creation?
SubQuestions.Answer: A perfect knowledge of God, of his will, and works, so far as was necessary to render him happy, and fit for universal obedience.

SubQuestions.Question: What righteousness had man at his creation?
SubQuestions.Answer: Not an imputed, but an inherent righteousness; which consisted in a perfect conformity of all the powers and faculties of his soul, to the pure nature of God, and the moral law written upon his heart, Eccl. 7:29.

SubQuestions.Question: In what consisted his holiness?
SubQuestions.Answer: In the lustre and beauty of his perfect knowledge and inherent righteousness, shining both in his heart and life.

SubQuestions.Question: Was the will of man, in a state of innocence, absolutely indifferent to good and evil?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; God set man's will only towards good; yet it was movable to evil, and that only by man himself; to whom God gave a sufficient power to stand in his integrity, if he had pleased, Eccl. 7:29.

SubQuestions.Question: What was the necessary consequence of this image of God drawn upon our first parents?
SubQuestions.Answer: The immortality of the whole man, and dominion over the creatures.

SubQuestions.Question: Would they have been immortal if they had not sinned?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; for it was only in case of sin that death was threatened, Gen. 2:17.

SubQuestions.Question: How could their bodies have been immortal, when made of the dust?
SubQuestions.Answer: The perfect purity or holiness of their souls, would have preserved their bodies from sickness, death, and corruption, Rom. 5:12 and 6:23.

SubQuestions.Question: In what did man's dominion over the creatures consist?
SubQuestions.Answer: In his princely power over the inferior creatures, by which he could rule and use them as be pleased, for God's glory and his own good, without any injustice, Gen. 1:28, and 2:19, 20.

SubQuestions.Question: Where did God put the man when he had formed him after his own image?
SubQuestions.Answer: In the garden of Eden; a place eminent for pleasantness, wherein nothing was wanting, either for necessity or delight, Gen. 2:8, 9.

SubQuestions.Question: What may we learn from the holy and happy state in which man was created?
SubQuestions.Answer: The unspeakable difference between man's former and present condition: formerly, in a state of innocence, man's understanding was a lamp of light, his will lay straight with the will of God, and his affections were pure and holy, free from all disorder and distemper; but now, the very reverse: so that we may say, "How is the gold become dim! how is the most fine gold changed!" Lam. 4:1. "The crown is fallen from our head! wo unto us that we have sinned!" chap. 5:16.

Data.Question: What are God's works of providence?
Data.Answer: God's works of providence are, his most holy, wise, and powerful preserving and governing all his creatures, and all their actions.

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear that there is a providence?
SubQuestions.Answer: From scripture, and by reason.

SubQuestions.Question: How does the scripture evidence that there is a providence?
SubQuestions.Answer: It tells us, that the Lord preserves man and beast, Psalm 36:6; that he gives "rain from heaven, and fruitful seasons, filling our hearts with food and gladness," Acts 14:17; that "he giveth to all, life, and breath, and all things," Acts 17:25.

SubQuestions.Question: How may providence be proved by reason?
SubQuestions.Answer: The admirable order and harmony among such a vast variety of creatures in the world, continuing for so many ages, notwithstanding of their different and opposite natures; the accomplishment of future events, exactly according to the predictions of them long before; the revolutions of kingdoms; the orderly returns of seed-time and harvest; and the preservation of a church on earth, against the fury of hell and wicked men: all these plainly evince, to the rational world, that there is a providence.

SubQuestions.Question: Can providence be denied without denying the being of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; for the same arguments that prove the one, prove the other: to deny that God governs the world, is to deny that God exists, Isaiah 41:23.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the object of God's providence, or to what does it extend?
SubQuestions.Answer: To all his creatures, and all their actions.

SubQuestions.Question: What is God's providence towards the angels?
SubQuestions.Answer: He permitted some of them to fall wilfully and irrecoverably into sin and damnation, Jude verse 6; and established the rest in holiness and happiness, 1 Tim. 5:21.

SubQuestions.Question: Are the smallest and meanest of the creatures the objects of God's providence, as well as the greatest and most considerable?
SubQuestions.Answer: God's providence disdains not the meanest worm, more than the mightiest prince: he counts the hairs of our head, Matt. 10:30, as well as the number of the stars, Psalm 147:4.

SubQuestions.Question: Does it reflect any dishonour upon the providence of God to take care of the meanest creatures?
SubQuestions.Answer: It can reflect no dishonour upon divine providence, to preserve what infinite wisdom saw meet to create, be it ever so mean in our view, Neh. 9:6.

SubQuestions.Question: Does providence extend to all the actions of the creatures, as well as to the creatures themselves?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; otherwise the creatures would be independent in their actions; and God would not be in all things the first cause, Gen. 45:7.

SubQuestions.Question: Are casual or contingent actions subject to divine providence?
SubQuestions.Answer: What is casual to us, is ordained by God: nothing can be more casual than a lot, yet "the whole disposing thereof is of the Lord," Proverbs 16:33.

SubQuestions.Question: Are voluntary or free actions subject to it likewise?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; for, though "there are many devices in a man's heart, nevertheless the counsel of the Lord, that shall stand," Proverbs 19:21.

SubQuestions.Question: How is the providence of God conversant about good actions?
SubQuestions.Answer: Not by compelling, but sweetly inclining and determining the will, both to the action and the right manner of performing it. Phil. 2:13 - "It is God who worketh in you, both to will and to do, of his good pleasure."

SubQuestions.Question: How is it conversant about sinful actions?
SubQuestions.Answer: In permitting them to be done, Acts 14:16; and in limiting and directing them to good and holy ends, contrary both to the nature of sin, and the intention of the sinner, 2 Kings 19:28.

SubQuestions.Question: What scripture instance may be given, of God's over-ruling the sinful actions of men to holy ends?
SubQuestions.Answer: The worst action that ever was committed, the crucifying the Lord of glory, was ordered and directed by God, for bringing about the greatest mercy, the redemption of a lost world, Acts 2:23, and 4:28.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the works of providence about the creatures and their actions?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are two; God's preserving them, and his governing them.

SubQuestions.Question: What is God's preserving work of providence?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is his upholding all the creatures in their being and operation, by the same power by which he made them at first, Heb. 1:3 - "Upholding all things, by the word of his power."

SubQuestions.Question: What would be the consequence of God's withholding from the creatures his preserving providence?
SubQuestions.Answer: They would presently sink into their original nothing, Psalm 104:29 - "Thou hidest thy face, they are troubled: thou takest away their breath, they die, and return to their dust."

SubQuestions.Question: What is God's governing work of providence?
SubQuestions.Answer: His:directing and leading all his creatures to the proper ends, which he has prescribed and appointed, Proverbs 16:9 - "A man's heart deviseth his way, but the Lord directeth his steps."

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove that God governs as well as preserves his creatures?
SubQuestions.Answer: From their dependence upon him for operation, as well as for being; for in him they live and move, as well as have their being, Acts 17:28; and it is expressly said, that "God ruleth by his power for ever," Psalm 66:7.

SubQuestions.Question: Does God's governing providence include in it his immediate concurrence with every action of the creature?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; God not only efficaciously concurs in producing the action, as to the matter of it; but likewise predetermines the creature to such or such an action, and not to another, Isaiah 10:6, 7; shutting up all other ways of acting, and leaving that only open, which he had determined to be done, Ezek. 21:21, 22.

SubQuestions.Question: How can God concur with the sinful actions of men, without sin, of which he cannot be the author?
SubQuestions.Answer: Although God not only preserves and supports the faculties with which a man sins, but likewise previously, immediately, and efficaciously concurs to the substance, matter, or entity of the action, yet he by no means concurs to the sinfulness or wickedness of the act, Isaiah 10:6, 7.

SubQuestions.Question: In what does the sinfulness of an action properly consist?
SubQuestions.Answer: Not in the matter of the action, but in the form of it; that is, not in the action itself, considered as an act, but in the deficiency or swerving of that act from the rule of the law, 1 John 3:4 - "Sin is the transgression of the law."

SubQuestions.Question: How may the difference between the matter and form of an action be illustrated by an example?
SubQuestions.Answer: In the stoning of Achan and Naboth; the matter of the action was the same, namely, the throwing of stones; but the form of the action, in point of conformity or disconformity to the law, was vastly different: the stoning of Achan, condemned by God, and all Israel, was an act of just punishment, agreeable to the law; but the stoning of Naboth, an innocent man, was an act of unjust murder, quite contrary to the law, Ex. 20:13.

SubQuestions.Question: From whence then does the sinfulness or viciousness of actions proceed?
SubQuestions.Answer: Although the power of acting be from God, yet the viciousness or malignity of the action is entirely from the inherent corruption of our own nature, James 1:13, 14.

SubQuestions.Question: Does not God present the object which is the occasion of sinning?
SubQuestions.Answer: Sin does not arise from the object which God, in his providence, presents to us, but from our own inward depravity, called, "the corruption that is in the world through lust," 2 Pet. 1:4. God delivered Christ to the Jews; he presented him to them; but neither infused that malice in them, by which they crucified him, nor did excite it, but it was entirely of themselves, Acts 2:23.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the properties of God's providence?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is most holy, wise, and powerful.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is the providence of God called most holy?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because of the infinite holiness and purity that shines in all his administrations, Psalm 145:17.

SubQuestions.Question: In what does the holiness of God's providence appear?
SubQuestions.Answer: In bringing glory to his mercy and justice out of sin.

SubQuestions.Question: How does he bring glory to his mercy out of sin?
SubQuestions.Answer: In making the worst of sinners become the choicest of saints, as in the instance of Paul, 1 Tim. 1:12, 13, and others.

SubQuestions.Question: How does he bring glory to his justice out of sin?
SubQuestions.Answer: By the judgments which he executes upon sinners, even in this life, Psalm 9:16.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is the providence of God said to be wise?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because it makes all things subservient to the end which God had fixed for himself, Rom. 8:28.

SubQuestions.Question: How is the wisdom of providence manifested?
SubQuestions.Answer: In the exact harmony of all the motions thereof with the word, Hos. 14:9.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is God's providence called powerful?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because it cannot be resisted, Dan. 4:35 - "He doth according to his will, in the army of heaven, and among the inhabitants of the earth: none can stay his hand, or say unto him, what dost thou?"

SubQuestions.Question: How does the power of providence discover itself?
SubQuestions.Answer: In bringing about great events, by small and apparently contemptible means: thus, he makes worm Jacob to thresh the mountains, Isaiah 41:15; and by the foolishness of preaching saves them that believe, 1 Cor. 1:21.

SubQuestions.Question: How is the providence of God usually distinguished?
SubQuestions.Answer: Into ordinary and extraordinary, common and special.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the ordinary providence of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is his observing the order of things, which he appointed from the beginning, Hos. 2:21, 22.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the extraordinary providence of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is his going beyond, or contrary to the natural order of things; and such events are called miraculous.

SubQuestions.Question: What is a miracle?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is such an astonishing and surprising effect, contrary to the ordinary course of nature, as surpasses the power of all created beings, and can be produced by divine omnipotence only; such as, dividing the waters of the Red Sea and Jordan, making the sun to stand still, raising the dead, giving eye-sight to the born blind, curing all manner of diseases by a word, and the like.

SubQuestions.Question: What is common providence?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is that which is exercised about all the creatures in general, Acts 17:28, called God's natural government.

SubQuestions.Question: What is special providence?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is that which is exercised about rational creatures in particular, Deut. 30:1518, called his moral government.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the special providence which God exercises about his church and people?
SubQuestions.Answer: His "eyes run to and fro throughout the whole earth, to show himself strong in behalf of them whose heart is perfect towards him," 2 Chron. 16:9; and he makes all things work together for their good, Rom. 8:28.

SubQuestions.Question: Are not all the dispensations of providence, prosperous or adverse, to be carefully observed?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; for "whoso is wise, and will observe these things, even they shall understand the loving-kindness of the Lord," Psalm 107:43.

SubQuestions.Question: How are the providences of God to be observed?
SubQuestions.Answer: With humility and reverence, under a sense of our weakness to penetrate into them, Rom. 11:34; and with gratitude and thankfulness, because there is always some mixture of mercy with judgment in this life, Psalm 101:1.

SubQuestions.Question: Is it not dangerous to overlook the operations of divine providence?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; for it is said, Psalm 28:5 - "Because they regard not the works of the Lord, nor the operation of his hands, he shall destroy them, and not build them up."

SubQuestions.Question: Are not some dispensations of providence very dark and mysterious?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; his ways are many times in the sea, and his paths in the great waters, and his footsteps are not known, Psalm 77:19.

SubQuestions.Question: In what does the mystery of providence appear?
SubQuestions.Answer: In the mysterious tract, and mysterious outward appearance of it.

SubQuestions.Question: How is providence mysterious in the tract of it?
SubQuestions.Answer: In attaining its end by seemingly contrary means; such as making Joseph's imprisonment the step to his being second in the kingdom, and the casting of Daniel into the lions' den, the path to his higher preferment.

SubQuestions.Question: In what is providence mysterious in the outward appearance of it?
SubQuestions.Answer: In that "all things come alike unto all;" there being one event to the righteous and to the wicked: and no man knowing love or hatred, by all that is before him in this life, Eccl. 9:1, 2.

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove that love or hatred cannot be known by the outward dispensations of providence in this life?
SubQuestions.Answer: From the parable of the rich man and Lazarus; the rich man, in his lifetime, received good things, and Lazarus evil things; and yet, after death, Lazarus is comforted, and the other tormented, Luke 16:19-28.

SubQuestions.Question: Is this seemingly unequal appearance of providence in this life, any reflection upon the wisdom and righteousness of it?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; for, though good men may be sometimes put to a stand by the outward prosperity of the wicked, and the straits and wants of the godly, as Jeremiah was, chap. 12:1 - "wherefore doth the way of the wicked prosper? wherefore are all they happy that deal very treacherously?" yet, if the enjoyments of the one, and wants of the other, are laid in the balance, it would be found, that a "little that the righteous man hath, is better than the riches of many wicked," Psalm 37:16.

SubQuestions.Question: What is our duty when providence seems to run contrary to the promise?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to believe the promise, and that providence is running in a direct line to the accomplishment of it, though we cannot see it at the time, as Abraham did, "who against hope believed in hope, and staggered not at the promise of God through unbelief," Rom. 4:18, 20.

SubQuestions.Question: Will not dark providences be opened to the saints some time or other?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; for, says Christ, "What I do thou knowest not now, but thou shalt know hereafter," John 13:7.

SubQuestions.Question: When will the mystery of providence be opened to the saints?
SubQuestions.Answer: It shall be fully unveiled at the end of the day, when the mystery of it shall be finished, and all the labyrinths, in which the saints were led, fully unwinded, Rev. 10:6, 7.

SubQuestions.Question: What will be the language of the saints, when the whole mystery of providence shall be explained?
SubQuestions.Answer: They will say, "He hath done all things well," Mark 7:37 - "Not one thing hath failed of all the good things which the Lord spake; - all are come to pass, - not one thing hath failed thereof," Josh. 23:14.

SubQuestions.Question: What improvement ought we to make of this doctrine of providence?
SubQuestions.Answer: To commit our way to the Lord; to "trust also in him, and he shall bring it to pass," Psalm 37:5.

Data.Question: What special act of providence did God exercise towards man, in the estate wherein he was created?
Data.Answer: When God had created man, he entered into a covenant of life with him, upon condition of perfect obedience; forbidding him to eat of the tree of knowledge of good and evil, upon the pain of death.

SubQuestions.Question: Was there any thing special in God's government of man, when he was created, above the other creatures?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; for God gave man a moral law, which the other creatures, not endued with reason, were not capable of: Job 35:10, 11 - "None saith, Where is God my maker? - Who teacheth us more than the beasts of the earth, and maketh us wiser than the fowls of heaven."

SubQuestions.Question: What call you a moral law?
SubQuestions.Answer: A moral law signifies a law of right manners, or good and suitable behaviour towards God and man, and adapted to man's rational nature, Rom 7:12.

SubQuestions.Question: How was this law first given to man?
SubQuestions.Answer: It was written upon the table of his heart, the moment that God created him in his own image, Gen. 1:27.

SubQuestions.Question: What do you understand by God's writing the law upon the table of his heart?
SubQuestions.Answer: God's inlaying a principle of obedience in his heart, disposing him to obey out of love to God, and a supreme regard to his authority, Eccl. 7:29.

SubQuestions.Question: What was the peculiar favour which God manifested to man in a state of innocence, besides writing the law upon his heart?
SubQuestions.Answer: The reducing that law to the form of a covenant, by which man became confederate with heaven.

SubQuestions.Question: What is a covenant?
SubQuestions.Answer: A mutual free compact and agreement between two parties, upon express terms or conditions.

SubQuestions.Question: How many covenants are there, relating to the life and happiness of man?
SubQuestions.Answer: Two: the covenant of works, and the covenant of grace, Gal. 4:24 - "These are the two covenants."

SubQuestions.Question: Which of these was the covenant which God entered into with man, when he was created?
SubQuestions.Answer: The covenant of works, or of life.

SubQuestions.Question: Why called a covenant of works?
SubQuestions.Answer: From the condition of it.

SubQuestions.Question: Why called a covenant of life?
SubQuestions.Answer: From the promise of it.

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear that God entered into a covenant with man in innocence?
