SubQuestions.Answer: In as much as the image of God, drawn upon the soul, is in sanctification, carried on to a nearer conformity, till we shall be perfectly like him, when we shall see him as he is, 1 John 3:2.

SubQuestions.Question: Do believers grow in grace at all times?
SubQuestions.Answer: They have a principle of growth, the seed of God remaining in them, 1 John 3:9; but they do not grow at all times; they have their winters, Song 2:11, in which the influences of grace, necessary for growth, are ceased, 5:2.

SubQuestions.Question: Whence is it that the believer's growth ceases at any time?
SubQuestions.Answer: Faith being like the pipe that received the oil from the bowl to each lamp in the candlestick, Zech. 4:2; if that pipe be stopped, or the saint's faith lie dormant and inactive, then all the rest of the graces will also languish and decay, Psalm 27:13.

SubQuestions.Question: How is growth in grace revived, after the languishings and decays of it?
SubQuestions.Answer: The pipe of faith remaining still at the Fountain, as a bond of union between Christ and the soul, the Lord Jesus clears this mean of conveyance, and then the influences for growth flow, and the believer's graces look fresh and green again, Hos. 14:7 - "They that dwell under his shadow shall return; they shall revive as the corn, and grow as the vine."

SubQuestions.Question: Since the tares have their growth, as well as the wheat, Matt. 13:26, how shall we distinguish between the growth of hypocrites, and the growth of the true Christian?
SubQuestions.Answer: The distinction lies in the nature of the growth: the growth of the true Christian is regular and proportionable in all the parts of the new man; it is a "growing up into him in all things who is the head," Eph. 4:15; whereas, hypocrites when they get more knowledge into their heads, and no more holiness into their hearts, may be more taken up with the externals of religion than formerly, and yet as great strangers to the power of godliness as ever, 2 Tim. 3:5.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the several ways in which believers grow at once?
SubQuestions.Answer: They grow inwardly and outwardly; upward and downward, Isaiah 37:31.

SubQuestions.Question: How do believers grow inwardly?
SubQuestions.Answer: By uniting more closely to Christ, and cleaving more firmly to him as the head of influences, which is the spring of all other true Christian growth, Eph. 4:15.

SubQuestions.Question: How do they grow outwardly?
SubQuestions.Answer: By being fruitful in good works in their life and conversation, Titus 3:8.

SubQuestions.Question: How do they grow upward?
SubQuestions.Answer: In heavenly-mindedness and contempt of the world, Phil. 3:20 - "Our conversation is in heaven."

SubQuestions.Question: How do they grow downward?
SubQuestions.Answer: In humility and self-abasement; the branches of the largest growth in Christ, are, in their own eyes, "less than the least of all saints," Eph. 3:8; yea, "the chief of sinners," 1 Tim. 1:15; they see that they can do nothing, 2 Cor. 3:5; that they deserve nothing, Gen. 32:10; and that they are nothing, 2 Cor. 12:11.

SubQuestions.Question: May not Christians mistake their case, by measuring their growth in one of these ways, exclusively of the rest of them?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; if, for instance, they measure it upwards, and not at all downwards; for, though a Christian may want the sweet consolations and flashes of affection, which he has sometimes had, yet, if he be growing in humility, self-denial, and a sense of needy dependence on the Lord Jesus, he is a growing Christian, Hos. 14:5 - "I will be as the dew unto Israel; he shall - cast forth his roots as Lebanon."

SubQuestions.Question: When believers cannot perceive their growth, how may they know if they have true grace at all, how ever weak?
SubQuestions.Answer: If they have any measure of self-loathing on account of sin, Ezek. 36:31; if they have a desire for grace, Neh. 1:11; if they prize Christ above all things, Phil 3:8; and if they love his members for his sake, 1 John 5:1.

SubQuestions.Question: What is meant by perseverance in grace?
SubQuestions.Answer: A continuing still in the state of grace, and the habitual practice of godliness, to the end, John 10:28.

SubQuestions.Question: Can none who are justified, adopted, and sanctified, fall totally and finally from grace?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; they can neither fall totally from all grace nor finally without recovery; for, "those that thou gavest me," says Christ, "I have kept, and none of them is lost," John 17:12.

SubQuestions.Question: How is the perseverance of the saints infallibly secured?
SubQuestions.Answer: By the immutability of electing love, Jer. 31:3; by an indissoluble union with Christ, Rom. 8:38, 39; by the merit of his purchase, 1 Pet. 1:18, 19; by the prevalency of his intercession, Luke 22:32; by the inhabitation of the Spirit, John 14:16; and by the power of a promising God, 1 Pet. 1:5.

SubQuestions.Question: What promise, among others, have believers for their perseverance in grace to the end?
SubQuestions.Answer: They have that remarkable promise, in Jer. 32:40 - "I will not turn away from them to do them good; but I will put my fear in their hearts, that they shall not depart from me."

SubQuestions.Question: What security have believers by this promise.
SubQuestions.Answer: They are secured on every side; both that God will never cast them off, and that they shall never depart from him.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the ground, in law, upon which believers are secured, that God will never cast them off, and that they shall never depart from him?
SubQuestions.Answer: Christ's perseverance in obedience to the law for them, till the condition of the covenant was perfectly fulfilled, Phil. 2:8, by which their perseverance was purchased, and infallibly secured, Titus 2:14.

SubQuestions.Question: Do all who make a zealous profession of religion persevere in it?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; many of them afterwards fall away, John 6:66.

SubQuestions.Question: What may we conclude about those who fall totally and finally from their profession?
SubQuestions.Answer: That they were never in reality what they professed themselves to be, 1 John 2:19 - "They went out from us, but they were not of us; for if they had been of us, they would no doubt have continued with us; but they went out, that they might be made manifest, that they were not all of us."

SubQuestions.Question: What are the chief branches of the promise of perseverance?
SubQuestions.Answer: A promise of the continued influence of grace, Isaiah 27:3; and a promise of continued pardon for the sins of the believer's daily walk, Jer. 33:8.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is the promise of the continued influences of grace necessary?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because the stock of inherent grace would soon fail: of itself, it would wither away, and die out, if it were not fed, John 15:16.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is the promise of continued pardon necessary to the perseverance of saints already justified?
SubQuestions.Answer: Not as if there were any need of new pardons with respect to their state; because none of their sins can bring them afterwards under the guilt of eternal wrath, Rom. 8:1; but only with respect to the sins of their daily walk, which bring them under the guilt of fatherly anger, Psalm 89:30-32.

SubQuestions.Question: How is the pardon of the sins of their daily walk granted to believers?
SubQuestions.Answer: Upon their renewed actings of faith in Jesus Christ, and of repentance towards God; yet not FOR their believing and repenting, but for Christ's sake, 1 John 2:1, 2, even as the first pardon is given, chap. 1:7.

SubQuestions.Question: Does repentance then go before the pardon of sin?
SubQuestions.Answer: Although repentance does not go before, but follows after the pardon of sin in justification; yet not only faith but repentance also, goes before the pardons given to those who are already justified, 1 John 1:9 - "If we confess our sins, he is faithful and just to forgive us our sins."

SubQuestions.Question: How does the perseverance of the saints flow from their justification?
SubQuestions.Answer: In as much as they who are once justified, and accepted in the Beloved, are always so; for "the gifts and calling of God are without repentance," Rom. 11:29.

SubQuestions.Question: How does their perseverance flow from adoption?
SubQuestions.Answer: In as much as he who has adopted them as his children, is their everlasting Father, Isaiah 9:6; and therefore they shall abide in his house for ever, John 8:35.

SubQuestions.Question: How does it flow from their sanctification?
SubQuestions.Answer: In as much as the sanctifying Spirit is given them to abide with them for ever, John 14:16; and to be in them a well of water, springing up into everlasting life, John 4:14.

SubQuestions.Question: What improvement should be made of this connexion of the benefits and blessings that accompany and flow from justification, adoption, and sanctification?
SubQuestions.Answer: It should excite in us a desire after the saving knowledge of the truth, as it is in Jesus, in whom all the lines of divine truth meet, as in their centre, Eph. 4:21; and to admire the infinite goodness and wisdom of God, who has so linked all the blessings of the covenant into one another, that they who are possessed of one, are possessed of all, 1 Cor. 3:22, 23.

Data.Question: What benefits do believers receive from Christ at death?
Data.Answer: The souls of believers are, at their death, made perfect in holiness, and do immediately pass into glory; and their bodies being still united to Christ, do rest in their graves till the resurrection.

SubQuestions.Question: Why are the persons spoken of in the ANSWER, called believers?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because they have been enabled, by grace, to credit the truth of God in his promise, and to embrace the good that is in it, Heb. 11:13.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the difference between believers, and others, in their death?
SubQuestions.Answer: Believers die in virtue of the promise of the covenant of grace, in which death is made over to them unstinged, as a part of Christ's legacy, 1 Cor. 3:22; whereas all others die in virtue of the threatening of the covenant of works, Gen. 2:17, having the sting of death sticking fast both in their souls and bodies.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the sting of death?
SubQuestions.Answer: The sting of death is sin, 1 Cor. 15:56; and the curse is the inseparable companion of sin, Gal. 3:10.

SubQuestions.Question: What security in law have believers against the sting of death?
SubQuestions.Answer: Christ's receiving it into his own soul and body, as their Surety, that they might be delivered from it: wherefore the promise of victory over death, made to him, Isaiah 25:8, secures the disarming of it to them, 1 Cor. 15:57.

SubQuestions.Question: How many fold are the benefits which believers receive from Christ at their death?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are twofold; such as respect their SOULS, and such as respect their BODIES.

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear that the souls of believers exist in a state of separation from their bodies?
SubQuestions.Answer: From the Lord's calling himself the "God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob," long after their death, as an evidence that their souls were living; for "God is not the God of the dead, but of the living," Matt. 22:32; and from the death of believers being called a departure, 2 Tim. 4:6; intimating that the soul, upon its separation, departs only from the earthly house of this tabernacle, to a house not made with hands, eternal in the heavens, 2 Cor. 5:1.

SubQuestions.Question: Are the souls of men absolutely and independently immortal?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; God only is so, 1 Tim. 6:16 - "Who only hath immortality."

SubQuestions.Question: In what sense then are souls immortal?
SubQuestions.Answer: In that, as to their natural constitution, they are incorruptible, having no inward principle of corruption, but remaining in a state of activity after the death of the body, Heb. 12:23 - "The spirits of just men made perfect."

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove the immortality of the soul from the nature of it?
SubQuestions.Answer: In its nature, it is a spiritual, immaterial, or incorporeal substance: and, therefore, where there is no composition of parts, there can be no dissolution of them, Luke 24:39 - "A spirit hath not flesh and bones."

SubQuestions.Question: How are we sure that the soul shall never be annihilated?
SubQuestions.Answer: From the promise of everlasting happiness to the righteous; and the threatening of everlasting misery to the wicked, Matt. 25:46 - "These shall go away into everlasting punishment; but the righteous into life eternal."

SubQuestions.Question: What are the benefits conferred upon the SOULS of believers, upon their separation from their bodies?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are made perfect in holiness, and do immediately pass into glory, Heb. 12:23; Philip. 1:23.

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear, that the souls of believers are not made perfect in holiness, while united to their bodies in this life?
SubQuestions.Answer: From the remains of corruption and indwelling sin which cleave to the best of the saints of God, while in an imbodied state, Rom. 7:23, 24.

SubQuestions.Question: In what consists that perfect holiness which is conferred upon the souls of believers at their separation?
SubQuestions.Answer: Not only in a perfect freedom from all sin, as to the very being of it, Rev. 21:4, but in a perfect likeness and conformity to God, 1 John 3:2.

SubQuestions.Question: What comfort may the believer have, in the prospect of the separation of his soul from his body?
SubQuestions.Answer: That as sin made its first entrance into him at the union of his soul and body, so it shall be for ever cast out at their separation; in which respect, among many others, death is great gain, Phil. 1:21.

SubQuestions.Question: Why must the souls of believers be perfectly holy at their separation?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because nothing that defileth can enter within the gates of the heavenly Jerusalem, Rev. 21:27.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the necessary concomitant of the soul's perfect holiness?
SubQuestions.Answer: Perfect and uninterrupted communion with God, 1 John 3:2.

SubQuestions.Question: Where is this perfect and uninterrupted communion to be enjoyed?
SubQuestions.Answer: In glory, 1 Cor. 13:12.

SubQuestions.Question: When do the souls of the saints pass into glory?
SubQuestions.Answer: As they are made perfect in holiness immediately upon their separation, so do they likewise immediately pass into glory.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is it said in the answer that they pass immediately into glory?
SubQuestions.Answer: To show that the fiction of a middle state, between heaven and hell, invented by the papists, has no manner of warrant, or foundation in scripture.

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove from scripture, that the souls of believers, upon their separation from their bodies, pass immediately into glory?
SubQuestions.Answer: The soul of that certain beggar, named Lazarus, was immediately, upon its separation, "carried by the angels into Abraham's bosom," Luke 16:22; in like manner the soul of the thief upon the cross was immediately glorified; for, says Christ to him, "To-day shalt thou be with me in paradise," Luke 23:43; and Stephen, among his last words, prays, "Lord Jesus, receive my spirit," Acts 7:59; plainly intimating, that he firmly believed his soul would be with Christ' in glory immediately after death.

SubQuestions.Question: What is that glory into which the souls of believers immediately pass?
SubQuestions.Answer: "Eye hath not seen, nor ear heard, neither have entered into the heart of man, the things which God hath prepared for them that love him," 1 Cor. 2:9. However, since naked discoveries of the heavenly glory, divested of earthly resemblances, would be too bright for our weak eyes; such is the condescension of God, that he has been pleased to represent to us heaven's happiness, under similitudes taken from earthly things, glorious in the eyes of men.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the similitudes by which this glory, into which the souls of believers immediately pass, is held forth in scripture?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is compared to a kingdom, Luke 12:32; to a "house not made with hands," 2 Cor. 5:1; to an "inheritance incorruptible," 1 Pet. 1:4; and to a "better country," Heb. 11:16.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is the heavenly glory compared to a kingdom?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because of the fulness of all spiritual and eternal good, of which the saints are there possessed; and the glorious dignity to which they are advanced, Rev. 1:6 - "And hath made us kings and priests unto God and his Father."

SubQuestions.Question: Why is it called a house not made with hands?
SubQuestions.Answer: To signify the unspeakable excellency of the heavenly mansions, above the most stately palaces built by the hands of men.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is it said to be an incorruptible inheritance?
SubQuestions.Answer: To intimate, that the happiness of the saints will be of an unfading nature for ever, 1 Pet. 5:4 - "Ye shall receive a crown of glory that fadeth not away."

SubQuestions.Question: Why is it called a better country?
SubQuestions.Answer: To show that there is no comparison between "the things which are seen, and are temporal, and the things which are not seen, and are eternal," 2 Cor 4:18.

SubQuestions.Question: What benefits do believers receive from Christ, at death, with respect to their bodies?
SubQuestions.Answer: Their bodies, being still united to Christ, do rest in their graves till the resurrection, Isaiah 57:1, 2; Job 19:26.

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear that the bodies of believers in their graves remain still united to Christ?
SubQuestions.Answer: The union was with the person of believers, of which their bodies are a part; and this union being indissoluble, it must still subsist with their bodies in the grave, as well as with their souls in heaven, Isaiah 26:19.

SubQuestions.Question: How may believers be assured of this from the union between the two natures in the person of Christ?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because, as at the death of Christ, though his soul was separated from his body, yet neither the one nor the other were separated from his divine person, but remained as firmly united to it as ever; so neither the soul nor body of the believer shall be separated from Christ by their separation from one another at death, but both of them remain indissolubly united to him for ever, Rom. 8:38, 39.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the difference of the grave to the righteous and to the wicked?
SubQuestions.Answer: To the one the grave is a resting-place; but to the other it is a prison-house, where they are kept in close custody for the judgment of the great day, Dan. 12:2.

SubQuestions.Question: Why are the bodies of the saints said to REST in their graves?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because their graves are like beds of ease, where their bodies lie in safety, till they shall be awakened in the morning of the resurrection, Isaiah 57:2.

SubQuestions.Question: How is their resting in the grave expressed in scripture?
SubQuestions.Answer: By "sleeping in Jesus," 1 Thess. 4:14; intimating, that they sleep in union with Jesus, and that his Spirit keeps possession of every particle of their dust, which he will quicken and rebuild as his temple at the last day, Rom. 8:11.

SubQuestions.Question: How long will they rest in their graves?
SubQuestions.Answer: Till the resurrection of all the dead at the great day, John 5:29.

SubQuestions.Question: How may believers be assured of receiving these promised benefits from Christ at their death?
SubQuestions.Answer: They may be assured of them, upon this ground, that the promises of these benefits to them are all ingrafted upon the promises made to him, as their glorious head, before the world began, 2 Tim. 1:9; Titus 1:2.

SubQuestions.Question: Upon what promise made to Christ, is the promise of disarming death, to the dying believer, ingrafted? Hos. 13:14 - "O death, I will be thy plagues."
SubQuestions.Answer: It is ingrafted upon the promise made to him, of complete victory over death, Isaiah 25:8 - "He will swallow up death in victory."

SubQuestions.Question: Upon what ground may believers be assured that their souls, at death, shall immediately pass into glory?
SubQuestions.Answer: The promise of transporting their souls into heaven, immediately upon the separation from their bodies, (Luke 23:43 - "Jesus said unto him, Verily I say unto thee, Today shalt thou be with me in paradise,") is ingrafted upon the promise made to Christ, that when he should make his soul an offering for sin, he should see his seed, Isaiah 53:10.

SubQuestions.Question: Upon what promise made to Christ is the promise of destroying death, to the dead believer, ingrafted; Hos. 13:14 - "O grave! I will be thy destruction?"
SubQuestions.Answer: It is ingrafted upon the promise made to him, of the resurrection of his mystical members, Isaiah 26:19 - "Thy dead men shall live, together with my dead body shall they arise. Awake, and sing, ye that dwell in the dust."

Data.Question: What benefits do believers receive from Christ at the resurrection?
Data.Answer: At the resurrection, believers being raised up in glory, shall be openly acknowledged and acquitted in the day of judgment, and made perfectly blessed in the full enjoying of God to all eternity.

SubQuestions.Question: Will not all others of mankind be raised as well as believers?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; "There shall be a resurrection of the dead both of the just and unjust," Acts 24:15.

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove, that there will be a general resurrection of the dead?
SubQuestions.Answer: From the power of God, which CAN raise them, and from the scriptures, which affirm that he WILL do it; by which two arguments, our Lord proves the doctrine of the resurrection, against the Sadducees, Matt. 22:29 - "Jesus answered and said unto them, Ye do err; not knowing the scriptures, nor the power of God."

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear that God CAN raise the dead?
SubQuestions.Answer: Since his power was able to speak the world into being out of nothing, surely the same power can as easily raise up the bodies of men out of their former dust, and put them into order after their dissolution, Rom. 4:17.

SubQuestions.Question: What scripture instances has God given of his power in raising the dead?
SubQuestions.Answer: In the Old Testament; the son of the widow of Sarepta was raised, when he was but newly dead, 1 Kings 17:22; the Shunamite's son, when he had lain dead a considerable time, 2 Kings 4:35; and the man cast into the sepulchre of Elisha, when they were burying him, chap. 13:21. In the New Testament; the daughter of Jairus, Mark 5:41, and Dorcas, Acts 9:40, were both raised to life, when lately dead; the widow's son in Nain, when they were carrying him out to bury him, Luke 7:12, 15; and Lazarus, when dead four days, John 11:39, 44.

SubQuestions.Question: How can the dust of men's bodies be distinguished and separated, when the ashes of many generations are mingled together?
SubQuestions.Answer: With men it is impossible, but not with God; for, whoever believes an infinite understanding, Psalm 147:5, must own, that no mass of dust can be so intermixed, but that God perfectly comprehends and infallibly knows how the most minute particle, and every one of them is to be matched; and therefore knows where the particles of each body are, and how to separate them one from another.

SubQuestions.Question: How is it evident from the scriptures, that God WILL raise the dead?
SubQuestions.Answer: From several passages therein, which expressly affirm that he will do so, such as, Dan. 12:2 - "And many of them that sleep in the dust of the earth shall awake; some to everlasting life, and some to shame and everlasting contempt." John 5:28, 29 - "All that are in their graves shall hear his voice, and shall come forth: they that have done good unto the resurrection of life, and they that have done evil unto the resurrection of damnation." See also Job 19:26, 27; Acts 24:15.

SubQuestions.Question: How did our Lord prove the resurrection against the Sadducees, who held only the five books of Moses as most authentic?
SubQuestions.Answer: From Ex. 3:6 - "I am the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob." From whence he argues, Luke 20:37, 38 - "Now, that the dead are raised, even Moses showed at the bush, when he called the Lord, the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob: for he is not the God of the dead, but of the living."

SubQuestions.Question: What is the force of this argument for proving the resurrection?
SubQuestions.Answer: It amounts to this: he is the God of their persons, and not the God of their souls only; and therefore, though their souls, in a separate state, love, worship, and praise him; yet their bodies must also be raised out of the dust, and be restored to life by the soul's resuming its possession, that they may, as living persons, or men, having soul and body united, love, serve, and adore him; and have the full enjoyment of all the blessings contained in his being their God, Heb. 11:16.

SubQuestions.Question: Will the self-same body that dies be raised again?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; it will be, for substance, the same body that will be raised, though endued with other qualities. The very notion of a resurrection implies as much; since nothing can be said to rise again, but that which falls.

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove from scripture, that the self-same body that dies, shall be raised again?
SubQuestions.Answer: Death, in scripture-language, is a sleep, and the resurrection, an awakening out of that sleep, Job 14:12; which shows the body rising up, to be the self-same that died; and the apostle tells us, that it is this mortal, which must put on immortality, 1 Cor. 15:53; and that Christ shall "change our vile body, that it may be fashioned like unto his glorious body," Phil. 3:21.

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove this from the equity of the divine procedure?
SubQuestions.Answer: Though the glorifying of the bodies of the saints cannot, in a strict sense, be said to be the reward of their services or sufferings on earth; yet it is not agreeable to the manner of the divine dispensation, that one body serve him, and another be glorified; that one fight, and another receive the crown.

SubQuestions.Question: Will the same bodies of the wicked, which are laid in the dust, be also raised again?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; that the same body which sinned may suffer: it being unsuitable, that one body be the instrument of sin here, and another suffer in hell for that sin.

SubQuestions.Question: By what means will the dead be raised?
SubQuestions.Answer: "The Lord Jesus himself shall descend from heaven with a shout, with the voice of the archangel and with the trump of God," 1 Thess. 4:16; and at his alarming voice, which shall be heard all the world over, the scattered dust of all the dead shall be gathered together, dust to its dust; and likewise every soul shall come again to its own body, never more to be separated.

SubQuestions.Question: In what order will they be raised?
SubQuestions.Answer: "The dead in Christ shall rise FIRST," 1 Thess. 4:16.

SubQuestions.Question: What will become of those who shall be found alive at the second coming of Christ?
SubQuestions.Answer: They shall not die, and soon after be raised again; but they shall be changed, in some such manner as Christ's body was on the mount, when transfigured; and they shall become like those bodies of the saints which are raised out of their graves, 1 Cor. 15:51.

SubQuestions.Question: In what time will the dead be raised, and the living changed?
SubQuestions.Answer: "In a moment, in the twinkling of an eye, at the last trump," 1 Cor. 15:52.

SubQuestions.Question: What will be the difference between the resurrection of the godly, and that of the wicked?
SubQuestions.Answer: The godly shall be raised by virtue of the SPIRIT of Christ, the blessed bond of their union with him, Rom. 8:11; and they shall come forth out of their graves with unspeakable joy, Isaiah 26:19 - "Awake and sing, ye that dwell in the dust:" but the wicked shall be raised by the POWER of Christ, as a just Judge; and they shall come forth with unspeakable horror and consternation, as so many malefactors, "to be punished with everlasting destruction from the presence of the Lord, and from the glory of his power," 2 Thess. 1:9.

SubQuestions.Question: In what state and condition will the bodies of believers be raised?
SubQuestions.Answer: They shall be raised up in glory, 1 Cor. 15:43.

SubQuestions.Question: What is meant by the glory in which they shall be raised?
SubQuestions.Answer: That they shall be incorruptible, glorious, powerful, and spiritual bodies, 1 Cor. 15:42-44 - "It is sown in corruption, it is raised in incorruption; it is sown in dishonour, it is raised in glory; it is sown in weakness, it is raised in power; it is sown a natural body, it is raised a spiritual body."

SubQuestions.Question: What do you understand by the bodies of believers being raised incorruptible?
SubQuestions.Answer: That they shall leave all the seeds of corruption behind them, in the grave; and be for ever incapable of any pain, sickness, or death: that they shall have an everlasting youth and vigour, no more subject to the decays which age produces in this life, Isaiah 33:24.

SubQuestions.Question: Why are their bodies said to be glorious?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because they shall "be fashioned like unto Christ's glorious body," Phil. 3:21; not only beautiful, comely, and well proportioned, but full of splendour and brightness; for they shall "shine forth as the sun in the kingdom of their Father," Matt. 13:43.

SubQuestions.Question: Why are they said to be powerful or strong bodies?
SubQuestions.Answer: Bec:use they shall be able to bear up, under an "exceeding and eternal weight of glory," 2 Cor. 4:17; and rest not day and night, but be, without intermission, for ever employed, in the heavenly temple, to sing and proclaim the praises of God, Rev. 4:8; weariness being a weakness incompetent to an immortal body.

SubQuestions.Question: In what respect will they be spiritual bodies?
SubQuestions.Answer: Not in respect of their being changed into spirits, (for they shall still retain the essential properties of bodies,) but in respect of their spirit-like qualities and endowments: they shall be nimble and active, and of a most refined constitution; for "they shall hunger no more, neither thirst any more;" and they shall never sleep, "but serve him day and night in his temple," Rev. 7:15, 16.

SubQuestions.Question: What will follow immediately upon the resurrection of the dead?
SubQuestions.Answer: The day of judgment, Rev. 20:13.

SubQuestions.Question: What kind of a day will the day of judgment be?
SubQuestions.Answer: It will be a day of wrath and vengeance to the wicked, 2 Thess. 1:8, 9; but a day of complete redemption to the godly, Luke 21:28.

SubQuestions.Question: What will be the privilege of believers in the day of judgment?
SubQuestions.Answer: They shall be openly acknowledged and acquitted, Matt. 25:23.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to be acknowledged by Christ in that day?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to be owned by him, as the blessed of his Father, for whom the kingdom of heaven is prepared, Matt. 25:34 - "Then shall the King say to them on his right hand, Come, ye blessed of my Father, inherit the kingdom prepared for you from the foundation of the world."

SubQuestions.Question: What is it for believers to be acquitted in the day of judgment?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is not only to be vindicated from all calumny and false aspersions cast upon them here, 1 Cor. 4:5, but to have all their sins declaratively pardoned, Acts 3:19.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the difference between the acquitting of believers, when they are justified in this life, and the doing of it in the day of judgment?
SubQuestions.Answer: In this life, believers are acquitted secretly, out of the sight of the world, and frequently without any intimation of it to themselves; but, then, the acquittal shall be pronounced in the most solemn and public manner.

SubQuestions.Question: Is not this what is meant by their being openly acknowledged and acquitted?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; for it shall be done before God, angels, and men, Rev. 3:5; Matt. 25:34- 41.

SubQuestions.Question: Why will it be done so openly?
SubQuestions.Answer: For the greater honour and comfort of the saints and the greater shame and confusion of their enemies, Isaiah 66:5 - "Your brethren that hated you, and cast you out for my name's sake, said, Let the Lord be glorified; but he shall appear to your joy, and they shall be ashamed."

SubQuestions.Question: On what account shall they be acquitted in that day?
SubQuestions.Answer: On the very same account they are justified here; namely, for Christ's righteousness sake, imputed to them, and received by faith alone, Rom. 3:24.

SubQuestions.Question: What benefits shall believers receive after the day of judgment in heaven?
SubQuestions.Answer: They shall be made perfectly blessed in the full enjoying of God to all eternity, 1 Thess. 4:17 - "So shall we be ever with the Lord."

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to be perfectly blessed?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to be entirely free from all misery, and fully possessed of all happiness, Rev. 21:4, 7.

SubQuestions.Question: In what does the highest pitch of happiness consist?
SubQuestions.Answer: In the full enjoying of God, the chief good, Psalm 73:25.

SubQuestions.Question: In what way and manner will God be fully enjoyed in heaven?
SubQuestions.Answer: By such a perfect knowledge of him as shall have no measure set to it except what arises from the finite capacity of the creature, 1 Cor. 13:12; for otherwise a creature's comprehensive knowledge of an infinite being is impossible, Job 11:7.

SubQuestions.Question: How many ways will God be perfectly and satisfactorily known?
SubQuestions.Answer: Two ways; the one is by sight, which will satisfy the understanding; and the other is by experience, which will satisfy the will.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it that will give the greatest satisfaction to the bodily eyes in heaven?
SubQuestions.Answer: A beholding that glorious and blessed body, which is united to the person of the Son of God, Job 19:27.

SubQuestions.Question: Will not the glory of the man Christ Jesus be unspeakably superior to the glory of all the saints?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes, surely; for, though the saints shall shine forth as the sun, yet not they, but the Lamb, shall be the light of the heavenly city, Rev. 21:23.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it that will make the glory of the human nature of Christ, shine with a peculiar lustre, in the eyes of the saints?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is the indissoluble subsistence of that nature in the person of the Son, as the everlasting bond of union between God and them, John 17:23 - "I in them, and thou in me, that they may be made perfect in one."

SubQuestions.Question: Is not the blissful sight of God in heaven, something else than the sight of that glory, which we will see with our bodily eyes, in the man Christ, or in the saints, or any other splendour and refulgence51 from the Godhead whatsoever?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; for no created thing can be our chief good and happiness, nor fully satisfy our souls; and as these things are somewhat different from God himself, so the scriptures assure us, that we shall see God, Matt. 5:8, and see him as he is, 1 John 3:2.

SubQuestions.Question: How will the saints see God, Father, Son, and Holy Ghost, in heaven?
SubQuestions.Answer: Not with their bodily eyes, in respect of which, God is invisible 1 Tim. 1:17; but with the eye of the understanding, being blessed with the most perfect, full, and clear knowledge of God and divine things, of which the creature is capable, 1 Cor. 13:12.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the difference between believers seeing God here, and their seeing him there?
SubQuestions.Answer: Here they have only a sight, as it were, of his back parts: but there they shall see his face, Rev. 22:4; it is but a passing view they can have of him here, but there they shall eternally, without interruption, feed the eyes of their souls upon him, Psalm 17:15 - "As for me, I will behold thy face in righteousness: I shall be satisfied, when I awake, with thy likeness."

SubQuestions.Question: What will the eyes of the saints be eternally fed upon?
SubQuestions.Answer: They will be for ever contemplating his infinite love, his unchangeable truths, and wonderful works, with the utmost complacency and delight, Psalm 16:11 - "In thy presence is fulness of joy, at thy right hand there are pleasures for evermore."

SubQuestions.Question: How will the saints in heaven contemplate the infinite love of God towards them?
SubQuestions.Answer: They shall be admitted to look into his heart, and there have a clear, distinct, and assured view of the love he bore to them from eternity, and will bear to them for evermore; for he has said, "I have loved thee with an everlasting love," Jer. 31:3. "Enter thou into the joy of thy Lord," Matt. 25:23.

SubQuestions.Question: How will they contemplate God's unchangeable truths?
SubQuestions.Answer: The light of glory will be a complete commentary on the Bible, and will disclose the whole treasure hid in that field, Psalm 36:9 - "In thy light shall we see light."

SubQuestions.Question: Will there be any occasion for written or printed Bibles in heaven?
SubQuestions.Answer: By no means, for the unchangeable truths of God, recorded in that holy book, will be indelibly stamped upon the minds of the redeemed company, as the subject of their everlasting song, Isaiah 59:21 - "My words - shall not depart - out of the mouth of thy seed's seed, saith the Lord, from henceforth and for ever." 1 Pet. 1:25 - "The word of the Lord endureth for ever."

SubQuestions.Question: What comprehension will they have of the wonderful works of God, particularly of creation?
SubQuestions.Answer: Their knowledge of all the creatures will then be brought to perfection, and they will see, that in wisdom he has made them all, Psalm 104:24.

SubQuestions.Question: What views will they have of adorable providence?
SubQuestions.Answer: They will see the checkered web of providence spread out at its full length, and that there was a necessity for all the trials and troubles they met with in time, 1 Pet. 1:6.

SubQuestions.Question: How will the saints in heaven contemplate the glorious work of redemption?
SubQuestions.Answer: It will be the matter of their eternal admiration; they shall for ever and alternately wonder and praise, and praise and wonder, at the mysteries of wisdom and love, goodness and holiness, mercy and justice, that shine through the whole of that glorious device, Rev. 1:5, 6.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the experimental knowledge the saints shall enjoy of God in heaven?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is the participation of the divine goodness in full measure, accompanied with a most lively sense of it in the innermost part of their souls, Rev. 7:17 - "The Lamb shall lead them to living fountains of water;" which are no other than God himself, "the fountain of living waters," Who will fully and freely communicate himself to them.

SubQuestions.Question: In what respect will the communication of God, to the experience of the saints in heaven, be full?
SubQuestions.Answer: In as much as they shall not be limited to any measure, but the enjoyment shall go as far as their most enlarged capacities can reach, Psalm 81:10.

SubQuestions.Question: Will the capacities of the saints above be of equal size?
SubQuestions.Answer: As there will be different degrees of glory, (the saints in heaven being compared to stars, which are of different magnitudes, Dan. 12:3;) so, some capacities will contain more, and others less, yet all shall be filled, and have what they can hold, Psalm 16:11.

SubQuestions.Question: In what will consist the freedom of God's communicating himself to the experience of the saints in heaven?
SubQuestions.Answer: In the unrestrained familiarity which he will there allow them with himself; he shall walk in them, 2 Cor. 6:16; his fulness shall ever stand open to them, there being no veil between him and them, to be drawn aside, for they shall see him face to face, 1 Cor. 13:12.

SubQuestions.Question: What will be the result of the free communication, and full participation of the divine goodness in the upper sanctuary?
SubQuestions.Answer: Perfect likeness to God, and unspeakable joy: hence says the Psalmist, "I shall be satisfied, when I awake, with thy likeness: - In thy presence is fulness of joy," Psalm 17:15, and Psalm 16:11.

SubQuestions.Question: Why will perfect likeness to God follow upon the beatific vision of him?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because the seeing of God in all his matchless excellencies, no more "through a glass darkly, but face to face," cannot but be attended with a swallowing up of all the imperfections of the saints, into a glorious transformation to his blessed image, 1 John 3:2 - "We shall be like him, for we shall see him as he is."

SubQuestions.Question: Why is the communication, and participation of God in heaven, accompanied with unspeakable joy?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because of the undoubted certainty, and full assurance which the saints have of the eternal duration of the same: the enjoyment of God being always fresh and new to them, through the ages of eternity; for they shall drink of living fountains of waters continually springing up in abundance, Rev. 7:17.

SubQuestions.Question: Why will the saints in heaven have an undoubted certainty of their full enjoyment of God to all eternity?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because the everlasting GOD himself will be their eternal life and happiness, 1 John 5:20 - "This is the true God and eternal life." Isaiah 60:19 - "The Lord shall be unto thee an everlasting light, and thy God thy glory." Hence it is said of heaven, that "the glory of God doth lighten it;" and that the Lamb is the light thereof, Rev. 21:23.

SubQuestions.Question: What improvement ought we to make of these benefits which believers receive from Christ at the resurrection?
SubQuestions.Answer: We should "be diligent, that we may be found of him in peace, without spot, and blameless," 2 Pet. 3:14; and occupy the talents he has given us, until he come, Luke 19:13; we should "judge ourselves, that we may not be judged," 1 Cor. 11:31; and because "the end of all things is at hand," we should "therefore be sober, and watch unto prayer," 1 Pet. 4:7; yea, we should "hope to the end, for the grace that is to be brought unto us at the revelation of Jesus Christ," 1 Pet. 1:13.

Data.Question: What is the duty which God requires of man?
Data.Answer: The duty which God requires of man, is obedience to his revealed will.

SubQuestions.Question: Why are the principles of faith, in the Shorter Catechism, treated of, before duties of obedience?
SubQuestions.Answer: To show, that man's duty cannot be rightly performed, unless it flow from a belief of these principles, as the root and spring of it, Heb. 11:6.

SubQuestions.Question: What do you understand by man's duty?
SubQuestions.Answer: That which he owes to God, out of love and gratitude, Luke 17:10.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it that man thus owes to God?
SubQuestions.Answer: Constant and universal obedience, 1 Sam. 15:22.

SubQuestions.Question: From whence does our obligation of obedience to God arise?
SubQuestions.Answer: From his universal supremacy, and sovereign authority over us, as rational creatures, Lev. 18:5, who depend entirely upon him, for our "life, and breath, and all things," Acts 17:25.

SubQuestions.Question: What motive or excitement have Christians, above others, to the duties of obedience?
SubQuestions.Answer: They have the revelation of God's free love, mercy, and grace in Christ, bringing salvation to them, which should teach them to "live soberly, righteously, and godly, in this present world," Titus 2:12.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the only rule and measure of our obedience?
SubQuestions.Answer: The revealed will of God, Isaiah 8:20.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is our obedience limited to God's revealed will?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because it is necessary that God should signify to us, in what instances he will be obeyed, and the manner how our obedience is to be performed; otherwise, it would rather be a fulfilling of our own will than his, Micah. 6:8.

SubQuestions.Question: Where has God revealed his will, as the rule and measure of our obedience?
SubQuestions.Answer: In the scriptures of the Old and New Testament, 2 Tim. 3:16.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the difference between God's secret and revealed will?
SubQuestions.Answer: His secret will is reserved to himself, as the rule of his own procedure; but his revealed will is made known to us, as the rule of our faith and obedience, Deut. 29:29 - "The secret things belong unto the Lord our God; but those things which are revealed belong unto us, and to our children for ever, that we may do all the words of this law."

SubQuestions.Question: Is it not agreeable to the revealed will of God that we give obedience to the just commands of our lawful superiors?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; for thus we are commanded, 1 Pet. 2:13 - "Submit yourselves to every ordinance of man, for the Lord's sake."

SubQuestions.Question: What is the difference between the obedience we should yield to God, and that which we should give to our lawful superiors?
SubQuestions.Answer: We should obey God for himself, or out of regard to his own authority, as the very ground and reason of our obedience; but we should obey our superiors, only in the Lord; or, as their commands are agreeable to his will, Eph. 6:1 - "Children, obey your parents in the Lord, for this is right."

SubQuestions.Question: What is our duty, when the commands of superiors are contrary to the commands of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: In that case we ought, without the least hesitation, "to obey God rather than men," Acts 5:29; Dan. 3:18.

SubQuestions.Question: Why ought God to be obeyed rather than men, when their commands are opposite?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because, "God alone is the Lord of the conscience, James, 4:12, and has left it free from the doctrines and commandments of men, which are in any thing contrary to his word," Acts 4:19.54

SubQuestions.Question: What is the nature of that obedience which is acceptable to God?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is such as flows from a vital union with Christ, and faith in him, as the principle of it, John 15:4, 5; is performed in a due manner, Psalm 5:7; and aims at the glory of God, as its highest and ultimate end, 1 Cor. 10:31.

SubQuestions.Question: What encouragement does God give us to essay a universal obedience to his revealed will?
SubQuestions.Answer: That he requires nothing of us in point of duty, but what he promises strength and furniture for the performance of, Ezek. 36:27 - "I will - cause you to walk in my statutes, and ye shall keep my judgments, and do them."

Data.Question: What did God at first reveal to man, for the rule of his obedience?
Data.Answer: The rule which God at first revealed to man for his obedience, was the moral law.

SubQuestions.Question: How are the laws of God distinguished?
SubQuestions.Answer: Into natural and positive.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the law of God natural, or the law of nature?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is that necessary unalterable rule of right and wrong, founded in the infinitely holy and just nature of God, to which men, as reasonable creatures, cannot but be indispensably bound, Rom. 2:14, 15.

SubQuestions.Question: What do you understand by positive laws?
SubQuestions.Answer: Such institutions as depend only upon the sovereign will and pleasure of God, and which he might not have enjoined, and yet his nature remain the same; such as, the command about not eating the forbidden fruit, and all the ceremonial precepts under the old dispensation.

SubQuestions.Question: Where were the dictates of the law of nature originally inscribed?
SubQuestions.Answer: A fair copy of them was originally written upon the heart or mind of man at his creation; because he was made after the image of God, Gen. 1:27.

SubQuestions.Question: Do these dictates become just and reasonable, because they are commanded; or, are they commanded, because they are just and reasonable in their own nature before?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are commanded, because they are just and reasonable in their own nature, antecedently to any divine precept about them, being founded in the very holiness and wisdom of God, Psalm 111:7, 8.

SubQuestions.Question: Did the dictates of the law of nature undergo any change or alteration in the mind of man, after the fall?
SubQuestions.Answer: The law of nature, being the natural instinct of the reasonable creature, implanted in the soul by God himself can never be totally erased or obliterated, as to its common and general principles, and immediate conclusions flowing from them; though, with reference to such native consequences as are more remote, it is grossly corrupted, and even altered and perverted, by the vicious and depraved nature of man, Rom. 1:21, 32.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the common and general principles of the law of nature, which are still engraved, in some measure, upon the minds of men, even where they have no written law?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are such as these; that God is to be worshipped: parents to be honoured: none are to be injured: that we should not do to others, what we would not wish them to do to us; and the like.

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove that these, and the like principles, are still ingrained in man's nature, even where there is no written law?
SubQuestions.Answer: From Rom. 2:14 - "The gentiles, which have not the law," namely, the written law, "do by nature the things contained in the law."

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear from men's own consciences, that they have innate principles of right and wrong implanted in their natures?
SubQuestions.Answer: From their consciences excusing or accusing them, as they commit actions manifestly agreeable or disagreeable to these innate or inbred principles, Rom. 2:15.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the horrid, though native, consequences, of denying innate principles of right and wrong?
SubQuestions.Answer: The denial of this saps the foundation of all religion, natural and revealed; subverts all difference between moral good and evil; and, consequently, opens a wide door to gross and downright atheism.

SubQuestions.Question: Is there any difference between the law of nature and the moral law?
SubQuestions.Answer: Although the same duties which are contained in the law of nature, are prescribed also in the moral law, yet there is this difference, that in the law of nature, there is nothing but what is moral; but in the moral law there is something also that is positive, namely, the means of worship, and circumscribing the particular day for the observance of the Sabbath.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the meaning of the word moral, when applied to the law?
SubQuestions.Answer: Though the word literally has a respect to the manners of men, yet, when applied to the law, it signifies that which is perpetually binding, in opposition to that which is binding only for a time.

SubQuestions.Question: Was there any express revelation of the moral law made to Adam in his state of innocence?
SubQuestions.Answer: He needed no express revelation of this, because it was interwoven with his very nature in his creation after the image of God, Eccl. 7:29 - "God made man upright."

SubQuestions.Question: Why then is it said in the answer, that the moral law was the rule which God at first revealed to man?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because it was so distinctly written in his heart, and impressed in his nature, that it was equal to an express revelation.

SubQuestions.Question: Is the moral law to be viewed only as the RULE of our obedience?
SubQuestions.Answer: It must be viewed also as the REASON of it. We must not only do what is commanded, and avoid what is forbidden in the law; but we must also do good, for this very reason, that God requires it, and avoid evil, because he forbids it, Lev. 18:4, 5 - "I am the Lord your God, ye shall THEREFORE keep my statutes, and my judgments."

SubQuestions.Question: Are the precepts of the moral law of immutable obligation, so as that they in no case can be dispensed with?
SubQuestions.Answer: With respect to God, those precepts which do not flow absolutely and immediately from his own nature, may, in certain particular cases, be altered or changed, provided it be done by his own express appointment; but with respect to man, all the precepts of the moral law are of immutable obligation, and none of them can in any instance be dispensed with by him, Matt. 5:18.

SubQuestions.Question: Did not God dispense with the law against manslaughter, when he commanded Abraham to offer his only son Isaac for a burnt-offering upon one of the mountains in the land of Moriah, which he was to tell him of? Gen. 22:2.
SubQuestions.Answer: Though Abraham, it would seem, looked upon this mysterious command of his sovereign Lord, to be peremptory, in as much as he immediately took journey with his son, to put the divine order into execution; yet in the issue it proved only to be probatory, to discover to Abraham himself the reality of his faith, and the submissiveness of his obedience to God, as flowing from it, ver. 12, 16, 17.

SubQuestions.Question: Would Abraham have been guilty of murder, had he been permitted to sacrifice his son, on this occasion?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; because he had the warrant of the most unquestionable authority, even the authority of the Lord, the Creator of the ends of the earth, for so doing, ver. 2.

SubQuestions.Question: Is the moral law a perfect rule of life and manners?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is so perfect that nothing can be superadded to it, or corrected in it, Psalm 19:7 - "The law of the Lord is perfect."

SubQuestions.Question: Did Christ supply any defects of the law, or correct any mistakes in it?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; he acted the part of an interpreter and defender of the law, but not of a new lawgiver; as is evident from his explaining the law, and vindicating it (Matt. chapters 5, 6 and 7) from the corrupt glosses that were put upon it.

SubQuestions.Question: Did not Christ say, John 13:34, "A new commandment I give unto you, that ye love one another?"
SubQuestions.Answer: This commandment was not new as to the substance of it, for it is the sum of the second table of the law, Matt. 22:39; and therefore called an "old commandment, which we had from the beginning," 1 John 2:7, 2 John ver. 5; but it is called new, because it was enforced with the new motive and example of Christ's unparalleled love to us, imported in the words immediately following: "As I have loved you, that ye also love one another."

SubQuestions.Question: Is the moral law abrogated under the New Testament?
SubQuestions.Answer: By no means; for Christ came not to destroy the law, but to fulfil it, Matt. 5:17.

SubQuestions.Question: Can righteousness and life be attained by the moral law, since the fall?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; for, "by the works of the law, shall no flesh be justified," Gal. 2:16.

SubQuestions.Question: Of what use, then, is the law to men, since righteousness and life cannot be attained by it?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is, notwithstanding, of much use, both to unregenerate sinners and to saints; "for the law is good, if a man use it lawfully," 1 Tim. 1:8; that is, in a suitableness to the state in which he is, either as a believer or unbeliever.

SubQuestions.Question: Of what use is the law, to unbelievers, or to unregenerate sinners?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is useful to discover to them their utter impotence and inability to attain justification and salvation by the works of it; and thus it is a schoolmaster to bring them to Christ, that they may be justified by faith, Gal. 3:24.55

SubQuestions.Question: How is the law a schoolmaster to bring sinners to Christ?
SubQuestions.Answer: By requiring spotless holiness of nature; perfect, personal, and perpetual obedience in this life; and full satisfaction for sin: which none of mankind being capable of, they are thus shut up to see the need they stand in of Christ, who has done all these things for them; "for Christ is the end of the law for righteousness, to every one that believeth," Rom. 10:4.

SubQuestions.Question: Has the law this effect upon all the unregenerate?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; the most part of them remain deaf to the dictates of the law, both as to their sin and danger, and are therefore rendered inexcusable, Rom. 1:20.

SubQuestions.Question: Of what use is the law to the regenerate, or to believers?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is of use to excite them to express their gratitude and thankfulness to Christ for his fulfilling it as a covenant, Rom. 8:3, 4; by their studying conformity to it, both in their hearts and lives, as the RULE of their obedience, Rom. 7:22, and 12:2.56

SubQuestions.Question: How can the moral law be the rule of obedience to believers, when it is said of them, Rom. 6:14, that they are not under the law?
SubQuestions.Answer: Though they are not under the law as a covenant of works, to be either justified or condemned by it, yet they are under it as a rule of duty, and account it their happiness and privilege to be so, 1 Cor. 9:21.

SubQuestions.Question: What may we learn from the nature of the moral law in general?
SubQuestions.Answer: That God having so clearly pointed out his own nature, and in a manner expressed his very image in it, Lev. 9:2, we ought to loathe and abhor ourselves for our want of conformity to it, and our innumerable transgressions of it, Psalm 40:12; and fly to the Lord Jesus, that by his righteousness imputed, the righteousness of the law may be fulfilled in us, Rom. 8:3, 4.

SubQuestions.Question: What other laws did God give to the Jews, besides the moral law?
SubQuestions.Answer: He gave them also the CEREMONIAL and JUDICIAL laws.

SubQuestions.Question: What was the CEREMONIAL law?
SubQuestions.Answer: It was a system of positive precepts, respecting the external worship of God in the Old Testament church; chiefly designed to typify Christ, as then to come, and to lead them to the knowledge of the way of salvation through him, Heb. 10:1.

SubQuestions.Question: What were the principal ceremonies about which this law was conversant?
SubQuestions.Answer: They were such as respected sacred persons, places, and things.

SubQuestions.Question: Who was the chief sacred person among the Jews?
SubQuestions.Answer: The high priest, who was ordained for men in things pertaining to God, Heb. 5:1.

SubQuestions.Question: In what respect was he a type of Christ?
SubQuestions.Answer: His being consecrated with a plentiful effusion of the holy anointing oil typified the immeasurable communication of the Spirit to Christ, Psalm 133:2; John 3:34; and his bearing the names of the children of Israel upon his shoulder, and in the breast-plate, signified that Christ is the representative of all his spiritual seed, and has their concerns continually at heart, Isaiah 49:3, 16.

SubQuestions.Question: Were not the other ordinary priests of Aaron's family likewise types of Christ?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; for in as much as they daily offered sacrifices according to the law, Heb. 10:11, they were typical of him, who "now once in the end of the world, hath appeared to put away sin by the sacrifice of himself," chap. 9:26.

SubQuestions.Question: What were the sacred places under the old dispensation?
SubQuestions.Answer: The tabernacle and temple.

SubQuestions.Question: What was the tabernacle?
SubQuestions.Answer: It was a movable and portable tent, secured from the injuries of the weather, by several coverings; the whole planned by God himself, and executed by Moses in the wilderness, precisely according to the pattern showed him on the mount, Heb. 8:5.

SubQuestions.Question: How was it enclosed?
SubQuestions.Answer: By a large or spacious court, open above, but hung round with curtains of fine twined linen, five cubits, or seven and a half feet high, Ex. 27:18.

SubQuestions.Question: When and where was the temple built?
SubQuestions.Answer: It was built by Solomon, at Jerusalem, on Mount Moriah, four hundred and eighty years after the children of Israel came out of Egypt; and, consequently, about the same number of years after the tabernacle was set up in the wilderness, 1 Kings 6:1, compared with 2 Chron. 3:1.

SubQuestions.Question: Was the plan of the temple the contrivance of human skill?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; like the tabernacle, it was devised by God himself; for David gave to Solomon, his son, the pattern of the whole of it, as he had it, by the Spirit, 1 Chron. 28:11, 12. And after enumerating several particular parts of the model, "All this," said David, "the Lord made me understand in writing by his hand upon me, even all the works of this pattern," verse 19.

SubQuestions.Question: What did the tabernacle and temple typify?
SubQuestions.Answer: Among other things, they both of them typified the human nature of Christ, which was assumed into union with his divine person, John 2:19, 21.

SubQuestions.Question: How many apartments were there, in these sacred places?
SubQuestions.Answer: Besides the large outward court, to which any of all Israel had access, who were not ceremonially unclean, there were, both in the tabernacle and temple, two sacred apartments; the first, called the holy, and the second, the most holy place, separated by an embroidered veil of cunning work, Ex. 26:31-34.

SubQuestions.Question: What did these several apartments signify?
SubQuestions.Answer: The outward court might signify the church visible, consisting in a mixture of saints and sinners; the holy place, the church invisible on earth, made up only of the true members of Christ's mystical body; and the holiest of all represented heaven itself, or the church triumphant in glory.

SubQuestions.Question: What were the sacred things, in the outward court, which was before the tabernacle?
SubQuestions.Answer: They were these three; the laver, the sacrifices, and the altar on which they were offered.

SubQuestions.Question: What was the laver?
SubQuestions.Answer: It was a brazen vessel for holding water, made of the mirrors, or polished pieces of brass, presented by the "women who assembled at the door of the tabernacle of the congregation," Ex. 38:8.

SubQuestions.Question: Where was it situated?
SubQuestions.Answer: "Between the tabernacle of the congregation and the altar," Ex. 30:18.

SubQuestions.Question: Why was it placed there?
SubQuestions.Answer: That Aaron and his sons might wash their hands and their feet thereat, when they went into the tabernacle, or when they came near to the altar to minister, under no less penalty than death, verse 19-21.

SubQuestions.Question: Why was this ordinance of the priest's washing at the laver, enjoined under so severe a penalty?
SubQuestions.Answer: To point out the absolute necessity of the application of the blood and Spirit of Christ to the soul, as that without which there can be no escaping of eternal death, 1 John 1:7, compared with Rom. 6:23.

SubQuestions.Question: What was the subject matter of the sacrifices?
SubQuestions.Answer: Such of the clean beasts and fowls, specified by God himself, as were perfectly free of any blemish or imperfection, Lev. 22:20.

SubQuestions.Question: What was signified by the sacrifices being without blemish?
SubQuestions.Answer: The spotless holiness and purity of the human nature of Christ, which was sacrificed for us, 1 Pet. 1:19.

SubQuestions.Question: What were the instructive ceremonies that were used in expiatory sacrifices or burnt-offerings?
SubQuestions.Answer: The sins of the offerers were to be typically laid upon the head of the sacrifice, Lev. 1:4; next, it was to be slain by blood-shedding, ver. 5; and then, it was to be consumed wholly, or in part, with fire upon the altar, ver. 9.

SubQuestions.Question: What was signified, by charging the sins of the offerers upon the head of the sacrifice?
SubQuestions.Answer: That the sins of an elect world were laid on Christ, to be expiated by him, Isaiah 53:6.

SubQuestions.Question: What was typified, by shedding the blood of the sacrifice unto death?
SubQuestions.Answer: That the blood of Christ was to be "shed for many, for the remission of sins," Matt. 26:28.

SubQuestions.Question: What was signified, by consuming the sacrifice with fire upon the altar?
SubQuestions.Answer: That the whole of that infinite wrath, which was due to sinners, and would have been consuming them for ever, was poured out upon the glorious Surety, and endured by him, Isaiah 53:10.

SubQuestions.Question: Upon what altar were the sacrifices offered and consumed?
SubQuestions.Answer: Upon the brazen altar, or altar of burnt-offerings, which was placed without, before the door of the tabernacle of the congregation, Ex. 40:6; intimating, that the sacrifice of Christ, was to be perfected on this earth, John 19:30.

SubQuestions.Question: What was typified by this altar?
SubQuestions.Answer: As the altar sanctifieth the gift, Matt. 23:19, so this altar typified the divine nature of Christ, as giving infinite worth and value to the sacrifice of the human nature, because of the personal union, Heb. 9:14.

SubQuestions.Question: From whence originally came the fire, which was kept burning on the altar of burnt-offering?
SubQuestions.Answer: It came originally and immediately from God himself; for when Moses was dedicating the tabernacle in the wilderness, "there came a fire out from before the Lord, and consumed, upon the altar, the burnt-offering, and the fat," Lev. 9:24. And afterwards at the dedication of Solomon's temple, "when he had made an end of praying, the fire came down from heaven, and consumed the burnt-offering and the sacrifices," 2 Chron. 7:1.

SubQuestions.Question: What was signified by this fire coming immediately from before the Lord, or from heaven?
SubQuestions.Answer: It :ignified God's acceptance of, and acquiescence in, the obedience unto death of his own eternal Son, typified by all these expiatory sacrifices, Isaiah 42:21.

SubQuestions.Question: Why was the fire never to go out, but to be kept ever burning upon the altar? Lev. 6:13.
SubQuestions.Answer: To show that it was not possible that the blood of bulls and goats could take away sin, Heb. 10:4; and therefore to teach the people, under that dispensation, to look to the atoning blood of the Messiah, as that only which could quench the flame of divine wrath against sin, and be "an offering and sacrifice to God, for a sweet smelling savour," Eph. 5:2, in which he might eternally rest.

SubQuestions.Question: What were the sacred things in the holy place, called the first tabernacle? Heb. 9:2.
SubQuestions.Answer: They were the candlestick, the table with the shew-bread, and the altar of incense.

SubQuestions.Question: What was typified by the CANDLESTICK?
SubQuestions.Answer: That all true spiritual light is conveyed to the church only from Christ, John 1:9, 18; and that, as the branches were supplied with oil from the body of the candlestick, so all the members are supplied out of the fulness of Christ for God giveth not the Spirit by measure unto him, chap. 3:34.

SubQuestions.Question: What was meant by the SHEW-BREAD, which was always set forth upon the table? Ex. 25:30.
SubQuestions.Answer: That in Christ, who is the bread of life, there is food continually for starving sinners of mankind, John 6:35; and that we may ever come to him for supply, because, "in him dwelleth all the fulness of the Godhead bodily," Col. 2:9.

SubQuestions.Question: What was typified by the altar of INCENSE, which was placed immediately before the veil? Ex. 30:6.
SubQuestions.Answer: The incense which was continually burnt upon this altar, every morning and evening, Ex. 30:7, 8, (after the sacrifices were offered without, upon the altar of burnt-offering,) typified the prevalent intercession of Christ, founded upon his meritorious oblation, 1 John 2:1, 2.

SubQuestions.Question: What were the sacred and significant things contained in the most holy place, or holiest of all, as it is called? Heb. 9:3.
SubQuestions.Answer: The apostle to the Hebrews says, that "the tabernacle which is called the holiest of all, - HAD the golden censer, and the ark of the covenant, overlaid round about with gold, wherein was the golden pot that had manna, and Aaron's rod that budded, and the tables of the covenant; and over it the cherubims of glory, shadowing the mercy-seat," Heb. 9:4, 5.

SubQuestions.Question: Did the golden censer, like other sacred utensils in the most holy place, remain in it perpetually?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; it remained no longer than the high priest continued within the veil, sprinkling the blood of the sin-offering "upon the mercy seat, and before it," Lev. 16:14, during which time the cloud of incense, kindled with coals of fire from the altar of burnt-offering covered the mercy-seat, ver. 12, 13; and then, when the high priest retired from the most holy place, he carried off the golden censer with him to the altar of incense, where it lay till there was next occasion for it.

SubQuestions.Question: Why then was the holiest of all said to HAVE the golden censer?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because the principal use of it, was to carry in burning incense to the most holy place, along with the blood of the sacrifice on the great day of atonement, once every year, Lev. 16:12, 13.

SubQuestions.Question: What was typified by this cloud of incense carried in by the high priest to the most holy place, along with the blood of the sacrifice once a year?
SubQuestions.Answer: The infallible prevalency of Christ's intercession, because of the infinite merit of his satisfaction, Heb. 7:25.

SubQuestions.Question: What was the most eminent pledge of the divine presence, in this most holy place?
SubQuestions.Answer: The ark with the mercy-seat that covered it, Ex. 25:21, 22 - "Thou shalt put the mercy-seat above upon the ark - and there will I meet with thee, and I will commune with thee."

SubQuestions.Question: What was put within the ark?
SubQuestions.Answer: Nothing but the two tables of stone, on which the Ten Commandments were written by the finger of God at Mount Sinai, 1 Kings 8:9 - "There was nothing in the ark, save the TWO TABLES of stone, which Moses put there at Horeb."

SubQuestions.Question: Were not the golden pot that had manna, and Aaron's rod that budded, put within the ark, as it would seem from Heb. 9:4?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; it is expressly said, that both these were appointed to be laid up BEFORE the testimony, not IN IT, Ex. 16:34, and Num. 17:10.

SubQuestions.Question: What did the golden pot that had manna signify?
SubQuestions.Answer: The inexhaustible provision of all spiritual blessings laid up in Christ, for the members of his mystical body, John 6:54, 55.

SubQuestions.Question: What was typified by Aaron's rod that budded?
SubQuestions.Answer: The fixed choice that God had made of Christ, to the office of priesthood, he being called of God, as was Aaron, Heb. 5:4.

SubQuestions.Question: For what end was the ARK of the covenant properly made?
SubQuestions.Answer: It was for holding the two tables of the law, which are called the testimony, Ex. 25:16, says God to Moses, "Thou shalt put into the ark the testimony which I shall give thee."

SubQuestions.Question: Why were the tables of the law called the two tables of testimony? Ex. 31:18.
SubQuestions.Answer: Because they testified the will of God to mankind as the unerring rule of duty, Isaiah 8:20.

SubQuestions.Question: Why were these tables put into the ark?
SubQuestions.Answer: To signify that the law, which was broken by the first Adam, was put up, as fulfilled in the second, Isaiah 42:21, that there might be "no condemnation to them which are in Christ Jesus," Rom. 8:1.

SubQuestions.Question: Why were these tables called the tables of the covenant, and the ark containing them, the ark of the covenant? Heb. 9:4.
SubQuestions.Answer: Because the Ten Commandments, written on these tables, were the matter of the covenant of works made with Adam, as the head of his posterity, Rom. 10:5, and the fulfilment of them, both in point of doing and suffering was the condition of the covenant of grace, made with Christ, as the representative of his spiritual seed, Matt. 3:15.

SubQuestions.Question: What was the mercy-seat?
SubQuestions.Answer: It was a plate of solid gold, exactly fitted to the breadth and length of the ark, (Ex. 25 ver. 10 and 17, compared,) so as to be a lid, or covering to the tables of the covenant, which were within it, ver. 21.

SubQuestions.Question: Why was it called the mercy-seat?
SubQuestions.Answer: To intimate, that God is propitious and merciful to sinners, only through the meritorious satisfaction of Christ, Rom. 5:21.

SubQuestions.Question: What was signified by its being a lid, or covering, to the tables of the covenant?
SubQuestions.Answer: That the broken law was so hid or covered by the glorious Surety, who answered all its demands, Rom. 8:33, 35, that it could accuse none before God, who had "fled for refuge to lay hold upon the hope set before them," Heb. 6:18.

SubQuestions.Question: What was it that peculiarly belonged to the mercy-seat?
SubQuestions.Answer: The "cherubims of glory shadowing it," Heb. 9:5.

SubQuestions.Question: What was represented by these cherubims?
SubQuestions.Answer: They represented the ministry and service of the holy angels to Christ and his church, Heb. 1:14.

SubQuestions.Question: Why called cherubims of glory?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because God manifested his glory from between them, Ex. 25:22, and gave gracious answers with respect to his church and people, Num. 7:89.

SubQuestions.Question: How did they shadow the mercy-seat?
SubQuestions.Answer: By stretching forth and spreading their wings over it, intimating their readiness to fly upon Christ's errands on all occasions, Psalm 104:4.

SubQuestions.Question: In what posture were the faces of these cherubims?
SubQuestions.Answer: They looked one to another, and towards the mercy-seat, Ex. 25:20.

SubQuestions.Question: What did this posture of their faces signify?
SubQuestions.Answer: Their looking one to another, signified their perfect harmony in serving the interests of Christ's kingdom, Ezek. 1:20; and their looking towards the mercy-seat, signified their desire to look, with the most profound veneration and wonder, into the adorable mystery of redeeming love, 1 Pet. 1:12 - "Which things the angels desire to look into."

SubQuestions.Question: Who was allowed to enter into this most holy place?
SubQuestions.Answer: The high priest alone, without any to attend or assist him, Lev. 16:17; and in this he was an eminent type of Christ, who has the whole work of redemption laid upon his shoulders, "And of the people there was none with him," Isaiah 63:3.

SubQuestions.Question: When did the high priest enter into the holiest of all?
SubQuestions.Answer: Only once every year; namely, on the great day of atonement, which was appointed to be a solemn anniversary fast, under that ceremonial dispensation, Lev. 16:29, 30.

SubQuestions.Question: In what manner did the high priest enter within the veil?
SubQuestions.Answer: He was expressly required to carry along with him the blood of the sacrifice, slain without the tabernacle, at the altar of burnt-offering, and the golden censer full of burning incense; without both which, he might by no means enter within the most holy place, Lev. 16:12-16.

SubQuestions.Question: What was typified by this solemnity?
SubQuestions.Answer: It typified the perpetual efficacy of the blood of Christ in heaven, for all the blessings and benefits for which it was shed on earth, Heb. 12:24.

SubQuestions.Question: Is the ceremonial law, or any part of it, obligatory now, under the New Testament?
SubQuestions.Answer: Although the divine truths, couched and signified under the ceremonies of God's own institution, be unchangeably the same, yet the observance of the ceremonies themselves is abrogated by the death and satisfaction of Christ, in whom they had their full accomplishment, John 1:17.

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove that the ceremonial law was abolished by the death and satisfaction of Christ?
SubQuestions.Answer: From the utter destruction, many ages since, of the temple at Jerusalem, where only it was lawful to offer sacrifices; which adorable Providence would never have permitted, if these ceremonial institutions had been intended to subsist after the death of Christ, of whom it was foretold that he should "cause the sacrifice and the oblation to cease," Dan. 9:27. See also Jer. 3:16 - "In those days, saith the Lord, they shall say no more, The ark of the covenant of the Lord; neither shall it come to mind, neither shall they remember it, neither shall they visit it, neither shall that be done any more."

SubQuestions.Question: What may we learn from the whole of this typical dispensation?
SubQuestions.Answer: That as the ceremonial law was a shadow of good things to come, Heb. 10:1, so it is a perpetual evidence of the faithfulness and power of God, in the full accomplishment of all the blessings that were prefigured by it, John 1:17.

SubQuestions.Question: What was the JUDICIAL law?
SubQuestions.Answer: It was that body of laws given by God, for the government of the Jews, partly founded in the law of nature, and partly respecting them, as they were a nation distinct from all others.

SubQuestions.Question: What were those laws which respected them as a people distinct from all others?
SubQuestions.Answer: They were such as concerned the redemption of their mortgaged estates, Lev. 25:13; the resting of their land every seventh year, Ex. 23:11; the appointment of cities of refuge for the man-slayer, Num. 35:15; the appearing of their males before the Lord at Jerusalem, three times in the year, Deut. 16:16; and the like.

SubQuestions.Question: Is this law abrogated, or is it still of binding force?
SubQuestions.Answer: So far as it respects the peculiar constitution of the Jewish nation, it is entirely abrogated; but in so far as it contains any statute, founded in the law of nature, common to all nations, it is still of binding force.

Data.Question: Wherein is the moral law summarily comprehended?
Data.Answer: The moral law is summarily comprehended in the Ten Commandments.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to be summarily comprehended?
SubQuestions.Answer: It :s to be briefly summed up, in such few and well chosen words, as to take in a great deal more than what is expressed, Rom. 3:9.

SubQuestions.Question: Where is the moral law thus briefly summed up?
SubQuestions.Answer: In the Ten Commandments, Deut. 10:4.
