SubQuestions.Question: Where is the law more largely and fully set forth?
SubQuestions.Answer: In the whole scriptures of the Old and New Testaments, Psalm 119:105.

SubQuestions.Question: By whom were the Ten Commandments first pronounced and promulgated?
SubQuestions.Answer: By God himself, Exod. 20:1; "GOD spake all these words."

SubQuestions.Question: Whether was it God essentially considered, or God considered as in the person of the Son, who spake these words?
SubQuestions.Answer: It was the three-one God considered as in the person of the Son, who was the speaker of them; as is evident from Acts 7:37, 38, where the Prophet, whom the Lord was to raise up unto the Jews of their brethren, like unto Moses, is expressly called the angel which spake to him in Mount Sinai. See also Heb. 12:25, 26.

SubQuestions.Question: What was the peculiar work of God about these words, after he had spoken them with an audible voice, in the hearing of all Israel?
SubQuestions.Answer: He wrote or enjoyed them with his own finger, on two tables of stone, Deut. 9:10.

SubQuestions.Question: Was each of these tables written on both sides?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is said expressly that they were, Ex. 32:15. "The tables were written on BOTH their sides; on the one side, and on the other were they written."

SubQuestions.Question: What did this signify?
SubQuestions.Answer: The tables being fully written on both sides, signified that nothing was to be added to the words of the law, or taken away from them, Deut. 4:2; and likewise, that the whole man, soul, spirit, and body, must be sanctified wholly, 1 Thess. 5:23.

SubQuestions.Question: How often were the commandments written on tables of stone?
SubQuestions.Answer: The first being broken by Moses, on occasion of the idolatry of Israel, Ex. 32:19, the Lord condescended to write on two other tables, the very same words that were on the former ones, chap. 34:1.

SubQuestions.Question: Was there any difference between the first two tables and the second?
SubQuestions.Answer: The first two, which were entirely the work of God, (the polishing as well as the engraving,) were broken beneath the mount, Ex. 32:16, 19; but the second, which were hewed by Moses, the typical mediator, were put into the ark, Deut. 10:3, 5.

SubQuestions.Question: What spiritual mystery was represented by this?
SubQuestions.Answer: That though the covenant of works, made with the first Adam, was broken and violated by him, yet it was fulfilled in every respect by Christ the true Mediator, who "restored that which he took not away," Psalm 69:4.

SubQuestions.Question: Why were the Ten Commandments written on tables of stone?
SubQuestions.Answer: To intimate the perpetuity, and everlasting obligation of the moral law, Psalm 111:8.

SubQuestions.Question: What was signified by their being written with the finger of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: That it is the work of God, alone, to put his laws into the mind of sinners, and to "write them in their hearts," Heb. 8:10.

SubQuestions.Question: Where was the law of the Ten Commandments thus expressly revealed?
SubQuestions.Answer: At Mount Sinai, which is also called Horeb, Deut. 5:2.

SubQuestions.Question: In what form was the law of the Ten Commandments given out at Mount Sinai?
SubQuestions.Answer: In the form of a COVENANT, Deut. 5:2 - "The Lord our God made a covenant with us in Horeb." Accordingly, the Ten Commandments are called the words of the covenant, Ex. 34:28; and the tables of stone are termed the tables of the covenant, Deut. 9:9.

SubQuestions.Question: Was the Sinai transaction in the form of the covenant of works, or in the form of the covenant of grace?
SubQuestions.Answer: There was, on that solemn occasion, a repetition of BOTH those covenants.

SubQuestions.Question: In what order were these two covenants repeated on Mount Sinai?
SubQuestions.Answer: The covenant of grace was first promulgated, and then the covenant of works was displayed, as subservient to it.

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear that the covenant of GRACE was first promulgated?
SubQuestions.Answer: From these words in the preface, prefixed to the commands, I am the Lord thy God, spoken to a select people, the natural seed of Abraham, as typical of his whole spiritual seed, Gal. 3:16, 17.

SubQuestions.Question: How are the Ten Commandments to be viewed, as they stand annexed to this promulgation of the covenant of grace on Mount Sinai?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are to be viewed as the law of Christ, or as a rule of life, given by Christ the Mediator to his spiritual seed, in virtue of his having engaged to fulfil the law, as a covenant, in their room, Rom. 7:4.

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear that the covenant of WORKS was likewise displayed on Mount Sinai?
SubQuestions.Answer: From the thunderings and lightnings, and the voice of the living God, speaking (the words of the Ten Commandments) out of the midst of the fire, Ex. 20:18; Deut. 5:22, 26.

SubQuestions.Question: What was signified by the thunderings and lightnings, and the voice of God, speaking out of the midst of the fire?
SubQuestions.Answer: These awful emblems represented that infinite avenging wrath, which was due to all of Adam's family, for the breach of the covenant of works, by which the whole of God's holy law was violated and infringed, Gal. 3:10.

SubQuestions.Question: Why did God make a display of the covenant of works in such an awful and tremendous manner?
SubQuestions.Answer: That sinners of mankind might be deterred from the most remote thought of attempting obedience to the law as a condition of life; and be persuaded to fly to, and acquiesce in the undertaking of Christ, who engaged his heart to approach unto God, as Surety in the room of an elect world, Jer. 30:21.

SubQuestions.Question: If both covenants, of grace and works, were exhibited on Mount Sinai, were not the Israelites, in that case, under both these covenants at one and the same time?
SubQuestions.Answer: They could not be under both covenants in the same respects, at the same time; and therefore they must be considered either as believers or unbelievers, both as to their outward church state and inward soul frame.

SubQuestions.Question: In what respects were the believing Israelites, in the Sinaitic transaction, under both covenants?
SubQuestions.Answer: They were internally and really under the covenant of grace, as all believers are, Rom. 6:14, and only externally, under the above awful display of the covenant of works, as it was subordinate and subservient to that of grace, in pointing out the necessity of the Surety-righteousness, Gal. 3:24.

SubQuestions.Question: In what respects were unbelievers among them, under these two covenants of works and grace?
SubQuestions.Answer: They were only externally, and by profession, in respect of their visible church state, under the covenant of grace, Rom. 9:4; but internally, and really, in respect of the state of their souls, before the Lord, they were under the covenant of works, chap. 4:14, 15.

SubQuestions.Question: Which of the two covenants was the principal part of the Sinai transaction?
SubQuestions.Answer: The covenant of grace was both in itself, and in God's intention, the principal part of it; nevertheless, the covenant of works was the more conspicuous part of it, and lay most obvious to the view of the people; for they SAW "the thunderings and the lightnings, and the noise of the trumpet, and the mountain smoking," Ex. 20:18. "And so terrible was the sight, that Moses said, I exceedingly fear and quake," Heb. 12:21.

SubQuestions.Question: What effect had this tremendous display of the covenant of works upon the Israelites?
SubQuestions.Answer: It tended to beat them off, in some measure, from that self-confidence which they had expressed before the publication of the law, Ex. 19:8; and to discover the necessity of a Mediator, and of faith in him as the sole foundation of all acceptable obedience, Rom. 16:25, 26.

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear that it had this effect?
SubQuestions.Answer: From their own words to Moses, after the terrible sight which they saw, Deut. 5:27 - "Speak thou unto us all that the Lord our God shall speak unto thee; and we will HEAR [that is, believe] and DO." On which account the Lord commends them, ver. 28, 29 - "They have well said all that they have spoken: O that there were such a heart in them, that they would fear me, and keep all my commandments always, that it might be well with them, and with their children for ever!"

SubQuestions.Question: In what respect had they said well in what they had spoken?
SubQuestions.Answer: In as much as they had made faith, or believing, the source and spring of acceptable doing; for, "whatsoever is not of faith is sin," Rom. 14:23.

SubQuestions.Question: How many commandments are commonly allotted to each of these two tables of the law?
SubQuestions.Answer: Four to the first table, containing our duty to God; and six to the second, containing our duty to man.

SubQuestions.Question: How are the precepts, which are naturally moral, distinguished from those that are but positively so?
SubQuestions.Answer: The:precepts which are naturally moral have, in them, an innate rectitude and holiness, which is inseparable from them; but the precepts which are positively moral have their rectitude, not from their own nature, but from the positive command of God.

SubQuestions.Question: What example may be given of this for illustration?
SubQuestions.Answer: The Fourth Commandment, as it requires God to be worshipped, is naturally moral, founded in the very nature of God; but as it enjoins, that he be worshipped on such a particular day of the week, it is positively moral, founded entirely in the will of God.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the difference between the commands that are expressed in affirmative, and those that are expressed in negative terms?
SubQuestions.Answer: "What God forbids is at no time to be done, Rom. 3:8; what he commands is always our duty, Deut. 4:8, 9; and yet every particular duty is not to be done at all times, Matt. 12:7."57

SubQuestions.Question: Why are negative precepts binding at all times?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because what is forbidden is at all times sinful; and ought never to be done, on any pretext whatsoever, Gen. 39:9.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the peculiar properties of the law of the Ten Commandments?
SubQuestions.Answer: That it is perfect, Psalm 19:7; spiritual, Rom. 7:14; and exceedingly broad, or most extensive, Psalm 119:96.

SubQuestions.Question: What rule is to be observed for the right understanding of the perfection of the law?
SubQuestions.Answer: "That it binds every one to full conformity in the whole man, unto the righteousness thereof, and to entire obedience for ever; so as to require the utmost perfection of every duty and to forbid the least degree of every sin, Matt. 5:21, to the end, James 2:10."58

SubQuestions.Question: What rule is to be observed for understanding the spirituality of the law?
SubQuestions.Answer: That it reaches to the thoughts and motions of the heart, as well as to the words and actions of the life, Deut. 6:5.59

SubQuestions.Question: What rule is to be observed for the right understanding of the breadth or extent of the law?
SubQuestions.Answer: That, as where a duty is commanded, the contrary sin is forbidden, Isaiah 57:13; and where a sin is forbidden, the contrary duty is commanded, Eph. 4:28; so, when any duty is commanded, all the causes and means of it are commanded also, Heb. 10:24, 25; and when any sin is forbidden, all occasions and temptations to it, are likewise forbidden, Gal. 5:26.60

Data.Question: What is the sum of the Ten Commandments?
Data.Answer: The sum of the Ten Commandments is, To love the Lord our God with all our heart, with all our soul, with all our strength, and with all our mind; and our neighbour as ourselves.

SubQuestions.Question: How is the sum of the Ten Commandments divided in this answer?
SubQuestions.Answer: Into the sum of the four commandments in the first table, which contain our duty to God; and into the sum of the six commandments in the second table, which contain our duty to man.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the sum of the four commandments in the first table, which contain our duty to God?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to love the Lord our God, with all our heart, with all our soul, with all our strength, and with all our mind, Luke 10:27.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is this called "the first and great commandment?" Matt. 22:38.
SubQuestions.Answer: Because the duties of the first table have a more direct relation to God, as being the immediate object of them, or, because love to our neighbour should flow from love to God, as the proper fountain and principle of it, 1 John 5:1.

SubQuestions.Question: What is meant by the sum of the commandments?
SubQuestions.Answer: The comprehensive duty of the law, which includes all other duties in the bosom of it, Rom. 13:9.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the comprehensive duty of the law?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is LOVE; for "love is the fulfilling of the law," Rom. 13:10.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the nature of that love which is the comprehensive duty of the law?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is such as flows from faith, as the source and fountain of it; for "faith worketh by love," Gal. 5:6.

SubQuestions.Question: What ought to be the supreme object of our love?
SubQuestions.Answer: The Lord, or JEHOVAH himself, as he is our God, Deut. 30:6.

SubQuestions.Question: How many ways may the Lord be said to be our God?
SubQuestions.Answer: Two ways; either by external revelation and offer; or, by special property and possession.

SubQuestions.Question: To whom does he make the external revelation and offer of himself, as their God?
SubQuestions.Answer: To all such of mankind, without exception, as have the word of this salvation sent to them, Proverbs 8:4; Heb. 8:10.

SubQuestions.Question: When is he our God by special property and possession?
SubQuestions.Answer: When by faith we are united to Christ, 1 Cor. 3:23, in whom mercy and truth are met together, righteousness and peace have kissed each other, Psalm 85:10.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to love the Lord our God with all our heart?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to love him unfeignedly, without hypocrisy or dissimulation, Rom. 12:9.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to love him with all our soul, and mind?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to have an intelligent, cordial, and affectionate love to God; expressed in all the duties, in which any power or faculty of the soul can be exercised, Isaiah 26:8, 9.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to love the Lord our God with all our strength?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to love nothing so much as God, Matt. 10:37; and nothing but in subordination to him, Luke 14:26.

SubQuestions.Question: How may we know, if we have such a supreme love to the Lord our God?
SubQuestions.Answer: If we love him purely for himself and his own matchless excellency, as shining in the face of Jesus, Song 1:3; if we account all things but loss in comparison of him, Phil. 3:8; and if we centre in him as the only resting-place of our souls for ever, Psalm 73:25, 26.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the sum of the six commandments in the second table, which contain our duty to man?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to love our neighbour as ourselves, Matt. 22:39 - "The second is like unto it, Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself."

SubQuestions.Question: Why is the sum of the second table said to be like unto the sum of the first?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because the duties of the second table are enjoined by the same authority as those of the first, James 2:10.

SubQuestions.Question: In which of the two tables is the lawful love of ourselves contained, seeing it is not expressly mentioned in either of them?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is fairly implied and supposed in both tables, particularly in the second, where love to ourselves is made the example and pattern, according to which we should love others, Luke 10:27 - "Thou shalt love - thy neighbour AS thyself."

SubQuestions.Question: What is lawful self-love?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is an aiming at our own happiness, in subordination to the glory of God, which ought to be our chief and ultimate end, 1 Cor. 10:31.

SubQuestions.Question: Whom are we to understand by our neighbour?
SubQuestions.Answer: All of mankind to whom we have any way access to be useful, either as to their temporal or spiritual good, Luke 10:36, 37.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to love our neighbour as ourselves?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to love him as truly and sincerely as we do ourselves, Eph. 5:29 - "No man ever hated his own flesh, but nourisheth and cherisheth it."

SubQuestions.Question: Should our love to our neighbour be as great as it is to ourselves?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is not required that it be as great in degree, but only that it be as sincere, and free of hypocrisy, as it is to ourselves, Rom. 12:9.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the rule according to which our love to our neighbour should be regulated?
SubQuestions.Answer: That we do to others what we would have them do to us, Matt. 7:12.

SubQuestions.Question: How is this rule to be explained for preventing the abuse of it?
SubQuestions.Answer: That we do as we would be done to, from a well-informed judgment; and by such as place themselves in the same relations, and in the same circumstances with us.

SubQuestions.Question: Why are we enjoined to esteem others better than ourselves? Phil. 2:3.
SubQuestions.Answer: Because the more of the grace of God we have in our hearts, we will the more clearly see that we ourselves are the chief of sinners, 1 Tim. 1:14, 15, and have the seed of all sin in us, which would soon spring up into the worst of actions, if not restrained, Rom. 7:23.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the difference between the love we should have to all in general, and the love we should have to the saints in particular?
SubQuestions.Answer: We should love all men in general, with a love of benevolence, and likewise of beneficence according to our ability, Gal. 6:10; but we should love the saints with a love of complacency and delight, Psalm 16:3.

SubQuestions.Question: How ought our love to extend itself to our enemies?
SubQuestions.Answer: By forgiving them, and praying for them, Matt. 5:44; Acts 7:60.

SubQuestions.Question: What may we learn from the sum of the commandments?
SubQuestions.Answer: That charity, or love, which is the end of the commandment, ought to flow from a pure heart, and a good conscience, and faith unfeigned, 1 Tim. 1:5.

Data.Question: What is the preface to the Ten Commandments?
Data.Answer: The preface to the Ten Commandments is in these words: I am the Lord thy God, which have brought thee out of the land of Egypt, out of the house of bondage.

Data.Question: What does the preface to the Ten Commandments teach us?
Data.Answer: The preface to the Ten Commandments teaches us, That because God is the Lord, and our God, and Redeemer, therefore we are bound to keep all his Commandments.

SubQuestions.Question: What is a preface?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is something spoken before, or a preparatory introduction to the following discourse.

SubQuestions.Question: :re these words, I am the Lord thy God, &c. to be understood as a preface to all the commandments, or to the first only?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are to be understood as a preface to them all, though they stand immediately connected with the first, as being the ground of the particular applicatory faith in a redeeming God, which is enjoined in it.

SubQuestions.Question: Why are the above words prefixed as a preface to all the commandments?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because they are designed as so many reasons and arguments to enforce our obedience to them.

SubQuestions.Question: Why does God give reasons to enforce obedience to his commands, when his will is the supreme law?
SubQuestions.Answer: To manifest his amazing condescension, in dealing with us in a suitableness to our natures as rational creatures, Hos. 11:4.

SubQuestions.Question: How many reasons or arguments are there in this preface, by which God enforces obedience to his law?
SubQuestions.Answer: Three; the first is, because he is THE LORD, or JEHOVAH; the second, because he is OUR GOD; and the third, because he is our REDEEMER.

SubQuestions.Question: Which of these three is the formal reason of obedience?
SubQuestions.Answer: The first, namely, God's essential greatness, as he is "JEHOVAH, the Most High over all the earth," Psalm 83:18; though, at the same time, his relative goodness, as our God, and the deliverance he has accomplished as our Redeemer, are invincible arguments and motives to obey him, Lev. 19:36, 37.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the strength of the first argument for obedience, taken from God's being the Lord?
SubQuestions.Answer: The strength of it lies in this, That because God is JEHOVAH, "the eternal, immutable, and almighty God, having his being in and of himself, and giving being to all his words and works:"61 therefore, all obedience and subjection is due to him, Lev. 20:8.

SubQuestions.Question: In what lies the strength of the second argument for obedience to God's law, taken from his being our God?
SubQuestions.Answer: It lies in this, that because he makes himself over to sinners of mankind, by a new covenant grant, in the word of divine revelation; therefore, this ought to sweeten all his commands, and powerfully excite us to the obedience of them, Lev. 20:7.

SubQuestions.Question: What does God make over to us in the word, when he makes a grant of himself in it to be our God?
SubQuestions.Answer: He makes over to us whatever he is, Hos. 13:4, and whatever he has, Psalm 84:11, as God, to be ours freely and eternally.

SubQuestions.Question: What does he make over to us when he makes a grant of whatever he is?
SubQuestions.Answer: He makes over to us both what he is essentially, and what he is personally.

SubQuestions.Question: What does he make over to us when he makes a grant of what he is essentially?
SubQuestions.Answer: All his glorious attributes and excellencies to be ours, Ex. 34:6; his infinity, to be the extent of our inheritance, Rev. 21:7; his eternity, to be the date of our happiness, John 14:19; his unchangeableness, to be the rock of our rest, Mal. 3:6; his wisdom, to direct us, Psalm 73:24; his power, to protect us, 2 Chron. 16:9; his holiness, to sanctify us, Ezek. 16:14; his justice, to justify and preserve us, Rom. 3:26; his goodness, to reward us in the way of grace, not of debt, 1 John 2:25; and his truth, to secure us in the accomplishment of all his promises, Heb. 10:23.

SubQuestions.Question: What does he make over to us, when he makes a grant of what he is personally?
SubQuestions.Answer: He makes over himself in the person of the Father, to be our God and Father in Christ, 1 Pet. 1:3; in the person of the Son, to be our Redeemer and Saviour, Isaiah 48:17; and in the person of the Holy Ghost, to be our Sanctifier and Comforter, John 14:16.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it that he makes over to us, when he makes a grant of whatever HE HAS?
SubQuestions.Answer: As he has all the good things we can possibly need in time, or through eternity, so he makes them all freely over to us in the promise, "All things are yours," 1 Cor. 3:21; for instance, he has life, for the quickening of us who are dead in trespasses and sins, Eph. 2:1; righteousness, for the justifying of us who are guilty, Isaiah 45:25; and redemption for delivering us who are lawful captives, chap. 49:24, 25. In a word, "Eye hath not seen, nor ear heard, neither have entered into the heart of man, the things which God hath prepared for them that love him," 1 Cor. 2:9.

SubQuestions.Question: Is this grant that God makes of himself to us in the word, to be our God, no more than a mere argument, or motive to enforce our obedience?
SubQuestions.Answer: It also strengthens and enables us to obey God, Ezek. 36:27, 28.

SubQuestions.Question: How does the revelation of God's being our God, strengthen and enable us to obedience?
SubQuestions.Answer: In as much as by the revelation of this, the Holy Ghost is conveyed as the immediate efficient of holiness, Gal. 3:2; and Faith is produced in the soul, as the spring and fountain of it, chap. 5:6.

SubQuestions.Question: Why does God front his law with this grant of himself as the Lord our God?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because it comprehends all the promises of the covenant, and all the blessings that are wrapt up in them, and therefore is the best encouragement to the obedience of faith; for, because he is our God, he will give us one heart, and one way; he will not turn away from us to do us good, but will put his fear in our hearts, that we shall not depart from him, Jer. 32:38-40.

SubQuestions.Question: Why does God make this declaration of his grace in the present time I am and not in the future, I WILL be thy God?
SubQuestions.Answer: To show that God's covenant of promise is always a solid ground and foundation for the present actings of faith, in every case and circumstance in which we can be situated, James 2:23.

SubQuestions.Question: Why does God, in this grant, address the sinner in the singular number, I am thy God?
SubQuestions.Answer: That every individual sinner, to whom the revelation of his grace may come, should believe it with a particular applicatory faith, Zech. 13:9 - "I will say, It is my people; and they shall say, The Lord is MY God."

SubQuestions.Question: How may we know, if ever we have, by faith, received the offer and grant that God makes of himself in the word?
SubQuestions.Answer: By our love and esteem of him, Ex. 15: by our reposing entire trust and confidence in him, Psalm 18:2; by our likeness and conformity to him, 1 John 3:3; and by our longing after the full fruition and enjoyment of him, Psalm 73:25.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the THIRD ARGUMENT, in the Preface, for enforcing our obedience?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is in these words: - which have brought thee out of the land of Egypt, out of the house of bondage.

SubQuestions.Question: How are these words explained in our Catechism?
SubQuestions.Answer: Of our spiritual redemption by Jesus Christ; for, the preface to the Ten Commandments teaches us, That because God is the Lord, and our God, and REDEEMER, therefore we are bound to keep all his commandments.

SubQuestions.Question: In what lies the strength of this argument, for enforcing our obedience to the commands of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: It lies in this, that as he brought Israel of old out of their bondage in Egypt, so he delivered us out of our spiritual thralldom; and therefore we should "serve him without fear, in holiness and righteousness before him, all the days of our life," Luke 1:74, 75.

SubQuestions.Question: In what respects did the deliverance of Israel out of Egypt resemble our spiritual redemption by Christ?
SubQuestions.Answer: The Israelites were made to serve the Egyptians with rigour, Ex. 1:14; so sinners, by nature, are under the most cruel bondage and servitude to sin and Satan, 2 Pet. 2:19; the Israelites were not able of themselves to shake off the Egyptian yoke, Ex. 2:23; no more are sinners of mankind capable of extricating themselves from a state of spiritual slavery in which they are naturally inthralled, Rom. 5:6; the Israelites were brought out of Egypt, "with a strong hand and a stretched out arm," Psalm 136:12; so are we, out of our spiritual thralldom, by the mighty power of God, Psalm 110:2, 3; the Egyptians were destroyed, when Israel were delivered, Ex. 14:28; so principalities and powers were spoiled, Col. 2:15, transgression finished, Dan. 9:24, and death unstinged, 1 Cor. 15:55, when our redemption was accomplished, ver. 57.

SubQuestions.Question: Seeing the deliverance of Israel, which was typical of our spiritual deliverance, was brought about by divine power, without the payment of a price, will it follow, that our spiritual redemption was also without a price?
SubQuestions.Answer: By no means; unless the similitude between the type and the antitype held in every respect, which it cannot possibly do; for, though there be a resemblance between them in some things, yet there is always a disparity in others; as might be made evident in every one of the scriptural types and metaphors, to which divine things are compared: for instance, Jonah was alive in the whale's belly, whereas Christ was actually dead in the grave.

SubQuestions.Question: Since God brought all the Israelites, without exception, out of Egypt, does it not from thence follow, that Christ redeemed all mankind from their spiritual bondage?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; because the Israelites did not typify and represent all mankind, but the elect only, Psalm 135:4.

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove that the elect only, and not all mankind, were redeemed by Christ?
SubQuestions.Answer: From the Father's gift of them to him from eternity, John 17:6; from his representing them in his death, John 10:11; and from his intercession within the veil for them only, John 17:9 - "I pray for them; I pray not for the world, but for them which thou hast given me."

SubQuestions.Question: Are the purchase and intercession of Christ precisely of the same extent?
SubQuestions.Answer: Surely they are; for, his intercession being founded on his purchase, and consisting in a presentation of the merit of it before the throne, Heb. 9:24, it clearly follows, that the one can be no more extensive than the other, John 17:24 - "Father, I will that they also Whom thou hast given me, be with me where I am."

SubQuestions.Question: How then are those scriptures to be explained, which seem to speak of a universal purchase of all mankind; such as, that Christ died for all, 2 Cor. 5:15; that he tasted death for every man, Heb. 2:9; that he is the propitiation also for the sins of the whole world, 1 John 2:2; and the like?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are to be explained in a limited sense, of some only, and not of every individual of mankind; as the like general terms are undoubtedly to be understood in other places of scripture; such as Col. 1:6, and Rev. 13:3; for, if it is alleged, that the above scripture expressions prove a universal purchase, it may be said, with the same parity of reason, that they prove a universal application of it, which few will assert.

SubQuestions.Question: Does not the universal offer of Christ prove the universal redemption of all, at least within the visible church?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; it only proves the unquestionable duty of all to believe, upon the call and command of God, 1 John 3:23; and the infinite intrinsic worth of the satisfaction of Christ for the salvation of all, had it been so designed, chap. 4:14.

SubQuestions.Question: Does the redemption purchased by Christ bring any benefit or advantage to the reprobate world?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is owing to it that the gospel is sent among them, John 4:4; that temporal judgments are shortened, Mark 13:20; and it is on account of the elect, who are to spring of them, that they are preserved for awhile in this world, Rom 11:30; but then these, or the like benefits, are not to be considered as the fruit of Christ's purchase to the reprobate themselves, but to the elect only, who are living among them, 2 Cor. 4:15, or who are to descend from them, Isaiah 6:13.

SubQuestions.Question: In what consists the spiritual bondage we are naturally under, and redeemed from by Christ?
SubQuestions.Answer: It consists in our being under the wrath of God, John 3:18; the guilt, power, and pollution of sin, Rom. 8:7; the tyranny of Satan, Eph. 2:2; the snares and temptations of the world, 1 John 2:16; and in our liability to the pains of hell for ever, Matt. 25:46.

SubQuestions.Question: What right had Christ to be our Redeemer from this state of spiritual bondage?
SubQuestions.Answer: He had a right of property, and a right of propinquity.

SubQuestions.Question: How had he a right of property?
SubQuestions.Answer: As God, he is the original owner, Rom. 9:21; and as Mediator, he has the elect given to him by his Father, John 17:6.

SubQuestions.Question: How has he a right of propinquity?
SubQuestions.Answer: He has it by the legal union which subsisted between him and us from eternity, in virtue of his being made a surety of a better testament, Heb. 7:22; and by the assumption of our nature in time, by which he became our kinsman, and "is not ashamed to call us brethren," Heb. 2:11, 12.

SubQuestions.Question: What does God's delivering Israel out of the land of Egypt teach us, with respect to his church and people in general?
SubQuestions.Answer: It teaches us, that as affliction is the lot of the Lord's people, in this present evil world, so deliverance from it is secured in due time, Psalm 34:19 - "Many are the afflictions of the righteous, but the Lord delivereth him out of them all."

SubQuestions.Question: What is the difference between the afflictions of the godly, and those of the wicked?
SubQuestions.Answer: The afflictions of the godly are the chastisements of a gracious Father, flowing from love, and designed for their profit, Heb. 12:6, 10; but the afflictions of the wicked are the punishments of an avenging Judge, flowing from wrath, and designed for their ruin and destruction, Eccl. 5:17.

SubQuestions.Question: What improvement ought we to make of our spiritual redemption?
SubQuestions.Answer: It should excite us to "stand fast in the liberty wherewith Christ hath made us free, and not to be entangled again with the yoke of bondage," Gal. 5:1; to ascribe all the praise of our spiritual liberty to our glorious Deliverer, Rev. 1:5, 6; and to testify our gratitude and thankfulness, to him, by a conversation becoming the gospel, Phil. 1:27.

Data.Question: Which is the First Commandment?
Data.Answer: The First Commandment is, Thou shalt have no other gods before me.

Data.Question: What is required in the First Commandment?
Data.Answer: The First Commandment requireth us to know and acknowledge God to be the only true God, and our God; and to worship and glorify him accordingly.

SubQuestions.Question: Why are most part of the commands of the law delivered in negative terms?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because negative precepts are of the strictest obligation, binding always, and at all times.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is the First Commandment, in particular, so expressed?
SubQuestions.Answer: Bec:use of the perpetual propensity of our nature, since the fall, to depart from the living God, "through an evil heart of unbelief," Heb. 3:12.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is this commandment set in front of all the rest?
SubQuestions.Answer: To teach us, that the having JEHOVAH to be our God, is the leading and fundamental duty of the law, Ex. 15:2, which sweetly and powerfully influences obedience to all the other commands of it, Psalm 118:28.

SubQuestions.Question: What influence has obedience to the first, upon obedience to the other precepts of the law?
SubQuestions.Answer: As obedience to the First Commandment, is to believe that God is our God, upon the gift of himself to us, in these words, I am the Lord thy God; so, without believing this it is impossible we can do any thing else that will please him, Heb. 11:6; for "whatsoever is not of faith is sin," Rom. 14:23.

SubQuestions.Question: Why do this, and other commands, run in the second person singular, THOU, and not in the plural, YOU, or YE?
SubQuestions.Answer: To signify, that God would have us to take his commandments, as spoken to each of us in particular, as if we were mentioned by name.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the connexion between the preface and the First Commandment?
SubQuestions.Answer: The preface reveals and exhibits the object of faith, and the First Commandment enjoins the duty of believing on that object: the one makes a grant of grace, and the other warrants us to lay hold on it.

SubQuestions.Question: Are the preface and First Commandment of equal extent?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; every one to whom the promise in the preface is revealed, is obliged, by the command, to believe it, with application, John 3:18.

SubQuestions.Question: Can the obligation of the law be in the least weakened by the grace of the gospel, published in the preface?
SubQuestions.Answer: So far from it, that it is impossible for any man to share of the grace of the gospel, published in the preface, but in a way of believing, enjoined in the first command of the law, Rom. 3:31 - "Do we make void the law through faith? God forbid."

SubQuestions.Question: What are the chief duties required in the First Commandment, as thus connected with the preface
SubQuestions.Answer: To know and acknowledge God, to be the only true God, and our God; and to worship and glorify him accordingly.

SubQuestions.Question: What KNOWLEDGE of God does the First Commandment require?
SubQuestions.Answer: It requires us to know that God is; and that he is such a God as he has manifested himself to be in his word, Heb. 11:6.

SubQuestions.Question: What has God manifested himself to be in his word?
SubQuestions.Answer: He has manifested himself to be, "The Lord, the Lord God merciful and gracious, long-suffering, and abundant in goodness and truth, keeping mercy for thousands, forgiving iniquity, transgression, and sin, and that will by no means clear the guilty;" namely, without a satisfaction, Ex. 34:6, 7; or, he has manifested himself to be in Christ, reconciling the world to himself, 2 Cor. 5:19.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to know God as he is in Christ?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to know that he is well pleased for Christ's righteousness' sake, because he has magnified the law, and made it honourable, Isaiah 42:21.

SubQuestions.Question: How is the knowledge of God usually distinguished?
SubQuestions.Answer: Into speculative or common, and practical or saving knowledge.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the speculative or common knowledge of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is only a floating knowledge of him in the head, without any saving influence or efficacy upon the heart and practice; as is to be found in ungodly persons or hypocrites, who may "profess that they know God, but in works they deny him," Titus 1:16.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to have a saving and practical knowledge of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to have such a lively apprehension of his relation to us as our God in Christ, as is accompanied with an habitual conformity to his will, in heart and life, 1 John 2:3, 4.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the evidences of true saving knowledge?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is an experimental, Col. 1:6, interesting, Psalm 41:11, sanctifying, 2 Pet. 1:8, and humbling knowledge, Job 40:4, 5.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to acknowledge God?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to own, avouch, and confess him, both in secret, and before the world, Rom. 10:10, - "With the mouth confession is made unto salvation."

SubQuestions.Question: Why are the knowing and acknowledging of God joined together?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because wherever the saving knowledge of God is implanted in the heart, there will be always some evidences of it, either to ourselves, or others, discovered in the life, Dan. 11:32 - "The people that do know their God, shall be strong, and do exploits."

SubQuestions.Question: What should we know and acknowledge God to be?
SubQuestions.Answer: We should know and acknowledge him to be the only true God, and our God.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to know and acknowledge God to be the only true God?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to believe and profess, that he alone, and none else, is possessed of all infinite perfection, and that the perfections of the divine nature are most eminently displayed and manifested in the person of Christ, our only Saviour and Redeemer, Hos. 13:4 - "Thou shalt know no God but me: for there is no Saviour besides me."

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to know and acknowledge God to be our God?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to profess our relation to him, as his people, upon the faith of the grant that he makes of himself to us as ours, in the word; Deut. 26:17, 18; Psalm 48:14.

SubQuestions.Question: Can we know and acknowledge God to be our God, (as required in this commandment) unless we believe in Christ?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; for "no man cometh unto the Father but by me," says Christ - "He that hath seen me hath seen the Father," John 14:6, 9.

SubQuestions.Question: Is not faith, or believing in Christ, a gospel precept only, and not required in the law?
SubQuestions.Answer: By no means; for, in the gospel, strictly and properly taken, as it is contradistinct from the law, there can be no precept; because the gospel in this strict sense, is nothing else than a PROMISE, or glad tidings of a Saviour, with grace, mercy, and salvation in him, for lost sinners of Adam's family; according to the following scriptures, Gen. 3:15; Isaiah 61:1-3; Luke 2:10, 11.

SubQuestions.Question: Since faith and repentance are duties consequently to the entrance of sin, and the revelation of the gospel, must they not therefore be new precepts, not given to Adam in innocence?
SubQuestions.Answer: Though there was no occasion for the exercise of these duties in an innocent state; yet Adam being bound by the law of creation, (particularly the Ten Commandments, given him in the form of a covenant of works,) to believe whatever God should reveal, and obey whatever he should command; no sooner was the gospel revelation made, than the very same law, which bound him, while in innocence, to believe in God as his Creator, obliged him, when fallen, to believe in God as his Redeemer, now revealed and made known to him; and likewise to turn from sin to God, Rom. 3:31.

SubQuestions.Question: Whence is it that the obligation of the law is so extensive, as to bind to the belief of whatever God shall reveal?
SubQuestions.Answer: This arises from the absolute perfection of the law, which being a complete rule of all obedience, cannot but fasten the duty, the same moment that the object is revealed, Psalm 119:96 - "Thy commandment is exceeding broad."

SubQuestions.Question: What is the absurdity of making faith and repentance new gospel precepts?
SubQuestions.Answer: The absurdity is, that by this another righteousness is introduced in our own persons, than the righteousness of Christ, as the immediate ground of our pardon and acceptance before God.

SubQuestions.Question: How does this absurdity necessarily follow from the aforesaid doctrine?
SubQuestions.Answer: If Christ, as our surety, has fulfilled the precept, and endured the penalty of the moral law, according to Gal. 4:4, 5, then it cannot but follow, that this law of faith and repentance, not being fulfilled by him, must be fulfilled by ourselves, in our own persons, as our righteousness before God: and thus another ground of justification is established, besides the Surety righteousness, contrary to Gal. 2:16, and 3:21.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the doctrine of our Larger Catechism on this head?
SubQuestions.Answer: That believing and trusting in God (which is the same with faith,) "being careful in all things to please him," and "sorrowful when in any thing he is offended," (which is the same with repentance,) are among "the duties required in the First Commandment:" and that "unbelief - distrust - incorrigibleness - and hardness of heart, or impenitency, (according to Rom. 2:5, there quoted,) are among the sins forbidden in it."62

SubQuestions.Question: What does God require of us in this commandment, as the evidence of our knowing and acknowledging him to be the only true God, and our God?
SubQuestions.Answer: That we worship and glorify him accordingly, Matt. 4:10 - "Thou shalt worship the Lord thy God, and him only shalt thou serve."

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to worship God?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to make him the supreme object of our esteem, Psalm 71:19, desire, Psalm 73:25, and delight, Psalm 142:5, and that not only in our secret devotions, but likewise when joining with others in any religious exercise, Psalm 111:1.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to glorify him?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to ascribe all possible glory and perfection to him, Ex. 15:11, and, in all our actions, to aim at the advancement of his honour and glory in the world, 1 Cor. 10:31.

SubQuestions.Question: What is imported in our being required to worship and glorify him accordingly?
SubQuestions.Answer: It imports, that since God commands us to know and acknowledge him, not only to be the true God, but our own God, in virtue of the covenant grant he makes of himself in the word; it becomes us, in all our actions, religious and civil to behave towards him, as standing in such a near and intimate relation to us, Psalm 45:11; 1 Cor. 6:20.

SubQuestions.Question: Can we glorify God aright, unless we acknowledge him to be our God in Christ?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; for, unless we acknowledge a God in Christ, as our God, we make him a liar, in saying, I am the Lord thy God, and rebel against his authority in the First Commandment, which is, "Thou shalt have no other gods before me."

SubQuestions.Question: Is believing the promise, then, the foundation of all acceptable worship and obedience?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; for all true obedience, is "the obedience of faith," Rom. 16:26, and "without faith it is impossible to please God," Heb. 11:6.

SubQuestions.Question: In what manner are we required to worship and glorify God?
SubQuestions.Answer: Both inwardly in our hearts, John 4:24, and outwardly in our lives, Matt. 5:16.

SubQuestions.Question: How are we to worship God inwardly in our hearts?
SubQuestions.Answer: By trusting, Isaiah 26:4; hoping, Psalm 130:5, and delighting in him, Psalm 37:4; by thinking and meditating upon him, Mal. 3:16, Psalm 63; devoting ourselves to him, Isaiah 44:5; and by being filled with grief, when he is offended by ourselves or others, Psalm 38:18, and 119:136.

SubQuestions.Question: How are we to worship and glorify him outwardly in our lives?
SubQuestions.Answer: By praying to him, and praising him with our lips, Psalm 142:1, and 145:21; by being zealous for his glory, Psalm 69:9; careful to please him, Col. 1:10; and by walking humbly before him, Micah. 6:8.

SubQuestions.Question: What improvement ought we to make of the covenant grant in the preface, I am the Lord thy God; and the precept enjoining the belief of this, Thou shalt have no other gods before me?
SubQuestions.Answer: That it is the duty of every one of us, without waiting till we find gracious qualifications wrought in us, instantly to lay claim to a God in Christ, as our God, Psalm 95:7; this being what he requires in the first place, as the foundation of all other acts of obedience, 2 Chron. 20:20.

SubQuestions.Question: If it is an external federal relation to the visible church, which God asserts in the preface, when he says, I am the Lord thy God, how can the First Commandment warrant the faith of a special relation?
SubQuestions.Answer: As the command always warrants a particular application of every general promise, so the external federal relation which God bears to the visible church, becomes a special one, the moment that the promise is believed with a particular applicatory faith, Jer. 3:22.

Data.Question: What is forbidden in the First Commandment?
Data.Answer: The First Commandment forbiddeth the denying, or not worshipping and glorifying the true God, as God and our God; and the giving that worship and glory to any other which is due to him alone.

SubQuestions.Question: To what general heads may the sins forbidden, in the First Commandment, be reduced?
SubQuestions.Answer: To these two: atheism and idolatry.

SubQuestions.Question: What is A THEISM?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is the denying, or not having a God.

SubQuestions.Question: How is atheism commonly distinguished?
SubQuestions.Answer: Into speculative and practical.

SubQuestions.Question: How is speculative atheism again subdivided?
SubQuestions.Answer: Into that which is directly, and that which is interpretatively such.

SubQuestions.Question: What is direct speculative atheism?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is a fixed persuasion in the heart, and an open profession with the mouth, that there is no God.

SubQuestions.Question: What is speculative atheism, interpretatively, or by necessary consequence?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is the rejection of any of those truths which are necessarily connected with the being of a God; such as the denial of providence, or any of the essential perfections of God: because from thence it would necessarily follow, that there is no God.

SubQuestions.Question: Why would it necessarily follow, from the denial of providence, or any of the divine perfections, that there is no God?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because it is impossible to conceive that there is a God, without conceiving, at the same time, that he preserves and governs the world, Isaiah 41; and it is impossible to conceive his being or existence, without conceiving him to be possessed of all infinite perfection, 1 John 1:5.

SubQuestions.Question: Can there be such a person among men, as a direct speculative atheist?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; there can be none of mankind, who has, at all times, such a fixed and constant persuasion that there is no God, as at no time whatsoever to have the least fear or doubt of the contrary, Dan. 5:6, 9.

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear that there can be no such person as a downright speculative atheist?
SubQuestions.Answer: From universal experience, which attests, that the knowledge and impression of the being of a God, is so natural to man, that he can no more divest himself of it at all times, than he can strip himself of his reason, or shake off his own existence, Rom. 1:19 - "That which may be known of God is manifest in them; for God hath showed it unto them:" that is, ingrained it in their natures.

SubQuestions.Question: Would it not seem, that there may be a downright speculative atheist, from Psalm 14:1 - "The fool hath said in his heart, there is no God?"
SubQuestions.Answer: The words do not import a fixed and permanent persuasion, but rather a secret wish: accordingly, the expression is not, The fool hath believed, or is persuaded in his heart, but hath said: that is, would fain have harboured such a secret desire.

SubQuestions.Question: Why do wicked men wish there were no God?
SubQuestions.Answer: To be free of any check or restraint upon their lusts, and that they may "work all uncleanness with greediness," Eph. 4:19.

SubQuestions.Question: Who are they that are interpretatively atheists?
SubQuestions.Answer: Not only they who deny the providence of God, or any essential attribute of his nature, but likewise all deists, who reject supernatural revelation; and all openly wicked and profane persons, who live as if there was no God, Psalm 10:4, 11, 13.

SubQuestions.Question: Is it speculative or practical atheism, that chiefly levelled against, in this commandment?
SubQuestions.Answer: Both: but especially practical atheism, as being universally prevalent, Rom. 3:11.

SubQuestions.Question: What is practical atheism?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is a denial of God, in our practice, Titus 1:16 - "They profess that they know God, but in works they deny him."

SubQuestions.Question: How does practical atheism evidence itself?
SubQuestions.Answer: In omitting the duties required in this commandment; namely, not knowing and acknowledging God to be what he really is, and neglecting to worship and glorify him accordingly.

SubQuestions.Question: Who are guilty of not knowing God?
SubQuestions.Answer: Not only heathens, who walk contrary to nature's light, Rom. 1:21; but likewise Christians, who being privileged with the means of knowing God, as in Christ, yet slight and neglect the same; John 15:22 - "If I had not come and spoken unto them, they had not had sin; but now they have no cloak for their sin."

SubQuestions.Question: Who are they that are guilty of not acknowledging God?
SubQuestions.Answer: They who rush upon the actions of life, without asking his counsel about them, Josh. 9:14 - "The men took of their victuals, and asked not counsel at the mouth of the Lord."

SubQuestions.Question: Who are guilty of not worshipping God?
SubQuestions.Answer: They who live in the habitual neglect of the public, private, and secret exercises of his worship, Isaiah 43:22 - "Thou hast not called upon me, O Jacob; thou hast been weary of me, O Israel."

SubQuestions.Question: Who are guilty of not glorifying God?
SubQuestions.Answer: They who set up themselves as their own rule, Psalm 12:4, and make themselves their own end and happiness, in opposition to God, Phil. 2:21.

SubQuestions.Question: When are men chargeable with this piece of practical atheism; namely, of setting themselves up as their own rule?
SubQuestions.Answer: When they perform any action, religious or civil, more because it is agreeable to self, than as it is pleasing to God, Zech. 7:5, 6; when they envy the gifts and prosperity of others, Psalm 73:3, and when they would model or frame God himself according to their own fancy, imagining him to be "altogether such a one as themselves," Psalm 50:21.

SubQuestions.Question: When do men make themselves their own end and happiness in opposition to God?
SubQuestions.Answer: When they ascribe the glory of what they have or do, to themselves, and not to God, Dan. 4:30; when they are more troubled for what disgraces themselves, than for what dishonours God, 1 Sam. 15:30; and when they prefer the pleasures and profits of this world, to the glorifying and enjoying of God, Matt. 19:22.

SubQuestions.Question: When may we be said to worship the true God, and yet not as God?
SubQuestions.Answer: When we draw nigh to him with the mouth, and honour him with our lips, but our hearts are far from him, Matt. 15:8.

SubQuestions.Question: When are we guilty of not worshipping and glorifying him, as our God?
SubQuestions.Answer: When, in the course or tenor of our behaviour and deportment towards him, we want the habitual exercise of the faith of our federal relation to him, Psalm 81:10, 11.

SubQuestions.Question: May not the saints themselves be chargeable with some degree of practical atheism?
SubQuestions.Answer: No doubt they may; when they entertain unbecoming thoughts of God in their mind, or speak unadvisedly to him with their lips. Thus Job is censured by Elihu, for charging God with injustice, chap. 33:10, 11; and Jonah speaks most rashly to God, when he says, "I do well to be angry, even unto death," chap. 4:9.

SubQuestions.Question: How may a person know when blasphemous thoughts, and atheistical expressions, are not inconsistent with a state of grace?
SubQuestions.Answer: When a blasphemous thought is so far from being indulged, that it is treated with abhorrence; and when an atheistical expression (uttered through surprise, and the hurry and violence of temptation) is deeply regretted and lamented, Psalm 73:21, 22.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the other general and comprehensive sin forbidden in this commandment?
SubQuestions.Answer: IDO:ATRY.

SubQuestions.Question: What is idolatry?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is the giving that worship and glory to any other, which is due to God alone.

SubQuestions.Question: How is idolatry commonly distinguished?
SubQuestions.Answer: Into that which is gross and external, and that which is more refined and internal.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the idolatry which is gross and external?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is an ascription of the ordinary signs of worship, or religious homage, to any person or thing, besides the true God, Lev. 26:1.

SubQuestions.Question: Who are they that are guilty of this grosser kind of idolatry?
SubQuestions.Answer: HEATHENS and PAPISTS.

SubQuestions.Question: What was the nature of the idolatry of the Heathens?
SubQuestions.Answer: They made gods of the sun, moon, and stars, and of almost every other creature; yea, of devils themselves, as the apostle witnesses, 1 Cor. 10:20. But that which was most frequent among them, was their making images or idols in the shape of some sort of living creatures, or of a mixture of them, and then worshipping them as if they were gods, Psalm 135:15-19.

SubQuestions.Question: How did Heathenish Idolatry take its rise in the world?
SubQuestions.Answer: By men becoming "vain in their imaginations, whereby they changed the glory of the incorruptible God into an image made like to corruptible man, and to birds, and four-footed beasts, and creeping things," Rom. 1:21, 23.

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear that the Papists are guilty of this grosser kind of idolatry?
SubQuestions.Answer: By their bowing to images and altars; giving divine honour to the consecrated bread in the sacrament; adoring the crucifix; praying to angels; invoking the saints, especially the virgin Mary, whom they supplicate much more frequently than they do Christ himself. By all which it appears, that Popish idolatry succeeds in the room of the Heathenish; and is more inexcusable than theirs, because those who practise it have the benefit of divine revelation which the heathens have not.

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove, that the paying religious homage to such things is gross idolatry?
SubQuestions.Answer: From the nature of idolatry itself; the very essence of which consists in giving divine worship and honour to any creature whatsoever, whether in heaven or earth; for it is written, "Thou shalt worship the Lord thy God, and him only shalt thou serve," Matt. 4:10.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the idolatry which is more refined and internal?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is a setting up of idols in the heart, Ezek. 14:4; or giving that room in our esteem and affection to any thing else, which God alone ought to possess, Luke 14:26.

SubQuestions.Question: To whom is this kind of idolatry incident?
SubQuestions.Answer: To all mankind naturally; and even believers themselves are cautioned and warned against it, 1 John 5:21 - "Little children, keep yourselves from idols."

SubQuestions.Question: What are these idols which have a seat in every man's and woman's heart by nature?
SubQuestions.Answer: Among many others, there are these two; which are worshipped and served by the generality, even of the visible church, namely, SELF and the WORLD.

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear that SELF is an idol which naturally reigns in the heart of every one?
SubQuestions.Answer: From the very first lesson in the school of Christianity, which is, to deny self, Matt. 16:24 - "Then said Jesus unto his disciples, If any man will come after me, let him deny himself."

SubQuestions.Question: What is it for a man to deny himself?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to give up with his self-wisdom, his self-will, and his self-righteousness.

SubQuestions.Question: When do we give up with the idol of self-wisdom?
SubQuestions.Answer: When we are made to see our own depraved reason to be but folly, when compared with the wisdom of God revealed in his word; "for the wisdom of this world is foolishness with God," 1 Cor. 3:19.

SubQuestions.Question: When is the idol of self-will dethroned?
SubQuestions.Answer: When God's will of precept becomes the sole rule of our heart and life, Psalm 119:105; and his will of providence is cheerfully acquiesced in as the best for us, Rom. 8:28.

SubQuestions.Question: When do we part with the idol of self-righteousness?
SubQuestions.Answer: When we submit to the righteousness of God, or found our plea, for eternal life wholly and entirely upon the meritorious obedience and satisfaction of Christ, as our Surety, in our room and stead, Phil. 3:8, 9.

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear that the WORLD is an idol seated in every man's heart by nature?
SubQuestions.Answer: From the habitual turn of our thoughts and affections to things temporal, Matt. 6:31; the eager pursuit of them, and ardent desire after them, in preference to those that are spiritual and eternal, chap. 16:26.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the things of this world which we naturally incline to idolise?
SubQuestions.Answer: Some make an idol of their worldly riches; making gold their hope, and saying to the fine gold, "Thou art my confidence," Job 31:24; some, of their worldly pleasures, being "lovers of pleasures, more than lovers of God," 2 Tim. 3:4; some make an idol of their worldly credit and reputation, receiving "honour one of another," and not seeking "the honour that cometh from God only," John 5:44; some, of their worldly relations bestowing more of their love upon them, than upon God, Matt. 10:37; and some make an idol of their worldly helps and confidences, trusting more to these than to God, Isaiah 31:1; Jer. 17:5.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the verdict of the Spirit of God concerning those who make the world their idol?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is this, that "if any man love the world, the love of the Father is not in him," 1 John 2:15.

SubQuestions.Question: How may Satan be said to be even idolised by those who profess to bear him an implacable hatred?
SubQuestions.Answer: When his suggestions are regarded more than the dictates of the Spirit of God in his word, Isaiah 40:27; 49:14.

SubQuestions.Question: How may the suggestions of Satan be distinguished from the dictates of the Spirit of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: The tendency of all Satan's suggestions is to set up in the soul some one thing or other in Christ's room, 2 Cor. 4:4; but the dictates of the Spirit of God are wholly calculated for giving Christ in all things the pre-eminence, John 16:14.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is Satan called the God of this world? 2 Cor. 4:4.
SubQuestions.Answer: Because he is "the spirit that worketh in the children of disobedience," Eph. 2:2, till "the prey be taken from the mighty, and the lawful captive delivered," Isaiah 49:24, 25.

SubQuestions.Question: Who are they that explicitly acknowledge the devil as their God?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are such as use sorcery, divination, witchcraft, charms, and other diabolical arts and practices, condemned in Deut. 18:10-12.

SubQuestions.Question: Was Joseph's cup an instrument of divination, or did he himself use this unlawful art, when he says, Gen. 44:15 - "Wot ye not that such a man as I can certainly divine?"
SubQuestions.Answer: By no means; for the word translated DIVINE is, on the margin, rendered make trial, or inquiry; and so the meaning is, Know ye not that such a man as I, who am so diligent and industrious in other matters, would soon miss the cup in which I usually drink, and make inquiry after the person who had stolen it?

SubQuestions.Question: What improvement ought we to make of the First Commandment, as it stands connected with the preface?
SubQuestions.Answer: That as God warrants and commands us to believe in him, as our God and Redeemer, Psalm 45:11; so it is our duty to carry along with us the faith of this relation, in all our approaches to his presence, Heb. 11:6.

Data.Question: What are we especially taught by these words BEFORE ME in the First Commandment?
Data.Answer: These words before me in the First Commandment, teach us, That God, who seeth all things, taketh notice of, and is much displeased with, the sin of having any other god.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the strength of the argument implied in these words before me?
SubQuestions.Answer: That the sin of having any other god, is committed in the presence of him, who seeth all things, Heb. 4:13.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it for God to see all things?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to have a most intimate, perfect, and comprehensive knowledge of them, Psalm 147:5 - "His understanding is infinite."

SubQuestions.Question: In what consists the infinity of God's knowledge?
SubQuestions.Answer: Not so much in the perfect and comprehensive knowledge of the creatures, which are finite; as in the perfect and comprehensive knowledge of himself, and his own excellencies and perfections, which are infinite, 1 Cor. 2:11.

SubQuestions.Question: How is it that God sees, or knows all things?
SubQuestions.Answer: He sees all things at once in his own essence, distinctly, infallibly, and immutably, 1 John 1:5.

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove that God has such a comprehensive sight and knowledge of all things?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because otherwise he could not be the Creator, Governor, and Judge of the world, 1 Cor. 4:5.

SubQuestions.Question: In what light does God see or know evil actions?
SubQuestions.Answer: As they are opposite to his nature, Jer. 44:4, and contrary to his law, 1 John 3:4, which is the sole and unerring standard of all rectitude, Rom. 7:12.

SubQuestions.Question: What is that sin which strikes more immediately and directly against the authority of God in this commandment?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is the sin of having any other god.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to have another god?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to have our minds, wills, and affections carried out after other objects, as much, or more than after God himself, Isaiah 46:9, compared with Ezek. 14:4.

SubQuestions.Question: What notice does God take of this sin?
SubQuestions.Answer: He threatens to resent it with the highest marks of displeasure, and that even in this life, as well as in the world to come, Deut. 29:24-29.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is God so much displeased with the sin of having any other God?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because it sets up a rival or competitor in his room, and that in his very sight and presence, Jer. 32:30.

SubQuestions.Question: What influence ought the presence of an all-seeing God to have upon us in all our actions?
SubQuestions.Answer: The consideration of this ought to quicken and animate us to every duty, Gen. 5:22, 24; and affright and deter us from every sin, as being an affronting of him to his face, who is our witness, and ere long will be our judge, Gen. 39:9.

Data.Question: Which is the Second Commandment?
Data.Answer: The Second Commandment is, Thou shalt not make unto thee any graven image, or any likeness of any thing that is in heaven above, or that is in the earth beneath, or that is in the water under the earth. Thou shalt not bow down thyself to them, nor serve them: for I the Lord thy God am a jealous God, visiting the iniquity of the fathers upon the children, unto the third and fourth generation of them that hate me; and showing mercy unto thousands of them that love me and keep my commandments.:

Data.Question: What is required in the Second Commandment?
Data.Answer: The Second Commandment requireth the receiving, observing, and keeping pure and entire, all such religious worship and ordinances as God hath appointed in his word.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the opinion of the Papists respecting this commandment?
SubQuestions.Answer: They allege that it is not a distinct precept from the first, but only an appendix, or supplement to it, by way of illustration.

SubQuestions.Question: What is their practice, in consequence of this opinion?
SubQuestions.Answer: They constantly leave it out in their mass books and other liturgies of their church, lest the people should observe the manifest contrariety of their image worship, to what is here so expressly forbidden.

SubQuestions.Question: In what then does the Second Commandment differ from the first?
SubQuestions.Answer: The First Commandment respects the object, and requires that we worship the true God for our God, and no other: the second respects the means of worship, and requires that the true God be worshipped in such a way only, and by such ordinances as he has appointed in his word, in opposition to all human inventions.

SubQuestions.Question: What is meant by religious worship?
SubQuestions.Answer: That homage and respect we owe to a gracious God, as a God of infinite perfection; by which we profess subjection to, and confidence in him, as our God in Christ, for the supply of all our wants; and ascribe the praise and glory that is due to him, as our chief good, and only happiness, Psalm 95:6, 7.

SubQuestions.Question: What are these religious ordinances, which God has appointed in his word?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are "prayer and thanksgiving in the name of Christ; the reading, preaching, and hearing of the word, the administration and receiving of the sacraments; church government and discipline; the ministry and maintenance thereof; religious fasting; swearing by the name of God; and vowing to him."

SubQuestions.Question: Is prayer a moral duty founded in the law of nature?
SubQuestions.Answer: It certainly is; the necessary dependence of the rational creature upon its Creator, plainly proves it to be so. Hence we find the very Heathens practising it, when reduced to straits, Jonah 1:14.

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear to be an instituted means of worship?
SubQuestions.Answer: From a variety of scripture texts enjoining the practice of it, in all cases and circumstances, Psalm 50:15; Phil. 4:6; 1 Thess. 5:17.

SubQuestions.Question: What is acceptable prayer?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is an asking in Christ's name, what God has promised to give, John 14:13; with a full persuasion that he hears, and will answer, Mark 11:24; James 1:6.

SubQuestions.Question: How manifold is religious thanksgiving?
SubQuestions.Answer: TWOFOLD; stated and occasional.

SubQuestions.Question: What is stated thanksgiving?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is not only the thankful acknowledgment of mercies daily received, which is a branch of prayer; but likewise the singing the praises of God with the voice, which is a stated act of worship, distinct from prayer, though ejaculatory prayer ought always to be joined with it, Psalm 57:7.

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove that singing with the voice is a stated act of worship appointed under the New Testament?
SubQuestions.Answer: From the example of Christ and his apostles, who, after the first supper, sang a hymn, (or psalm, as on the margin,) Matt. 26:30; and from the injunction laid upon all Christians to be employed in this exercise, as a stated duty, Eph. 5:18, 19; James 5:13.

SubQuestions.Question: What should be the subject matter of our praises to God?
SubQuestions.Answer: The psalms, hymns, and spiritual songs, which are dictated by the Spirit of God in scripture; and not any human composure whatever, Eph. 5:19.

SubQuestions.Question: In what manner should these be sung?
SubQuestions.Answer: "With grace in our hearts to the Lord," Col. 3:16.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to sing with grace in our hearts to the Lord?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to have our hearts going along with our voice, in suitable acts of faith, and elevated affections, Psalm 57:7.

SubQuestions.Question: Are not the Psalms of David, as we sing them in our language, of human composure?
SubQuestions.Answer: The translation in metre is human, but the sense and meaning are the same as the original.

SubQuestions.Question: What is occasional thanksgiving?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is the setting some time apart for giving thanks to God, on account of some remarkable mercy and deliverance, respecting either churches and nations in general, Neh. 12:27; or ourselves and families in particular, Eph. 5:20.

SubQuestions.Question: How ought we to engage in this duty?
SubQuestions.Answer: With an humble sense of our utter unworthiness of the least of all God's favours, 2 Sam. 7:18.

SubQuestions.Question: Are reading, hearing, and preaching of the word, acts of worship?
SubQuestions.Answer: Although they are not acts of such immediate worship as prayer and praise, in which God is immediately addressed; yet being the instituted and ordinary means of salvation, they ought to be practised and attended with that reverence and regard which is due to the great God our Saviour, who is present in them, Matt. 28:20; Acts 10:33.

SubQuestions.Question: How are the administration and receiving of the sacraments acts of worship?
SubQuestions.Answer: As in them, by the sensible signs of divine appointment, Christ, and his benefits, are represented, sealed, and applied to believers, Gal. 3:26; 1 Cor. 11:26.

SubQuestions.Question: In what sense are church government and discipline to be ranked among the ordinances of divine worship?
SubQuestions.Answer: In as far as they are exercised in the name of the Lord Jesus, the alone head of the church, according to the rule of his word, by church judicatories lawfully constituted, Matt. 18:20.

SubQuestions.Question: Why are the ministry and the maintenance of it placed among religious ordinances?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because, as a standing ministry in the church, till the end of time, is of express divine institution, Eph. 4:11-13; so the suitable and comfortable maintenance of it, is as expressly appointed, not only in the Old Testament, Num. 18:21, 24; but likewise in the New, 1 Cor. 9:13, 14 - "Do ye not know, that they which minister about holy things, live of the things of the temple? and they which wait at the altar, are partakers with the altar? Even so hath the Lord ordained, that they which preach the gospel should live of the gospel."

SubQuestions.Question: What is religious fasting?
SubQuestions.Answer: "A religious fast requires total abstinence, not only from all food, (unless bodily weakness do manifestly disable from holding out, till the fast be ended,) but also from all worldly labour, discourses, and thoughts, and from all bodily delights."64 Josh. 7:6; Judges 20:26.

SubQuestions.Question: Is bodily fasting, or bare abstinence from food, any part of religious worship?
SubQuestions.Answer: Not properly in itself; but as it is a mean of divine appointment, for fitting and disposing us for more spiritual and solemn exercises.

SubQuestions.Question: How does fasting appear to be a mean of divine appointment?
SubQuestions.Answer: From the practice of the saints under the Old Testament, Esth. 4:16; Dan. 10:2, 3; from the testimony of Christ, Matt. 6:17, 18, and 17:21; and the example of his apostles under the New, Acts 13:3; and 14:23.

SubQuestions.Question: What are those spiritual and solemn exercises for which fasting is designed to dispose us?
SubQuestions.Answer: Deep humiliation of soul before the Lord on account of sin, Ezra 9:6; free confession of it, Dan. 9:20, and turning from it, Joel 2:12, as the genuine fruits of our taking hold of God's covenant, Jer. 50:4, 5; together with an importunate requesting of our gracious God, for that which is the particular occasion of the fast, Psalm 35:13.

SubQuestions.Question: Is religious fasting an occasional or a stated duty?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is merely occasional and extraordinary, to be observed as the call of Providence may require and direct.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the occurrences in providence, which are a call to this extraordinary duty?
SubQuestions.Answer: "When some great and notable judgments are either inflicted upon a people," Dan. 9:3, 12-14, "or apparently imminent," 2 Chron. 20:2-4; "or, by some extraordinary provocations notoriously deserved," 1 Sam. 7:3, 6; "as also when some special blessing is to be sought and obtained,"65 ver. 5, 8, 10.

SubQuestions.Question: Is swearing by the name of God an act of immediate and instituted worship?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is undoubtedly: and that either when we devote ourselves to God in a covenant of duties, Deut. 6:13, or declare the truth upon oath, when called thereto: because, in both cases the name of God is solemnly interposed and invoked, Jer. 4:2.

SubQuestions.Question: To whom are vows to be made?
SubQuestions.Answer: To God alone, as the only party and witness in the making and performing of them, Psalm 76:11 - "Vow and pay unto the LORD your GOD."

SubQuestions.Question: What should be the subject matter of our vows to God?
SubQuestions.Answer: Nothing except what may tend either to promote the practice of commanded duty, Psalm 119:57, or prevent the commission of any sin to which we are more ordinarily inclined and addicted, verse 106.

SubQuestions.Question: What does this commandment require, with respect to all those ordinances, and parts of worship, which God has appointed in his word?
SubQuestions.Answer: The receiving and observing them; and keeping them pure and entire.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to receive God's ordinances?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to approve of, and embrace them, as bearing the stamp of his authority upon them, Psalm 84:1, 2.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to observe them?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to set about the practice of them, or to be actually employed in them, Psalm 55:17, and 119:164; Luke 2:37.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to keep the ordinances of God pure?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to contribute our utmost endeavour to preserve them from all mixture of human invention, Deut. 12:32.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to keep them entire?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is, in the exercise of faith, to attend upon each of them in its proper season, so as that one duty may not jostle out another, Luke 1:6.

SubQuestions.Question: What does God require of us in this command, with reference to all false worship?
SubQuestions.Answer: He requires "the disapproving, detesting, opposing all false worship, Psalm 16:4; and according to each one's place and calling, removing it, and all monuments of idolatry, Deut. 7:5."66:

Data.Question: What is forbidden in the Second Commandment?
Data.Answer: The Second Commandment forbiddeth the worshipping of God by images, or any other way not appointed in his word.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the leading sins forbidden in this commandment?
SubQuestions.Answer: Idolatry and will-worship.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the idolatry here condemned?
SubQuestions.Answer: The worshipping of God by images: "Thou shalt not make unto thee any graven image," &c.

SubQuestions.Question: What is an image?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is a statue, picture, or likeness of any creature whatever.

SubQuestions.Question: Is it lawful to have images or pictures of mere creatures?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes, provided they be only for ornament; or the design be merely historical, to transmit the memory of persons and their actions to posterity.

SubQuestions.Question: Can any image or representation be made of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; it is absolutely impossible; he being an infinite, incomprehensible Spirit, Isaiah 40:18 - "To whom will ye liken God? or, what likeness will ye compare unto him?" If we cannot delineate our own souls, much less the infinite God; Acts 17:29 - "We ought not to think that the Godhead is like unto gold, or silver, or stone, graven by art and man's device."

SubQuestions.Question: What judgment should we form of those who have devised images of God, or of the persons of the adorable Trinity?
SubQuestions.Answer: We should adjudge their practice to be both unlawful and abominable.

SubQuestions.Question: Why unlawful?
