SubQuestions.Question: What is it commonly called when both the guilty persons are married?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is called double adultery, as was the case between David and Bathsheba, 2 Sam. 11:3, 4.

SubQuestions.Question: Whether are the consequences to families worse, when the man is married and the woman free; or when the woman is married and the man free?
SubQuestions.Answer: The consequences to families seem to be worse when the woman is married; because a man's offspring is thus corrupted, and his inheritance is alienated to a spurious issue.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the aggravations of this heinous sin?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is a breach of the marriage oath, Mal. 2:14; an involving of two at once in the same guilt, 1 Cor. 6:16; and is a crime committed after obtaining the remedy which God has provided against it, chap. 7:2.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the fatal effects of adultery in this life?
SubQuestions.Answer: It consumes the body, Proverbs 5:11; wastes a man's estate, bringing him "to a piece of bread," chap. 6:26; and leaves an indelible blot upon his name: "His reproach shall not be wiped away," ver. 33.

SubQuestions.Question: What will be the effect of it in the life to come?
SubQuestions.Answer: Eternal wrath and damnation, if rich mercy and grace prevent it not, Eph. 5:5.

SubQuestions.Question: How does God testify his abhorrence of this sin?
SubQuestions.Answer: By declaring that he will reserve the punishment of it, in his own hand, to be inflicted in a very peculiar manner, upon such as are guilty of it, Heb. 13:4 - "Whore-mongers and adulterers God will judge."

SubQuestions.Question: What are the usual incentives to this and other acts of uncleanness?
SubQuestions.Answer: Drunkenness, Gen. 19:33; "fulness of bread, and abundance of idleness," Ezek. 16:49.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the evil of idleness?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is a deliberate wasting of precious time, to the manifest detriment both of soul and body, Eccl. 10:18; and is a fit season for temptations to lust, Proverbs 7:7, 8.

SubQuestions.Question: In what consists the evil of gluttony?
SubQuestions.Answer: It indisposes for all duty, both religious and civil, Proverbs 23:21; and is making a god of our belly, Phil. 3:19.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the evil of drunkenness?
SubQuestions.Answer: It deforms the image of God in the soul, by divesting a man of the right use of his reason; and leaves him defenceless against all temptations, Proverbs 23:29, 30.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the proper remedies against lust, and all the incentives to it?
SubQuestions.Answer: A serious reflection upon the all-seeing eye of an infinitely holy God, Gen. 39:9; walking "in the Spirit," which will preserve us from fulfilling "the lusts of the flesh," Gal. 5:16; keeping a strict watch over our hearts, Proverbs 4:23; studying to shun all occasions of this sin by the external senses, Job 31:1; and fervent prayer to God to be kept from it, and all temptations to it, Psalm 119:37.

Data.Question: Which is the Eighth Commandment?
Data.Answer: The Eighth Commandment is Thou shalt not steal.

Data.Question: What is required in the Eighth Commandment?
Data.Answer: The Eighth Commandment requireth the lawful procuring and furthering the wealth and outward estate of ourselves and others.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the subject matter of this commandment?
SubQuestions.Answer: The wealth and outward estate of ourselves and others.

SubQuestions.Question: What does it require with reference to these?
SubQuestions.Answer: The procuring and furthering of them.

SubQuestions.Question: In what manner does it enjoin us to procure and further them?
SubQuestions.Answer: Only in a lawful manner; for it requires the LAWFUL procuring and furthering of them.

SubQuestions.Question: Whose wealth is it we should procure and further?
SubQuestions.Answer: Our own wealth, and that of others.

SubQuestions.Question: By what lawful means should we procure and further OUR OWN wealth?
SubQuestions.Answer: By labour and industry in some honest calling, Eph. 4:28.

SubQuestions.Question: What is included in the labour and industry we should exercise in our respective stations and callings?
SubQuestions.Answer: Frugality in managing the affairs of our calling, and a moderate endeavour to recover our own when wrongfully detained from us.

SubQuestions.Question: What is to be understood by frugality in managing the affairs of our calling?
SubQuestions.Answer: Prudence and moderation in our expenses, so as to be sure always to spend within our incomes, Proverbs 31:16.

SubQuestions.Question: Is it warrantable to go to law, for recovering our own, when wrongfully detained?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes, surely; provided other means have been previously tried without success.

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove that it is warrantable for Christians to go to law with one another, when urged by necessity?
SubQuestions.Answer: From the lawfulness of magistracy, which is the ordinance of God, Rom. 13:2, "for the punishment of evil doers, and for the praise of them that do well," 1 Pet. 2:14.

SubQuestions.Question: Does not our Lord find fault with this method, when he says, "If any man will sue thee at the law, and take away thy coat, let him have thy cloak also?" Matt. 5:40.
SubQuestions.Answer: The meaning is, that we should rather part with a little of our right, than run ourselves into unnecessary charges at law, perhaps vastly beyond the value of what we are seeking to regain; and thus discover a contentious and quarrelsome spirit, unbecoming Christianity.

SubQuestions.Question: Does not the apostle also blame Christians for this practice, when he says, "Ye go to law one with another; why do ye not rather take wrong?" 1 Cor. 6:7.
SubQuestions.Answer: The apostle is there speaking of bringing pleas unnecessarily before Heathen magistrates; and his meaning is, that Christians should make up differences among themselves, by submitting to arbitration; or even by suffering some wrong, rather than by vexatious law-suits, (especially about lesser matters) thus bringing a scandal upon the religion which they profess.

SubQuestions.Question: How is the necessity of labouring in an honest calling enforced in scripture?
SubQuestions.Answer: From the necessity of eating: the apostle argues from the natural necessity of the one, to the moral necessity of the other, 2 Thess. 3:10 - "This we commanded you, that if any would not work, neither should he eat."

SubQuestions.Question: Can we procure and further our wealth and outward estate, merely by our own labour and industry?
SubQuestions.Answer: Our own industry is necessary; but without the Lord's blessing upon it, it will not be successful; "for it is the blessing of the Lord that maketh rich," Proverbs 10:22.

SubQuestions.Question: What ends should we propose to ourselves, in endeavouring to further, or increase, our own outward estate?
SubQuestions.Answer: That we may honour the Lord, with our substance, Proverbs 3:9; live comfortably ourselves, Eccl. 5:19; and be useful to others, Eph. 4:28.

SubQuestions.Question: By what means should we procure and further the wealth and outward estate of OTHERS?
SubQuestions.Answer: By exercising justice and righteousness towards all, Psalm 15:2; and by relieving the wants and necessities of those who stand in need of our charity, 1 John 3:17.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the rule and standard of that justice and righteousness we should exercise towards all men?
SubQuestions.Answer: That we so deal with others, as we would have them deal with us, if we were in their place or condition; or, that we should never do that to another, which, if we were in the other's place or circumstances, we would reckon to be unjust, Matt. 7:12.

SubQuestions.Question: In what cases is this rule to be particularly applied, according to the scope of this commandment?
SubQuestions.Answer: In all contracts, or matters of traffic and commerce between man and man; and likewise in making satisfaction for injuries.

SubQuestions.Question: How is it to be applied in contracts, or matters of traffic between man and man?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to be applied thus: that in buying and selling, there be always a just proportion between the price and the thing sold; or, that the sale be according to the worth or value of the goods; without taking the advantage of ignorance or poverty on either side, Gen. 23:15, 16.

SubQuestions.Question: How may the worth and value of goods be known?
SubQuestions.Answer: By this general maxim, That every thing is worth as much as it may be currently sold for.

SubQuestions.Question: May not the price of the same commodity vary and change at different times?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; according to the plenty or scarcity of the commodity at the time of sale.

SubQuestions.Question: What satisfaction should be made to others, for taking or detaining what belongs to them, or in any manner defrauding them?
SubQuestions.Answer: No other satisfaction is agreeable to God's will of precept, or will gain the approbation of men, but RESTITUTION, if the injuring party is ever capable to make it, Lev. 6:2-6; 1 Sam. 12:3.

SubQuestions.Question: What if the person to whom the restitution should be made, or his nearest of kin, cannot be found?
SubQuestions.Answer: In that case, what has been unjustly detained ought to be given to the poor, or some pious use, Num. 5:8.

SubQuestions.Question: Is relieving the necessities of the poor a duty required in this commandment?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; because it is a furthering the outward estate of our neighbour who is in want.

SubQuestions.Question: Why should we relieve the necessities of the poor?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because, "He that hath pity upon the poor, lendeth to the Lord; and that which he hath given, will he pay him again," Proverbs 19:17.

SubQuestions.Question: Who are the proper objects of Charity?
SubQuestions.Answer: All who are in real poverty and want, and are not able to work; especially those "who are of the household of faith," Gal. 6:10.

SubQuestions.Question: How should our acts of charity be managed?
SubQuestions.Answer: They should be conducted with prudence, namely, as our own circumstances will permit, and the necessity of the object requires, 1 John 3:17.

SubQuestions.Question: When should we perform acts of charity?
SubQuestions.Answer: Presently, if the necessities of those whom we are bound to relieve, call for present assistance, Proverbs 3:28.

SubQuestions.Question: What should we shun or avoid, in our acts of charity?
SubQuestions.Answer: All ostentation, or a desire to be seen of men, and commended by them, Matt. 6:2-5.

Data.Question: What is forbidden in the Eighth Commandment?
Data.Answer: The Eighth Commandment forbiddeth whatsoever doth or may unjustly hinder our own or our neighbour's wealth or outward estate.

SubQuestions.Question: What does the forbidding of THEFT necessarily suppose?
SubQuestions.Answer: That there are distinct rights and properties among men, which cannot be justly invaded or encroached upon, Lev. 6:4.

SubQuestions.Question: What would be the necessary consequences of a community of goods among men?
SubQuestions.Answer: It would destroy traffic and commerce; abolish all acts of charity; encourage sloth and idleness; and if there were no right and property there could be no encroachment upon it by theft or stealing.

SubQuestions.Question: From whom are we forbidden to steal?
SubQuestions.Answer: Both from ourselves and others.

SubQuestions.Question: How may we be said to steal from OURSELVES?
SubQuestions.Answer: By idleness, niggardliness, and prodigality.

SubQuestions.Question: How do we steal from ourselves, or impair our own estates, by idleness?
SubQuestions.Answer: When we either live without a lawful calling, Proverbs 19:15; or neglect it, if we have any, chap. 18:9.

SubQuestions.Question: How may a person be said to steal from himself by niggardliness?
SubQuestions.Answer: When he defrauds himself of the due use and comfort of that estate which God has given him, Eccl. 6:2.

SubQuestions.Question: How do persons on the other hand, steal from themselves, by prodigality?
SubQuestions.Answer: By being lavish and profuse in spending above their income, Proverbs 23:20, 21.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the sin which is more directly pointed at in this commandment?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is stealing from OTHERS; or laying hands upon, and taking away unjustly, that which is the right and property of another.

SubQuestions.Question: How many ways may persons be said to steal from others, or unjustly hinder their neighbour's wealth or outward estate?
SubQuestions.Answer: Several ways; particularly, by theft, robbery, resetting, defrauding, monopolising, and taking unlawful usury.

SubQuestions.Question: What is theft?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is the taking away clandestinely, or privily from another, that which is his, Lev. 19:11.

SubQuestions.Question: How is theft commonly distinguished?
SubQuestions.Answer: Into private and public.

SubQuestions.Question: What is private theft?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is the taking away less or more of any private person's property, without their knowledge or consent, Obadiah ver. 5.

SubQuestions.Question: Against whom is public theft committed?
SubQuestions.Answer: Both against the church and commonwealth.

SubQuestions.Question: How is public theft called, as committed against the church?
SubQuestions.Answer: Either Simony or sacrilege.

SubQuestions.Question: What is Simony?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is the buying and selling of ecclesiastical places and offices for money, or other good deeds; so called, from the wicked practice of Simon Magus, who offered the apostles "money, saying, Give me also this power, that on whomsoever I lay hands, he may receive the Holy Ghost," Acts 8:18, 19.

SubQuestions.Question: What is sacrilege?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is the taking away or alienating of any thing which has been dedicated to a sacred use, Proverbs 20:25; Mal. 3:8.

SubQuestions.Question: Why are these called public theft, when, for the most part, they are privately committed?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because they very much affect the public interest and welfare of the church; nothing having a greater tendency to her ruin, than Simoniacal compacts and sacrilegious usurpations.

SubQuestions.Question: In what consists public theft, as committed against the commonwealth?
SubQuestions.Answer: In embezzling the current coin, or doing detriment to the public for private advantage, Rom. 13:7; Phil. 2:4.

SubQuestions.Question: What is robbery or rapine?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is the taking away the goods of another by violence and open force, Job 20:19.

SubQuestions.Question: In what lies the aggravation of this crime?
SubQuestions.Answer: In its being an avowed pillaging or plundering of our neighbour; and in being ordinarily accompanied with a threatening to take away his life, if he ventures to make the least resistance, Judges 9:25.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the evil of resetting101, or receiving of what is taken away, whether by stealth or violence?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is a manifest encouragement of, and participation with thieves and robbers in their sins, Psalm 50:18; and consequently, a coming under the same guilt and condemnation with them, Proverbs 29:24.

SubQuestions.Question: How do men commonly defraud one another?
SubQuestions.Answer: In buying, selling and borrowing.

SubQuestions.Question: How do they defraud in buying?
SubQuestions.Answer: By depreciating and vilifying what they intend to buy, that they may have it cheaper than the value, Proverbs 20:14.

SubQuestions.Question: How do they defraud one another in selling?
SubQuestions.Answer: By taking an unreasonable price, 1 Thess. 4:6; or, cheating by false weights and measures, Deut. 25:13-15.

SubQuestions.Question: How do they defraud in borrowing?
SubQuestions.Answer: When they borrow what they know they can never be able, in the ordinary course of providence, to pay, Psalm 37:21.

SubQuestions.Question: If a man's creditors compound with him for less than he owes, is he therefore discharged of the whole debt?
SubQuestions.Answer: Though his creditors, for fear of losing all, may compound and discharge for a part, so that there can be no action in law for the remainder; yet, in the court of conscience, and before God, he is bound, if ever he is able, to pay every farthing: and, if he is an honest man, he will never reckon his substance his own, till he do it, Rom. 13:8.

SubQuestions.Question: How may servants defraud their masters?
SubQuestions.Answer: By wasting their masters' goods, which they may have in their hands; and not working faithfully for their wages, Titus 2:9, 10.

SubQuestions.Question: How may masters defraud their servants?
SubQuestions.Answer: By detaining from, or tricking them out of their wages, Lev. 19:13; or by exacting of them too rigorous labour, Ex. 5:9.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to monopolise?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to engross commodities, in order to enhance the price of them.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the worst kind of monopolising or forestalling?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is the buying up grain, or other provisions, in large quantities, in order to exact a higher price for them afterwards.

SubQuestions.Question: In what consists the evil of this sin?
SubQuestions.Answer: They who are guilty of it enrich themselves upon the spoils of others, Ezek. 22:29; they "grind the faces of the poor," Isaiah 3:15; and bring upon themselves the curse of the people, Proverbs 11:26 - "He that withholdeth corn, the people shall CURSE him; but blessings shall be upon the head of him that selleth it."

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to take USURY, according to the proper signification of the word?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to take gain, profit, or interest, for the loan of money.

SubQuestions.Question: What kind of usury or interest is lawful?
SubQuestions.Answer: That which is moderate, easy, and no way oppressive, Deut. 23:20, compared with Ex. 22:21.

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove that moderate usury is lawful?
SubQuestions.Answer: From the very light of nature, which teaches, that since the borrower proposes to gain by the loan, the lender should have a reasonable share of his profit, as a recompense for the use of his money, which he might otherwise have disposed of to his own advantage, 2 Cor. 8:13.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the usury condemned in scripture, and by right reason?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is the exacting of more interest or gain for the loan of money, than is settled by universal consent, and the laws of the land, Proverbs 28:8 - "He that by usury, and unjust gain, increaseth his substance, shall gather it for him that will pity the poor."

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove from scripture, that moderate usury, or common interest, is not oppression in itself?
SubQuestions.Answer: From the express command laid upon the Israelites not to "oppress a stranger," Ex. 23:9; and yet their being allowed to take usury from him, Deut. 23:20; which they would not have been permitted to do, if there had been an intrinsic evil in the thing itself.

SubQuestions.Question: Is it warrantable to take interest from the poor?
SubQuestions.Answer: By no means; for, if such as are honest, and in needy circumstances, borrow a small sum towards a livelihood, and repay it in due time, it is all that can be expected of them; and therefore the demanding of any profit or interest, or even taking any of their necessaries of life in pledge, for the sum, seems to be plainly contrary to the law of charity, Ex. 22:25-28; Psalm 15:5.

SubQuestions.Question: Were not the Israelites forbidden to take usury from their brethren, whether poor or rich? Deut. 23:19 - "Thou shalt not lend upon usury to thy brother."
SubQuestions.Answer: This text is to be restricted to their poor brethren, as it is explained, Ex. 22:25, and Lev. 25:25, 35; or, if it respects the Israelites indifferently, then it is one of the judicial laws peculiar to that people, and of no binding force now.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the spring of all these different ways by which men defraud and injure one another in their outward estate?
SubQuestions.Answer: Covetousness, Luke 12:15, or an inordinate prizing and loving of worldly goods, Psalm 62:10.

SubQuestions.Question: What should affright and deter every one from such wicked practices?
SubQuestions.Answer: The consideration of the curse that shall enter into the house of the thief, Zech. 5:3, 4; and of the vengeance that shall light upon such as go beyond and defraud their neighbour: for, "the Lord is the avenger of all such," 1 Thess. 4:6.

Data.Question: Which is the Ninth Commandment?
Data.Answer: The Ninth Commandment is, Thou shalt not bear false witness against thy neighbour.

Data.Question: What is required in the Ninth Commandment?
Data.Answer: The Ninth Commandment requireth the maintaining and promoting of truth between man and man, and of our own and our neighbour's good name, especially in witness-bearing.

SubQuestions.Question: In what does the Ninth Commandment differ from the three preceding ones?
SubQuestions.Answer: The three commands immediately preceding, have a respect to the injuries that may be done to ourselves or others by deeds or actions; but the ninth has a reference to wrongs done by words.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the general duty required in this commandment?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is the maintaining and promoting of truth between man and man.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the TRUTH, between man and man, we are required to maintain and promote?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is the strict veracity of our words or speeches, in whatever we assert or deny; whether in our ordinary conversation, or in our oaths, promises, bargains, and contracts, Zech. 8:16 - "Speak ye every man the truth to his neighbour."

SubQuestions.Question: In what consists the strict veracity that ought to be in our words and speeches?
SubQuestions.Answer: In uttering things as they really are in themselves, according to our belief of them; that is, that there be an exact agreement and harmony between our thoughts, words, and the things themselves, Psalm 15:1, 2 - "Who shall dwell in thy holy hill? He that - speaketh truth is his heart."

SubQuestions.Question: Why will God have nothing to be uttered but strict truth?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because he is "a God of truth, and without iniquity; just and right is he," Deut. 32:4.

SubQuestions.Question: Is it lawful at any time to conceal part of the truth?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; when neither the glory of God, nor our own, or our neighbour's good requires that the whole of it be told; only no untruth must be uttered in concealing it, 1 Sam. 16:2, 5.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the chief end for which the tongue or gift of speech is conferred upon us?
SubQuestions.Answer: That we may thus glorify God by praying to, Psalm 50:15, and praising him, verse 23; and by contending earnestly for, Jude verse 3, and confessing his truth, Rom. 10:10; hence is the tongue called our glory, Psalm 30:12 - "To the end that my GLORY (that is, my tongue, as on the margin) may sing praise unto thee, and not be silent."

SubQuestions.Question: What is the subordinate end of it?
SubQuestions.Answer: The edification and profit of our fellow-creatures, Eph. 4:29 - "Let no corrupt communication proceed out of your mouth, but that which is good, to the use of edifying;" (margin, "to edify profitably,") in opposition to the insipid and vain talk which is in the mouths of most men.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the particular duty required in the Ninth Commandment?
SubQuestions.Answer: That we maintain and promote our own and our neighbour's good name, especially in witness-bearing.

SubQuestions.Question: What is a good name?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is the having of reputation and esteem, especially among the sober and religious, Psalm 16:3, and 101:6.

SubQuestions.Question: How may a good name be obtained?
SubQuestions.Answer: By being useful in the world, in the several stations and relations in which adorable providence has placed us, Psalm 112:9.

SubQuestions.Question: Is self-commendation a fit mean to obtain a good name?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; it is ordinarily the highway to procure scorn and contempt, 2 Cor. 10:12.

SubQuestions.Question: Does not the apostle commend himself, when he says, "In nothing am I behind the very chiefest apostles?" 2 Cor. 12:11.
SubQuestions.Answer: He only magnifies and exalts his office, and at the same time lessens and disparages himself; for, although he says, "In nothing am I behind the very chiefest apostles," yet he immediately subjoins, "though I be nothing;" and 1 Cor. 15:9 - "I am the least of the apostles, who am not meet to be called an apostle, because I persecuted the church of God."

SubQuestions.Question: May we not commend the grace of God in us?
SubQuestions.Answer: To be sure we may; for, whatever is spoken to the commendation of free grace, is for the abasement of self, 1 Cor. 15:10 - "By the grace of God I am what I am."

SubQuestions.Question: How ought we to maintain and promote our own good name?
SubQuestions.Answer: Not only by a blameless walk and conversation before the world, Phil, 2:15; but likewise by vindicating ourselves from the calumnies and aspersions that may be injuriously cast upon us, Acts 24:12, 13.

SubQuestions.Question: With what frame of spirit ought the lawful vindication of ourselves to be managed?
SubQuestions.Answer: With moderation, meekness, and readiness to forgive those who have reproached and injured us, Col. 3:12, 13.

SubQuestions.Question: Who ought, in a special manner, to maintain and promote their own good name?
SubQuestions.Answer: This is especially incumbent on professors of religion, Matt. 5:16; and such as are in places of public trust, Titus 2:7, 8.

SubQuestions.Question: Why should professors be careful to maintain their good name?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because the loss of it tends to reflect dishonour on religion, by which the enemies of it take occasion to blaspheme, 2 Sam. 12:14.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the advantage of a good name?
SubQuestions.Answer: A good name procures mutual love to, and confidence in one another; and, consequently, tends to promote the interests both of sacred and civil society; on which account "a good name" is said to be "better than precious ointment," Eccl. 7:1; and "rather to be chosen than great riches," Proverbs 22:1.

SubQuestions.Question: What does this command require in reference to our neighbour's good name?
SubQuestions.Answer: The maintaining and promoting it, "as we would do our own," Phil. 2:4; and that both in his presence and in his absence.

SubQuestions.Question: How should we behave in the presence of our neighbour, for maintaining and promoting of his good name?
SubQuestions.Answer: When we observe any thing faulty in him, which deserves present notice, we should reprove it with meekness and love, Lev. 19:17; and what is really commendable we should prudently encourage and applaud, Rom. 1:8.

SubQuestions.Question: How should we maintain and promote the good name of others in their absence?
SubQuestions.Answer: By commending what is praise-worthy in them, 3 John ver. 12; vindicating their character when unjustly attacked, Proverbs 25:23; and by covering their infirmities and blemishes, so far as can be done in a consistency with truth, and the credit of religion, 1 Pet. 4:8.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is the word ESPECIALLY subjoined to witness-bearing?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because, as we should give testimony to truth on all occasions, so, in a special manner, when called by lawful authority to declare the matter of fact upon oath, Jer. 4:2.

SubQuestions.Question: What special obligation lies upon us, to declare the true matter of fact, between man and man, when called to do it upon oath?
SubQuestions.Answer: In an oath, God is appealed to, that we will declare nothing but the truth, as we shall answer to him at the great day; and therefore, our doing otherwise, either out of hatred, or favour, is laying ourselves open to his immediate wrath and displeasure, according to Mal. 3:5 - "I will be a swift witness - against false swearers, - saith the Lord of hosts."

Data.Question: What is forbidden in the Ninth Commandment?
Data.Answer: The Ninth Commandment forbiddeth whatsoever is prejudicial to truth, or injurious to our own or our neighbour's good name.

SubQuestions.Question: What does this command forbid in general?
SubQuestions.Answer: Whatsoever is prejudicial to truth.

SubQuestions.Question: What are we to understand, by that which is prejudicial to truth?
SubQuestions.Answer: All falsehood and lying of whatever kind, James 3:14 - "Lie not against the truth."

SubQuestions.Question: What is the formal nature and meaning of a LIE?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is voluntarily to speak or express what we know to be false, as the old prophet at Bethel did to the man of God, 1 Kings 13:18.

SubQuestions.Question: How is a lie aggravated?
SubQuestions.Answer: When it is uttered with a design to deceive, and to harm others by it; like the devil, when he said, "Ye shall not surely die. - Ye shall be as gods, knowing good and evil," Gen. 3:4, 5.

SubQuestions.Question: May not persons utter what is untrue or false and yet not be guilty of a lie?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; and that either through ignorance or misinformation.

SubQuestions.Question: When may they be said to utter what is false through ignorance, and yet not be guilty of lying?
SubQuestions.Answer: When they speak rashly, according to their present conception of things, without due examination; as the barbarians, when they "saw the venomous beast hang on Paul's hand, said: among themselves, No doubt this man is a murderer," &c., Acts 28:4.

SubQuestions.Question: When may we utter what is false through misinformation, and not be guilty of a lie?
SubQuestions.Answer: When we speak according to the report we have had from others, without any suspicion of being imposed upon; as Jacob did, when, by the imposition of his sons, (who had sold Joseph into Egypt, and dipped his coat in he blood of a kid) he said, "It is my son's coat; an evil beast, hath devoured him: Joseph is without doubt rent in pieces," Gen. 37:33.

SubQuestions.Question: How many sorts of lies are there?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are commonly ranked into three sorts; namely, ludicrous, pernicious, and officious lies.

SubQuestions.Question: What is a ludicrous or jocose lie?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is when persons relate things they know to be false, with a design to make a jest or diversion to others.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to be guilty of a pernicious lied?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to contrive or spread some malicious report we know or suspect to be false, on purpose to bring about some hurt or damage to another, as Ziba did against Mephibosheth, 2 Sam. 16:3.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the aggravation of a pernicious lie?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is the very worst sort of lying, being both a contempt of the omniscient God, who is witness to the falsehood; and a deliberate intention to do injury to our neighbour, though in our conscience we believe him innocent of what we lay to his charge.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it for a person to make an officious lie?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to tell a downright untruth, for their own, or their neighbour's safety and security in time of danger, as Rahab did who hid the spies in the roof of her house, and yet alleged they were gone out of the city, and that she knew not where they went, Josh. 2:4-6.

SubQuestions.Question: Does not the apostle ascribe this action of hers to her faith, when he says, Heb. 11:31 - "By faith, Rahab, the harlot, perished not with them that believed not, when she had received the spies with peace?"
SubQuestions.Answer: No; What he ascribes to her faith is, her having received the spies with peace, that is, her having consulted their safety and preservation with the greatest care and diligence; but not the lie she invented in order to conceal them. Her protecting the spies is commended, but not the manner in which she did it.

SubQuestions.Question: Who are they that plead in favour of officious lies?
SubQuestions.Answer: The Papists, Socinians, and most of our modern moralists.

SubQuestions.Question: What arguments do they allege in defence of this sort of lying?
SubQuestions.Answer: That it has been practised by saints in scripture; and that it is so far from being hurtful to any, that it has been beneficial to some in certain cases.

SubQuestions.Question: What answer is to be given to the practice of the saints in this matter?
SubQuestions.Answer: That their sinful failures, in this and other instances, are not recorded in scripture for imitation, but for caution and warning, that we fall not into the same snares.

SubQuestions.Question: How do you answer the other argument for officious lying, "That it is so far from being hurtful to any, that it has been beneficial and advantageous to some, in certain cases, particularly in saving the life of a dear friend, or useful member of society, which might otherwise have been manifestly endangered?"
SubQuestions.Answer: It is answered thus, that in no case are we to do evil that good may come, Rom. 3:8. If we are not to speak wickedly for God, nor talk deceitfully for him, according to Job 13:7, neither are we to do so, though it were for the benefit of all mankind, or the best among them.

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove lying to be sinful, or unlawful, in itself?
SubQuestions.Answer: From this, that lying of all sorts, without exception, is condemned in scripture, as hateful and abominable to God, Proverbs 6:17, 19, and 12:22; Col. 3:9.

SubQuestions.Question: Who is the author and father of lies?
SubQuestions.Answer: The devil, John 8:44 - "When he speaketh a lie, he speaketh of his own; for he is a liar, and the father of it."

SubQuestions.Question: How does God testify his displeasure against lying of all kinds?
SubQuestions.Answer: By declaring that "he who speaketh lies shall perish," Proverbs 19:9; accordingly it is said, "ALL liars shall have their part in the lake which burneth with fire and brimstone," Rev. 21:8.

SubQuestions.Question: What is more particularly forbidden in this commandment, according to the answer?
SubQuestions.Answer: Whatever is injurious to our own or our neighbour's good name.

SubQuestions.Question: How may we injure our own good name?
SubQuestions.Answer: By a vain-glorious commendation of ourselves, 2 Tim 3:2; by despising of others who ought justly to be esteemed, Luke 18:9, 11; or by doing any thing scandalous and offensive in the eye of the world, 1 Sam. 2:17, 30.

SubQuestions.Question: In what may we be injurious to our neighbour's good name?
SubQuestions.Answer: By flattering him to his face, Proverbs 28:4; by defaming him behind his back, Psalm 50:20; or by bearing false witness against him in public judicature, Ezek. 22:9.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the evil of flattering our neighbour to his face?
SubQuestions.Answer: It tends to foster and foment his pride, and thus to bring on his ruin, Proverbs 26:28 - "A flattering mouth worketh ruin."

SubQuestions.Question: What is the evil of defaming him behind his back?
SubQuestions.Answer: Nothing can be more devilish and malicious, than to fix calumny and reproach upon one, when he is not present to vindicate and defend himself: hence the same original word, which is rendered slanderer, 1 Tim. 3:11, is used also to signify the devil, 1 Pet. 5:8.

SubQuestions.Question: Who are they that maybe guilty of bearing false witness against their neighbour in public judicature?
SubQuestions.Answer: The prosecutor, defendant, witness, advocate, and judge, may each of them be guilty in this way.

SubQuestions.Question: How may the prosecutor be guilty?
SubQuestions.Answer: In making an unjust demand upon the defendant, Acts 24:5; or laying to his charge that of which he believes him to be innocent, chap. 25:7.

SubQuestions.Question: How is the defendant, upon the other hand, chargeable with guilt in this matter?
SubQuestions.Answer: By artful and dilatory evasions, by which the plaintiff is put to needless trouble and charge in the obtaining of justice.

SubQuestions.Question: How may witnesses, in public judicature, be injurious to their neighbour's good name?
SubQuestions.Answer: Not only by the heinous sin of bearing testimony to a downright falsehood, but likewise by denying, mincing, or keeping back the truth, or any part of it.

SubQuestions.Question: When are advocates or attorneys guilty in this way?
SubQuestions.Answer: When they take in hand to plead and maintain a bad cause, looking on it as a part of their profession to be as warm and zealous in defending what is wrong, as what is just and right.

SubQuestions.Question: How may the judge be guilty of bearing false witness?
SubQuestions.Answer: By a rash, partial, and iniquitous sentence; thus perverting justice, and injuring the innocent, like Pilate, Matt. 27:24, 26.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the evil of injuring our neighbour in his good name?
SubQuestions.Answer: It robs him of a most valuable treasure; for, if once his good name or character is sunk, his further usefulness in the world is, to all appearance, irrecoverably gone.

SubQuestions.Question: What should affright and deter us from the sins of the tongue, forbidden in this commandment?
SubQuestions.Answer: That we are to answer, in the last and great day for our words, as well as our actions, Matt. 12:36, 37 - "Every idle word that men shall speak, they shall give account thereof in the day of judgment; for, by thy words thou shalt be justified, and by thy words thou shalt be condemned."

Data.Question: Which is the Tenth Commandment?
Data.Answer: The Tenth Commandment is, Thou shalt not covet thy neighbour's house, thou shalt not covet thy neighbour's wife, nor his man-servant, nor his maidservant, nor his ox, nor his ass, nor any thing that is thy neighbour's.

Data.Question: What is required in the Tenth Commandment?
Data.Answer: The Tenth Commandment requireth full contentment with our own condition, with a right and charitable frame of spirit toward our neighbour, and all that is his.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the practice of the Papists with reference to the Tenth Commandment?
SubQuestions.Answer: They have; (in some of their formularies,) erased the Second Commandment, because contrary to their image worship; therefore, in order to keep up the number TEN, they split THIS into two, making these words, "Thou shalt not covet thy neighbour's house," to be the ninth; and, "Thou shalt not covet thy neighbour's wife," &c. to be the tenth.

SubQuestions.Question: How are they confuted?
SubQuestions.Answer: By the words of this commandment (as they are here inserted from Ex. 20:17,) being transposed into a different order in Deut. 5:21; where desiring our neighbour's wife is put before coveting of his house; which is a plain evidence, that what the Papists make two is but one undivided precept; otherwise what, according to them, is the ninth in the one place, will be the tenth in the other.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the general duty required in this commandment?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is an inward disposition and inclination of the whole soul, to perform all the duties contained in the law, particularly in the second table, which this commandment more immediately respects; and that out of love to God, and a desire to please him, Psalm 119:5, 47.

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove this to be the general duty required?
SubQuestions.Answer: From the general sin forbidden; namely, COVETOUSNESS, which includes the motion or stirring of corruption against all the commands of the law, because of their holiness and contrariety to depraved nature, Rom. 7:7, 8.

SubQuestions.Question: What inward disposition of soul does this commandment require with reference to ourselves in particular?
SubQuestions.Answer: It requires, with reference to ourselves, full contentment with our own condition, 1 Tim. 6:6.

SubQuestions.Question: What do you understand by full contentment with our own condition?
SubQuestions.Answer: A cheerful acquiescence in the lot which God, in his holy and wise providence, is pleased to carve out for us in this world, Heb. 13:5 - "Be content with such things as ye have."

SubQuestions.Question: Is full contentment with our own condition attainable in this life?
SubQuestions.Answer: Though the perfection of no grace is attainable in this life, yet a great measure, and eminent degrees of grace, particularly this of contentment, may be, and has been, attained by the saints in this world, Phil. 4:11 - "I have learned, in whatever state I am, therewith to be content."

SubQuestions.Question: Is contentment, in a prosperous condition, an easy attainment?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; without grace it cannot be attained; because, naturally, our ambitious and covetous desires increase in proportion to our riches; as is evident in the instance of Ahab, whom a kingdom could not satisfy without Naboth's vineyard, 1 Kings 21:4.

SubQuestions.Question: How is true contentment attained under prosperous circumstances?
SubQuestions.Answer: By looking above all the enjoyments of time as transitory and vain, to God himself, as our chief good and eternal inheritance, Psalm 62:10, and 16:5, 6.

SubQuestions.Question: Is contentment likewise required under cross dispensations of providence; such as, poverty, reproach, bodily afflictions, and loss of near relations?
SubQuestions.Answer: Though it be a grievous sin to be stupidly insensible and unconcerned under these or the like circumstances, Hos. 7:9; yet a contentment of submission, or such as is without repining and murmuring, is, undoubtedly, required under the severest troubles that can befall us in this life, Lam. 3:39 - "Wherefore doth a living man complain, a man for the punishment of his sins?" And, Ezra. 9:13 "...seeing that thou our God hast punished us less than our iniquities deserve,"

SubQuestions.Question: What ground of contentment have we under outward poverty and want?
SubQuestions.Answer: That, though we be the poor of this world, yet we may be "rich in faith, and heirs of the kingdom," James 2:5.

SubQuestions.Question: Why should we bear reproach without murmuring?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because whatever reproach is cast upon us for Christ's sake, he will wipe it clean off at his second appearing, Luke 22:28, 29; Matt. 25:34.

SubQuestions.Question: What reason for contentment have we under bodily afflictions?
SubQuestions.Answer: That they are only of short duration, 2 Cor. 4:17; mixed with mercy, Lam. 3:32; consistent with love, John 11:3; and designed for "our profit, that we might be partakers of his holiness," Heb. 12:10.

SubQuestions.Question: What should content and comfort us under the loss of near and dear relations?
SubQuestions.Answer: That the Lord Jesus, who stands in every amiable relation to us, is always at hand, being "the same yesterday, today, and for ever," Heb. 13:8.

SubQuestions.Question: Are we required to be content under divine desertion, or the want of the sense of the love of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: Though we have no reason to quarrel with God, for withdrawing the light of his countenance, which we never deserved; yet it is impossible for any gracious soul to be easy and content under the hidings of his face, but it must needs earnestly long for, and ardently breathe after the returns of his love; as is evident from the example and practice of the saints, in the following texts, Job 23:3, and 29:2, 3; Psalm 13:1, 42:1, 2, and 84:2.

SubQuestions.Question: What inward frame or disposition of soul does the Tenth Commandment require with reference to our neighbour?
SubQuestions.Answer: It requires a right and charitable frame of spirit toward him, and all that is his, Rom. 12:16.

SubQuestions.Question: When may we be said to have this right and charitable frame of spirit here required?
SubQuestions.Answer: When our inward motions and affections are influenced by grace, to sway and determine us to promote and rejoice in the welfare of our neighbour, both as to his spiritual and temporal concerns, 1 Cor. 13:4-8.

SubQuestions.Question: When may it be evident to ourselves, that we have a right and charitable frame of spirit towards those who excel us in gifts and graces?
SubQuestions.Answer: When, under an humbling sense of our own defects, we are thankful for the honour that is brought to God, by the shining of his gifts or graces in others, Gal. 1:23, 24.

SubQuestions.Question: What should induce us to a right and charitable frame of spirit towards those that are in more prosperous circumstances than ourselves; or whose condition in the world is better than our own?
SubQuestions.Answer: The considering that a flourishing condition in the world is not always the best, Psalm 38:16; that if we enjoy communion with God, it is infinitely preferable to all outward prosperity without it, Psalm 16:5, 6.

SubQuestions.Question: How may such a right and charitable frame of spirit be attained?
SubQuestions.Answer: Only by the implantation of faith, as the root of this and all other motions of the soul that are acceptable to God, Heb. 11:6; Rom. 14:23.

Data.Question: What is forbidden in the Tenth Commandment?
Data.Answer: The Tenth Commandment forbiddeth all discontentment with our own estate, envying or grieving at the good of our neighbour, and all inordinate motions and affections to any thing that is his.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the leading sin forbidden in this commandment?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is COVETOUSNESS: Thou shalt not covet.

SubQuestions.Question: What is covetousness?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is an excessive and irregular desire after those worldly goods which we have not, Proverbs 1:19, and which God, in his providence, does not see meet that we should have, Psalm 75:6, 7.

SubQuestions.Question: How does the excess of an avaricious mind discover itself?
SubQuestions.Answer: By such an insatiable thirst after worldly gain, as can never be satisfied, Proverbs 30:15.

SubQuestions.Question: In what consists the irregularity of covetousness?
SubQuestions.Answer: In the desire of worldly goods which are in the possession of our neighbour, and even sometimes as they are his, 1 Kings 21:2.

SubQuestions.Question: How does the covetousness of the heart discover itself?
SubQuestions.Answer: By discontentment with our own estate, and envying or grieving at the good of our neighbour.

SubQuestions.Question: What is discontentment with our own estate?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to murmur and fret at our present condition in the world, as being worse than we think should fall to our share, or than we are expecting and looking for, 2 Kings 6:33.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the aggravation of this sin?
SubQuestions.Answer: It argues an unwillingness to be at God's disposal, Psalm 12:4; an esteeming ourselves more competent judges than he, of what is best for us, 1 Kings 1:5; and it is, in effect, usurping the throne of God, and taking his government into our own hands, Ex. 5:2.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the proper remedies against it?
SubQuestions.Answer: The only sovereign remedy, is to give Christ the pre-eminence in our hearts, Psalm 73:25; for then we will undervalue all temporal things, in comparison of him, Psalm 76:4.

SubQuestions.Question: What is envying or grieving at the good of our neighbour?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to repine and grudge at his prosperous circumstances, Neh. 2:10, or any superior endowment or privilege he is possessed of above ourselves, Psalm 112:9, 10.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the evil of this sin?
SubQuestions.Answer: It wastes and consumes the body, Proverbs 14:30 - "Envy is the rottenness of the bones," and it is fertile of "confusion, and every evil work," James 3:16.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the source or spring of covetousness?
SubQuestions.Answer: The inordinate motions and affections that are in our souls.

SubQuestions.Question: What do you understand by the inordinate motions and affections here forbidden?
SubQuestions.Answer: Not only the unlawful purposes, intentions, and desires, that are actually formed in the heart, but even the first risings and stirrings of corruption in the soul, which are antecedent to the consent of the will, Gen. 6:5.

SubQuestions.Question: Are not the vicious lusts and desires that are, formed and assented to in the heart, forbidden in other commandments of the second table, as well as in this?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; as appears from our Saviour's exposition of the Seventh Commandment, Matt. 5:28 - "But I say unto you, Whosoever looketh on a woman to lust after her, hath committed adultery with her already in his heart."

SubQuestions.Question: How then is this commandment distinguished from others, which forbid heart sins equally with it?
SubQuestions.Answer: This commandment is levelled particularly at the root of all sin, namely, habitual lust, or corruption of nature, together with its very first motions, and especially as these are contrary to the love of our neighbour; whereas, other commandments chiefly respect such secret and heart sins as are actually committed, though not known to the world.

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear that this commandment is levelled particularly at habitual lust, or at the root of all sin?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because, since other commandments chiefly forbid heart sins actually formed, this commandment must forbid the very rise of them, or the least bias and inclination to evil; otherwise it would not be distinct from the rest, nor would the law be absolutely perfect.

SubQuestions.Question: Does not the apostle James distinguish between lust and sin, chap. 1:15 - "When lust hath conceived it bringeth forth sin;" and will it not from thence follow, that lust, or corruption of nature, is not properly sin, and consequently not forbidden in this commandment?
SubQuestions.Answer: The apostle distinguishes between lust and sin merely as a corrupt principle and the act which it produces; both which are hateful to God, and contrary to his law.

SubQuestions.Question: If lust, or corruption of nature, cannot be remedied, or extirpated by any prescription in the Divine law, why is it at all prohibited?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is nevertheless prohibited, both because contrary to the nature of God, and as a mean to reprove and humble us for it, Rom. 7:9.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the difference between human and Divine laws on this head?
SubQuestions.Answer: Human laws respect only overt or open acts of sin, but Divine laws respect likewise the internal inclination and disposition which persons have to commit it, Psalm 66:18.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the opinion of the Papists concerning the prohibition of habitual lust?
SubQuestions.Answer: They pretend that the law of God respects only the corruption of our actions, but not the habit or principle from whence they proceed.

SubQuestions.Question: How are they refuted?
SubQuestions.Answer: From the spirituality of the law, which extends to the motions of the heart, as well as the actions of the life, Rom. 7:14, 23.

SubQuestions.Question: If, the first motions of corruption are not entertained, but immediately curbed and restrained, why are they prohibited as sinful?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because, however soon they are curbed or restrained; yet having once been in the soul, they cannot but leave a stain and pollution behind them, contrary to the holiness and purity required in the law, James 1:14.

SubQuestions.Question: Who are they that are sensible of these inordinate motions and affections of the heart, and are humbled for the same?
SubQuestions.Answer: None properly but the regenerate; as is evident from the instance of the apostle, who says of himself, after his conversion, "I had not known lust, except the law had said, Thou shalt not covet," Rom. 7:7.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the apostle's meaning in these words?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is, as if he had said, I had not known this strong propensity that is in my heart to all manner of sin, even before it be consented to, or deliberately committed; unless the Spirit of God had discovered it to me, in this precept of the law forbidding the same.

SubQuestions.Question: How does this propensity to sin evidence itself?
SubQuestions.Answer: In that no sooner is the object presented, than instantly there is an inordinate motion and affection of the heart after it. The combustible matter within catches fire at the very first spark of temptation, Josh. 7:21.

SubQuestions.Question: What may we learn from the general scope of this, and all the other commandments?
SubQuestions.Answer: That though we could forbear the evil, and do the good contained in every commandment, it would not be sufficient, except we did it for the Lord's sake, out of love to him, and regard to his authority, Ezek. 20:19.

Data.Question: Is any man able perfectly to keep the commandments of God?
Data.Answer: No mere man, since the fall, is able, in this life perfectly to keep the commandments of God, but doth daily break them, in thought, word, and deed.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it perfectly to keep the commandments of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is, from a nature perfectly holy, to yield constant and uninterrupted obedience to them, both in heart and life, Matt. 22:37, 39.

SubQuestions.Question: Was ever any man, in this world, able to keep the commandments of God in this manner?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; Adam, before his fall, was able to give perfect obedience to them all, Eccl. 7:29 - "God made man upright."

SubQuestions.Question: Whether was Adam's ability to keep the commandments of God, concreated with him, or, was it a superadded gift?
SubQuestions.Answer: It was concreated with him, as being made after the image of God, Gen. 1:27.

SubQuestions.Question: Has none, since the fall, been able to keep them perfectly?
SubQuestions.Answer: No mere man has ever been able to do it, since that time, Rom. 3:9, 10.

SubQuestions.Question: What do you understand by a mere man?
SubQuestions.Answer: One who is no more than a man; and all Adam's family, descending from him by ordinary generation, are only mere men, Acts 17:26.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is the limitation of no mere man inserted in the answer?
SubQuestions.Answer: That Christ might be excepted, who is infinitely more than a man, being IMMANUEL, "God with us," Matt. 1:23.

SubQuestions.Question: Why should HE be excepted?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because he not only yielded perfect obedience to the law in our nature, but an obedience meritorious of life, for all his spiritual seed, Matt. 3:15; Rom. 5:17, 19.

SubQuestions.Question: Do not the saints, in this life, keep the commandments of God perfectly?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; "for there is not a just man upon earth, that doeth good, and sinneth not," Eccl. 7:20.

SubQuestions.Question: Will they ever be capable of doing it?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; when they come to heaven, where they are made perfect, Heb. 12:23; and where "the former things are passed away," Rev. 21:4.

SubQuestions.Question: Why are they not able perfectly to keep them in this life?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because of the remains of corruption cleaving to every one of them, while in this world, Rom. 7:23; and from which they long to be delivered, verse 24.

SubQuestions.Question: But may not grace received in this life enable them to keep the commandments of God perfectly?
SubQuestions.Answer: There is no promise of any such grace, nor would it be consistent with the gradual nature of spiritual growth, as the saints do not arrive at their full stature till they come to glory, 1 Thess. 3:13.

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear from scripture, that the saints cannot attain perfection in this life?
SubQuestions.Answer: The scripture expressly affirms, that "in many things they offend all," James 3:2; and it records the failings and infirmities of the most eminent of them that ever lived, such as Abraham, Gen. 20:2; Moses, Psalm 106:33; David, 2 Sam. 11:4, 15; Peter, Matt. 26:72, 74; and many others.

SubQuestions.Question: Do not the saints themselves ingenuously acknowledge, that they cannot attain perfection while here?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; Job 9:20 - "If I say, I am perfect, it shall also prove me perverse." Paul, likewise, Phil. 3:12 - "Not as though I had already attained, or were already perfect."

SubQuestions.Question: But is it not said that Noah, Gen. 6:9; Hezekiah, Isaiah 38:3; and Job, Job 1:8, were each of them perfect?
SubQuestions.Answer: The perfection ascribed to them, is only comparative; that is, they were more holy and circumspect than many others; but it cannot be understood of absolute perfection, as their sins and blemishes stand also upon record: Noah, for drunkenness, Gen. 9:21; Hezekiah, for ingratitude, 2 Chron. 32:25; and Job, for some degree of impatience under the rod, chap. 3.

SubQuestions.Question: If the saints cannot attain perfection in this life, why is it said, that they do not commit sin? 1 John 3:9 - "Whosoever is born of God, doth not commit sin."
SubQuestions.Answer: The meaning is, they do not take pleasure and delight in sin, nor make a trade of it, as unregenerate persons do, who are therefore called "the workers of iniquity," Psalm 125:5.

SubQuestions.Question: Is not the perfection of sincerity attainable by the saints?
SubQuestions.Answer: They may attain to a very high and eminent degree of sincerity in this world, Psalm 18:23; 2 Cor. 1:12; but the absolute perfection of this, or any other grace, is not to be expected by them, till they come to heaven, 1 Cor. 13:12.

SubQuestions.Question: Will they not be accepted upon such sincerity as they can attain to, though short of the perfection required in the law?
SubQuestions.Answer: Their acceptance before God is not founded on their sincerity, or any other branch of their sanctification; but solely in their justification, by which the "righteousness of the law" is fulfilled in them, in virtue of the surety righteousness imputed to them, Rom. 8:4; and thus they are "accepted in the Beloved," Eph. 1:6.

SubQuestions.Question: Since none of mankind are able, in this life, perfectly to keep the commandments of God, how often does the answer say that they break them?
SubQuestions.Answer: It says that they break them daily or continually, Gen. 6:5.

SubQuestions.Question: In what do they daily break them?
SubQuestions.Answer: They do it in thought, word, and deed.

SubQuestions.Question: Is there any other possible way of breaking the commandments of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; there is no other way of breaking any of them, (as to actual transgression,) than either in our thoughts, words, or deeds; and our doing so, in all these respects, shows the justice of that charge which the Lord has against every one of us, Jer. 3:5 - "Behold, thou hast spoken and done evil things as thou couldst."

SubQuestions.Question: How do we break the commandments of God in our THOUGHTS?
SubQuestions.Answer: When our thoughts are sinfully employed either with reference to God, ourselves, or our neighbours.

SubQuestions.Question: When are our thoughts sinfully employed about God?
SubQuestions.Answer: When they are entertaining unworthy and unbecoming notions and conceptions of him, Psalm 50:21, and 94:7, such as reflect dishonour upon his perfections and providence, Zeph. 1:12; or such as are inconsistent with the discovery he has made of himself, as being "in Christ reconciling the world to himself," 2 Cor. 5:19.

SubQuestions.Question: When are our thoughts sinfully exercised about ourselves?
SubQuestions.Answer: When they are gratifying our pride, Obadiah ver. 3, ambition, Isaiah 14:13, 14, and self-applause, Rom. 12:3.

SubQuestions.Question: When are they sinfully employed about our neighbours?
SubQuestions.Answer: When they are meditating and indulging envy, Gen. 4:15; reproach, Jer. 20:10; or revenge against them, Gen. 27:41.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the aggravating evil and malignity of sinful thoughts?
SubQuestions.Answer: The evil and malignity of them consists in this, that they are the immediate source and spring from whence all our sinful words and deeds flow; "for out of the abundance of the heart the mouth speaketh," Matt. 12:34.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the proper remedy and antidote against sinful thoughts?
SubQuestions.Answer: The Spirit's taking the things of Christ, and showing them unto us, John 16:14, by which they will become the subject matter of our meditation and highest esteem: "for where the treasure is, there will be the heart also," Matt. 6:21.

SubQuestions.Question: How do men break the commandments of God by their WORDS?
SubQuestions.Answer: When, besides idle and unprofitable words, Matt. 12:36, they utter such as are more directly dishonouring to God, Psalm 73:9, 11, and hurtful and prejudicial to themselves and others, Psalm 140:3.

SubQuestions.Question: How do they break them by their DEEDS?
SubQuestions.Answer: When those sins are committed, which have been conceived in the thought, and uttered by the tongue; being inconceivably more than can be condescended upon, "for, innumerable evils have compassed us about," Psalm 40:12.

SubQuestions.Question: What may we learn from man's inability to keep the commandments perfectly in this life?
SubQuestions.Answer: That we must be wholly indebted to the free grace of God, for salvation and eternal life, Titus 3:5, and not to any thing in ourselves, who are, at best, but unprofitable servants, Luke 17:10.

Data.Question: Are all transgressions of the law equally heinous?
Data.Answer: Some sins in themselves, and by reason of several aggravations, are more heinous in the sight of God than others.

SubQuestions.Question: What do you understand by some sins being more heinous than others?
SubQuestions.Answer: That they are more abominable, hateful, and offensive to God than others are, Ezek. 8:6, 13, 15.

SubQuestions.Question: Are not all sins hateful, and offensive to God?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; but not equally so, Matt. 7:3 - "Why beholdest thou the MOTE that is in thy brother's eye, but considerest not the BEAM that is in thine own eye?"

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear that all sins are not equally offensive to God?
SubQuestions.Answer: From the different degrees of punishment that shall be inflicted in the other world, Matt. 11:22 - "But I say unto you, it shall be more tolerable for Tyre and Sidon in the day of judgment than for you." See also Luke 12:47, 48.

SubQuestions.Question: In whose sight are some sins more heinous than others?
SubQuestions.Answer: In the sight of God, who is the best judge of the heinousness of sins, Job 36:9.

SubQuestions.Question: In what respects are some sins more heinous in the sight of God than others?
SubQuestions.Answer: Some are more heinous in themselves, and some are so by reason of several aggravations.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it for sins to be heinous in themselves?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to be heinous in their own nature, though no other aggravating circumstances should attend them.

SubQuestions.Question: How are these sins, that are in their own nature more heinous than others, commonly ranked?
SubQuestions.Answer: Sins committed more immediately against God, or the first table of his law, are more heinous in their own nature, than sins committed more immediately against man, or any precept of the second table. Likewise, some sins against the second table, are more heinous in themselves, than other sins against the said table.

SubQuestions.Question: What examples are usually given of both these?
SubQuestions.Answer: Blasphemy against God, is more heinous in its own nature, than defaming, or speaking evil of our neighbour, 1 Sam. 2:25; and adultery is more heinous than theft, Proverbs 6:30, to the end of the chapter.

SubQuestions.Question: "What are those aggravations that make some sins more heinous than others?"
SubQuestions.Answer: "Sins receive their aggravation, 1. From the persons offending. 2. From the parties offended. 3. From the nature and quality of the offence. 4. From the circumstances of time and place."102

SubQuestions.Question: How may the persons OFFENDING be viewed?
SubQuestions.Answer: They may be viewed, either as to their age, gifts, or office.

SubQuestions.Question: What aggravation arises from the age of the persons offending?
SubQuestions.Answer: If persons are advanced in years, by which they may be supposed to have more experience, their sins are more highly aggravated than if committed by children, or such as are raw and inexperienced, Job 32:7.

SubQuestions.Question: How are sins aggravated from the gifts of the persons offending?
SubQuestions.Answer: If the offenders have been eminent for their profession, 2 Sam. 12:14, or have had a larger measure of gifts, 1 Kings 11:9, or grace, James 4:17, conferred upon them, their sins will be proportionably aggravated beyond others, who have not been so privileged.

SubQuestions.Question: How are sins aggravated from the office, or station, in which persons offending may be placed?
SubQuestions.Answer: If the persons who give the offence be in an eminent station in the world, or vested with any office in the church, Jer. 23:11, 14, or in the state, 1 Kings 14:16; their sins cannot but be of a deeper tincture and dye, because their example is more likely to be followed by others, Jer. 23:14.

SubQuestions.Question: How do sins receive their aggravation from the parties OFFENDED?
SubQuestions.Answer: If committed "immediately against God, his attributes and worship; against Christ and his grace; against the Holy Spirit, his witness and working; against superiors, and such as we stand especially related and engaged unto; against any of the saints, particularly weak brethren: - and the common good of all, or many."103

SubQuestions.Question: On what account is sin aggravated as being committed immediately against God, his attributes and worship?
SubQuestions.Answer: In as much as it is doing evil in his sight, Psalm 51:4; is despising "the riches of his goodness," Rom. 2:4; and undervaluing his ordinances, Mal. 1:8, and the glory he has stamped upon them, verse 14.

SubQuestions.Question: In what consists the heinousness of sin, as being against Christ and his grace?
SubQuestions.Answer: In its being a slighting and contemning the only remedy which infinite wisdom has provided for our malady, Acts 4:12; and surely there can be no escape, if we "neglect so great salvation," Heb. 2:3.

SubQuestions.Question: How is sin aggravated by its being committed against the Holy Spirit, his witness and working?
SubQuestions.Answer: In as much as it is a rejection of his testimony without us, in the word, John 15:26, and a quenching his motions and operations within us, 1 Thess. 5:19.

SubQuestions.Question: What aggravation does sin receive, as being committed against superiors, and such as we stand especially related and engaged to?
SubQuestions.Answer: In so far as sin is committed against any of these, it is a violation of the most sacred bonds, both of nature, Proverbs 30:17, and gratitude, Psalm 55:12, 13.

SubQuestions.Question: How is it aggravated, as being committed against the saints, particularly weak brethren?
SubQuestions.Answer: As being committed against the saints, it is a contempt of the image of God in them, Luke 10:16; and as against weak brethren, it is laying a stumbling-block before them, by which they may be ensnared and fall, 1 Cor. 8:12.

SubQuestions.Question: Who are they that sin against the common good of all men, or many of them?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are such as do what in them lies to hinder the propagation of the gospel where it is not, and to mar the success of it where it is, 1 Thess. 2:15, 16; there being nothing that tends more to the common good of all men, than the word of this salvation being sent among them, Acts 13:26.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the aggravation of this sin?
SubQuestions.Answer: It makes those who are guilty of it bear the nearest resemblance they can to the devil, who aims at nothing more than the ruin and destruction of mankind, 1 Pet. 5:8.

SubQuestions.Question: How are sins aggravated from the NATURE and QUALITY of the offence?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are much aggravated, "if the offence be against the express letter of the law; break many commandments; - if it break forth in words and actions; - admit of no reparation; - if against conviction of conscience; - if done deliberately obstinately, and with delight."104

SubQuestions.Question: Why is the offence said to be aggravated from being committed against the express letter of the law?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because in this case there can remain no manner of doubt about the sinfulness of the action; and therefore it must be sinning with the greatest boldness and presumption, Rom. 1:32.

SubQuestions.Question: What aggravation is there in breaking many commandments at once?
SubQuestions.Answer: The sin thus becomes a Complicated offence, containing many crimes in the bosom of it; like David's sin in the matter of Uriah, 2 Sam. 12:9.

SubQuestions.Question: How is sin aggravated by breaking forth in words and actions?
SubQuestions.Answer: Sinful words and actions reflect a more public dishonour on God, Matt. 5:22, and do greater injury to men, Micah. 2:1, than if they were latent only in the thought.

SubQuestions.Question: What aggravation is there in those sins which admit of no reparation?
SubQuestions.Answer: Their admitting of no reparation, cannot fail to aggravate them in the very nature of things; thus murder or adultery cannot but be more heinous than theft, because there may be restitution of one kind or other for theft, Lev. 6:4, 5; but nothing can compensate the taking away of the life of another, Num. 35:31 or the violation of the marriage-bed and covenant, Proverbs 6:35.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the aggravation of sinning, against convictions of conscience?
SubQuestions.Answer: This kind of sinning offers violence to ourselves, contrary to the checks of that judge and reprover which every one has in his own breast, Rom. 1:32.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the evil of sinning deliberately, obstinately, and with delight?
SubQuestions.Answer: It argues the giving a kind of defiance to the Almighty, Ex. 5:2; a rooted hatred of him, Rom. 8:7; and is a strong evidence of judicial blindness and hardness of heart, Zech. 7:11, 12.

SubQuestions.Question: What aggravation do sins receive from the circumstance of TIME?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are more heinous if committed on the Lord's day, Jer. 17:27, or on days occasionally set apart for fasting or thanksgiving, Isaiah 22:12, 13, than at other times.

SubQuestions.Question: How are sins aggravated from the circumstance of the PLACE in which they are committed?
SubQuestions.Answer: An offence is more heinous, if it be done in a land of gospel light, Isaiah 26:10; or if committed "in public, or in the presence of others, who are thereby likely to be provoked or defiled, 2 Sam. 16:22."105

SubQuestions.Question: What improvement should we make of this doctrine of sin in its aggravations?
SubQuestions.Answer: To be more humbled and abased before the Lord, under a sense of our sins thus aggravated, Ezra 9:6; and likewise so much the more to admire the riches of pardoning mercy, as extended to the very chief of sinners, 1 Tim. 1:13, 15.

Data.Question: What doth every sin deserve?
Data.Answer: Every sin deserves God's wrath and curse, both in this life, and that which is to come.

SubQuestions.Question: What do you understand by the desert or demerit of sin?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is that in the nature of sin, which of itself deserves all that wrath and curse, which God, in his infinite justice, has entailed upon it, Gal. 3:10.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it in the nature of sin, which, of itself, deserves this wrath and curse?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is the opposition, and contrariety of it to the holiness of God expressed in his law, Hab. 1:13; which is the very thing that constitutes the enormity, or heinousness of it, Jer. 44:4.

SubQuestions.Question: Can wrath be ascribed to God as it is a passion?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; for all passions, properly speaking, are inconsistent with God's absolute unchangeableness, Mal. 3:6, and independency, Acts 14:15.

SubQuestions.Question: What then is to be understood by God's wrath?
SubQuestions.Answer: That most pure and undisturbed act of his will, which produces most dreadful effects against the sinner, Isaiah 33:14.

SubQuestions.Question: What are these dreadful effects, which the wrath of God produces against the sinner?
SubQuestions.Answer: All the miseries of this life, death itself, and the pains of hell for ever.106

SubQuestions.Question: Is the desert of sin separable from the nature of it?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; as sin is the very opposite of God's holy nature and righteous law, it cannot but deserve his wrath and curse, Rom. 6:23.

SubQuestions.Question: If every sin deserves God's wrath and curse, must not the sins of believers deserve the same likewise?
SubQuestions.Answer: Whatever be the desert of their sin, their persons can never be exposed, or liable to God's vindictive wrath, either in this life, or that which is to come, Zeph. 3:17; Hos. 13:14.

SubQuestions.Question: Why cannot the persons of believers be liable to the wrath and curse of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because of their union with Christ, Rom. 8:1, who has fulfilled all righteousness for them, ver. 33, 34; or answered all the demands of law and justice in their room and stead, chap. 4:25.

SubQuestions.Question: What do the Papists mean by venial sins?
SubQuestions.Answer: Such sins as are in their own nature so small and trivial, that they do not deserve eternal punishment.

SubQuestions.Question: Are there any sins in this sense venial?
SubQuestions.Answer: By no means; for the least sin, being committed against a God of infinite perfection, must, on that account, be objectively infinite, and consequently deserve an infinite punishment, 2 Thess. 1:9.

SubQuestions.Question: May not smaller offences be atoned for, by human satisfaction or penances?
SubQuestions.Answer: "Even the least sin - cannot be expiated, but by the blood of Christ," Heb. 9:22; 1 Pet. 1:18, 19.107

SubQuestions.Question: What may we learn from the desert of sin?
SubQuestions.Answer: The amazing love of God, in transferring the guilt and punishment of sin, to the glorious Surety, making "him to be sin for us, who knew no sin, that we might be made the righteousness of God in him," 2 Cor. 5:21.

Data.Question: What doth God require of us that we may escape his wrath and curse, due to us for sin?
Data.Answer: To escape the wrath and curse of God, due to us: for sin, God requireth of us faith in Jesus Christ, repentance unto life, with the diligent use of all the outward means whereby Christ communicateth to us the benefits of redemption.

SubQuestions.Question: What weighty argument or motive (among many others,) does the scripture afford, for essaying the practice of what God requires of us?
SubQuestions.Answer: That though we are enjoined, to work out our own salvation with fear and trembling; yet, we are at the same time assured, that "it is God which worketh in us, both to will and to do, of his good pleasure," Phil. 2:12, 13.

SubQuestions.Question: Does God require any thing of us in point of duty, without promising suitable furniture, for the performance of it?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; for he has said, "I will cause you to walk in my statutes, and ye shall keep my judgments, and do them," Ezek. 36:27.

SubQuestions.Question: Can we escape the wrath and curse of God, due to us for sin, by any thing we can do of ourselves?
SubQuestions.Answer: No, surely; for "all our righteousnesses are as filthy rags," Isaiah 64:6; and, "by the works of the law, shall no flesh be justified," Gal. 2:16.

SubQuestions.Question: Why then does the answer say, that to escape the wrath and curse of God, due to us for sin, God requires of us, faith in Jesus Christ, repentance unto life, and a diligent use of all the outward means?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because, though these duties, as performed by us, can neither give a title to, nor possession of eternal life; yet God appoints and requires them, both as they are MEANS of conveying and improving the salvation purchased, 1 Cor. 1:21, and likewise, as they are EVIDENCES of our interest in it, when conveyed, John 6:47.

SubQuestions.Question: Why does God require faith in Jesus Christ as the sovereign means of escaping his wrath and curse?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because there is salvation in no other; there being "none other name under heaven, given among men, whereby we must be saved," Acts 4:12.

SubQuestions.Question: What encouragement have we to essay believing in Jesus Christ?
SubQuestions.Answer: There cannot be a greater encouragement than this, that faith "is the gift of God," Eph; 2:8; and accordingly the promise runs, "I will say, It is my people, and they shall say, The Lord is my God," Zech. 13:9.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is repentance unto life required?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because it is the inseparable fruit and effect of faith or believing, Zech. 12:10 - "They shall look upon me whom they have pierced, and they shall mourn for him."

SubQuestions.Question: What encouragement have sinners of mankind, privileged with gospel light, to look for, or expect this blessing of repentance unto life, which God requires of them?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are warranted to expect it on this ground, that as Christ has "received gifts for men," Psalm 68:18, so "him hath God exalted with his right hand to be a Prince and a Saviour, to give repentance to Israel," Acts 5:31.

SubQuestions.Question: Why does God require of us the diligent use of all the outward means whereby Christ communicates to us the benefits of redemption?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because a neglect or contempt of the means of divine appointment, for communicating the benefits of redemption, is, in the sight of God, the same thing as a neglect or contempt of these inestimable benefits themselves, Luke 10:16 - "He that despiseth you, despiseth me; and he that despiseth me, despiseth him that sent me."

SubQuestions.Question: Can our believing, repenting, and diligent use of means, as they are acts of ours, be the procuring cause of our escaping wrath, or found our title to life and salvation?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; for, "by the deeds of the law, there shall no flesh be justified in his sight," Rom. 3:20. Our security from wrath and title to heaven, are founded on the imputation of the surety righteousness alone, Isaiah 45:25.

SubQuestions.Question: What would be the consequence of making our faith, repentance, and good works, the procuring cause of our escaping the wrath and curse of God due to us for sin?
SubQuestions.Answer: This would be setting aside the satisfaction of Christ, and making a saviour of our duties, than which nothing could nail us more effectually down under the curse, Gal. 3:10 - "As many as are of the works of the law, are under the curse."
