SubQuestions.Question: Have unbelieving and impenitent sinners any warrant to conclude, that they have escaped the wrath and curse of God, due to them for sin?
SubQuestions.Answer: No, surely; for "he that believeth not, is condemned already," John 3:18; and our Lord says, "Except ye repent, ye shall all likewise perish," Luke 13:3.

SubQuestions.Question: Is our escaping the wrath and curse of God suspended on the condition of our faith, repentance, and diligent use of the outward means?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; for, if any promised blessing were suspended upon the condition of our personal obedience, it would be the very form of the covenant of works, Rom. 10:5 - "Moses describeth the righteousness which is of the law, that the man which doth these things, shall live by them."

SubQuestions.Question: When do carnal and unregenerate men turn the dispensation of the covenant of grace into the form of the covenant of works?
SubQuestions.Answer: When they separate the duties of faith, repentance, and the diligent use of the means, from the promises of the Covenant, and hope to make themselves accepted with God by their personal performance of these duties, Rom. 10:3.

SubQuestions.Question: What CONNEXION have faith, repentance, and the use of outward means, with salvation?
SubQuestions.Answer: They have the connexion of APPOINTED MEANS prescribed by God himself, which, by his blessing, are subservient for such a valuable end; being themselves a part of salvation, and evidences of it, 2 Thess. 2:13.

SubQuestions.Question: How are the means of salvation usually distinguished?
SubQuestions.Answer: Into internal and external.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the internal means?
SubQuestions.Answer: Faith and repentance, with the other graces that accompany or flow from them.

SubQuestions.Question: Why called internal, or inward?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because they are wrought in the hearts of the elect, by the Spirit of God, as the fruits and effects of Christ's purchase and mediation, Zech. 12:10.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the external or outward means?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are the ordinances of Divine institution, and appointment; such as, the word, sacraments, and prayer.

SubQuestions.Question: How is faith in Jesus Christ connected with salvation?
SubQuestions.Answer: As it is the hand that receives Christ and his righteousness, as the all of our salvation, Psalm 68:31; John. 1:12.

SubQuestions.Question: How is repentance unto life connected with salvation?
SubQuestions.Answer: As it consists in that godly sorrow for sin, flowing from faith, which is both the exercise and ornament (in some measure) of all the travellers Zion-ward, while in this world, Jer. 50:4; 2 Cor. 7:11.

SubQuestions.Question: How is the diligent use of outward means connected with salvation?
SubQuestions.Answer: As it is by them that Christ communicates to us the benefits of redemption, Proverbs 2:1-16.

SubQuestions.Question: Could he not communicate the benefits of redemption, without the outward means?
SubQuestions.Answer: Whatever he could do, yet his ordinary method is to honour his own ordinances, as the means of communicating these benefits to us, which we are not to expect but in the use of them, Proverbs 8:34; Rom. 10:17.

SubQuestions.Question: What USE does God require us to make of the outward means?
SubQuestions.Answer: He requires us to make a diligent use of them.

SubQuestions.Question: What is a diligent use of the outward means?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is an embracing every opportunity offered in providence, for attending upon God in them, looking earnestly for his blessing upon them, by which alone they become efficacious for our spiritual benefit, 1 Cor. 3:6, 7.

Data.Question: What is faith in Jesus Christ?
Data.Answer: Faith in Jesus Christ is a saving grace, whereby we receive and rest upon him alone for salvation, as he is offered to us in the gospel.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the several kinds of faith mentioned in scripture?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are these four: historical, temporary, the faith of miracles, and saving faith.

SubQuestions.Question: What is historical faith?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is a bare assent to the truth of what is revealed in the word, without any real affection or regard to the things revealed in it. Such a faith as this may be found in devils, James 2:19; and in wicked men, Acts 8:13.

SubQuestions.Question: Why called historical?
SubQuestions.Answer: Not merely because it believes only the histories of the Bible; but because it assents to the truths revealed in it, as being little or no way concerned in them, or without any particular application of them to the soul, Acts 28:26.

SubQuestions.Question: What is temporary faith?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is such as, together with an assent to the truth of divine revelation, is also accompanied with some slight and transient motion upon the affections; which may endure for awhile, and then vanishes, Matt. 13:20, 21.

SubQuestions.Question: Has this kind of faith any influence upon the practice?
SubQuestions.Answer: It may be, for a time, accompanied with an external reformation from some grosser sins, 2 Pet. 2:20.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the faith of miracles?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is that peculiar gift, by which a person believes, that, by the power of God, something shall be effected by him which is quite above the power of all natural causes, 1 Cor. 13:2.

SubQuestions.Question: On what occasion has God bestowed upon any this faith?
SubQuestions.Answer: For the confirmation of some extraordinary mission, or of some important article of revealed religion; as the miracles of Moses under the Old Testament; and of the apostles under the New.

SubQuestions.Question: Was not the faith of miracles, in the days of our Saviour and his apostles, conferred upon some who were not in a state of salvation?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; both the extraordinary gift of the faith of miracles, and the ordinary and common gifts of the Spirit, were conferred upon some, who, we are assured, will be utterly rejected of God, Matt. 7:22, 23 - "Many will say unto me in that day, Lord, Lord, have we not PROPHESIED in thy name? and in thy name have CAST OUT DEVILS? and in thy name done many WONDERFUL WORKS? And then will I profess unto them, I never KNEW you: depart from me, ye that work iniquity."

SubQuestions.Question: What is saving and justifying faith?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is that faith in Jesus Christ, which is described in the answer, "whereby we receive and rest upon him alone for salvation," &c.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is this faith, described in the answer, called a grace?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because it is the gift of God, freely bestowed upon the sinner, Eph. 2:8, who has no antecedent worth, value, or good qualification, of which he can boast, 1 Cor. 4:7.

SubQuestions.Question: Why a saving grace?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because wherever true faith is, there salvation is already begun, which shall certainly be consummated in due time, John 3:36.

SubQuestions.Question: Where is the connexion established between faith and salvation?
SubQuestions.Answer: Faith being the gifted hand that is stretched out to receive Christ in the promise, Psalm 68:31, cannot but be inseparably connected with salvation; because Christ, whom faith receives, is the ALL of our salvation, Col. 3:11: hence is that promise, Mark 16:16 - "He that believeth - shall be saved."

SubQuestions.Question: Why is it called faith in Jesus Christ?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because Christ is the main, or principal object of saving faith, Acts 16:31.

SubQuestions.Question: Why do you call him the main or principal object of faith?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because nothing can fill the eye or hand of faith, but Christ only, or God in him, Psalm 73:25.

SubQuestions.Question: How is faith in Jesus Christ denominated in the answer?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is called a receiving, John 1:12, and resting on him, Psalm 37:7.

SubQuestions.Question: Are there not other denominations of faith in Christ of the same divine authority with those mentioned?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; such as eating, drinking, flying, entering, and many others.

SubQuestions.Question: From whence are these various denominations of faith derived?
SubQuestions.Answer: From the different views in which Christ is represented in the word.

SubQuestions.Question: How may the above denominations of faith be applied to the different views in which Christ is represented in the word?
SubQuestions.Answer: When the flesh and blood of Christ (or his incarnation and satisfaction) are exhibited as meat indeed, and drink indeed; faith, in conformity to this, is called eating and drinking of the same, John 6:55, 56; when Christ is held forth as a refuge, faith is a flying to him for safety, Heb. 6:18; and when he is represented as a door, faith is an entering in by him, John 10:9.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is faith, in the answer, expressed by receiving?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because Christ, the glorious object of it, is revealed in scripture, under the notion of a gift, 2 Cor; 9:15, presented to such as are quite poor, and have nothing of their own, Rev. 3:17, 18.

SubQuestions.Question: Can there be a receiving of Christ, without a previous giving of him?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; there may indeed be a giving, where there is no receiving, because the gift may be refused; but there can be no such thing as a receiving of Christ, without a giving of him before; for "a man can receive nothing except it be given him from heaven," John 3:27.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is faith called a resting on Christ?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because he is revealed in the word as a firm foundation, Isaiah 28:16, on which we may lay the weight of our everlasting concerns, with the greatest confidence and satisfaction, Psalm 116:7.

SubQuestions.Question: To what other scripture expression is resting on Christ equivalent?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is the same with TRUSTING in him, Isaiah 26:4; or relying on his righteousness and fulness, as laid out in the word, for our unanswerable plea, and inexhaustible treasure, chap. 45:24.

SubQuestions.Question: For what end do we receive Christ and rest upon him?
SubQuestions.Answer: For salvation, Acts 15:11.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the salvation for which we receive and rest upon Christ?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is salvation from sin, Matt. 1:21, as well as from wrath, 1 Thess. 1:10; consisting in a life of holiness here, as well as of happiness hereafter. It is salvation begun in this life, and consummated in glory, Rev. 3:21.

SubQuestions.Question: Why are we said to receive and rest upon Christ alone for this salvation?
SubQuestions.Answer: To exclude every thing else except Christ himself, and his righteousness, as the ground of our confidence before God, and title to eternal life, Acts 4:12.

SubQuestions.Question: What else do men ordinarily rest upon for salvation?
SubQuestions.Answer: Upon the general mercy of God; the works of the law; or a mixture of their own works with the righteousness of Christ.

SubQuestions.Question: Who are they that rest on the general mercy of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: They who never saw the necessity of a satisfaction to law and justice, in order to the honourable exercise of mercy, according to Ex. 34:7.

SubQuestions.Question: Who are they who rest on the works of the law, as the ground of their confidence?
SubQuestions.Answer: Such as have never been convinced that the demands of the law are utterly above their reach, Gal. 3:12.

SubQuestions.Question: Who are they that are for blending or mixing their own works with the righteousness of Christ, as the ground of their hope?
SubQuestions.Answer: Such as foolishly imagine they can supply what is defective in their own obedience, by what Christ has done for them, Rom. 9:31, 32.

SubQuestions.Question: To what does our Lord resemble this practice?
SubQuestions.Answer: To the putting "a piece of new cloth into an old garment," by which "the rent is made worse," Matt. 9:16.

SubQuestions.Question: Are not the very expressions of receiving and resting on Christ, designed to exclude the works of the law, from being any part of the ground of our hope of salvation?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; for, when a poor man receives his alms, or a weary man sits down, and rests himself; neither of them can, in any propriety of speech, be said to work.

SubQuestions.Question: Upon what warrant do we receive and rest upon him for salvation?
SubQuestions.Answer: Upon the warrant of his being offered.

SubQuestions.Question: To whom is he offered?
SubQuestions.Answer: He is offered to us, men and women of Adam's family, in contradistinction to the angels that fell, Heb. 2:16.

SubQuestions.Question: Where is the offer made?
SubQuestions.Answer: In the gospel.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the gospel as containing this offer.
SubQuestions.Answer: It is good tidings, Luke 2:10; or the promise of eternal life, 1 John 2:25, to sinners of mankind, as such, through Jesus Christ our Lord, Proverbs 8:4.

SubQuestions.Question: Though the offer of Christ to us be last mentioned, in the answer, yet is it not the first thing to Be believed?
SubQuestions.Answer: Surely it is; for unless one believe that Christ is offered to him as a Saviour, he will never receive and rest upon him for salvation, Rom. 10:14.

SubQuestions.Question: Who offers Christ to us in the gospel?
SubQuestions.Answer: God, essentially considered in the person of the Father, makes the original or authentic gospel offer of him, John 6:32 - "My Father GIVETH you the true bread from heaven."

SubQuestions.Question: In what form or tenor does this authentic offer run?
SubQuestions.Answer: In the form of a deed of gift, or grant, in which he makes over his Son, Jesus Christ, to mankind lost, that whosoever of them all shall receive this gift, shall not perish, but have eternal life.

SubQuestions.Question: In what text of scripture (amongst others) is this grant, or authentic gospel offer, contained?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is expressed in so many words, John 3:16 - "God so loved the world, that he GAVE his only begotten Son, that WHOSOEVER believeth on him should not perish, but have everlasting life."

SubQuestions.Question: Who are they that offer Christ to sinners in subordination to God?
SubQuestions.Answer: Ministers of the gospel, who have a commission from him so to do, 2 Cor. 5:19, 20.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the ministerial offer?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is the publishing or proclaiming of Heaven's gift, or grant, to sinners of mankind, without exception, as the foundation of their faith or warrant to believe, 1 John 5:11.

SubQuestions.Question: What would be the consequence, if there were any exception in the authentic gospel offer?
SubQuestions.Answer: The consequence would be, that no ministerial offer of Christ could be made to the party excepted, more than to the fallen angels.

SubQuestions.Question: Does the universality of Heaven's grant, and of the ministerial offer founded on it, infer a universal redemption as to purchase?
SubQuestions.Answer: By no means; it only infers a universal warrant to believe.

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove that it infers a universal warrant to believe?
SubQuestions.Answer: From this, that if there were not such a gift and grant of Christ as warranted all to receive him, the unbelieving world could not be condemned for rejecting him, as we find they are, John 3:18 - "He that believeth not is condemned already."

SubQuestions.Question: Is there any analogy, or proportion, between our receiving and resting on Christ, and the offer that is made of him in the gospel?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; we receive and rest upon him as he is offered in it, 1 Cor. 15:11 - "So we preach, and so ye believed."

SubQuestions.Question: How is he offered in the gospel?
SubQuestions.Answer: He is offered freely, wholly, and particularly.

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove, that he is offered, and should be received freely?
SubQuestions.Answer: From Isaiah 55:1 - "Ho, every one that thirsteth, come ye to the waters, and he that hath no money; come ye buy and eat; yea, come, buy wine and milk, without money and without price;" Rev. 22:17 - "Whosoever will, let him take the water of life FREELY."

SubQuestions.Question: Why is Christ to be received freely?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because God, out of his sovereign and matchless love, makes a free gift of him to mankind sinners, John 3:16, as being infinitely above all price, Job 28:13-24.

SubQuestions.Question: What do the proud and legal hearts of sinners bring as a price for Christ, who is absolutely inestimable?
SubQuestions.Answer: Their duties, their good qualifications, their honest aims, their sincere endeavours, and the like.

SubQuestions.Question: Why do they presume to bring such things as these?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because they know not that they are "wretched, and miserable, and poor, and blind, and naked," Rev. 3:17.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to receive Christ wholly?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to receive him in his person, as vested with all his relative offices, of prophet, priest, and king.

SubQuestions.Question: Why must he be received wholly?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because there is nothing of Christ we can possibly do without: standing in absolute need of him, as a prophet for instruction; as a priest, for righteousness; and as a king, for sanctification, 1 Cor. 1:30.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it for a person to receive Christ particularly?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to be verily persuaded that Christ is his, upon the grant and offer of him, in the word, to him in particular, John 7:37, and 9:36.

SubQuestions.Question: Is it not sufficient that a man believe, that the grant and offer of Christ is to sinners of mankind in general?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; there can be no benefit by a belief of the general offer, without a particular application, or appropriation of it to the person himself, 1 Tim. 1:15.

SubQuestions.Question: How is this illustrated by an example?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is commonly illustrated thus: If a king makes a proclamation of pardon and indemnity to all the rebels within his kingdom, it is plain, that every individual rebel must either believe the pardon of his own crime of rebellion in particular, or else reject the king's proclamation of grace, and continue in his rebellious practices: there is no medium.

SubQuestions.Question: Is not believing that an indemnity is offered to rebels in general, a medium between the two?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; because loyal subjects, who need no pardon, may believe that a general indemnity is offered to rebels; and this even rebels themselves may believe, who yet may reject the benefit of that indemnity, and continue in their rebellion, John 5:40.

SubQuestions.Question: Is a belief and persuasion of the mercy of God in Christ, and of Christ's ability and willingness to save all that come to him, all that is necessary to constitute justifying faith?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; because there being no appropriation, or particular application in this persuasion, it can be no more than such a faith as devils and reprobates may have; or such as Papists and Arminians may subscribe to, consistently with their other errors and heresies.

SubQuestions.Question: What is that appropriating persuasion, in the nature of faith, which is necessary to answer the call and offer of the gospel?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is not a persuasion that Christ is mine in possession, or that I am already in a state of grace: but a persuasion that Christ is mine in the gift of God, and offer of the gospel, Zech. 13:9 - "I will say, It is my people; and they shall say, The Lord is my God": and therefore I appropriate to myself the common salvation, Acts 15:11; or what did lie before me in common, in the gospel offer, I take home to my own soul in particular, Gal. 2:20 - "Who loved me, and gave himself for me"believing that I shall have life and salvation by Christ; and that whatever he did, for the redemption of sinners, he did it for me.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is an appropriating persuasion (or, a man's being persuaded that Christ is his in particular) necessary to the nature of saving and justifying faith?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because nothing can relieve the sinner from the curse of the law, accusing and condemning him in particular, but faith's application of an offered Saviour, as "made a curse" for him in particular, to deliver him from that 'law-curse,' Gal. 3:10, 13.

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove, that a particular application of Christ is the effectual relief from the curse of the law, denounced against the sinner in particular?
SubQuestions.Answer: From this, that the free gift is as full to justification, as the offence, through the law, was to condemnation; for, "as by the offence of one, judgment came upon all men to condemnation; even so, by the righteousness of one, the free gift came upon all men to justification of life," Rom. 5:18.

SubQuestions.Question: Since an appropriating persuasion is necessary to the nature of faith, has every one that has true faith, always an assurance of his being in a gracious state?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; for though a believer be persuaded that Christ is his in the promise and offer of the gospel: yet, through the prevalency of remaining corruption, he may frequently doubt of his being in a state of grace, or of his present title to eternal life, Isaiah 49:14.

SubQuestions.Question: Is doubting, then, in the nature of faith, because it is incident to the believer?
SubQuestions.Answer: Doubting can no more be said to be in the nature of faith because, through the prevalence of unbelief and corruption, it sometimes takes place in the believer, than darkness can be said to be in the nature of the sun, because it is sometimes eclipsed; for faith and doubting are, in their own nature, opposite, Matt. 21:21 - "If ye have faith, and doubt not."

SubQuestions.Question: Have all true believers the same measure of saving faith?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; some are but "of little faith," Matt. 14:31; whereas others are "strong in faith; giving glory to God," Rom. 4:20. Howbeit the lowest measure of true and saving faith is infallibly connected with glory, Matt. 12:20.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the evidences of a strong faith?
SubQuestions.Answer: Trusting to the bare word of a faithful and powerful God, even when the outward course of providence seems to run against the performance of the promise, Rom. 4:19; a fixed resolution to wait on the Lord, for the promised good which we want, even after seeming repulses and refusals, Matt. 15:22-29; and a sedate reposing ourselves on an unchangeable God, under all the vicissitudes of time, Psalm 112:7.

SubQuestions.Question: How may the weakness of faith be discerned?
SubQuestions.Answer: The more easily a person can suspect the love and favour of God, Isaiah 40:27; the more impatient under delays of answering requests, chap. 38:14; and the more addicted to a life of sense, John 20:25, the weaker is the faith.

SubQuestions.Question: How may the truth and reality of saving faith be known, though it be in the weakest and lowest degree?
SubQuestions.Answer: If we bear an inward enmity to all sins, because offensive to God, Psalm 51:4; if we can say, that it is the desire of our souls to love Christ above all things, John 21:17; and to be eternal debtors to free grace, reigning through his righteousness, Rom. 5:20, 21; then we may warrantably conclude, that our faith, however weak, is yet of a saving nature.

SubQuestions.Question: To what is true faith opposed in scripture?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is opposed to a staggering at the promise, Rom. 4:20; to wavering, James 1:6; to doubting, Matt. 21:21; and, in a word, to unbelief, Mark 9:24.

SubQuestions.Question: Who are they who will not be charged with the sin of unbelief?
SubQuestions.Answer: The Heathen world, who are not privileged with the light of gospel-revelation, Rom. 10:14 - "How shall they believe in him of whom they have not heard?"

SubQuestions.Question: What is the evil of this sin in those who are favoured with gospel light?
SubQuestions.Answer: It makes God a liar, 1 John 5:10; treads "under foot the Son of God;" and does "despite unto the Spirit of grace," Heb. 10:29.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the proper seat of faith?
SubQuestions.Answer: The HEART "for with the HEART man believeth unto righteousness," Rom. 10:10; though faith be radically in the understanding, yet it operates upon the will, which embraces the object with particular application, Heb. 11:13.

SubQuestions.Question: Is knowledge necessary to saving faith?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is so necessary that there can be no saving faith without it, 1 John 4:16 - "We have KNOWN and believed the love that God hath to us."

SubQuestions.Question: What is the difference between the knowledge of faith, and speculative knowledge?
SubQuestions.Answer: The knowledge of faith is humbling, 1 Cor. 8:2; transforming, Acts 26:18; affectionate, 1 John 4:8; and progressive, Hos. 6:3; whereas, common or speculative knowledge has none of these properties, nor effects.

SubQuestions.Question: In what consists the harmony or agreement between faith, love and hopes?
SubQuestions.Answer: By faith, we get a sight of an unseen good, and believe it, Heb. 11:27; by love we desire and seek after it, Isaiah 26:8; and by hope, we confidently expect, and patiently wait for it, Rom. 8:25.

SubQuestions.Question: How does faith view and consider its objects?
SubQuestions.Answer: It views them, as certain, suitable, and invisible.

SubQuestions.Question: Why does it view them as certain?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because of the unquestionable veracity of God who reveals them, John 6:69 - "We believe, and are SURE, that thou art that Christ, the Son of the living God."

SubQuestions.Question: Why does it consider them as suitable?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because they are exactly adapted to the state and circumstance of the soul, whatever they are, 1 Cor. 1:30; 1 Tim. 1:15.

SubQuestions.Question: Why does faith view its objects as invisibles?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because it acts and goes forth toward them, upon the bare testimony of God; not only without the concurrence of sense and carnal reason, John 20:29, but oftentimes contrary to them, Rom. 4:18, 19.

SubQuestions.Question: Is faith any part of our justifying righteousness?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; we acknowledge no other righteousness, for pardon and acceptance, but the righteousness of Christ alone, Phil, 3:9.

SubQuestions.Question: Why then are we said to be "justified by faith"? Rom. 5:1.
SubQuestions.Answer: Because it is faith which lays hold upon, and receives that righteousness by which we are justified, Rom 3:22.

SubQuestions.Question: Is not faith necessary to interest us in Christ, and the benefits of his purchase?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; for though the endorsement of the promise to us, gives us a right of access, Acts 2:39; yet it is faith, that gives the right of possession, John 6:47 - "He that believeth on me HATH everlasting life."

Data.Question: What is repentance unto life?
Data.Answer: Repentance unto life is a saving grace, whereby a sinner, out of a true sense of his sin, and apprehension of the mercy of God in Christ, doth, with grief and hatred of his sin, turn from it unto God, with full purpose of, and endeavour after, new obedience.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is the repentance, described in the answer called repentance unto life? Acts 11:18.
SubQuestions.Answer: Because being a saving grace, it is inseparably connected with salvation, of which it is a part; and likewise to distinguish it from the "sorrow of the world," which "worketh death," 2 Cor. 7:10.

SubQuestions.Question: What is meant by the sorrow of the world working death?
SubQuestions.Answer: The meaning is, that the legal sorrow, or horror of conscience, which the men of the world may have, from a dread of God, as a vindictive judge, ready to pour out the vials of his wrath and vengeance upon them, without any conception or belief of his mercy through Christ, is nothing else but the beginning of eternal death, and inconceivable misery; as was the case with Cain, Judas, and others.

SubQuestions.Question: Whether is repentance a transient action or an abiding principle?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is an abiding principle, continually disposing the person to mourn for sin, and to turn from it all the days of his life, Isaiah 38:14, 15.

SubQuestions.Question: Is repentance then to be considered as a thing that is over with the first days of one's religion?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; but it is to be viewed as a permanent grace, an habitual frame of soul, inclining those who are privileged with it, to mourn daily for sin, till "God shall wipe away all tears from their eyes," in heaven, Rev. 21:4.

SubQuestions.Question: Who is the proper subject of repentance?
SubQuestions.Answer: None but a sinner can be the subject capable of it: for just or righteous persons "need no repentance," Luke 15:7.

SubQuestions.Question: By whom is it wrought in the heart of a sinner?
SubQuestions.Answer: "By the Spirit of God," Zech. 12:10."108

SubQuestions.Question: What is the instrument or means, by which the Spirit works this grace?
SubQuestions.Answer: "The word of God," Acts, 11:18, 20, 21."109

SubQuestions.Question: What is the instrumentality of the word, in the hand of the Spirit, for working repentance?
SubQuestions.Answer: In the word there is a display of the holiness of the divine nature and law, to which we ought to be conformed, Lev. 19:2; the word also discovers the necessity of union with Christ, and the imputation of his righteousness, as the foundation of true holiness, 1 Cor. 1:30; together with the inevitable ruin of all who go on in their trespasses, Psalm 68:21, and all these powerfully set home, by the Spirit, upon the conscience of the sinner.

SubQuestions.Question: In what consists a true sense of sin?110
SubQuestions.Answer: In a "sight and sense, not only of the danger, but also of the filthiness and odiousness of sin, Ezek. 36:31,"111 as contrary to the holiness of God, and, consequently, as highly offensive to him, Psalm 51:4.

SubQuestions.Question: How is a true sense of sin begotten in the soul?
SubQuestions.Answer: By faith, or an apprehension of the mercy of God in Christ.

SubQuestions.Question: May there not be a sense of sin without this apprehension of the mercy of God in Christ?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; but not a true sense; there may be a sense of sin as hurtful to the person, Gen. 4:13; but not as hateful to God, Hab. 1:13.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is the mercy of God said to be apprehended in Christ?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because though God is essentially merciful, yet his mercy can have no egress towards any sinner of mankind, consistent with the honour of his justice and holiness, except through the obedience and satisfaction of Christ, Ex. 34:6, 7.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to APPREHEND the mercy of God in Christ?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is the same with faith, or believing; it being by faith only, that we can lay hold upon his mercy, Psalm 13:5.

SubQuestions.Question: Is it from faith then that repentance flows, as the proper source of it?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; for though faith and repentance are graces given together, and at once in respect of time; yet, in the order of nature, the acting of faith goes before the exercise of repentance, Zech. 12:10.

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear, from scripture, that faith goes before repentance, in the order of nature?
SubQuestions.Answer: The scriptures set forth the blessed object of faith, and the promises of rich grace, as powerful motives and inducements to repentance, Jer. 3:14; Joel 2:13; by which it is evident that it must be by a believing application of this glorious object, brought nigh in the promise, that a sinner is enabled to exercise true repentance, Acts 11:21 - "And a great number believed, and turned unto the Lord."

SubQuestions.Question: How may the precedency of faith be evinced from the nature of repentance itself?
SubQuestions.Answer: Repentance is turning from sin unto God; but there can be no turning to God, but through Christ, John 14:6; and no coming to Christ except by faith, chap. 6:35.

SubQuestions.Question: Is not repentance placed before faith in scripture, Mark 1:15 - "Repent ye, and believe the gospel"?
SubQuestions.Answer: The reason is, repentance being the end, and faith the means to that end; though the end be first in one's intention, yet the means are first in practice. Thus, in the text quoted, Christ commands sinners to repent; but then in order to their repenting, he commands them to believe the gospel, as the only way to do it.

SubQuestions.Question: How are we sure, that where repentance is named before faith in scripture, it is to be understood of repentance as the end, and of faith as the only way and means?
SubQuestions.Answer: From Acts 20:21:"Testifying - repentance toward God, and faith toward our Lord Jesus Christ" where it is obvious, that if "faith toward our Lord Jesus Christ" is not the "means of repentance toward God," that fundamental truth would be destroyed, that "Christ is the only way to the Father," as he himself affirms, John 14:6 - "No man cometh unto the Father but by me."

SubQuestions.Question: Is repentance to be separated from faith?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; though these graces are to be distinguished, yet they are never to be separated from one another; being conjoined in the same promise, Zech. 12:10 - "They shall LOOK upon me whom they have pierced, and they shall MOURN for him."

SubQuestions.Question: What is the evil of maintaining that none but true penitents have a warrant to embrace Christ by faith?
SubQuestions.Answer: It sets sinners upon spinning repentance out of their own bowels, that they may fetch it with them, as a price in their hand to Christ, instead of coming to him by faith, to obtain it from him, as his gift, Acts 5:31.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the constituent parts, or ingredients, of true repentance, as flowing from faith?
SubQuestions.Answer: Grief and hatred of sin; turning from it unto God; with full purpose of, and endeavour after, new obedience.

SubQuestions.Question: What is that grief which is an ingredient of true repentance?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is a real, inward and abiding sorrow for sin, as offensive and dishonouring to a holy and gracious God, Job 40:4, 5.

SubQuestions.Question: What is that hatred of sin, which accompanies true repentance?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is not only a loathing and abhorring of our sin, but of ourselves, on account of it, Isaiah 6:5.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the qualities of this hatred?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is universal, against all sin, Psalm 119:104; and irreconcilable to any known sin, Psalm 101:3.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the formal nature of evangelical repentance, or that which properly completes it?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is when a sinner doth, with grief and hatred of his sin, turn from it unto God.

SubQuestions.Question: From what does the sinner turn in repentance?
SubQuestions.Answer: He turns from sin; because a continuance in the practice of sin is inconsistent with repentance, Ezek. 14:6 - "Repent and turn - from your idols, and turn away your faces from all your abominations."

SubQuestions.Question: How can penitents be said to turn from sin, when it remains in them, and they are daily offending while in this life?
SubQuestions.Answer: Though they cannot shake themselves loose of the being and remains of sin, yet they turn from it, not only in their life and conversation, but likewise in their heart and affection.

SubQuestions.Question: How do they evidence that they turn from it in their life and conversation?
SubQuestions.Answer: By resisting the outbreakings of sin, and all temptations to it, Psalm 18:23; by watching against all occasions of it, Proverbs 4:14, 15; and endeavouring to "have always a conscience void of offence toward God, and toward men," Acts 24:16.

SubQuestions.Question: How do they manifest their turning from sin in heart and affection?
SubQuestions.Answer: In as much as though sin cleaves to them, they do not cleave to it, as formerly, but hate and loathe it, Psalm 119:104, 113.

SubQuestions.Question: To what does the sinner turn in repentance?
SubQuestions.Answer: He turns unto God, Hos. 6:1 - "Come, and let us return unto the Lord."

SubQuestions.Question: Do not many turn from one sin to another, and never to God?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; "They return, but not to the Most High," Hos. 7:16.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the true cause of the sinner's turning to God?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is his being turned unto God first, Jer. 31:19 - "Surely, after that I was turned, I repented."

SubQuestions.Question: How is the sinner turned unto God first?
SubQuestions.Answer: By the Spirit's working faith in him, whereby he receives and rests on Christ for salvation, of which remission of sin, and repentance, are a part, Acts 5:31.

SubQuestions.Question: In what does the sinner's turning to God consist?
SubQuestions.Answer: It consists in his turning to the loving of God, as his Lord and Master, Isaiah 26:13; and to his duty to him as such, Acts 9:6.

SubQuestions.Question: How does the returning sinner express his love to God, as his Lord and Master?
SubQuestions.Answer: By a voluntary choice of him as his only Lord, Hos. 2:7; and by looking upon his service as the greatest freedom and happiness, Psalm 84:4.

SubQuestions.Question: How does he testify his returning to his duty to God, as his Lord and Master?
SubQuestions.Answer: By a full purpose of, and endeavour after new obedience.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the nature of this purpose of duty to God, into which the true penitent enters?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is a purpose or resolution to return to the practice of every known duty, Psalm 119:106, and to spirituality in it, Phil. 3:3.

SubQuestions.Question: Why called a FULL purpose?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because it is not only a resolution of what a person will do hereafter, but a resolution which is immediately put in execution, without delay, Psalm 119:60 - "I made haste, and delayed not to keep thy commandments;" like the prodigal, who says, "I will arise, and go to my father;" and immediately he arose and went, Luke 15:18, 20.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the inseparable concomitant of this full purpose in all true penitents?
SubQuestions.Answer: An endeavour after new obedience.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is a full purpose of new obedience connected with an endeavour after it?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because purposes, without endeavours, are but like blossoms without fruit, which can never prove one to be a true penitent, Matt. 21:30.

SubQuestions.Question: Why called an endeavour after new obedience?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because, though the penitent is sensible he cannot perform this kind of obedience in his own strength, yet he aims at it, and at no less than perfection in it, Phil. 3:14 - "I press toward the mark, for the prize of the high calling of God in Christ Jesus."

SubQuestions.Question: Why is the obedience which the true penitent purposes and endeavours after, called new obedience?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because it is such an obedience as flows from a new principle, is influenced by new motives, performed in a new manner, and is aimed at a new end.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the new principle from which this obedience flows?
SubQuestions.Answer: A principle of faith, Rom. 14:23, and a principle of love, John 14:15.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the new motives by which this new obedience is influenced?
SubQuestions.Answer: The "grace of God," Titus 2:11, 12; and the "love of Christ," 2 Cor. 5:14, 15.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the motives by which men, in a natural state, are influenced to duties?
SubQuestions.Answer: The dictates of a natural conscience, Rom. 2:15; their own interest and reputation, Matt. 6:5, a mercenary hope of heaven, Micah 6:6, 7, or a slavish fear of hell, Isaiah 33:14.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the new manner in which new obedience is performed?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is performed in the strength of Christ, Phil. 4:13; or in a dependence on the furniture secured in the promise, 2 Cor. 12:9; it is done with delight, Isaiah 64:5; and with the whole heart, Psalm 119:69.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the new end at which it aims?
SubQuestions.Answer: The glory of God is the ultimate end of it, 1 Cor. 10:31.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the difference between legal and gospel repentance?
SubQuestions.Answer: Legal repentance flows from a dread of God's wrath, Matt. 27:3-6; but gospel repentance from the faith of his mercy, Psalm 130:4; in legal repentance, the sinner is taken up mostly with the fatal consequences of sin, Isaiah 49:9-12; in gospel repentance, he is chiefly affected with the evil nature of it, as contrary to the holy nature and law of God, Luke 15:21.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the motives that should produce repentance?
SubQuestions.Answer: The command of God, Acts 17:30; the suffering of Christ, Zech. 12:10; and the certain danger of impenitency, Luke 13:5.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the evidences of true repentance?
SubQuestions.Answer: The very same that are mentioned by the apostle, 2 Cor. 7:11 - "For behold, the self-same thing that ye sorrowed after a godly sort, what carefulness it wrought in you; yea, what clearing of yourselves; yea, what indignation; yea, what fear; yea, what vehement desire; yea, what zeal; yea, what revenge?

SubQuestions.Question: What is that carefulness which is a mark of the true penitent?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is carefulness about the one thing needful, that good part which shall not be taken away, Luke 10:42.

SubQuestions.Question: Upon what ground will the true penitent clear himself?
SubQuestions.Answer: Only upon the ground of the surety-righteousness imputed to him, Isaiah 45:24.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the principal object of his indignation?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is sin, as striking immediately against God, Psalm 51:4, compared with Psalm 119:104.

SubQuestions.Question: What is that fear, which is an evidence of true repentance?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is a filial and reverential fear of God, or a standing in awe to offend him, Gen. 39:9.

SubQuestions.Question: What is that vehement desire, with which a true penitent is privileged?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is an earnest and ardent desire after conformity to God, and fellowship with him, Psalm 27:4.

SubQuestions.Question: What kind of zeal is it, that is evidential of gospel repentance?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is zeal for the glory of God, and the interest of Christ in the world, Psalm 137:5, 6.

SubQuestions.Question: What is that revenge, which is competent to a true penitent?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is Such a revenge against sin, as aims at its utter ruin and extirpation, Rom. 7:24.

SubQuestions.Question: In what respects is repentance necessary?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is necessary in respect of the command of God, Acts 17:30, and as evidential of the reality of faith, of which it is the native fruit, and effect, Zech. 12:10.

SubQuestions.Question: May not this duty be delayed or put off for a while?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; because of the uncertainty of time, Luke 12:19, 20, and of the continuance of the Spirit's striving, Gen. 6:3.

SubQuestions.Question: When should the Lord's people apply to him, for the exercise of this grace of repentance, in a more especial and particular manner?
SubQuestions.Answer: After great falls, 2 Sam 12:13; when under severe trials, or deep affliction, 2 Sam. 15:26, 30; and when they are to ask of God some singular favour or mercy, Dan. 9:8, compared with verses 18, 19.

SubQuestions.Question: By what means may the lively exercise of repentance be attained?
SubQuestions.Answer: By looking on it as the gift of Christ, Acts 5:31; and by viewing our sins as laid on him, who was pierced for them, Zech 12:10; together with searching and trying our ways, Lam. 3:40.

Data.Question: What are the outward and ordinary means whereby Christ communicateth to us the benefits of redemption?
Data.Answer: The outward and ordinary means whereby Christ communicateth to us the benefits of redemption, are his Ordinances, especially the word, sacraments, and prayer, all which are made effectual to the elect for salvation.

SubQuestions.Question: What do you understand by the benefits of redemption?
SubQuestions.Answer: All the blessings of Christ's purchase, which may be summed up in grace here, and glory hereafter, Psalm 84:11.

SubQuestions.Question: Who communicateth these benefits or blessings to us?
SubQuestions.Answer: Christ himself, who has them wholly at his disposal, Luke 22:29 - "I appoint unto you a kingdom."

SubQuestions.Question: How comes Christ to have the disposal of them wholly in his hands?
SubQuestions.Answer: By his Father's gift, John 3:35 - "The Father loveth the Son, and hath GIVEN all things into his hand;" and by his own purchase of them; hence called a "purchased possession," Eph. 1:14.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it for Christ to communicate the benefits of redemption?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is not to give away the property of them from himself, but to make us "sharers with him" in them all; that is, to make us "heirs of God, and joint heirs with Christ," Rom. 8:17.

SubQuestions.Question: Does Christ communicate them in a mediate or immediate way?
SubQuestions.Answer: In a mediate way, through the intervention of ordinances, Eph. 4:11-14.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the ordinances by which Christ communicates to us the benefits of redemption?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are "prayer and thanksgiving, in the name of Christ; the reading, preaching, and hearing of the word; the administering, and receiving the sacraments; church government and discipline; the ministry and maintenance thereof; religious fasting; swearing by the name of God, and vowing unto him."112

SubQuestions.Question: Why are these called His ordinances?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because they are all of them instituted and prescribed by him in his word, as the alone King and Head of his church, to be observed in it to the end of the world, Matt. 28:20.

SubQuestions.Question: Have we any reason to expect, that the benefits of redemption will be communicated by ordinances of man's invention and appointment?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; for all such ordinances, having no higher sanction than the commandments of men, are declared to be IN VAIN, Matt. 15:9; they are condemned as will-worship, Col. 2:23; and the observers of them severely threatened, Micah. 6:16.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is it said, especially the word, sacraments, and prayer?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because, though the other ordinances above mentioned are not to be excluded, as being all of them useful in their own place; yet the word, sacraments, and prayer, are the chief or principal outward means for communicating the benefits of redemption, Acts 2:42.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the special usefulness of the word for communicating the benefits of redemption?
SubQuestions.Answer: In the word these benefits are exhibited and offered to sinners of mankind, as the ground of their faith, that, believing they may be possessed of them all, John 20:31.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the special usefulness of the sacraments for communicating these benefits?
SubQuestions.Answer: The sacraments represent to our senses, 1 Cor. 10:16, what the word does to our faith, and are designed for the confirmation of it, Rom. 4:11.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the special usefulness of prayer for the above purpose?
SubQuestions.Answer: The prayer of faith fetches home to the soul all the good that is wrapped up both in the word and in the sacraments, Mark 11:24 - "What things soever ye desire when ye pray, believe that ye receive them, and ye shall have them."

SubQuestions.Question: Why are the word, sacraments, and prayer, called means, by which Christ communicates to us the benefits of redemption?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because he is pleased to begin and carry on the work of grace in the soul, by and under these ordinances, Acts 2:41, 42.

SubQuestions.Question: Why called the outward means?
SubQuestions.Answer: To distinguish them from faith, repentance, and other inward means; and particularly to distinguish them from the inward and powerful influences of the Holy Spirit, which are necessary to accompany the outward means in order to salvation, Zech. 4:6.

SubQuestions.Question: Why called ordinary means?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because they are the stated and ordinary way and method, by which Christ communicates the benefits of redemption to sinners of mankind, Rom. 10:14-18; Ezek, 37:28.

SubQuestions.Question: Are there any extraordinary means without the word, by which Christ communicates the benefits of redemption to adult persons?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; for whatever providences God may make use of, when he is beginning or carrying on his work of grace in the soul, Acts 9:3-7; yet these dispensations are always to be considered in a subserviency to the word, chap. 16:25-33, or as occasions of the Spirit's working in concurrence with it, 2 Pet. 1:18, 19.

SubQuestions.Question: Are the ordinances, of themselves, effectual for communicating the benefits of redemption?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; they are made effectual, Rom. 1:16.

SubQuestions.Question: To whom are they made effectual?
SubQuestions.Answer: To the elect only, Acts 13:48.

SubQuestions.Question: For what end are they made effectual to the elect?
SubQuestions.Answer: For salvation, Heb. 10:39

SubQuestions.Question: What is meant by salvation?
SubQuestions.Answer: Not only a begun deliverance from all sin and misery, and a begun possession of all happiness and blessedness in this life, John 3:15; but likewise a total freedom from the one, and a full and uninterrupted enjoyment of the other, in the life to come, Rev. 21:4.

SubQuestions.Question: If the ordinances are made effectual to the elect only for salvation, why have others, in the visible church, the benefit of them?
SubQuestions.Answer: To show the infinite intrinsic sufficiency of the satisfaction of Christ, 1 John 4:14; and, at the same time, to render those who slight such valuable privileges the more inexcusable, John 15:22.

SubQuestions.Question: What may we learn from Christ's instituting his Ordinances to be the outward and ordinary means of salvation?
SubQuestions.Answer: We may from thence learn the difference between the church militant, which sees but through a glass darkly, and the church triumphant, which sees "face to face," 1 Cor. 13:12

Data.Question: How is the word made effectual to salvation?
Data.Answer: The Spirit of God maketh the reading, but especially the preaching of the word, an effectual means of convincing and converting sinners, and of building them up in holiness and comfort, through faith, unto salvation.

SubQuestions.Question: What is meant by the word in this answer?
SubQuestions.Answer: The whole of divine revelation, contained in the scriptures of the Old and New Testament.

SubQuestions.Question: What has God appointed with reference to his word, that it may be effectual to salvation?
SubQuestions.Answer: He has appointed the reading, John 5:39; "but especially the preaching thereof," 2 Tim. 4:2.

SubQuestions.Question: "Is the word of God to be read by all?"
SubQuestions.Answer: "Although all are not permitted to read the word publicly to the congregation, Deut. 31:9, 11, yet all sorts of people are bound to read it apart by themselves, chap. 17:19, and with their families, chap. 6:7."113

SubQuestions.Question: What is the meaning of these words in our Larger Catechism, "all are not permitted to read the word publicly to the congregation?"
SubQuestions.Answer: The meaning is: not, as if there were an order of men appointed by Christ, to be READERS in the church, distinct from ministers; but only, that none ought to read publicly to the congregation, except those whose office it is, not only to read the word of God, but to explain it to the edification of others, Neh. 8:8 - "So they read in the book of the law of God distinctly, and gave the SENSE, and caused them (namely, the people) to understand the reading."

SubQuestions.Question: Why is the reading of the scriptures apart by ourselves necessary for every one?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because the scriptures are a sword for defence, Eph. 6:17; a lamp for direction, Psalm 119:105; and food for nourishment, Jer. 15:16; in all which respects they are necessary for every Christian travelling Zion-ward, 2 Tim. 3:16, 17.

SubQuestions.Question: May not the reading of the scriptures in our families, supersede the reading of them apart by ourselves?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; the doing of the one ought by no means to jostle out the other.

SubQuestions.Question: What is essentially requisite in order to capacitate the unlearned to read the scriptures?
SubQuestions.Answer: That they be "translated out of the original into vulgar languages, 1 Cor. 14:11."114

SubQuestions.Question: How is the word of God to be read?
SubQuestions.Answer: "The holy scriptures are to be read with a high and reverend esteem of them, Neh. 8:5; with a firm persuasion that they are the very word of God, 2 Pet. 1:21; and that he only can enable us to understand them, Luke 24:45."116

SubQuestions.Question: Why should we read the scriptures with a high and reverend esteem of 115them?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because they are dictated by the Holy Ghost, and "are able to make us wise unto salvation," 2 Tim. 3:15.

SubQuestions.Question: Why should we read them with a firm persuasion that they are the very word of God?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because without this we can never build our hope on them, as containing the words of eternal life, 1 Thess. 2:13.

SubQuestions.Question: Why should we read them with a persuasion that God only can enable us to understand them?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because, without this, we cannot exercise a dependence upon him, for that spiritual and internal illumination, which is necessary to a saving and experimental knowledge of them, 1 Cor. 2:10.

SubQuestions.Question: "By whom is the word of God to be preached?"
SubQuestions.Answer: "Only by such as are sufficiently gifted, Mal. 2:7, and also duly approved and called to that office, Rom. 10:15; 1 Tim. 4:14."116

SubQuestions.Question: Who are they that are sufficiently gifted?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are such as are not only of a blameless moral walk, and "have a good report of them that are without," 1 Tim. 3:7; but likewise such as have a competent stock of human literature, Titus 1:9; and are, in the judgment of charity, reputed to be pious and religious men, 2 Tim. 1:5.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to be duly approved and called to that office?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is not only to be approved by the presbytery, who have the sole power of trying the ministerial qualifications, and of ordination to that office, 1 Tim. 4:14; but likewise to have the call and consent of the people, who are to be under the pastoral inspection and charge, Acts 1:23, and 14:23.

SubQuestions.Question: "How is the word of God to be preached by those that are called thereunto?"
SubQuestions.Answer: They are to preach sound doctrine "diligently, plainly, faithfully, wisely, zealously, and sincerely."117

SubQuestions.Question: What are we to understand by sound doctrine?
SubQuestions.Answer: The whole system of divine truth, contained in the holy scriptures, or evidently deducible from it; particularly whatever has the greatest tendency to depreciate self, and to exalt Christ, who ought to be the main and leading subject of all gospelpreaching, 2 Cor. 4:5.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to preach sound doctrine diligently?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to be instant "in season, and out of season," 2 Tim. 4:2118 embracing every opportunity of doing good to souls; and watching for them, "as they that must give account," Heb. 13:17.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to preach plainly?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to essay it, "not in enticing words of man's wisdom, but in demonstration of the Spirit, and of power," 1 Cor. 2:4.119

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to preach the word faithfully?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is a "making known the whole counsel of God," (or at least a not shunning to do so), Acts 20:27.120

SubQuestions.Question: When may ministers be said to preach wisely?
SubQuestions.Answer: When in studying, or preaching, they are wholly taken up in applying themselves to the necessities and capacities of the hearers,"121 Luke 12:42; 1 Cor. 3:2.

SubQuestions.Question: When do they preach the word zealously?
SubQuestions.Answer: When they do it "with fervent love to God, and the souls of his people,"122 2 Cor. 5:14, and 12:15.

SubQuestions.Question: How is the word preached sincerely?
SubQuestions.Answer: When there is an "aiming at God's glory," and his people's "conversion, edification, and salvation, 1 Thess. 2:4; 1 Cor. 9:22; 1 Tim. 4:16."123

SubQuestions.Question: Who is it that makes the reading and preaching of the word effectual to salvation?
SubQuestions.Answer: (THE SPIRIT OF GOD), 1 Cor. 2:11 - "The things of God knoweth no man, but the SPIRIT of God."

SubQuestions.Question: How does he make them effectual?
SubQuestions.Answer: By accompanying them with his divine power upon the soul, Rom. 1:16.

SubQuestions.Question: Of what is it that the Spirit of God makes the reading and preaching of the word an effectual means?
SubQuestions.Answer: He makes them an effectual means of convincing and converting sinners, and of building them up in holiness and comfort, through faith, unto Salvation.

SubQuestions.Question: Does the Spirit make more frequent and ordinary use of the reading, or of the preaching of the word, for these valuable ends?
SubQuestions.Answer: He makes more frequent and ordinary use of the preaching of the word; and therefore there is an ESPECIALLY prefixed to it in the answer.

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove, that the preaching of the word is honoured as the most ordinary means?
SubQuestions.Answer: From express scripture testimony to this purpose, Acts 4:4 - "Many of them which heard the word believed;" chap. 11:20, 21 - "And some of them - spake unto the Grecians, preaching the Lord Jesus. And the hand of the Lord was with them: and a great number believed, and turned unto the Lord."124

SubQuestions.Question: May not people be more edified in reading good sermons at home, than in hearing from the pulpit, such as are not perhaps, so well digested?
SubQuestions.Answer: If they are in health, and not necessarily detained from the public ordinances, they have no ground to expect any real and saving benefit to their souls in the neglect of hearing the word preached: because it pleases "God, by the foolishness of preaching, to save them that believe," 1 Cor. 1:21; and "faith cometh by HEARING," Rom. 10:17.

SubQuestions.Question: What use does the Spirit make of the reading, but especially of the preaching of the word, with reference to sinners in a natural state?
SubQuestions.Answer: He makes use of them as an effectual means of convincing and converting them, 1 Cor. 14:24; Acts 26:18.

SubQuestions.Question: What does the Spirit convince sinners of by the word?
SubQuestions.Answer: Of their sin and misery.125

SubQuestions.Question: Is it by the word of the law, or the word of the gospel, that the Spirit convinces of sin?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is ordinarily by the word of the law, Rom. 3:20 - "By the LAW is the knowledge of sin."

SubQuestions.Question: What of sin does the Spirit convince sinners by the law?
SubQuestions.Answer: Both of the nature and desert of sin.

SubQuestions.Question: In what consists the nature of sin?
SubQuestions.Answer: In the want of conformity to, and transgression of, the law of God.126

SubQuestions.Question: What is the desert of sin?
SubQuestions.Answer: The wrath and curse of God, both in this life and that which is to come.127

SubQuestions.Question: How does the Spirit convince men effectually, by the word, that they are sinners?
SubQuestions.Answer: By convincing them, from it, that they are unbelievers, John 16:8, 9 - "He the Spirit will reprove or convince the world of sin, because they believe not on me," says our Lord.

SubQuestions.Question: What influence has a conviction of unbelief, upon convincing a person that he is indeed a sinner?
SubQuestions.Answer: Were a person once convinced, that unbelief is a rejection of the only method of salvation, devised in infinite wisdom, or treating of God's unspeakable gift offered in the word, with the utmost contempt, he could not but conclude himself, on this account, to be the greatest of sinners, and that he deserved the severest of punishments, Heb. 10:29.

SubQuestions.Question: How does the Spirit make the word an effectual means of converting sinners?
SubQuestions.Answer: By making use of it "to open their eyes, and to turn them from darkness to light, and from the power of Satan to God," Acts 26:18.

SubQuestions.Question: Do all convictions of sin issue in conversion?
SubQuestions.Answer: Far from it: many may be very deeply convinced of sin by the law, and yet never have a thorough change wrought upon their hearts; as in the instances of Cain, Judas, and others.

SubQuestions.Question: What is conversion?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is the spiritual motion of the whole man toward God in Christ, as the immediate effect of the real and supernatural change, that is wrought in regeneration, Jer. 3:22.

SubQuestions.Question: Is there any difference between conversion and regeneration?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are as inseparably conjoined, as the effect is to its cause. Regeneration, or the formation of the new creature (in which we are wholly passive), is the cause; and conversion, or the motion of the soul to God, is the effect, which infallibly follows, Hos. 6:2.

SubQuestions.Question: Cannot man be the author of his own regeneration?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; he can neither prepare himself for it, nor co-operate with God in it.

SubQuestions.Question: Why can he not prepare himself for it?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because the carnal mind is enmity against God, and remains so until regenerating grace take place in the soul, Rom. 8:7, 8.

SubQuestions.Question: Why cannot man co-operate with God in this work?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because there can be no acting, without a principle of action. Regeneration, being the infusing of spiritual life into the soul, it is impossible the creature can cooperate or concur with God in it, any more than Lazarus in the grave could concur in his own resurrection, till the powerful voice of Christ infused life and strength into him.

SubQuestions.Question: What would be the consequence if man could co-operate with God in regeneration?
SubQuestions.Answer: The consequence would be, that God would not be so much the author of grace, as he is of nature; nor have such a revenue of glory from the one, as from the other.

SubQuestions.Question: How are regeneration and conversion denominated in scripture, to prove that God alone can be the author of them?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are called a "creation," Eph. 2:10, and a "resurrection," chap. 5:14.

SubQuestions.Question: Why called a creation?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because there is nothing in the heart of man, out of which the new creature can be formed; "every imagination of the thoughts of his heart" being "only evil continually," Gen. 6:5.

SubQuestions.Question: Why called a resurrection?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because it is God only "who quickeneth the dead, and calleth things which be not, as though they were," Rom. 4:17.

SubQuestions.Question: What influence has the word upon the conversion of sinners?
SubQuestions.Answer: It has no physical or natural influence of itself, but only as it is an instituted means, in the hand of the Spirit of God to that end, John 6:63.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the efficacy of the word, in the work of conversion, compared to in scripture?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is compared to a fire, to a hammer, Jer. 23:29; to rain, Deut. 32:2; and to light, Psalm 119:105.

SubQuestions.Question: Why compared to fire?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because as fire purifies the metal, separating the dross; so the word, in the hand of the Spirit, purifies the heart, purging away the dross of sin and corruption that is there, Isaiah 4:4.

SubQuestions.Question: Why compared to a hammer?
SubQuestions.Answer: As a hammer "breaketh the rock in pieces," Jer. 23:29, and thus fits it for the building, so the Spirit of God, by the word, breaks the hard heart of man, and fits it for being built on the foundation God has laid in Zion, Proverbs 16:1.

SubQuestions.Question: Why compared to rain?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because as the rain falls irresistibly, so there is no withstanding the efficacy of the word in the hand of the Spirit, Isaiah 55:11.

SubQuestions.Question: Why compared to light?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because as light discovers things that were indiscernible in the dark; so the Spirit, by the word, discovers the latent wickedness of the heart, 1 Cor. 14:25, and the matchless glory and excellency of Christ, as IMMANUEL, "God with us," John 16:14.

SubQuestions.Question: What use does the Spirit make of the reading, but especially the preaching of the word, with reference to SAINTS, who are brought into a state of grace?
SubQuestions.Answer: He makes use of it as an effectual means of building them up in holiness and comfort, through faith unto salvation, Acts 20:32; Rom. 15:4.

SubQuestions.Question: Is holiness necessary in order to our justification before God?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is necessary in the justified, but not in order to their justification; because this would found their justification upon works, contrary to Rom. 3:20 - "By the deeds of the law shall no flesh be justified in his sight."128

SubQuestions.Question: Is it necessary as the ground of our title to heaven?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is necessary to clear our title; but our title itself can be founded only in our union with Christ, and the imputation of his righteousness, 1 Cor. 3:22, 23 - "All are yours, and ye are Christ's "compared with Rom. 8:30 - "Whom he justified, them he also glorified."

SubQuestions.Question: Why are the saints said to be built up in holiness?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because the work of sanctification, like a building, is gradually carried on towards perfection until death, Proverbs 4:18.

SubQuestions.Question: How does the Spirit make the reading and preaching of the word, an effectual means of building up the saints in holiness?
SubQuestions.Answer: By giving them, in the glass of the word, such clear and repeated discoveries of the glory of Christ, as to transform them more and more into the same image with him, 2 Cor. 3:18.

SubQuestions.Question: How does he, by means of these ordinances, build them up in comfort?
SubQuestions.Answer: By conveying with power to their souls, the great and precious promises, which contain all the grounds of real and lasting comfort, Gal. 3:29, and 4:28.

SubQuestions.Question: Through what instrument is it, that the Spirit makes these means effectual, for building up the saints in holiness and comfort?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is through faith, 1 Thess. 2:13.

SubQuestions.Question: What instrumentality has faith, in the hand of the Spirit, for building up the saints, in holiness and comfort?
SubQuestions.Answer: It rests upon God's faithful word for the promotion of both, Psalm 138:8 - "The Lord will perfect that which concerneth me."

SubQuestions.Question: To what end does the Spirit, by means of the word, build them up in holiness, and comfort through faith?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is unto their complete and eternal salvation, Rom. 1:16.

SubQuestions.Question: What may we learn from the Spirit's making the means effectual to salvation?
SubQuestions.Answer: That as no special blessing can be expected from God, in the wilful neglect of the ordinances, Proverbs 28:9; so we may sit all our days under a pure dispensation of the gospel, without reaping any spiritual profit, unless divine supernatural agency concur, 1 Cor. 3:6.

Data.Question: How is the word to be read and heard, that it may become effectual to salvation?
Data.Answer: That the word may become effectual to salvation, we must attend thereunto with diligence, preparation, and prayer; receive it with faith and love; lay it up in our hearts, and practise it in our lives.

SubQuestions.Question: What has God enjoined upon us, in order to our reading and hearing his word in a right manner?
SubQuestions.Answer: That we attend thereunto; that we receive it; and that we lay it up in our hearts, and practise it in our lives.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to attend to the reading and hearing of the word?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to make the reading and hearing of it the main business of our life; to have it mostly at heart, because the word contains "that good part which shall not be taken away," Luke 10:42.

SubQuestions.Question: How ought we to attend to, or set about the reading and hearing of the word?
SubQuestions.Answer: With diligence, preparation, and prayer.

SubQuestions.Question: What do you understand by attending to the word with diligence?
SubQuestions.Answer: A careful observing and embracing every seasonable opportunity, that may offer in providence, for reading and hearing the same, Proverbs 8:34.

SubQuestions.Question: What preparation should we make for reading and hearing the word?
SubQuestions.Answer: We should consider, that the word has the authority of God stamped upon it, 2 Tim. 3:16; that it is he himself who speaks to us in it, Heb. 12:25; that it is his ordinance for our salvation, John 5:39; and will be the savour either of life or death to us, 2 Cor. 2:16.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is prayer requisite for reading and hearing the word in a right manner?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because as it is God alone, and none else, who can dispose our hearts for the right performance of those religious exercises, so he ought always to be addressed and supplicated for that end, Psalm 119:18.

SubQuestions.Question: What should we pray for, when setting about the reading and hearing of the word?
SubQuestions.Answer: That it may be "the power of God unto our salvation," Rom. 1:16; or an effectual means in his hand for convincing, converting, and edifying our souls, John 6:63.

SubQuestions.Question: What is our immediate duty, when we are actually engaged in reading or hearing of the word?
SubQuestions.Answer: Our immediate duty, in that case, is to receive it.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to receive the word?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is, with all readiness of mind, to take it in, as the dictates of the Holy Ghost to our souls, Acts 17:11.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is the right improvement of the word, in time of reading and hearing of it, called a receiving it?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because we can reap no real benefit to our souls, by the offer and exhibition of all the blessings that are brought nigh to us in it, unless we receive them as God's free gift to us, John 3:27.

SubQuestions.Question: How are we to receive the word, and all the good that is in it?
SubQuestions.Answer: With faith and love.

SubQuestions.Question: When is the word received with faith, in time of reading and hearing of it?
SubQuestions.Answer: When there is an application of it to the soul in particular, in a suitableness to the state and case of the person, and the nature of the word, whether in a way of promise, Lam. 3:24, or threatening, Psalm 119:120.

SubQuestions.Question: How may a person know if he receives the word with faith?
SubQuestions.Answer: By the quickening, Psalm 119:50, enlightening, ver. 130, sanctifying, ver. 9, and strengthening effect of it, Dan. 10:19.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the native consequence of receiving the word with faith?
SubQuestions.Answer: A receiving it also with love; for "faith worketh by love," Gal. 5:6.

SubQuestions.Question: How may our receiving the word with love be discerned?
SubQuestions.Answer: When our affections are drawn out to the blessed truths and objects revealed in it; so as to esteem them more than "thousands of gold and silver," Psalm 119:72, or even than our "necessary food," Job 23:12.

SubQuestions.Question: What improvement ought we to make of the word after reading or hearing of it?
SubQuestions.Answer: We should lay it up in our hearts, and practise it in our lives.

SubQuestions.Question: What do you understand by the heart, where the word should be laid up?
SubQuestions.Answer: The soul, with all its faculties, Proverbs 23:26; the understanding, to know the word; the will to comply with it; the affections to love it; and the memory to retain it.

SubQuestions.Question: What is implied in laying up the word in our hearts?
SubQuestions.Answer: That we account it the most valuable treasure, Psalm 119:127; that we keep it with the utmost care, ver. 11; and that we resolve to use it in all the future exigencies129 of our souls, ver. 24.

SubQuestions.Question: How may we know if the word is really laid up in our hearts?
SubQuestions.Answer: By our delighting to meditate upon it, Psalm 119:97; by the Spirit's bringing it to our remembrance, John 14:26; and by our habitual desire of farther conformity and subjection unto it, Psalm 119:5.

SubQuestions.Question: For what end should we lay up the word in our hearts?
SubQuestions.Answer: That we may practise it in our lives.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to practise the word in our lives?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to have a conversation becoming the gospel, Phil. 1:27; or to have both the outward and inward man regulated according to the unerring rule of the word, Psalm 119:105.

SubQuestions.Question: What does the right manner of reading and hearing of the word teach us?
SubQuestions.Answer: That the bare outward performance of duty will not be acceptable to God, unless the heart is engaged in it, Isaiah 29:13.

Data.Question: How do the sacraments become effectual means of salvation?
Data.Answer: The sacraments become effectual means of salvation, not from any virtue in them, or in him that doth administer them; but only by the blessing of Christ, and the working of his Spirit in them that by faith receive them.

SubQuestions.Question: What is meant by effectual means of salvation?
SubQuestions.Answer: Such means as, by the blessing of God, do fully attain the end for which they are appointed, 1 Thess. 2:13.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the meaning of these words in the answer not from any virtue in them?
SubQuestions.Answer: The meaning is, that the sacraments have not any virtue or efficacy in themselves to confer salvation; being only among the outward and ordinary means of grace, which can have no more efficacy of themselves to confer any saving benefit than the rainbow of itself has to prevent a deluge.

SubQuestions.Question: Who are they who maintain that the sacraments have a virtue or power in themselves to confer grace?
SubQuestions.Answer: The Papists, who affirm that the sacraments of the New Testament are the true, proper, and immediate causes of grace; and that the efficacy of them flows from the sacramental action of receiving the external elements.

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove that the sacraments have not any innate or intrinsic virtue in themselves to confer grace or salvation?
SubQuestions.Answer: From this one argument, that if the sacraments had any such virtue, then grace, or salvation, would be infallibly connected with the external use of them: but it is obvious from scripture, that after Simon Magus was baptised, he remained still "in the gall of bitterness, and bond of iniquity," Acts 8:13, 23.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is it said in the answer, that the sacraments become effectual means of salvation, not from any virtue in him that doth administer them?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is so said in opposition to the Papists, who maintain, that the efficacy of the sacraments depends upon the intention of the priest; so that any benefit by them, is conferred, or withheld, according to them, just as the secret will of the administrator would have it.

SubQuestions.Question: How is this error refuted?
SubQuestions.Answer: If the efficacy of the sacraments depended upon the intention of the administrator, then there could be no certainty about the efficacy of them at all; because no mortal can be absolutely certain about the intention of another; the secrets of the heart being known to God only, Acts 1:24.

SubQuestions.Question: From whence, then, have the sacraments their efficacy and virtue?
SubQuestions.Answer: Only from the blessing of Christ, and the working of his Spirit.

SubQuestions.Question: What do you understand by the blessing of Christ?
SubQuestions.Answer: That divine power and life, with which he is pleased to accompany the sacraments and other ordinances; and without which they would be utterly ineffectual, Rom. 1:16.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the working of his Spirit, which is necessary to make the sacraments effectual means of salvation?
SubQuestions.Answer: Not only the planting of grace in the soul at first, but the drawing of it out into suitable exercise on all sacramental occasions, Zech. 4:6.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is the working of the Spirit necessary to the efficacy of the sacraments?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because we are utterly impotent of ourselves for any thing that is spiritually good, John 15:5.

SubQuestions.Question: In whom are the sacraments (by the blessing of Christ, and the working of his Spirit,) effectual means of salvation?
SubQuestions.Answer: In them that by faith receive them.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to receive the sacraments by faith?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to apply Christ, and the benefits of his purchase, as represented, and exhibited to us in them, Luke 22:19, 20.

SubQuestions.Question: What may we learn from the necessity of Christ's blessing, and of the Spirit's working, in order to the efficacy of the sacraments?
SubQuestions.Answer: It teaches us, that our whole dependence for the blessing, whether upon ourselves, when we partake of the sacrament of the supper, or upon our children, when we are sponsors for them in baptism, should be only on Christ alone, and the saving influences and operations of his Spirit, held forth in the promise, to accompany his own institutions; and therefore our partaking of these solemn ordinances, dispensed by some ministers, to the slighting of them as dispensed by others, equally sound and faithful, though perhaps in our esteem somewhat inferior in outward gifts, says upon the matter, that the efficacy of the sacraments depends, somehow, upon the administrator, and not upon the blessing of Christ alone: quite contrary to the mind of the Spirit of God, 1 Cor. 3:7 - "So, then, neither is he that planteth anything, neither he that watereth; but God that giveth the increase."

Data.Question: What is a sacrament?
Data.Answer: A sacrament is a holy ordinance instituted by Christ, wherein, by sensible signs, Christ, and the benefits of the new covenant, are represented, sealed, and applied to believers.
