SubQuestions.Question: From whence is the word sacrament derived?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is of Latin origin, being anciently used, by the Romans, to signify their military oath; or that oath which their soldiers took to be true and faithful to their prince, and that they would not desert his standard.

SubQuestions.Question: How is it used by the church?
SubQuestions.Answer: Not only to signify something that is sacred, but likewise a solemn engagement to be the Lord's.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the general nature of a sacrament?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is a holy ordinance, instituted by Christ.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is a sacrament called a holy ordinance?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because it is appointed not only for holy ends and uses, but likewise for persons federally holy.

SubQuestions.Question: Is it necessary that a sacrament be instituted by Christ?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; it is essentially necessary that it have his express and immediate warrant and institution, otherwise it does not deserve the name, 1 Cor. 11:23 - "For I have RECEIVED of the Lord, that which also I delivered unto you," &C.

SubQuestions.Question: Why must sacraments be expressly or immediately instituted by Christ?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because he alone is the head of the church; and has the sole power and authority to institute sacraments and other ordinances in it, Eph. 1:22, 23.

SubQuestions.Question: "What are the parts of a sacrament?"
SubQuestions.Answer: "Two; the one, an outward and sensible sign, used according to Christ's own appointment; the other, an inward and spiritual grace, thereby signified, Matt. 3:11; 1 Pet. 3:21."130

SubQuestions.Question: What are the outward signs in sacraments?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are the sacramental elements, and the sacramental actions; but chiefly the elements, because it is about these that the sacramental actions are exercised.

SubQuestions.Question: Why called sensible signs?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because they are obvious to the outward senses of seeing, tasting, feeling, &c.

SubQuestions.Question: What kind of signs are sensible signs in a sacrament?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are not natural, nor merely speculative; but voluntary and practical signs.

SubQuestions.Question: Why are they not natural signs?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because natural signs always signify the self-same thing, as smoke is always a sign of fire, and the morning light a sign of the approaching sun; whereas the signs in a sacrament never signify what they represent in that holy ordinance, but when sacramentally used.

SubQuestions.Question: Why are they practical, and not merely speculative signs?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because they are designed not only to represent the spiritual grace signified by them; but likewise to seal and apply the same.

SubQuestions.Question: Why are the signs in a sacrament called voluntary signs?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because they depend entirely upon the divine institution to make them signs; yet so as there is some analogy or resemblance between the sign and the thing signified.

SubQuestions.Question: When are sacramental signs used according to Christ's own appointment?
SubQuestions.Answer: When they are dispensed with the words of institution annexed to them, Matt. 28:19; 1 Cor. 11:23-25.

SubQuestions.Question: What do the words of institution imply or contain in them?
SubQuestions.Answer: They contain, "together with a precept authorising the use" of them, "a promise of benefit to the worthy receivers, Matt. 28:20."131

SubQuestions.Question: What is the inward and spiritual grace signified by the sensible signs in a sacrament?
SubQuestions.Answer: Christ and the benefits of the new covenant.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is the covenant of grace called the new covenant?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because it is always to remain in its prime and vigour, without the least change or alteration; for "that which decayeth and waxeth old, is ready to vanish away," Heb. 8:13.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the benefits of the new covenant?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are all the blessings contained in the promises of it, which may be summed up in grace here, and glory hereafter, Psalm 84:11.

SubQuestions.Question: Are Christ, and the benefits of the new covenant, separable from one another?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; for, "he that hath the Son, hath life," 1 John 5:12; whoever has Christ, has all things along with him; "all are yours, and ye are Christ's," 1 Cor. 3:22, 23.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the intention and design of sensible signs in a sacrament, with reference to Christ and the benefits of the new covenant?
SubQuestions.Answer: The design of them is, that Christ and his benefits may be represented, sealed, and applied by them.

SubQuestions.Question: Why are Christ and his benefits said to be represented by the signs in a sacrament?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because as sacramental signs are of divine institution, so there is a resemblance or similitude between the signs and the things signified.

SubQuestions.Question: Why are Christ and his benefits said to be sealed by these signs?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because, by the sacramental signs, Christ and his benefits are confirmed to the believer, even as a seal is a confirmation of a bond or deed, Rom. 4:11.

SubQuestions.Question: Why said to be applied?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because, by the right and lawful use of the sacramental signs, Christ and his benefits are really communicated, conveyed, and made over to the worthy receiver, 1 Cor. 11:24 - "Take, eat; this is my body, which is broken for you."

SubQuestions.Question: To whom do the sacramental signs represent, seal, and apply Christ and his benefits?
SubQuestions.Answer: Not to all who use them, but to believers only.

SubQuestions.Question: Why to believers only?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because nothing but true faith can discern, and apply the spiritual grace, which is represented and exhibited by sensible signs in the sacrament, Gal. 3:26, 27.

SubQuestions.Question: In what consists the FORM of a sacrament?
SubQuestions.Answer: In "a spiritual relation, or sacramental union, between the sign and the thing signified."132

SubQuestions.Question: What is the consequence of this sacramental union between the sign and the thing signified?
SubQuestions.Answer: The consequence is, "that the names and effects of the one are attributed to the other."133 Thus Christ is called our passover, 1 Cor. 5:7; and the bread in the supper is called Christ's body - "This is my body," 1 Cor. 11:24.

SubQuestions.Question: When are the signs and the things signified, united in those who partake of the sacraments?
SubQuestions.Answer: When, together with the signs, (in virtue of Christ's institution) the blessings signified are received by faith, Gal. 3:27.

SubQuestions.Question: How may this be illustrated by an example?
SubQuestions.Answer: A little earth and stone put into a man's hand at random, signify nothing; but when this is done in a regular manner, according to the forms of law, to give a proprietor possession of his lands, from whence these symbols were taken, it is of great importance to corroborate his right: so bread and wine in the sacrament, are of little value in themselves abstractly considered; yet when received in faith, as the instituted memorials of the death of Christ, by which his testament was ratified and sealed, the believer's right to all the blessings of his purchase is by it most comfortably confirmed, 1 Cor. 11:24 - "This is my body, which is broken FOR YOU."

SubQuestions.Question: Are the sacraments necessary for the confirmation of the word?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; the word being of divine and infallible authority, needs no confirmation without itself: but they are necessary on OUR account, for helping our infirmity, and confirming and strengthening our faith, Rom. 4:11.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the difference between the word and the sacraments?
SubQuestions.Answer: The word may be profitable to the adult, without the sacraments; but the sacraments cannot profit them without the word, Gal. 5:6.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the END of the sacraments?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is "to represent Christ and his benefits; and to confirm our interest in him: as also to put a visible difference between those that belong unto the church, and the rest of the world; and solemnly to engage them to the service of God in Christ, according to his word."134

SubQuestions.Question: Who are they that have a right to the sacraments?
SubQuestions.Answer: They "that are within the covenant of grace, Rom 15:8."135

SubQuestions.Question: Who are to be reckoned within the covenant of grace, in the sight of men?
SubQuestions.Answer: They who "profess their faith in Christ, and obedience to him, Acts 2:38;" and "infants descending from parents, either both or but one of them professing faith in Christ, and obedience to him, are, in that respect, within the covenant, Rom. 11:16."136

SubQuestions.Question: What may we learn from the nature of the sacraments in general?
SubQuestions.Answer: The amazing love of the Lord Jesus, in giving us not only the word as the instrument in the hand of the Spirit, for besetting faith, and all other graces, Eph 1:13; but likewise the sacraments for strengthening and increasing the same, as well as for cherishing our love and communion with one another, 1 Cor. 12:13.

Data.Question: What are the sacraments of the New Testament?
Data.Answer: The sacraments of the New Testament are, baptism and the Lord's supper.

SubQuestions.Question: What were the ordinary sacraments under the Old Testament?
SubQuestions.Answer: They were two: CIRCUMCISION and the PASSOVER.

SubQuestions.Question: When was circumcision first instituted?
SubQuestions.Answer: In the ninety-ninth year of Abraham's age, Gen. 17:24; at which time, both he, "and all the men of his house, were circumcised," verse 26, 27.

SubQuestions.Question: At what age were the male children afterwards to be circumcised?
SubQuestions.Answer: Precisely on the eighth day after they were born, Gen. 17:12.

SubQuestions.Question: What was the spiritual meaning of this sacramental ceremony?
SubQuestions.Answer: It signified the impurity and corruption of nature, Jer. 4:4; the necessity of regeneration, or being cut off from the first Adam, as a federal head, Rom. 2:28, 29; and of being implanted in Christ, in order to partake of the benefits of his mediation, chap. 8:1; together with a solemn virtual engagement to be the Lord's, Gen. 17:11.

SubQuestions.Question: What was the other sacrament of the Old Testament?
SubQuestions.Answer: The passover.

SubQuestions.Question: When was it instituted?
SubQuestions.Answer: At the departure of the children of Israel out of Egypt, Ex. chapter 12.

SubQuestions.Question: Why called the PASSOVER?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because the destroying angel passed over the houses of the Israelites in the night when he smote the first-born with death, in every house or family of the Egyptians, Ex. 12:27.

SubQuestions.Question: On what account did the angel pass over the houses of the Israelites?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because, according to the express command of God, the blood of the passoverlamb was stricken upon the lintels and side posts of their doors, as a signal to the destroying angel to pass over them, Ex. 12:22, 23.

SubQuestions.Question: What was meant by striking the blood upon their lintels and door posts?
SubQuestions.Answer: It signified, that it is only in virtue of the blood or satisfaction of Christ, that the curse and sentence of the law (which is the Wrath of God) is not executed upon the sinner, Rom. 5:9.

SubQuestions.Question: What were the significant ceremonies of divine institution that were to be observed in this sacrament?
SubQuestions.Answer: The passover lamb was to be without blemish, Ex. 12:5; it was to be slain, verse 6; it was to be roasted with fire, verse 9; and it was to be eaten, and that wholly and entirely, verse 10.

SubQuestions.Question: Why was it necessary that the passover-lamb should be without blemish?
SubQuestions.Answer: To signify, that though our sins were imputed to Christ, yet he was in himself "holy, harmless, undefiled," Heb: 7:26; and therefore called "a Lamb without blemish and without spot," 1 Pet. 1:19.

SubQuestions.Question: Why must the lamb be slain, or killed by blood shedding?
SubQuestions.Answer: To denote, that the death of Christ was necessary, for satisfying justice, and reconciling us to God, Luke 24:26 - "Ought not Christ to have suffered these things?"

SubQuestions.Question: Why was it to be roasted with fire?
SubQuestions.Answer: To intimate, that Christ's sufferings, as our Surety, were exquisitely and inconceivably great, without the least abatement of any of that wrath which was due to our sins, Isaiah 53:10 - "It pleased the Lord to bruise him;" Rom. 8:32 - "God spared not his own Son."

SubQuestions.Question: Why was it to be eaten wholly and entirely, and none of it to be left?
SubQuestions.Answer: To signify, that Christ was to be wholly applied, in a way of believing, as being, "of God, made unto us wisdom and righteousness, and sanctification, and redemption," 1 Cor. 1:30.

SubQuestions.Question: Why were all the families of Israel to eat the passover, at one and the same time? Ex. 12:8.
SubQuestions.Answer: To signify that there is enough in Christ to satisfy the need of all his people at once; "for in him dwelleth all the fulness of the Godhead bodily," Col. 2:9.

SubQuestions.Question: Why was it to be eaten the very same evening in which it was slain? ver. 6, 8.
SubQuestions.Answer: To signify, that Christ ought to be applied and appropriated by faith speedily, without delay: "Behold, NOW is the accepted time," 2 Cor. 6:2.

SubQuestions.Question: "How many sacraments hath Christ instituted in his church under the New Testament?
SubQuestions.Answer: "Under the New Testament, Christ hath instituted in his church only two sacraments; baptism and the Lord's supper."137

SubQuestions.Question: How do these two sacraments come in the place of those under the Old Testament?
SubQuestions.Answer: Baptism comes in the place of circumcision; and the Lord's supper in the place of the passover.

SubQuestions.Question: Were the sacraments of the Old Testament no more than shadows of that grace, which is actually conferred by the sacraments under the New, as the Papists would have it?
SubQuestions.Answer: By no means; for "the sacraments of the Old Testament, in regard of the spiritual things thereby signified and exhibited, were, for substance, the same with those of the New, 1 Cor. 10:1-5."138

SubQuestions.Question: In what do they differ?
SubQuestions.Answer: The sacraments of the Old Testament represented Christ as yet to come; whereas those of the New hold him forth as already come, and as having finished the work of our redemption, as to the purchase of it, Eph. 5:2.

SubQuestions.Question: Is there any difference between them as to clearness and perspicuity?
SubQuestions.Answer: The words annexed to the outward signs in the sacraments of the New Testament, make the things signified appear vastly more plain and perspicuous, than in the sacraments of the Old.

SubQuestions.Question: What other sacraments do the Papists add to baptism and the Lord's supper?
SubQuestions.Answer: They boldly venture to add other five; namely, confirmation, penance, orders, marriage, and extreme unction.

SubQuestions.Question: How may it appear, in a word, that all these are false and spurious sacraments?
SubQuestions.Answer: In regard that none of them have sacramental signs of divine institution, signifying any inward and spiritual grace; and, consequently, none of them can be appointed seals of God's covenant.

SubQuestions.Question: Who may lawfully dispense the sacraments of the New Testament?
SubQuestions.Answer: "Neither of them may be dispensed by any, but a minister of the word, lawfully ordained, 1 Cor. 4:1"139

Data.Question: What is baptism?
Data.Answer: Baptism is a sacrament, wherein the washing with water, in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost, doth signify and seal our ingrafting into Christ, and partaking of the benefits of the covenant of grace and our engagement to be the Lord's.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the proper signification of the word baptism?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is of Greek origin, and properly signifies a washing, sprinkling, or pouring out, in order to cleansing, Mark 1:8 - "I indeed baptise you with water, but he shall baptise you with the Holy Ghost;" that is, he shall pour his Spirit upon you, according to the promise, Isaiah 44:3 - "I will pour my Spirit upon thy seed, and my blessing upon thine offspring."

SubQuestions.Question: Who is the author of baptism?
SubQuestions.Answer: The Lord Jesus Christ, the Mediator and Head of the church.

SubQuestions.Question: When did he institute and appoint it, as a sacrament of the New Testament?
SubQuestions.Answer: A little before his ascension into heaven, when he gave his apostles that solemn charge, Matt. 28:19 - "Go ye, therefore, and teach all nations, baptising them in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost."

SubQuestions.Question: Was not baptism used before that time?
SubQuestions.Answer: It was used long before by the Jews, in receiving their proselytes, but not by divine institution.

SubQuestions.Question: When came baptism to have a divine warrant and restitution?.
SubQuestions.Answer: When God sent John the Baptist to baptise with water, John 1:33.

SubQuestions.Question: Was there any difference between the baptism of John, and the baptism dispensed by the apostles after Christ's ascension?
SubQuestions.Answer: There was no essential difference between them; for both of them had the same visible sign, and the same blessings signified by it. The difference was only circumstantial, in respect of time, and the objects of administration.

SubQuestions.Question: How did they differ in respect of time?
SubQuestions.Answer: The baptism of John was dispensed before Christ had finished the work which his Father gave him to do; but the baptism of the apostles was mostly after Christ had suffered, and had entered into his glory.

SubQuestions.Question: How did they differ as to the objects of administration?
SubQuestions.Answer: The baptism of John was confined to Judea only; but the baptism of the apostles extended to all nations, to whom the gospel was preached, Matt. 28:19.

SubQuestions.Question: Did not Paul rebaptise some disciples at Ephesus who had been before baptised by John?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; he only declares, that they who had heard John preach the doctrine of repentance and faith in Christ, were by John baptised in the name of the Lord Jesus, and so needed not to be rebaptised by any other.

SubQuestions.Question: Why did Christ, who had no need of it, condescend to be baptised by John?
SubQuestions.Answer: He gives the reason himself; "It becometh us," says he, "to fulfil all righteousness," Matt. 3:15.

SubQuestions.Question: Did Christ himself baptise any?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; "Jesus himself baptised not, but his disciples," John 4:2.

SubQuestions.Question: Why did not Christ baptise any himself?
SubQuestions.Answer: That he might commend the ministry of men of like passions with ourselves; and to show that the efficacy of the ordinance did not depend upon the administrator, but upon the divine blessing; even as the words spoken by him on earth, when they were efficacious, were so, not merely as spoken or uttered from his lips, but as accompanied with his own almighty power, Luke 5:17.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the visible sign, or outward element in baptism?
SubQuestions.Answer: Only water, pure and unmixed, Acts 10:47.

SubQuestions.Question: How is water to be applied to the body in baptism?
SubQuestions.Answer: "Dipping of the person into the water is not necessary, but baptism is rightly administered by pouring or sprinkling water upon the person."140

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear from scripture, that baptism is rightly administered by pouring or sprinkling water upon the person?
SubQuestions.Answer: From repeated instances of the administration of baptism by the apostles in this manner; particularly when three thousand were baptised by them, Acts 2:41, water must have been sprinkled upon them, as the apostles could not have time, in a part only of one day, to take them one by one, and plunge them into it. Nor is it probable that the jailer, Acts 16:33, had such store of water in the night season, as was sufficient for himself and whole family to be dipped into; or that they went abroad in quest of some river for that purpose; it is much more reasonable to infer, that in both the above instances, they were baptised by sprinkling. The same may be said of Paul's baptism, Acts 9:18; and of the baptism of Cornelius and his friends, Acts 10:47, 48.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is it most expedient to sprinkle water upon the face in baptism?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because the face is the principal part of the body, and the whole person is represented by it, Ex. 10:29.

SubQuestions.Question: What is signified by water in baptism?
SubQuestions.Answer: The cleansing virtue of the blood of Christ, Rev. 1:5, and Spirit of Christ, Titus 3:5.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the difference between cleansing by the blood, and cleansing by the Spirit of Christ?
SubQuestions.Answer: The blood of Christ cleanseth meritoriously, 1 John 1:7; the Spirit of Christ efficaciously, Ezek. 36:27. By the former, the guilt of sin is, at once, taken away in justification; by the latter, the blot and stain of it is gradually carried off in sanctification.

SubQuestions.Question: What is signified by sprinkling of water upon the body?
SubQuestions.Answer: The application of the blood of Christ to the soul, by the Spirit of God, Titus 3:5, 6.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the analogy, or resemblance, between the sign in baptism, and the thing signified?
SubQuestions.Answer: Water makes clean, what before was foul; so the blood and Spirit of Christ purify from the guilt and pollution of sin, Zech. 13:1 water is open and free to all; so Christ and his benefits are freely offered to all the hearers of the gospel, Rev. 22:17.

SubQuestions.Question: In whose name are we baptised?
SubQuestions.Answer: In the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost, Matt. 28:19.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to be baptised in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is not only to be baptised by the will, command, and authority of the Threeone God; but likewise to be, by baptism, solemnly dedicated and devoted to the Father, the Son, and the Holy Ghost, as our God and portion for ever, Isaiah 44:5.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to be baptised by the command and authority of the Father, Son, and Holy Ghost?
SubQuestions.Answer: It intimates that the Trinity of persons do not only authorise and appoint baptism to be a sacrament of the New Testament; but that they become jointly engaged to make good all the blessings of the covenant, signified and sealed by that ordinance, Jer. 31:33 - "I will be their God, and they shall be my people."

SubQuestions.Question: What is included in our being by baptism, solemnly dedicated and devoted to the Father, Son, and Holy Ghost, as our God and portion for ever?
SubQuestions.Answer: It includes a solemn profession, that these three adorable persons have the sole right to all our religious worship, Psalm 5:7; that all our hope of salvation is from them, Psalm 62:1, 5, and that we should be wholly and for ever the Lord's, Psalm 48:14.

SubQuestions.Question: Is it necessary that baptism be dispensed in these express words, "In the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost?"
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; because ministers are peremptorily commanded by Christ, to baptise in this very form, Matt. 28:19 - "Go ye, therefore, and teach all nations; baptising them in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost."

SubQuestions.Question: Did not the apostles baptise in another form, when they baptised in the name of the Lord Jesus? Acts 8:16.
SubQuestions.Answer: It is not to be supposed, that the apostles would alter the form, so expressly delivered to them by their glorious Master; and therefore, when any are said to be baptised in the name of the Lord Jesus, it is not designed by this to notify to us in what form of words they were baptised; but only that they were baptised by the authority of Christ, who appointed this sacrament; and to faith in him, and communion with him.

SubQuestions.Question: How ought the mentioning of the holy Trinity to be introduced in baptism?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is proper that it be introduced by words in the first person, expressing the present act of administration; and likewise setting forth the authority that a minister, lawfully called, has to dispense this sacrament; such as, "I baptise thee, in the name," &c.141

SubQuestions.Question: What are the ends and uses of baptism?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are to signify and seal our ingrafting into Christ, and partaking of the benefits of the covenant of grace.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to signify and seal our ingrafting into Christ?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to signify and seal our union with him, and consequently the imputation of his righteousness to us, Gal. 3:27 - "As many of you as have been baptised into Christ, have put on Christ."

SubQuestions.Question: What are the benefits of the covenant of grace, the partaking of which is signified and sealed in baptism?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are "remission of sins by the blood of Christ; regeneration by his Spirit, adoption, and resurrection unto everlasting life."142

SubQuestions.Question: What is the consequence of its being signified and sealed to us in baptism, that we partake of such great and glorious benefits?
SubQuestions.Answer: The consequence is, that on this account, we enter into an open and professed engagement to be - the Lord's."143

SubQuestions.Question: What is included in our engagement to be the Lord's?
SubQuestions.Answer: That we shall be his "wholly and only."

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to be his wholly?144
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to be his, in all that we are, soul, spirit, and body, 1 Cor. 6:19, 20; and in all that we have, whether gifts, graces, or worldly comforts, 1 Chron. 29:14.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to be the Lord's only?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to be his in opposition to all his rivals and competitors, every one of whom we profess to renounce in baptism, Hos. 14:8.

SubQuestions.Question: Who are these rivals and competitors with God, whom we profess to renounce in baptism?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are sin, Rom. 6:6; Satan, Acts 26:18, and the world, John 17:14.

SubQuestions.Question: Does baptism make or constitute persons church members?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; they are supposed to be church-members before they are baptised, and if they are children of professing parents, they are born members of the visible church, 1 Cor. 7:14.

SubQuestions.Question: Why must they be church-members before they are baptised?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because the seals of the covenant can never be applied to any, but such as are supposed to be in the covenant; nor can the privileges of the church be confirmed to any that are without the church.

SubQuestions.Question: Why then do our Confession,145 and Larger Catechism,146 say that "the parties baptised are solemnly admitted into the visible church?"
SubQuestions.Answer: Because there is a vast difference between making a person a church-member, who was none before; and the solemnity of the admission of one, who is already a member. All that our Confession and Catechism affirm, is, that, by baptism, we are SOLEMNLY admitted into the visible church; that is, by baptism we are publicly declared to be church-members before, and thus have our membership solemnly sealed to us: "For by one Spirit we are all baptised into one body," 1 Cor. 12:13.

SubQuestions.Question: Is it warrantable to call the baptising of any, the Christening of them?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; because this is an encouraging of the superstitious Popish notion, that baptism makes even those who are born within the visible church, to become Christians; and that by the want of it, they remain infidels, and are left to uncovenanted mercy.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the extremes about the necessity of baptism?
SubQuestions.Answer: The Socinians and Quakers deny that it is necessary at all; on the other hand, the Papists, and some others, maintain that it is so absolutely necessary, that no salvation can be expected without it.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the doctrine of our Confession of Faith, on this head?
SubQuestions.Answer: That "although it be a great sin to contemn or neglect this ordinance, yet grace and salvation are not so inseparably annexed unto it, as that no person can be regenerated and saved without it; or that all who are baptised are undoubtedly regenerated."147

SubQuestions.Question: In what consists the greatness of the sin of contemning and slighting this ordinance?
SubQuestions.Answer: It consists in despising an express and positive institution of Christ, appointed to be administered in his church to the end of the world, Matt. 28:19, 20; and in slighting all the great and glorious benefits and privileges signified and sealed by it, Luke 7:30.

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear that grace and salvation are not inseparably annexed to baptism?
SubQuestions.Answer: From the instance of Abraham, who had the righteousness of faith before he was circumcised, Rom. 4:11; of Cornelius, who feared God, and was accepted of him, before he was baptised, Acts 10:2, 4; and from the instance of the thief on the cross, who was saved without being baptised at all, Luke 23:43.

SubQuestions.Question: How does the scripture evince, that all who are baptised are not regenerated and saved?
SubQuestions.Answer: From the instance of Simon Magus, who was baptised, and yet, after baptism, remained "in the gall of bitterness, and in the bond of iniquity,"149 Acts 8:13, 23.

SubQuestions.Question: Does baptism give a right to covenant-blessings; or, is it only a declarative sign and seal of them?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is only a declarative sign and seal of them, as circumcision was, Rom. 4:11.

SubQuestions.Question: What, then, gives a right?
SubQuestions.Answer: The promise of the covenant, which is endorsed to the children, as well as to the parents, Acts 2:39 - "The promise is unto you, and to your CHILDREN."

SubQuestions.Question: Is baptism designed to make the covenant more sure, or our faith stronger?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is designed only to make our faith stronger; for the sureness of the covenant flows from the faithfulness of God, which is inviolable and unchangeable, Psalm 89:33, 34; Isaiah 54:10.

SubQuestions.Question: In what consists the efficacy of baptism?
SubQuestions.Answer: It consists in sealing and ratifying the right to covenant blessings, which persons have from the promise, so infallibly, that they shall certainly be put in possession of them, Eph. 5:25, 26. For, according to the doctrine of our Confession, "the grace promised is not only offered, but really exhibited and conferred, by the Holy Ghost, to such (whether of age, or infants,) as that grace belongeth unto, according to the counsel of God's own will, in his appointed time."148

SubQuestions.Question: Is baptism efficacious at the time of its administration?
SubQuestions.Answer: Not always: "the efficacy of baptism is not tied to that moment of time wherein it is administered,"149 but may take place afterwards, as God in his sovereignty has fixed it; "for the wind bloweth where it listeth," &c., John 3:8.

SubQuestions.Question: What may we learn from the nature of baptism?
SubQuestions.Answer: The infinite goodness of God, in appointing an initiating ordinance, irreversibly sealing all the blessings of the covenant to the elect seed, Gen. 17:7.

Data.Question: To whom is baptism to be administered?
Data.Answer: Baptism is not to be administered to any that are out of the visible church, till they profess their faith in Christ, and obedience to him: but the infants of such as are members of the visible church are to be baptised.

SubQuestions.Question: Who may administer the sacrament of baptism?
SubQuestions.Answer: Neither of the two sacraments "may be dispensed by any, but by a minister of the word, lawfully ordained.150

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove, that ordination by presbyters is lawful and valid, without a diocesan bishop?
SubQuestions.Answer: From express scripture testimony, asserting the validity of ordination to the ministry, by "the laying on of the hands of the PRESBYTERY," 1 Tim. 4:14.

SubQuestions.Question: Why should ministers lawfully ordained, and no other persons whatsoever, dispense the sacraments of the New Testament?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because they only are the "stewards of the mysteries of God," 1 Cor. 4:1; and have the sole commission and authority from Christ to preach and baptise, Matt. 28:19 - "Go ye, therefore, and TEACH all nations, BAPTISING them," &c.

SubQuestions.Question: Is public prayer requisite before the administration of baptism?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is evident, that our Lord, at the first institution of the supper, and his apostles, afterwards, according to his example, prayed for the divine blessing to attend the dispensation of that solemn ordinance, 1 Cor. 11:24; and therefore, by parity of reasoning, ministers ought to pray, and the people to join in it, for the same blessing upon the administration of the sacrament of baptism.

SubQuestions.Question: Ought not teaching, or preaching of the word, to go before baptism?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; because our Lord has joined them together, Matt. 28:19 - "Go ye, therefore, and TEACH all nations, BAPTISING them," &c. And accordingly it was the uniform practice of the apostles to preach when they baptised, Acts 2:38-41; 8:35, 38, and 16:32, 33.

SubQuestions.Question: Is naming of children necessary at baptism?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; baptism dispensed by sprinkling of water, together with the words of institution, is every way valid and complete, though the person baptised is not named at all.

SubQuestions.Question: But was not the naming of children, at circumcision, an ancient practice among the Jews? Luke 1:59.
SubQuestions.Answer: It was so; and the names of children may be published at baptism still, provided it is not looked upon as essential to that solemn ordinance; for it is the parent, and not the minister, who gives the name.

SubQuestions.Question: May baptism be administered in private?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is more agreeable to the nature of this ordinance, when the Lord gives his people peace and opportunity for their public assemblies, that it be administered wherever the congregation is orderly called together, to wait on the dispensing of the word, Acts 2:41.151

SubQuestions.Question: What if the child should be removed by death, before such a regular opportunity can be had?
SubQuestions.Answer: Then the parents may comfort themselves in this, that they were neither guilty of an unnecessary delay, nor of contemning the ordinance; and that, in these circumstances, the want of it cannot harm the child, 2 Sam. 12:18, 23.

SubQuestions.Question: With what frame and disposition of mind ought this sacrament to be dispensed and witnessed?
SubQuestions.Answer: With a firm persuasion that it is an ordinance of God; with a filial and reverential fear of him on our spirits; and with gratitude and thankfulness for the inestimable benefits that are signified and sealed in it.

SubQuestions.Question: How often is baptism to be administered to any person?
SubQuestions.Answer: But once only, Acts 19:4, 5.

SubQuestions.Question: Why but once only?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because when our ingrafting into Christ (which is the comprehensive benefit signified and sealed in baptism) once takes place, it is never repeated, but remains firm and inviolable for ever, John 17:23.

SubQuestions.Question: To whom is baptism not to be administered?
SubQuestions.Answer: Baptism is not to be administered to any that are out of the visible church.

SubQuestions.Question: Whom do you understand by those that are out of the visible church?
SubQuestions.Answer: All infidels, or such as are Jews, or Heathens, and their children.

SubQuestions.Question: Why may not these be baptised?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because being strangers from the covenant of promise, they can have no right to the seals of it, Eph. 2:12.

SubQuestions.Question: May infidels in no event be baptised?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes, they may, so soon as they profess their faith in Christ, and obedience to him.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to profess faith in Christ?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to profess a belief of the whole doctrines of the Christian religion, Acts 8:37.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to profess obedience to him?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to yield an external subjection to all the ordinances and institutions of Christ, Acts 2:46.

SubQuestions.Question: Whom does such a profession respect?
SubQuestions.Answer: It respects only the adult, or such as are grown up to ripeness of age.

SubQuestions.Question: Have not INFANTS (who can make no such profession) a right to baptism?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; the infants of such as are members of the visible church are to be baptised.

SubQuestions.Question: Who are the members of the visible church?
SubQuestions.Answer: They "are all such as profess the true religion, and their children."152

SubQuestions.Question: What are we to understand by the true religion?
SubQuestions.Answer: We are to understand by it the whole of those doctrines deduced from the holy scriptures, which are contained in our Confession of Faith, and Catechisms, as agreeing, in the main, with the Confessions of other reformed churches, 2 Tim. 1:13 - "Hold fast the form of sound words."

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to profess the true religion?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is openly to acknowledge, on all proper occasions, a steadfast adherence to the whole of divine truth; without espousing or countenancing any opposite error, Psalm 119:105. Rom. 10:10.

SubQuestions.Question: Is a bare profession of the true religion sufficient?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; for "faith without works is dead." James 2:26.

SubQuestions.Question: Upon what ground have the infants of such as are members of the visible church a right to baptism?
SubQuestions.Answer: Upon the ground of the grace and goodness of God in the promise, including them in the same covenant with their parents; as in the promise made to Abraham, Gen. 17:7 - "I will establish my covenant between me and thee, and thy seed after thee - to be a God unto thee, and to thy seed after thee."

SubQuestions.Question: But what if this promise of including the seed in the same covenant with the parents have a respect only to the natural offspring of Abraham, and to none else?
SubQuestions.Answer: The apostle Peter plainly affirms, that it is a promise of the covenant of grace, extending to the Gentiles, as well as to the Jews; and, at the same time, that it is the foundation of church-membership, and consequently, of baptism, when he says, Acts 2:38, 39, "Repent, and be baptised, every one of you; - for the promise is unto you, and to your children, and to all that are afar off, even as many as the Lord our God shall call."

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear from the text, that the promise of assuming the children into the same covenant with their parents, extends to the Gentile nations?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because the apostle says, that the promise is unto "all that are AFAR OFF, even as many as the Lord our God shall call;" namely, by the external call or the word, which is appointed to be published "to every creature," Mark 16:15.

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear, that this promise is the foundation of churchmembership, and consequently of baptism?
SubQuestions.Answer: It appears from this, that the apostle enforces his exhortation to repent, and be baptised, upon the adult persons to whom he is speaking, from this powerful and encouraging motive, that then their children should have a right and title to the privileges of the same covenant of promise, and the seal of which they themselves were to receive in their baptism; "Repent," says he, "and be baptised; for the promise is unto you and to your children."

SubQuestions.Question: To what promise does the apostle here point?
SubQuestions.Answer: He points at the promise made to Abraham, Gen. 17:7 - "I will be a God unto thee, and to thy seed after thee."

SubQuestions.Question: What seal was annexed to this promise, or promulgation of the covenant of grace, made to Abraham?
SubQuestions.Answer: The seal of circumcision, ver. 10 - "This is my covenant, which ye shall keep between me and you; - Every man-child among you shall be circumcised." And ver. 12 - "He that is eight days old shall be circumcised among you."

SubQuestions.Question: What connexion is there between circumcising the seed of Abraham on the eighth day, under the Old Testament, and baptising the children of professing parents under the New?
SubQuestions.Answer: The connexion is, that though circumcision and baptism be different signs, yet they are both of them seals of the same covenant of grace; and since the infant-seed of Abraham received the seal of circumcision under the Old Testament, by parity of reason, the infant children of professing parents should receive the seal of baptism under the New; especially as baptism is now come in the room of circumcision.

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove, from scripture, that baptism is come in the room of circumcision?
SubQuestions.Answer: From Col. 2:10-12 - "Ye are complete in him - in whom, also, ye are circumcised with the circumcision made WITHOUT hands - buried with him in baptism, wherein also ye are risen with him."

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear, from this text, that baptism is now come in the room of circumcision?
SubQuestions.Answer: From the plain and obvious scope of it, which is to show, that there is no need now of that circumcision which was outward in the flesh, as we have all the blessed fruits and effects of Christ's death and resurrection more clearly, and, at the same time, more extensively, represented and sealed in baptism; which is dispensed equally to both sexes.

SubQuestions.Question: What would be the consequence, if the infants of professing parents, under the New Testament, were not admitted to the initiating seal of the covenant, as well as the infants of the Jews under the Old?
SubQuestions.Answer: The consequence would be, that the privileges of the New Testament church would be more abridged and lessened, than those of the Old, whereas they are rather increased and enlarged, Isaiah 54:2, 3.

SubQuestions.Question: How can infants be baptised, when they are incapable of making a profession of their faith, which seems to be required in order to baptism? Acts 8:37.
SubQuestions.Answer: An explicit or formal profession of faith, is required only of them that are adult, or come to age, when they are to be baptised: but not of infants now, any more than when they were circumcised of old, on the eighth day after their birth.

SubQuestions.Question: Are infants capable of the blessings signified and sealed in baptism?
SubQuestions.Answer: Undoubtedly they are; for some of them have been filled with the Holy Ghost even from their mother's womb, Luke 1:15; and, consequently, by grace capable of regeneration, pardon, and eternal life; wherefore the sign and seal of these blessings ought not to be withheld.

SubQuestions.Question: How are children of professing parents designated in scripture?
SubQuestions.Answer: If any one of the parents be a visible believer, or regular church-member, the children, on that account, are called holy, 1 Cor. 7:14 - "The unbelieving husband is sanctified by the wife; and the unbelieving wife is sanctified by the husband; else were your children unclean, but now are they holy."

SubQuestions.Question: What holiness is here meant?
SubQuestions.Answer: Federal holiness, or being admitted to church membership, together with their believing or professing parent.

SubQuestions.Question: May not this holiness be understood of legitimacy, or being lawfully begotten?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; because marriage being an ordinance of the law of nature, the children of married parents, though both of them be infidels, are as lawfully begotten as those of professing Christians.

SubQuestions.Question: How does federal holiness entitle an infant to baptism?
SubQuestions.Answer: Federal holiness necessarily supposes a being within the covenant, in virtue of the credible profession of the parent; and, consequently, a right to the initiatory seal of it.

SubQuestions.Question: Is there any express precept in the New Testament for baptising the infants of visible believers?
SubQuestions.Answer: The privilege of the infant seed of visible church members, having been settled ever since Abraham's time, and never reversed, there was no need of any more than the general precept, "Go, teach and baptise," Matt. 28:19.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is there need of no precept more express than this general one?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because the infants' privilege of being assumed into the same covenant with their parents is declared to be continued in New Testament times, Acts 2:39 - "The promise is unto you, and to your children."

SubQuestions.Question: Have we any scripture example for infant baptism?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; the apostles baptised whole households or families at once; such as the household of Lydia, Acts 16:15; all the jailer's family, ver. 33; and the household of Stephanas, 1 Cor. 1:16.

SubQuestions.Question: But there is no mention of their baptising infants in those families.
SubQuestions.Answer: Neither is there mention of their baptising adult persons in them; only, since they baptised the whole, it may be inferred that there were some infants, or young ones, among them.

SubQuestions.Question: "How is our baptism to be improved by us?"
SubQuestions.Answer: "By serious and thankful consideration of the nature of it, and of the ends for which Christ instituted it; - by being humbled for our sinful defilement, our falling short of, and walking contrary to our engagements; - and by endeavouring to live by faith, to have our conversation in holiness and righteousness, as those that have therein given up their names to Christ, and to walk in brotherly love, as being baptised by the same Spirit into one body."153

SubQuestions.Question: When should we thus improve our baptism?
SubQuestions.Answer: "All our life long, especially in the time of temptation, and when we are present at the administration of it to others."154

Data.Question: What is the Lord's Supper?
Data.Answer: The Lord's supper is a sacrament, wherein, by giving and receiving bread and wine, according to Christ's appointments his death is showed forth; and the worthy receivers are, not after a corporal and carnal manner, but by faith, made partakers of his body and blood, with all his benefits, to their spiritual nourishment, and growth in grace.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is this sacrament compared to a supper?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because it was instituted immediately after eating the passover, (Matt. 26:26), which was always at night, Ex. 12:6, 8.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is it called the Lord's supper?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because the Lord Jesus was the sole author of it, 1 Cor. 11:23; and it is highly requisite it should be so.

SubQuestions.Question: Why was it highly requisite that the Lord Jesus should be the sole author of this holy ordinance?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because all the grace that is held forth in it, is treasured up wholly in him; and is conveyed and applied by him to the soul, John 1:16.

SubQuestions.Question: When did Christ institute and appoint this sacrament?
SubQuestions.Answer: "The same night in which he was betrayed," 1 Cor. 11:23.

SubQuestions.Question: What night was that?
SubQuestions.Answer: It was the very last night before his death, Matt. 26:47, 48, compared with chap. 27:1, 35, 46, 50.

SubQuestions.Question: What is implied in his instituting this sacrament the same night in which he was betrayed?
SubQuestions.Answer: It implies his infinite goodness, and inviolable attachment to mankind lost, whom he represented; that in the immediate prospect of his greatest sufferings and soul agonies in their stead, he should have their salvation and comfort so much at heart, as to leave this memorial and pledge of his dying love among them, till he come again, Matt. 26:29.

SubQuestions.Question: Are Christians under any obligation to celebrate this ordinance at night, as our Lord and his disciples did at the first institution of it?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; the substitution of this sacrament in the room of the passover, (which was eaten immediately before) was the occasion of its being first administered at night; and that particular occasion can never recur again.

SubQuestions.Question: In what posture should the Lord's supper be received?
SubQuestions.Answer: This sacrament being called the Lord's table, 1 Cor. 10:21, a table posture, which is sitting, seems to be most agreeable to the practice of our Lord, and his disciples, at the first supper, Matt. 26:20, 26.

SubQuestions.Question: From whence did the practice of kneeling at the sacrament take its rise?
SubQuestions.Answer: From the church of Rome, who maintain that the consecrated bread, or wafer, is changed into the real body of Christ, and therefore to be worshipped.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the outward ELEMENTS, appointed by Christ, in this sacrament?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are bread and wine, Mark 14:22, 23.

SubQuestions.Question: What sort of bread and wine is proper to be used?
SubQuestions.Answer: Just such as is ordinarily used in entertainments among men.

SubQuestions.Question: Is the sacrament of the supper to be received, by every partaker, in both elements?
SubQuestions.Answer: Certainly it ought; for our Lord gave both elements to his disciples; and the apostle appoints both the elements to be dispensed to communicants, 1 Cor. 11:28 - "Let a man examine himself, and so let him eat of that BREAD, and drink of that CUP." And therefore the withholding of the cup from the people, as is done by the church of Rome, is both sacrilegious and impious.

SubQuestions.Question: What is signified by the bread and the wine?
SubQuestions.Answer: The body and blood of Christ, 1 Cor. 11:24, 25.

SubQuestions.Question: What is to be understood by Christ's body and blood?
SubQuestions.Answer: His incarnation and satisfaction, for the complete accomplishment of our redemption, John 6:51 - "The bread that I will give is my flesh, which I will give for the life of the world."

SubQuestions.Question: What is the analogy, or resemblance, between the bread and wine, and what is signified and represented by these elements?
SubQuestions.Answer: As bread and wine make a sufficient entertainment for the nourishment of the body; so the righteousness and fulness of Christ, are a full and satisfying feast for the refreshment of the soul, John 6:55 - "My flesh is meat indeed, and my blood is drink indeed."

SubQuestions.Question: What are the sacramental actions with reference to these elements?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are all of them comprehended in the answer, under giving and receiving bread and wine, according to Christ's appointment.

SubQuestions.Question: Whom do these sacramental actions respect?
SubQuestions.Answer: Some of them respect the administrator, and some the partakers in this holy ordinance.

SubQuestions.Question: Who are the administrators of this sacrament?
SubQuestions.Answer: Christ himself was the first administrator of it; and after him, ministers of the word, lawfully called and set apart to that office.

SubQuestions.Question: What were the actions of Christ, the first administrator, which ministers are to imitate, in dispensing this sacrament?
SubQuestions.Answer: After his example, they take the bread, and the cup; they bless these elements; they break the bread, and give both the bread and the wine to be distributed among the communicants.

SubQuestions.Question: What is meant by taking the bread and the cup?
SubQuestions.Answer: Christ's voluntarily assuming the human nature into union with his divine person, Heb. 2:16, that in it he might be a sacrifice of infinite value in our stead, Eph. 5:2.

SubQuestions.Question: What is implied in blessing the elements?
SubQuestions.Answer: That Christ has appointed the bread and the wine in this sacrament to be the visible signs or symbols of his body and blood; and likewise, by his example, has warranted ministers to set apart, by solemn prayer, so much of these elements, as shall be used in this sacrament, from a common, to a holy use.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is Christ's blessing the elements called his giving thanks? 1 Cor. 11:24.
SubQuestions.Answer: Because so inconceivably great was his love to lost sinners of mankind, that he was thankful he had all their debt to pay, Psalm 40:7, 8; and that he was able to do it to the uttermost, Heb. 7:25.

SubQuestions.Question: What is to be understood by breaking the bread?
SubQuestions.Answer: The most exquisite sufferings of the Son of God, Psalm 22:14, 15, and the necessity of them, as the channel, in which mercy was to be vented to the sinner, Rom. 5:21.

SubQuestions.Question: What is intimated to us by giving the bread and giving the cup? Matt. 26:26, 27.
SubQuestions.Answer: It intimates, that Christ is the free gift of God to sinners of mankind, for salvation and eternal life, John 3:16.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the sacramental actions of the partakers in this sacrament, included in their receiving of bread and wine?
SubQuestions.Answer: They take the bread and the cup: they eat the bread, and drink a part of the wine in the cup.

SubQuestions.Question: What is imported in their taking the bread and the cup?
SubQuestions.Answer: It imports, that our receiving of Christ, is founded on the gift and grant that is made of him in the word; for, "a man can receive nothing, except it be given him from heaven," John 3:27.

SubQuestions.Question: What is included in their eating the bread, and drinking the wine?
SubQuestions.Answer: It includes that there ought to be an application of Christ to the soul in particular, in virtue of the particular endorsement of the promise, to every one that hears the gospel: "For the promise," says the apostle Peter, "is unto you, (that is, unto every one of you,) and to your children," Acts 2:39.

SubQuestions.Question: For what end did Christ institute these sacramental elements and actions?
SubQuestions.Answer: That thereby his death, might be showed forth, 1 Cor. 11:26, and the remembrance of it kept up, Luke 22:19.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to show forth the death of Christ?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to profess, by partaking of the sacrament, that we believe his death, in our room, to have been most acceptable to God, Eph. 5:2; and that we acquiesce in it, together with his obedience, as the sole ground of our hope of salvation, Rom. 4:25.

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear, that his death, in our room, was most acceptable to God?
SubQuestions.Answer: By his resurrection from the dead, 1 Thess. 1:10 and his entrance into glory, Luke 24:26.

SubQuestions.Question: How may we know if we acquiesce in the obedience and death of Christ, as the sole ground of our hope of salvation?
SubQuestions.Answer: If we are renouncing all other confidences, Hos. 14:3, and are convinced that the meritorious obedience unto death of the Son of God as our Surety, is the sole payment of the debt we owed to law and justice, Jer. 23:6 - "This is his name whereby he shall be called, THE LORD OUR RIGHTEOUSNESS."

SubQuestions.Question: Why has Christ appointed this sacrament to be observed in remembrance of him, Luke 22:19 - "This do in remembrance of me?"
SubQuestions.Answer: Because though his incarnation and satisfaction are the greatest events that ever happened in the world, and the most interesting to us, yet we are apt to forget them; or at least not to have the solid and lively impression of them habitually upon our spirits, Psalm 106:13 - "They soon forgot his works."

SubQuestions.Question: What is it about the death of Christ which we ought to remember in this sacrament?
SubQuestions.Answer: The truth of it, the necessity of it, and the sufficiency of it.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to remember the truth of Christ's death?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is by a true and saving faith, to believe that Christ really did and suffered all these things for us, that are recorded of him in scripture, 1 Cor. 15:3, 4.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to remember the necessity of his death, Luke 24:26 - "Ought not Christ to have suffered these things?"
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to believe, that we had certainly gone down to the pit, unless God had found a ransom, or an atonement, Job 33:24.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to remember the sufficiency of it?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to believe that it is infinitely valuable; and, therefore, could have procured the salvation of thousands of worlds, had it been so ordained, it being the death and blood of him, who is the supreme God, Acts 20:28 - "Feed the church of God, which he hath purchased with his own blood."

SubQuestions.Question: In what MANNER should we show forth and remember the death of Christ in this sacrament?
SubQuestions.Answer: We ought to do it fiducially,155 humbly, mournfully, and thankfully.

SubQuestions.Question: Why ought we to remember his death fiducially?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because as he "was delivered for our offences," Rom. 4:25, so "God raised him up from the dead, and gave him glory, that our faith and hope might be in God," 1 Pet. 1:21.

SubQuestions.Question: Why ought we to remember it humbly?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because when we are unworthy of the least of all God's mercies, Gen. 32:10, we are much more so of the greatest that can be conferred, John 3:16 - "God so loved the world" &c.

SubQuestions.Question: Why mournfully?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because our sins were the procuring cause of his sufferings, Isaiah 53:5, 6 - "He was wounded for OUR transgressions, he was bruised for OUR iniquities - The Lord hath laid on him the iniquities of us all."156

SubQuestions.Question: Why should the death of Christ be remembered thankfully?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because his death was in our room, Titus 2:14; and was the finishing stroke of the work which his Father gave him to do, John 19:30.

SubQuestions.Question: How often should the death of Christ be remembered, by partaking of this sacrament?
SubQuestions.Answer: The scripture has not precisely determined how often; but it would appear that it ought frequently to be done.

SubQuestions.Question: How does it appear that the death of Christ should be frequently remembered in the supper?
SubQuestions.Answer: From the words of our Lord, 1 Cor. 11:25, 26 - "This do ye, as oft as ye drink it, in remembrance of me; for, AS OFTEN as ye eat this bread," &c., plainly implying, that it ought OFTEN to be done.

SubQuestions.Question: When will the death of Christ be remembered perpetually, without interruption?
SubQuestions.Answer: In heaven, though not in a sacramental way, Rev. 21:22 - "I saw no temple there."

SubQuestions.Question: How may it be proved, that it will be perpetually remembered in heaven?
SubQuestions.Answer: From the song of the redeemed there, recorded, Rev. 1:5, 6 - "Unto him that loved us, and washed us from our sins in his own blood - to him be glory." And chap. 5:9-14 - "And they sung a new song; saying - Thou wast slain, and hast redeemed us to God by thy blood," &c.

SubQuestions.Question: Who are called worthy receivers, in the answer?
SubQuestions.Answer: None are worthy receivers of this sacrament, but true believers; and even they, in order to their partaking worthily and comfortably, ought to have grace in exercise, as well as in the habit; Song 1:12.

SubQuestions.Question: Why are true believers called WORTHY receivers?
SubQuestions.Answer: Not on account of any worthiness in themselves, for they have nothing of their own of which they can boast; but because they are united to Christ, and have all that grace from him, which enables them to partake in a suitable and becoming manner, 2 Cor. 3:5.

SubQuestions.Question: What are the worthy receivers made partakers of in this sacrament?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are made partakers of Christ's body and blood, with all his benefits.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to be partakers of Christ's body and blood?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to be entertained, in the sacrament upon all that was transacted upon the person of Christ, as God-man, Mediator: this being the only proper and suitable food of the soul, John 6:51, 53.

SubQuestions.Question: In what respect is it, that the worthy receivers are NOT made partakers of his body and blood?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are not made partakers after a corporal and carnal manner.

SubQuestions.Question: Why are these words inserted in the answer, not after a corporal and carnal manner?
SubQuestions.Answer: They are inserted in opposition to the Popish doctrine of transubstantiation, "which maintains a change of the substance of bread and wine, into the substance of Christ's body and blood, by consecration of a priest."157

SubQuestions.Question: What is the absurdity of this doctrine?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is "repugnant not to scripture alone, but even to common sense and reason; overthroweth the nature of the sacrament; and hath been and is the cause of manifold superstitions, yea, of gross idolatries."158

SubQuestions.Question: How is it repugnant to scripture?
SubQuestions.Answer: The scripture expressly affirms, that Christ gave the very same bread and cup to his disciples, after consecration, that he had taken into his hands before, Matt. 26:26, 27. Whereas the doctrine of transubstantiation maintains, that the elements, after consecration, are no more the same, having only the form, colour, taste, and smell of bread and wine, wanting the substance of either; being turned into the substance of Christ's body and blood; in opposition to which, the apostle calls the elements, after consecration, by the same names they had before it, to intimate, that there was no change of their substance, 1 Cor. 11:26-28 - "As often as ye eat this BREAD, and drink this CUP," &c.

SubQuestions.Question: How is transubstantiation repugnant to common sense and reason?
SubQuestions.Answer: Common sense and reason tell us, that a body occupies but one place, and cannot be in divers places at one and the same time; whereas they who defend transubstantiation must allow, that the body of Christ may be in a thousand places at once, even as many places as there are consecrated wafers.

SubQuestions.Question: How does transubstantiation overthrow the nature of the sacrament?
SubQuestions.Answer: By destroying the spiritual or sacramental relation, that is between the sign and the thing signified; for if the sign be turned into the thing signified, then all relation and similitude between them cease. Besides, the sacrament being a commemoration of what was done and suffered in the human nature of Christ, it supposes his body to be absent, whereas transubstantiation supposes it present.

SubQuestions.Question: How is it the cause of manifold superstitions and gross idolatries?
SubQuestions.Answer: In as much as strange and surprising effects are ascribed to the host, or consecrated wafer, even when not used sacramentally; and the alleged change of the bread and wine, into the substance of Christ's body and blood in the sacrament, is the very pretence, why they pay religious worship and adoration to the elements themselves; which is gross superstition and idolatry.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the difference between the Papists and Lutherans on this head?
SubQuestions.Answer: The Papists maintain, that the bread and wine lose their own natural substance, and are turned into the substance of Christ's body and blood; but the Lutherans affirm, that the bread and wine retain their own natural substance still, and, at the same time, that the substance of Christ's body and blood is in, with, or under, these elements.

SubQuestions.Question: Are not both opinions equally absurd?
SubQuestions.Answer: Yes; for transubstantiation supposes, that one body may be in many places at the same time; and consubstantiation takes it for granted, that two bodies may be together in the very same place, or that they may both occupy the same individual space at the same time.

SubQuestions.Question: Is Christ offered up, in this sacrament, as a sacrifice for the remission of sins?
SubQuestions.Answer: No; there is in it "only a commemoration of that one offering up of himself, by himself; upon the cross, once for all; and a spiritual oblation of all possible praise unto God for the same.159

SubQuestions.Question: Why does our Confession say, that Christ's once offering up of himself was done BY HIMSELF?
SubQuestions.Answer: In opposition to the unbloody sacrifice of the mass, which is offered up daily by the Popish priests, for remission of the sins both of the quick and the dead.

SubQuestions.Question: What does our Confession of Faith affirm concerning this Popish "sacrifice of the mass," as they call it?
SubQuestions.Answer: It affirms, that it is "most abominably injurious to Christ's one only sacrifice, the alone propitiation for all the sins of the elect, Heb. 7:27."160

SubQuestions.Question: Is not Christ really present in the sacrament of the supper?
SubQuestions.Answer: He is "as really, but spiritually, present to the faith of believers in that ordinance, as the elements themselves are to their outward senses, 1 Cor. 11:29."161

SubQuestions.Question: If Christ be really present in the sacrament only in a spiritual sense, and not corporally, why does he say of the bread, "This is my body"?
SubQuestions.Answer: The plain and obvious meaning is, "This bread is the sign or symbol of my body": so that the words are to be understood in the figurative, not in the literal sense.

SubQuestions.Question: How do you prove, that these words, "This is my body," are to be understood in the figurative, and not in the literal and proper sense?
SubQuestions.Answer: From this known rule in all language, that when the strict literal sense involves a manifest absurdity, or contradiction, we must of necessity have recourse to the figurative sense; as when the apostle says, 1 Cor. 10:4 - "That rock was Christ," it cannot be understood literally, as if that rock, materially considered, was really Christ; but, figuratively, that rock signified Christ; and so of a great many other scripture expressions.

SubQuestions.Question: Since the worthy receivers are not made partakers of Christ's body and blood after a corporal and carnal manner, how do they partake of the same?
SubQuestions.Answer: They partake of his body and blood, in this sacrament, only by faith.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it for the worthy receivers to partake of his body and blood by faith?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to apply and appropriate himself and his righteousness, with all his benefits, to themselves, Psalm 16:5, 6.

SubQuestions.Question: What are these benefits which faith, in this sacrament, applies together with Christ himself?
SubQuestions.Answer: Among many others, there are these three comprehensive ones; namely, an ample indemnity of all sin, Micah 7:19; an unquestionable security for the progress of sanctification, Job 17:9; and an undoubted title to eternal life, John 10:28.

SubQuestions.Question: Why are these, and the like, called his benefits?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because he is the purchaser, Titus 2:14, proprietor, John 3:35, and dispenser of them, Eph. 4:8.

SubQuestions.Question: Why are worthy receivers said to be made partakers of all his benefits?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because where himself is received, all good things go along with him, 1 Cor. 3:22, 23 - "all are yours; and ye are Christ's."

SubQuestions.Question: What is the fruit and effect of their being, by faith, made partakers of Christ, and all his benefits?
SubQuestions.Answer: The fruit and effect of it is, their spiritual nourishment, and growth in grace.

SubQuestions.Question: What does their spiritual nourishment imply in it?
SubQuestions.Answer: That this sacrament is not a converting, but a nourishing ordinance.

SubQuestions.Question: What does their growth in grace imply?
SubQuestions.Answer: That the worthy receivers are already in a state of grace.

SubQuestions.Question: How may spiritual nourishment and growth in grace be discerned?
SubQuestions.Answer: If there is a more enlarged desire after the sincere milk of the word, 1 Pet. 2:2; if there is more living by faith, and not by sense, 2 Cor. 5:7; and if there is more inward opposition to sin, Psalm 66:18, and outward tenderness in the walk, Psalm 39:1.

Data.Question: What is required to the worthy receiving of the Lord's supper?
Data.Answer: It is required of them that would worthily partake of the Lord's supper, that they examine themselves of their knowledge to discern the Lord's body, of their faith to feed upon him, of their repentance, love, and new obedience; lest, coming unworthily, they eat and drink judgment to themselves.

SubQuestions.Question: What preparatory duty is here required of those that would partake of the Lord's supper?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is, that they examine themselves, 1 Cor. 11:28 - "But let a man examine himself, and so let him eat of that bread, and drink of that cup."

SubQuestions.Question: What is it for persons to examine themselves?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to make a strict inquiry into, and to pass an impartial judgment upon their spiritual state and frame, by the rule of the word, Psalm 77:6, and 119:105.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the best and most successful way of essaying this duty?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to put it into the hand of the Spirit of God to manage it for us, Psalm 139:23, 24 - "Search me, O God, and know my heart," &c.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is self-examination necessary before receiving the Lord's supper?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because it is peremptorily commanded, in order to discover whether we be in a gracious state; or, if we have grace in any measure of exercise; without either of which there can be no comfortable participation of this ordinance: "Let a man examine himself, and so let him eat."

SubQuestions.Question: Is this the duty of every man, or of some only?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is unquestionably the duty of every man: "Let a man examine himself;" that is, every man and woman, without exception, whether they think themselves gracious or graceless.

SubQuestions.Question: Why should a gracious man examine himself?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because "there is not a just man upon earth, that doeth good and sinneth not," Eccl. 7:20.

SubQuestions.Question: Why should they, who think they are graceless, examine themselves?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because "they that be whole need not a physician, but they that are sick," Matt. 9:12. They thus come to see more clearly their absolute need of Christ.

SubQuestions.Question: Is self-examination the duty of those only who are to partake for the first time?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is the duty of persons every time they venture to partake of this ordinance, as the words of the precept evidenty bear, "so let him eat;" that is, let none approach this holy table at any time without first essaying this duty.

SubQuestions.Question: Is self-examination to be practised only about the time of communion?
SubQuestions.Answer: It ought to be practised daily or habitually, 2 Cor. 13:5; and especially in the view of such a solemn approach to the Lord at his table.

SubQuestions.Question: What are those things, about which they that would worthily partake of the Lord's supper are required to examine themselves?.
SubQuestions.Answer: They are required to examine themselves of their knowledge - of their faith - of their repentance, love, and new obedience.

SubQuestions.Question: What are they to try or examine about their knowledge?
SubQuestions.Answer: If they have a competent measure of it; and if the measure they have, be of a saving kind.

SubQuestions.Question: What is that competent measure of knowledge, which is requisite to the worthy receiving of the Lord's supper?
SubQuestions.Answer: That there be some understanding of the person, offices, and righteousness of Christ; of the fulness, freedom, and stability of the covenant of grace; of the nature, use, and end, of the sacrament of the supper; and likewise of our own manifold sins and wants.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is such a knowledge necessary?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is necessary, to discern the Lord's body.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to discern the Lord's body in this sacrament?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to view the meritorious atonement, made by the Son of God in our nature, through the symbols of bread and wine, which are designed to signify and represent the same.

SubQuestions.Question: Who are they who are guilty of not discerning the, Lord's body?
SubQuestions.Answer: They who rest in partaking of the outward elements, without a firm belief of the mysteries that are wrapped up in them.

SubQuestions.Question: How may we know if the measure of knowledge we have attained, be of a saving kind?
SubQuestions.Answer: If we think we know nothing yet, as we ought to know, 1 Cor. 8:2; if we are following on to know the Lord more and more, Hos. 6:3; and if our knowledge influences our practice, John 13:17 - "If ye know these things, happy are ye if ye do them."

SubQuestions.Question: Why is faith necessary to the worthy partaking of the Lord's supper?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is necessary in order to feed upon him.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to feed upon Christ in the sacrament of the supper?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to receive into our souls, from his fulness, all that spiritual good which is exhibited to us in the promise, John 1:16.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it of Christ that faith feeds upon in the sacrament?
SubQuestions.Answer: It feeds upon all those discoveries of him that are made in the word; such as, his person, offices, mediatorial character, and relations, John 6:57.

SubQuestions.Question: How may we know if we have that faith which feeds on Christ in the word and sacrament?
SubQuestions.Answer: Where this true and saving faith is, it is of an appetising nature, whetting the spiritual appetite after more and more of him, Isaiah 26:8, 9; it purifies the heart, Acts 15:9; accounts all things but loss for Christ, Phil. 3:8; and is careful to maintain good works, Titus 3:8.

SubQuestions.Question: What is the use of repentance in this sacrament?
SubQuestions.Answer: Without repentance there can be no mourning for sin, which is an inseparable concomitant of faith's looking to, or improving a crucified Saviour in this ordinance, Zech. 12:10 - "They shall look upon me whom they have pierced, and they shall mourn for him."

SubQuestions.Question: How may we know if our repentance be genuine or of a right kind?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is true and genuine, if we are grieved for sin as it is offensive to God, Psalm 51:4; if we are forsaking, and turning from it both in heart and life, Hos. 14:8; and, particularly, if we are deeply affected with the sin of unbelief, John 16:9.

SubQuestions.Question: What necessity is there for the exercise of the grace of love in partaking of the Lord's supper?
SubQuestions.Answer: Without love to Christ, there can be no communion with him in this, or any other ordinance, John 14:21 - "He that loveth me, shall be loved of my Father, and I will love him, and I will manifest myself to him."

SubQuestions.Question: How may we know if our love to Christ be sincere and unfeigned?
SubQuestions.Answer: If it put us upon essaying the most difficult duties he may call us to, Psalm 23:4; if it engage us to put a favourable construction upon the afflicting providences we meet with in our lot, Heb. 12:10, and if we love his members out of love to himself, or because they are "begotten of him," 1 John 5:1.

SubQuestions.Question: Why is the obedience required of worthy receivers called new obedience?
SubQuestions.Answer: Because it flows from a new principle of faith and love, Gal. 5:6; it is performed in a new manner, namely, in the strength of "the grace that is in Christ Jesus," 2 Tim; 2:1, and is directed to a new end, even the glory of God; 1 Cor. 10:31.

SubQuestions.Question: How may we know if our obedience is indeed new obedience?
SubQuestions.Answer: If we are conscientiously diligent in the practice of every duty, and at the same time look on ourselves as unprofitable servants, Luke 17:10, and lean wholly to the surety-righteousness as the sole ground of our acceptance, Isaiah 45:24.

SubQuestions.Question: What risk do they run who omit to examine themselves as to the above graces, before they come to the Lord's table?
SubQuestions.Answer: They run the risk of coming unworthily.

SubQuestions.Question: What is it to come unworthily?
SubQuestions.Answer: It is to come without any real sense, or consciousness of the need that we stand in of Christ, as "of God made unto us wisdom, righteousness, sanctification, and redemption," 1 Cor. 1:30.

SubQuestions.Question: What danger do they incur who thus come unworthily?
SubQuestions.Answer: They eat and drink judgment to themselves, 1 Cor. 11:29.

SubQuestions.Question: In what sense can they who come unworthily, be said to eat and drink judgment to themselves?
SubQuestions.Answer: In so far as by their eating and drinking unworthily, they do that which renders them obnoxious to the righteous judgment of God.

SubQuestions.Question: To what judgment do they render themselves obnoxious?
SubQuestions.Answer: To temporal judgments, or afflictions of various kinds, in the present life; and to eternal judgment, or condemnation (if mercy prevent not) in the life to come, 1 Cor. 11:30, 32.

SubQuestions.Question: "May not one who doubteth of his being in Christ, or of his due preparation, come to the Lord's supper?
SubQuestions.Answer: "If he be duly affected with the apprehension of the want of" an interest in Christ, "and unfeignedly desires to be found in him, and to depart from iniquity:" in that case, "he is to bewail his unbelief, and labour to have his doubts resolved; and, in so doing, he may and ought to come to the Lord's supper, that he may be further strengthened."162

SubQuestions.Question: When may a person be said to be duly affected with the apprehension of his want of an interest in Christ?
SubQuestions.Answer: When he is filled with a restless uneasiness, and can take no comfort in any outward enjoyment, while he thinks himself destitute of an interest in Christ; and, at the same time, is active and diligent in the use of all the ordinary means, in which Christ is usually to be found, Song 3:1-5.
